前言

PREFACE

每年都有成千上万的学生选择数学作为自己的专业。这些学生中有很多都非常聪明和勤奋。然而，即使是最优秀的学生也难以适应向高等数学过渡的要求。一些困难归因于日益增加的独立学习要求。然而，其他困难则更为根本：数学的重点从计算转向证明，因此学生需要以不同的方式与之互动。这些变化并不神秘——数学教育研究已经揭示了许多必要的调整——但它们并不明显，确实需要解释。

Every year, thousands of students declare mathematics as their major. Many of these students are extremely intelligent and hardworking. However, even the best struggle with the demands of making the transition to advanced mathematics. Some struggles are down to the demands of increasingly independent study. Others, however, are more fundamental: the mathematics shifts in focus from calculation to proof, and students are thus expected to interact with it in different ways. These changes need not be mysterious—mathematics education research has revealed many insights into the adjustments that are necessary—but they are not obvious and they do need explaining.

本书旨在为学生读者提供这样的解释，它不同于那些已经针对类似读者的书籍。它不是一本流行的数学书；它不太关注数学的好奇心或应用，而更关注如何参与学术内容。它不是一本通用的学习技巧指南；它关注的是应对正式的、抽象的本科数学的挑战。最重要的是，它不是一本教科书。已经存在许多“过渡”或“桥梁”或“基础”教科书，虽然这些教科书在介绍新的数学内容和为读者提供练习方面做得很好，但我认为它们仍然假设了太多关于抽象数学的运作和价值的知识；一个期望数学以程序形式出现以供抄袭的学生将不知道如何与通过定义、定理和证明呈现的材料互动。事实上，研究表明，这样的学生可能会忽略大部分解释性文字，而过分关注明显的符号部分和练习。本书旨在从学生的现状入手，避免此类问题；它承认现有的技能，指出共同的经验和期望，并重新定位学生，使他们知道在抽象数学的文本和讲座中要寻找什么。因此，它可以被视为一般适用于高级教科书，特别是标准过渡教科书。

This book aims to offer such explanation for a student audience, and it differs from those already aimed at similar audiences. It is not a popular mathematics book; it is less focused on mathematical curiosities or applications, and more focused on how to engage with academic content. It is not a generic study skills guide; it is focused on the challenges of coping with formal, abstract undergraduate mathematics. Most importantly, it is not a textbook. Many “transition” or “bridging” or “foundations” textbooks exist already and, while these do a good job of introducing new mathematical content and providing exercises for the reader, my view is that they still assume too much knowledge regarding the workings and values of abstract mathematics; a student who expects mathematics to come in the form of procedures to copy will not know how to interact with material presented via definitions, theorems, and proofs. Indeed, research shows that such a student will likely ignore much of the explanatory text and focus disproportionately on the obviously symbolic parts and the exercises. This book aims to head off such problems by starting where the student is; it acknowledges existing skills, points out common experiences and expectations, and re-orients students so that they know what to look for in texts and lectures on abstract mathematics. It could thus be considered a universal prelude to upper-level textbooks in general and to standard transition textbooks in particular.

由于本书的对象是学生，因此其写作风格是一本友好、易读（但具有挑战性和发人深省）的自助书。这意味着数学家和其他数学教师会发现，这种风格比通常的数学书籍更具叙述性和对话性。特别是，他们可能会发现，在首次介绍概念时，他们会强调的一些技术细节被一笔带过了。我特意决定采用这种方法，以避免在早期阶段陷入细节，并将重点放在成功解释高级数学所需的大规模变化上。集合成员资格、函数域的精确指定等技术问题在脚注中指出和/或分离出来，在第 1 部分的后面章节中进行详细讨论。

Because this book is aimed at students, it is written in the style of a friendly, readable (though challenging and thought-provoking) self-help book. This means that mathematicians and other mathematics teachers will find the style considerably more narrative and conversational than is usual in mathematics books. In particular, they might find that some technical details that they would emphasize are glossed over when concepts are first introduced. I made a deliberate decision to take this approach, in order to avoid getting bogged down in detail at an early stage and to keep the focus on the large-scale changes that are needed for successful interpretation of upper-level mathematics. Technical matters such as precise specification of set membership, of function domains, and so on, are pointed out in footnotes and/or separated out for detailed discussion in the later chapters of Part 1.

为了引导学生进一步思考这些观点，并避免重复其他地方已经介绍过的内容，我在每章末尾都添加了一个进一步阅读部分。这些阅读清单旨在提供指导，而不是详尽无遗，我希望任何对数学感兴趣的学生都能广泛阅读这些材料，从而从各种专家提供的见解中受益。

To lead students to further consideration of such points, and to avoid replicating material that is laid down well elsewhere, I have included a further reading section at the end of each chapter. These lists of readings aim to be directive rather than exhaustive, and I hope that any student who is interested in mathematics will read widely from such material and thus benefit from the insights offered by a variety of experts.

如果没有参考文献中出现的众多研究人员的研究报告，本书就不可能问世。我还要衷心感谢牛津大学出版社的 Keith Mansfield、Clare Charles 和 Viki Mortimer，感谢原书提案的审阅者，以及以下同事、朋友和学生，他们非常友善，对本书的早期版本提供了详细而周到的反馈：Nina Attridge、Thomas Bartsch、Gavin Brown、Lucy Cragg、Anthony Croft、Ant Edwards、Rob Howe、Matthew Inglis、Ian Jones、Anthony Kay、Nathalie Matthews、David Sirl 和 Jack Tabeart。特别感谢 Matthew，他知道我打算写作，并在我的生日时送给我相关书籍，成功地帮助我开始了写作。

This book would not have been possible without the investigations reported by the many researchers whose works appear in the references. My sincere thanks also to Keith Mansfield, Clare Charles, and Viki Mortimer at Oxford University Press, to the reviewers of the original book proposal, and to the following colleagues, friends, and students who were kind enough to give detailed and thoughtful feedback on earlier versions of this work: Nina Attridge, Thomas Bartsch, Gavin Brown, Lucy Cragg, Anthony Croft, Ant Edwards, Rob Howe, Matthew Inglis, Ian Jones, Anthony Kay, Nathalie Matthews, David Sirl, and Jack Tabeart. Thanks in particular to Matthew, who knew that I was intending to write and who gave me related books for my birthday in a successful attempt to get me started.

最后，谨将此书献给我的老师乔治·萨特克利夫 (George Sutcliff)，他让我发现了自己的思考能力。

Finally, this book is dedicated to my teacher George Sutcliff, who allowed me to find out how well I could think.

8.5

8.5

介绍

INTRODUCTION

这篇简短的介绍解释了本书的目的和结构，并建议不同群体的读者可以按不同的顺序阅读各章。对于尚未开始本科学习的学生，它还解释了一些有用的词汇。

This short introduction explains the aim and structure of this book, and suggests that different groups of readers might like to approach the chapters in different orders. For those who have not yet begun their undergraduate studies, it also explains some useful vocabulary.

本书的目的

本书讲述如何充分利用数学专业。它讲述了本科数学的本质、教授希望学生思考数学的方式以及如何在享受本科生活的同时保持学习的领先地位。它是为那些打算攻读数学专业的学生和已经开始攻读数学专业的学生撰写的。

This book is about how to make the most of a mathematics major. It is about the nature of undergraduate mathematics, about the ways in which professors expect students to think about it, and about how to keep on top of studying while enjoying undergraduate life. It is written for those who intend to study for a mathematics major, and for those who have already started.

如果你属于第一类人，那么你可能处于以下两种情况之一。你可能会对整个事情感到有点紧张。也许到目前为止，你的数学成绩很好，但你认为你的成功主要归功于努力工作。也许你认为其他人具有你缺乏的数学天赋，在高级课程中，你将与一群天才为伍，但最终被发现是骗子。作为一名数学教授，我遇到过很多这样的学生。他们中的一些人总是怀疑自己，他们获得了学位，但并不真正享受学习。其他人确实意识到他们的思维和其他人一样好。他们对自己更加有信心，他们成功了，他们享受整个学习过程。如果你有点紧张，我希望这本书能帮助你做好准备，取得良好的进步，并最终成为后者。

If you are among the first group, you are probably in one of two positions. You might be a bit nervous about the whole business. Perhaps you have done well in mathematics so far, but you think that your success is mostly down to hard work. Perhaps you believe that others have some innate mathematical talent that you lack, and that in upper-level courses you will be in classes full of geniuses and will end up being found out as a fraud. As a mathematics professor, I meet quite a lot of students like this. Some of them always doubt themselves, and they get their degrees but they don’t really enjoy their studies. Others do come to realize that their thinking is as good as that of anyone else. They develop more faith in themselves, they succeed, and they enjoy the whole process of learning. If you are a bit nervous, I hope that this book will help you to feel prepared, to make good progress, and to end up in this latter group.

另一方面，你也许会对自己的成功充满信心。我刚开始在英国读本科时就是这样的。我一直都是数学课上最优秀的学生，我高中时选修的额外数学课没有问题，而且我非常确定自己想成为一名数学家。但是当我上大学并开始选修相当于高级数学的课程时，我不得不调整自己的期望。有一段时间，我认为自己勉强有资格获得学位，应该认真降低自己的职业抱负。后来，我迎来了令人欣慰的转机，我掌握了高等数学，并最终获得了所谓的“一等”学位。这很大程度上要归功于我从一些优秀老师那里获得的一些关键见解。事实上，这些见解促使我决定研究人们如何思考数学比学习数学更有趣，所以我继续攻读数学教育博士学位。现在我讲授本科数学课程，其余时间则进行研究，调查人们如何学习和思考数学。

You might, on the other hand, be confident that you are going to succeed. That’s how I felt when I began my undergraduate studies in the UK. I’d always been the best student in my mathematics classes, I had no problems with the extra mathematics I took in high school, and I was pretty sure I wanted to be a mathematician. But when I arrived at college and began taking the equivalent of upper-level mathematics courses, I was forced to adjust my expectations. For a while I thought that I would only barely merit a degree and that I should seriously downgrade my career aspirations. Then, in a very gratifying turnaround, I got the hang of advanced mathematics and was eventually awarded what is known as a “first class” degree. This was largely due to a few key insights that I gained from some excellent teachers. In fact, these insights prompted me to decide that studying how people think about mathematics is even more interesting than studying mathematics, so I went on to do a PhD in Mathematics Education. These days I give lectures on undergraduate mathematics, and spend the rest of my time conducting research studies to investigate how people learn and think about it.

我学到的一件简单但重要的事情是，无论他们对将数学作为自己的专业有何感受，大多数学生在如何有效地学习数学方面还有很多东西需要学习。即使是那些最终表现出色的学生，通常一开始也效率不高。这就是我写这本书的原因：给你一个助力，让你的学术生活比原本更轻松、更愉快。

One simple but important thing I have learned is that, whatever their feelings on declaring mathematics as their major, most students have a lot to learn about how to study it effectively. Even those who end up doing very well are usually somewhat inefficient to start with. That’s why I’m writing this book: to give you a leg-up so that your academic life is easier and more enjoyable than it would otherwise be.

然而，这本书并不是关于如何不费吹灰之力就能完成数学专业的神奇方法。相反，这需要付出很多努力。但这是值得接受的。数学专业应该具有挑战性——如果它很容易，每个人都会去学习。而且，如果你在学习中取得了如此大的成就，你一定体验过掌握最初觉得困难的东西的满足感。然而，这本书是关于如何确保你关注正确的事情，这样你就可以避免不必要的困惑，让你的辛勤工作得到回报。

However, this book is not about some magical easy way to complete a mathematics major without really trying. On the contrary, a lot of hard work will be required. But this is something to embrace. A mathematics major should be challenging—if it were easy, everyone would have one. And, if you’ve got this far in your studies, you must have experienced the satisfaction of mastering something that you initially found difficult. The book is, however, about how to make sure that you’re paying attention to the right things, so that you can avoid unnecessary confusion and so that your hard work will pay off.

本书结构

本书分为两部分。第一部分讲述数学内容，第二部分讲述学习过程。

This book is split into two parts. Part 1 is about mathematical content and Part 2 is about the process of learning.

第 1 部分可以称为“你的数学教授可能不会想到告诉你的事情”。它描述了高等数学的结构，讨论了它与早期数学的不同之处，并提供了有关你可以做些什么来理解它。我把这部分放在第一位，因为这可能是那些在宣布专业之前读过这本书的学生所期望的。请注意，我的目的不是教授数学——那是你的教授和导师的工作。所以你不会发现这本书包含很多数学内容。它包含的是如何与内容交互的信息。因此，它包括详细的插图，但没有练习。如果你想练习，有很多好书可以参考，我在每章末尾的“进一步阅读”部分列出了其中一些。

Part 1 could be called “Things that your mathematics professor might not think to tell you.” It describes the structure of advanced mathematics, discusses how it differs from earlier mathematics, and offers advice about things you could do to understand it. I’ve put this part first because it is probably what is expected by students who read this before declaring their major. Note that I do not aim to teach the mathematics—that is the job of your professors and instructors. So you will not find that the book contains a lot of mathematical content. What it contains instead is information on how to interact with the content. It thus includes detailed illustrations, but not exercises. If you want exercises, there are many good books you can work with, and I list some of these in the Further Reading section at the end of each chapter.

第 2 部分是关于如何充分利用讲座，以及如何组织自己以便跟上数学并享受它。我把这部分放在第二部分，因为我预计许多刚开始上大学的学生会想，“哎呀！我不需要学习技巧的信息！我已经在几十场考试中取得了好成绩，显然我是个好学生。”如果你是这么想的，那很好。但也许第1 部分会让你相信，因为随着你进入高级课程，数学的性质会发生变化，所以对你的方法进行一些调整可能会有用。事实上，有些人可能正是因为他们知道他们没有很好地组织他们的学习而阅读这本书。处于这种情况的人可能想先读第 2 部分。任何落后太多以至于陷入恐慌状态的人都应该直接翻到第 12 章并从那里开始。

Part 2 is about how to get the most out of your lectures, and about how to organize yourself so that you can keep up with the mathematics and therefore enjoy it. I’ve put this part second because I expect that many students who are relatively new to college studies will be thinking, “Pah! I don’t need information on study skills! I have done well in dozens of exams already and clearly I am a good student.” If that is what you’re thinking, good for you. But maybe Part 1 will convince you that, because the nature of the mathematics changes as you move into upper-level courses, some tweaks to your approach might be useful. Indeed, some people might be reading this book precisely because they know that they are not organizing their studies very well. Those in this position might want to read Part 2 first. And anyone who is so far behind that they find themselves in a state of panic should turn straight to Chapter 12 and start there.

为了符合所有读者的体验，我决定以向即将宣布自己专业的人讲话的方式写作，并介绍对处于这种位置的人来说应该有趣但具有挑战性的材料。这意味着您在阅读时可能会遇到新概念，并且您肯定必须认真思考。我已尽力将所有内容解释清楚，正如我上面提到的，您应该愿意作为一名本科生接受挑战。但是，当您有更多经验可以借鉴时，您可能会发现稍后回顾其中的一些想法很有用。我希望这本书在您的数学专业学习期间对您有用。

To fit in with the experience of all readers, I decided to write as though I’m addressing someone who is on the point of declaring their major, and to present material that should be interesting but challenging to someone in that position. This means that you might encounter new concepts while you are reading, and you’ll certainly have to think hard. I have done my best to explain everything clearly and, as I mentioned above, you should be willing to be challenged as an undergraduate student. But you might find it useful to come back to some of the ideas later, when you have more experience to draw on. I hope that this book will be useful throughout your mathematics major.

有用的词汇

我试图让每一章都相当独立，这样你就可以从任何地方开始阅读（虽然第一部分比较难，所以我建议你按顺序阅读大部分内容）。我也试图介绍在需要时，我们会列出技术术语，并在介绍之前提供了一份列表，总结了本书中使用的数学符号。但是，您会发现熟悉以下词汇对于本科学习的一些实际方面很有用。

I have tried to make each chapter fairly self-contained, so that you can jump in anywhere (though that was harder with Part 1, so I do recommend that you read most of that in order). I have also tried to introduce technical terms when they are needed, and have provided a list, prior to this introduction, summarizing the mathematical notation used in the book. However, you will find it useful to be familiar with the following vocabulary for some practical aspects of undergraduate studies.

数学专业：在前两年，有意主修数学的学生通常会学习一系列微积分课程和一些线性代数。他们通常被要求在第二年确定专业。一些大学要求新专业学生学习“过渡”或“桥接”课程，通过介绍证明的概念来为学习高级数学做好准备。高级课程通常包括实分析和抽象代数，但大多数机构都提供纯数学和应用数学的各种课程，学生通常可以选择学习哪些课程。本书旨在供所有数学专业学生使用，尽管它侧重于过渡到高级课程和纯数学。

Mathematics major: In their first two years, intending mathematics majors usually take a sequence of Calculus courses and some Linear Algebra. They are usually required to declare a major in their second year. Some colleges require new majors to take a “transition” or “bridging” course to prepare them for upper-level mathematics by introducing ideas about proof. Upper-level work usually includes Real Analysis and Abstract Algebra, but most institutions offer a variety of courses in both pure and applied mathematics, and students usually have some choice about which ones to take. This book is designed to be useful for all mathematics majors, although it focuses on the transition to upper-level courses and on pure mathematics.

课程：选择修读课程的学生必须注册特定的课程。对于每学期有数百名学生修读的低级课程，可能有许多课程可供选择。对于涉及更专业主题的高级课程，可能只有一两个课程。不同的课程将涵盖相同的材料，但将在不同的时间和地点讲授，并且（通常）由不同的教授讲授。在运营荣誉课程的机构中，可能会有特定的荣誉课程；希望注册这些课程的学生可能需要某种形式的特殊许可。

Sections: Students electing to take a course will have to register for a particular section. For lower-level courses that are taken by hundreds of students every semester, there might be many sections to choose from. For upper-level courses on more specialist topics, there might be just one or two. Different sections will cover the same material but will be taught at different times and places and (often) by different professors. In institutions that operate honors programs, there might be specific honors sections; students wishing to register for these might need some form of special permission.

复习和问题课：许多课程都有相关的复习或问题课；有时，一个大班可能会被分成多个小班进行复习。这些课程的重点是解决问题，它们可能由课程教授或研究生助教等其他讲师主持。

Recitations and problems sessions: Lots of courses have associated recitations or problems sessions; sometimes a large lecture class might be split into multiple smaller classes for recitations. These sessions focus on working through problems, and they might be run by the course professor or by an alternative instructor such as a postgraduate teaching assistant.

问题集：数学教授会为他们的课程分发问题集。这些问题集可能是课程教科书中的练习列表，也可能是教授制作的单独打印纸。问题集通常每周分发一次，或者在主题或章节开始或结束时分发。我将它们称为问题集，但它们也被称为示例表、练习或家庭作业。

Problem sets: Mathematics professors distribute sets of problems for their courses. These might be lists of exercises from a course textbook, or they might be on separate printed sheets produced by the professor. Problem sets are usually distrubuted weekly, or perhaps when a topic or chapter begins or ends. I’ll refer to them as problem sets, but they are also variously called example sheets, exercises, or just homework.

课程作业：数学教授还会布置一些需要提交以获得学分的作业，即为学生最终获得的成绩做出贡献。这些作业有多种形式，包括从问题集中选出的问题、单独的书面作业以及在课堂上或在计算机上进行的测试。我将这些统称为课程作业。

Coursework assignments: Mathematics professors also set work that is to be submitted for credit; that is, to contribute to the grades that students are eventually awarded. This work takes many forms, including selected problems from problem sets, separate written assignments, and tests taken during class time or on a computer. I’ll refer to these things collectively as coursework assignments.

在线资料：大学通常有一个计算机环境，学生可以通过它访问学术资料。在某些情况下，这将是一个虚拟学习环境(VLE)，它可能被冠以商业或当地名称（在我的大学，VLE 被称为“学习”）。您通常必须登录 VLE，但当您登录时，您会发现系统知道您注册了哪些课程，并为每个课程提供单独的页面链接。在每个课程页面中，您的教授可以提供资源（讲义、问题解决方案、在线测试链接等）供您下载。或者，可能没有这样的 VLE，而是由您的部门或个别教授维护的课程网页。主要的大学页面还将包含指向其他服务和设施的链接，并可能允许您进行与大学相关的金融交易。不用说，有人会为您提供有关所有这些的信息。

Online materials: Colleges usually have a computer environment via which students can access academic materials. In some cases this will be a virtual learning environment (VLE), which might be referred to by a commercial or locally-decided name (at my university, the VLE is called “Learn”). You usually have to log in to a VLE, but when you do you’ll find that the system knows what courses you are registered for and provides a link to a separate page for each one. Within each course page, your professor can provide resources (lecture notes, problem solutions, links to online tests, and so on) for you to download. Alternatively, there might be no VLE as such, but course webpages maintained by your department or by individual professors. The main college pages will also have links to other services and facilities, and might allow you to make college-related financial transactions. Needless to say, someone will provide you with information about all of this.

顾问：美国式大学体系为学生提供了许多选择，让他们可以自行安排个人学位课程；可以选择课程以顺利完成主修（和辅修）课程，同时满足其他要求。先决条件结构意味着这不是一个微不足道的过程，因此学术顾问通常会帮助学生做出明智的决定。

Advisers: US-style college systems give students a lot of choice about how to organize their personal degree programs; about how to select courses to make good progress through a major (and minor) while also fulfilling other requirements. Prerequisite structures mean that this is not a trivial process, so academic advisers are usually available to help students make sensible decisions.

最后一个值得一提的术语是“自主学习”。学生有时会误解这个术语。他们知道大学要求自主学习，但有些人认为这意味着他们必须独自学习，没有任何帮助或支持。事实并非如此，我希望本书能清楚地说明这一点。学习过程中会遇到挑战，你必须付出一些个人的智力努力。但那些有一点主动性的人会发现有很多帮助（特别是第 10 章），提出好的问题并以富有成效的方式思考可以带来快速的进步。

One final term worth mentioning is independent learning. Students sometimes misinterpret this term. They know that independent learning is expected in college, but some think this means that they will have to study alone with no help or support. This is far from true, as I hope will be clear from the whole of this book. There will be challenges, and you will have to put in some individual intellectual effort. But those with a bit of initiative will find that plenty of help is available (see especially Chapter 10) and that asking good questions and thinking in productive ways can lead to rapid progress.

考虑到这一点，让我们开始吧。

With that in mind, let’s get started.

第一部分

数学

PART 1

Mathematics

第一章

计算程序

CHAPTER 1

Calculation Procedures

本章讨论了学生过渡到高等数学时经常出现的一些问题。它讨论了本科生如何巩固现有的数学技能；它还确定了学生从低级课程转到高级课程时数学期望的变化方式。它描述了不同的学习方法，并论证了在处理高等数学时某些方法比其他方法更有用。

This chapter addresses some issues that frequently arise when students make the transition to advanced mathematics. It discusses ways in which undergraduates can build on their existing mathematical skills; it also identifies ways in which mathematical expectations change when a student moves from lower-level to upper-level courses. It describes different approaches to learning, and argues that certain approaches are more useful than others when dealing with advanced mathematics.

1.1 计算与高等数学

1.1 Calculation and advanced mathematics

本书的第一部分是关于高等数学的性质。高等数学与低等数学有许多共同之处，被数学专业录取的学生已经具备了一系列对他们大有裨益的数学技能。另一方面，高等数学也在一些重要方面不同于低等数学。这意味着大多数学生需要扩展和调整他们现有的技能才能继续取得好成绩。对于那些从未真正思考过自己技能性质的人来说，进行这样的扩展和调整可能会很困难，因此第 1 部分将详细讨论这些内容。

The first part of this book is about the nature of upper-level mathematics. Upper-level mathematics has much in common with lower-level mathematics, and students who have been accepted onto a mathematics major already have an array of mathematical skills that will serve them well. On the other hand, upper-level mathematics also differs from lower-level mathematics in some important respects. This means that most students need to extend and adapt their existing skills in order to continue doing well. Making such extensions and adaptations can be difficult for those who have never really reflected on the nature of their skills, so Part 1 discusses these in some detail.

您肯定已经学会了应用数学程序来计算标准问题的答案。有些人喜欢做这种工作。他们喜欢得到一页正确答案的满足感，他们喜欢知道如果他们做对了所有事情，那么他们的答案确实是正确的安全感。有时他们认为数学与其他学科相比更具优势，因为其他学科的东西似乎更多的是一个见仁见智的问题，而且“没有正确答案”。

One thing you have certainly learned to do is to apply mathematical procedures to calculate answers to standard questions. Some people enjoy doing this type of work. They like the satisfaction of arriving at a page of correct answers, and they like the security of knowing that if they do everything right then their answers will, indeed, be correct. Sometimes they compare mathematics favorably with other subjects in which things seem to be more a matter of opinion and “there are no right answers.”

其他人不喜欢数学的这个方面。他们觉得做大量重复的练习很无聊，而了解各种程序的工作原理以及它们如何结合在一起会让他们感到更满足。我将在本章中进一步讨论这种差异。不过，现在请注意，知道如何应用程序非常重要，因为如果计算不熟练，就很难将注意力集中在更高级的概念上。

Other people dislike this aspect of mathematics. They find it dull to do lots of repetitious exercises, and they get more satisfaction from learning about why the various procedures work and how they fit together. I will discuss this difference further in this chapter. For now, however, note that knowing how to apply procedures is extremely important because, without fluency in calculations, it is hard to focus your attention on higher-level concepts.

当你开始学习高级课程时，教授们会希望你能熟练地使用你已经学过的方法。他们会希望你能够准确地操作代数表达式，解方程，对函数进行微分和积分等等。他们会希望你能够做到这些事情，而不必每次都停下来查找规则，他们可能对做不到这一点的学生没有耐心。这并不是因为他们对学生不耐烦——大多数教授都很乐意花很长时间和你谈论新的数学知识，或者回答那些说“我知道如何做，但我从来没有真正理解我们为什么这样做”的学生。但他们不会希望重新教授你已经学过的东西。所以你应该在开始一门课程之前复习一下你的知识，特别是如果你整个夏天都没有学过数学的话。

When you start taking upper-level courses, professors will expect you to be fluent in using the procedures you have already learned. They will expect you to be able to accurately manipulate algebraic expressions, to solve equations, to differentiate and integrate functions, and so on. They will expect you to be able to do these things without having to stop each time to look up a rule, and they might not be patient with students who are not able to do so. This is not because they are impatient with students in general—most professors will be very happy to spend a long time talking with you about new mathematics, or responding to students who say, “I know how to do this, but I’ve never really understood why we do it this way.” But they will not expect to have to re-teach things you have already studied. So you should brush up your knowledge prior to beginning a course, especially if, say, you’ve done no mathematics all summer.

一旦你开始学习，你会发现一些高级数学涉及学习新的程序。这些程序，不出所料，会比你以前遇到的程序更长、更复杂。不过，我并不担心你应用长而复杂的程序的能力，因为要走到这一步，你必须能够做到那种事。在这里，我想关注你与程序交互方式的更实质性的变化。

Once you do begin, you’ll find that some upper-level mathematics involves learning new procedures. These procedures, unsurprisingly, will be longer and more complicated than those you met in earlier work. I am not worried about your ability to apply long and complicated procedures, however, because to have got this far you must be able to do that kind of thing. Here, I want to focus on more substantive changes in the ways in which you have to interact with the procedures.

1.2 关于程序和程序内的决策

1.2 Decisions about and within procedures

第一个实质性的区别是，你将承担更多责任来决定应用哪种程序。当然，你已经学会了在某种程度上做到这一点。例如，你已经学会了如何乘以括号并写下以下内容：

The first substantive difference is that you will have more responsibility for deciding which procedure to apply. Of course, you have learned to do this to some extent already. For instance, you have learned how to multiply out brackets and write things like:

但希望你也已经了解到，在尝试简化分数时，像这样进行乘法是不明智的：

But hopefully you have also learned that it is not sensible to multiply out when trying to simplify a fraction like this:

对于分数，如果我们将因数保持“可见”，简化会更容易。尽管如此，许多人还是会自动进行乘法运算，可能是因为乘法运算是他们学习代数时学会的第一件事。但是，如果他们学会先停下来思考什么能让他们取得最大的进步，他们就会成为更有效的数学家。如果这不适用于你解决这一类问题，那么它适用于其他问题吗？你是否曾经做过长时间的计算，然后意识到你不需要这样做？如果你先停下来思考，你能避免这种情况吗？决定采用哪种程序的一部分是，在你跳进去做第一个想到的事情之前给自己一点时间思考。

For the fraction, simplification is easier if we keep the factors “visible.” Nonetheless, many people automatically multiply out, probably because multiplying out was one of the first things they learned to do when studying algebra. They would, however, become more effective mathematicians if they learned to stop and think first about what would allow them to make the most progress. If this doesn’t apply to you for this particular type of problem, does it apply in others? Have you ever done a long calculation and then realized that you didn’t need to? Could you have avoided it if you’d stopped to think first? Part of deciding which procedure to apply is giving yourself a moment to think about it before you leap in and do the first thing that comes to mind.

这听起来可能不是什么大问题，但请想一想，你有多少次不必选择应用哪种程序。通常，书本或考试中的问题会告诉你该怎么做。他们会说“使用乘积规则来区分这个函数”。即使问题没有直接告诉你，有时从上下文中也能看出。在高中，如果你的老师花了一节课向你展示如何应用双角公式，然后给你一组问题让你做，那么你很可能认为这些会涉及双角公式。这对你有帮助，但这意味着很多时候你不必决定应用哪种程序。在更广阔的世界和高等数学中，决策更受重视，也更常被期待。这意味着问题纸上或考试中的问题通常只会说“解决这个问题”，而不是“用这种方法解决这个问题”。

This might not sound like a big deal, but think for a moment about how often you don’t have to make a choice about what procedure to apply. Often, questions in books or on tests tell you exactly what to do. They say things like, “Use the product rule to differentiate this function.” Even when a question doesn’t tell you outright, it is sometimes obvious from the context. In high school, if your teacher spent a lesson showing you how to apply double angle formulas, then gave you a set of questions to do, it was probably safe for you to assume that these would involve double angle formulas. This helped you out, but it means that much of the time you didn’t have to decide what procedure to apply. In the wider world, and in advanced mathematics, making decisions is more highly valued and more often expected. This means that questions presented to you on problem sheets or in exams will usually just say “solve this problem” rather than “solve this problem using this procedure.”

决定应用哪种程序的另一个部分是能够区分看起来相似但最好以不同方式处理的情况。例如，考虑积分，更具体地说是分部积分。您可能知道，当我们想要积分两个函数的乘积时会用到它，其中一个函数在我们对其进行微分，而另一个在积分时不会变得更复杂。例如，在 中，如果我们对 x 进行微分，它会变得更简单，而如果我们对 e x进行积分，它也不会变得更复杂。但是，您可能还知道，有时数学情况看起来表面上相似，但最好使用不同的程序来解决。在积分情况下，代换积分有时可能更合适。例如，在 中，我们可能希望使用代换积分而不是分部积分。您明白为什么吗？

Another part of deciding which procedure to apply is being able to distinguish between cases that look similar but are best approached in different ways. For example, consider integration, and more specifically integration by parts. You may know that this is used when we want to integrate a product of two functions, one of which gets simpler when we differentiate it, and the other of which does not get any more complicated when we integrate it. For instance, in , x gets simpler if we differentiate it, and ex gets no more complicated if we integrate it. You might also know, however, that sometimes mathematical situations look superficially similar, but are best tackled using different procedures. In the integration case, integration by substitution might sometimes be more appropriate. For instance, in we would probably want to use integration by substitution instead of by parts. Can you see why?

代换积分法是另一个我要提出的要点的一个很好的例子，这次是关于在程序中做出决策。你可能读到最后一段的结尾，然后想，“但是我应该使用什么替代方法呢？”也许你的老师或书本总是告诉你要使用什么，但我认为他们不一定非要这样做。一段时间后，你应该注意到某些替代方法在某些情况下是有用的。如果你注意这些案例的结构，那么即使你不确定你能为新案例挑选出一个好的替代方法，你也应该知道一些明智的做法。如果你以前没有刻意考虑过这个问题，我建议你现在就这样做。提出一些关于代换积分法的问题，不用真正做这些问题，看看建议的替代方法。你能预料到为什么这些替代方法会起作用吗？那么你能预料到在类似情况下什么会起作用吗？我将在本章后面回到这个例子。

Integration by substitution is a good case for another point I want to make, this time about making decisions within procedures. It might be that you read the end of the last paragraph and thought, “But what substitution should I use?” Perhaps your teachers or books always told you what to use, but I would argue that they shouldn’t necessarily have to. After a while, you should notice that certain substitutions are useful in certain cases. If you pay attention to the structures of these cases then, even if you wouldn’t be sure that you could pick a good substitution for a new case, you should have an idea of some sensible things to try. If you haven’t deliberately thought about this before, I suggest you do so now. Get out some questions on integration by substitution and, without actually doing the problems, look at the suggested substitutions. Can you anticipate why those substitutions will work? Can you then anticipate what would work in similar cases? I’ll come back to this illustration later in this chapter.

那么，学生如何才能提高他们在程序内做出决策的能力呢？我有两个建议。第一个建议是尝试做练习，练习中要应用的程序并不明显。一个好的地方是章末练习，它们往往涵盖更多的材料。第二个建议是把普通的练习变成反思的机会。当你完成一个练习时，不要直接转到下一个练习，而是停下来思考这些问题：

So how can a student improve their ability to make decisions about and within procedures? I have two suggestions. The first is to try doing exercises from a source where the procedure to be applied is not obvious. A good place to look is in end-of-chapter exercises, which tend to cover more material. The second suggestion is to turn ordinary exercises into opportunities for reflection. When you finish an exercise, instead of just moving on to the next one, stop and think about these questions:

1. 该程序为何有效？

1. Why did that procedure work?

2. 问题中可以做哪些改变以使其仍然有效？

2. What could be changed in the question so that it would still work?

3. 问题中可以进行哪些改变以使其不再起作用？

3. What could be changed in the question so that it would not work?

4. 我可以修改该程序，以便它能适用于其中一些情况吗？

4. Could I modify the procedure so that it would work for some of these cases?

所有这些问题都应该有助于您灵活地应用您所知道的知识。

All of these questions should help you build up flexibility in applying what you know.

1.3 从少量（或没有）示例中学习

1.3 Learning from few (or no) examples

当你在高中学习一种新程序时，你的老师可能会通过向你展示几个示例来介绍它。这些示例可能略有不同，因此前面的比较容易，后面的比较难。你的老师可能会给你布置一些练习，让你自己练习。你可能用手边的示例做这些练习，将该方法应用于你得到的新案例。

When you learned a new procedure in high school, your teacher probably introduced it by showing you several worked examples. These examples probably varied a bit, so that the first ones were easier and the later ones were harder. Your teacher probably then set you some exercises so you could practice for yourself. You probably did these exercises with the worked examples to hand, applying the method to the new cases you were given.

在高级课程中，当你开始尝试一个问题时，手头上很少有几个示例可供参考。你可能只有一两个。这些示例不会涵盖应用该程序的所有可能变化，因此你将更有责任确定你是否可以完全遵循它，或者你是否需要调整它，因为你正在处理略有不同的情况。

In upper-level courses it’s less common to have several worked examples to hand when you begin trying a problem. You might have just one or two. These will not encompass all the possible variation in applying the procedure, so you will be more responsible for working out whether you can follow it exactly, or whether you need to adjust it because you’re working with a slightly different situation.

举一个需要进行调整的简单例子，考虑一下那些已经学会了如何通过分解因式然后将因数设为 0 来解决x 2 − 5 x + 6 = 0等二次方程的学生。他们可能会写出类似这样的内容：

For a straightforward example in which an adjustment is necessary, consider school students who have learned to solve quadratic equations like x2 − 5x + 6 = 0 by factorizing then setting the factors equal to 0. They might write something like this:

现在假设要求某位学生解方程x 2 − 5 x + 6 = 8，他写下：

Now suppose such a student is asked to solve the equation x2 − 5x + 6 = 8, and writes this:

这里到底出了什么问题？确保你能回答这个问题——发现逻辑论证中的错误很重要。你能解释错误是什么以及为什么是错误吗？然而，你能明白为什么有人会犯这个错误吗？请注意，这并不疯狂——该程序表面上看起来可能有效，因为方程似乎属于同一类型。它在本例中不起作用，因为虽然如果ab = 0 则我们必须有a = 0 或b = 0 是正确的，但如果ab = 8 则我们必须有a = 8 或b = 8 是不正确的。对程序进行合理的修改是先从两边减去 8，然后使用标准形式的方程。

What exactly has gone wrong here? Make sure you can answer this—spotting the errors in logical arguments is important. Can you explain what the error is and why it is an error? Can you see, nonetheless, why someone might make this mistake? Notice that it isn’t crazy—the procedure looks on the surface like it might work because the equation seems to be of the same kind. It doesn’t work in this case because, while it is true that if ab = 0 then we must have a = 0 or b = 0, it is not true that if ab = 8 then we must have a = 8 or b = 8. A sensible modification of the procedure would have been to subtract 8 from both sides first, and work with an equation in the standard form.

这是一个简单的例子，当你学会做这种事情时，你的老师可能不会指望你只用一个实际的例子来处理相关但不相同的情况。事实上，在低级数学中，学生通常只看到一切正常的情况——相对较少的时间用于识别标准程序不适用的例子。所以你可能没有太多练习过发现程序局限性所需的批判性思维，你应该在攻读专业的过程中准备培养这种技能。

This is a simple illustration and, when you learned to do this kind of thing, your teachers probably didn’t expect you to use just one worked example to work out how to deal with related but non-identical cases. Indeed, in lower-level mathematics, students are usually only shown cases in which everything works—comparatively little time is devoted to recognizing examples for which standard procedures do not apply. So you might not have had much practice at the critical thinking needed to spot the limitations of procedures, and you should be prepared to develop this skill as you work toward your major.

事实上，在高等数学中，有时你会被要求在完全没有看过任何示例的情况下应用某个程序。这听起来可能不可能，但事实并非如此，因为有用的信息有时会以其他形式出现。具体来说，应用程序通常涉及将事物代入公式中。例如，微分的乘积规则涉及一个公式，通常表示如下（如果你使用的公式看起来不完全像这样，你能看出它与你熟悉的公式有何对应吗？）：

In fact, in upper-level mathematics, you will sometimes be asked to apply a procedure without having seen any worked examples at all. This might sound impossible, but it isn’t, because useful information sometimes comes in other forms. In particular, applying procedures often involves substituting things into formulas. For instance, the product rule for differentiation involves a formula, and is often expressed as follows (if the formula you use does not look exactly like this, can you see how it corresponds to the one you’re familiar with?):

要应用乘法法则，我们需要确定u和v的值，然后计算出我们需要的所有其他值并将它们代入公式中。当你第一次看到这个时，你的老师可能会通过几个例子来向你展示如何做到这一点。但这真的有必要吗？如果你现在学到了类似的东西，你是否需要有人一步一步地指导你，或者你可以自己做所有适当的替换并自己完成？

To apply the product rule, we decide what we want u and v to be, then work out all the other things we need and substitute them into the formula. When you first saw this, your teacher probably went through a few examples, showing you how to do this. Was that really necessary, though? If you learned something similar now, would you need someone to walk you through it step by step, or could you just make all the appropriate substitutions and follow it through yourself?

再举一个例子，考虑一下导数的定义。你可能在第一次接触微分时就见过这个。你必须在主修期间详细地接触它，所以我们将在这里使用它来展示如何在不需要实际例子的情况下应用通用公式。它在这里：

For another illustration, consider the definition of the derivative. You may have seen this when you were first introduced to differentiation. You’ll have to engage with it in detail during your major, so we’ll use it here to show how you might apply a general formula without needing a worked example. Here it is:

定义： 假设这个极限存在。

Definition: provided this limit exists.

为什么这是一个合理的定义这个问题很重要，同样重要的还有为什么我们需要说“假设这个极限存在”。但是，我们在这里不关注这些问题（请在高级微积分或分析课程中寻找答案）。现在，假设我们已经给出了这个定义，并被要求使用它来求出由f ( x ) = x 3给出的函数f的导数（我知道你已经知道答案是什么，但请容我解释一下）。我们该怎么办？好吧，我们想要求 d f / d x，因此这个公式可以按原样使用——我们不需要做任何重新排列。我们有一个f的公式，因此我们可以将其代入：

The question of why this is a reasonable definition is important, as is the question of why we need to say “provided this limit exists.” However, we’re not focusing on those questions here (look out for the answers in a course called Advanced Calculus or Analysis). For now, suppose we’ve been given this definition and asked to use it to find the derivative of the function f given by f(x) = x3 (I know you already know what the answer is, but humor me for a moment). What would we do? Well, we want to find df / dx, so the formula can be used exactly as it is—we don’t need to do any rearranging. We have a formula for f, so we can substitute that in:

然后我们可以简化得到的表达式：

Then we can simplify the resulting expression:

最后，我们可以观察到，当h趋向于 0 时， 3 x 2保持不变，但 3 xh趋向于 0， h 2也是如此。所以极限等于 3 x 2。因此，通过代入定义，我们确定

Finally, we can observe that as h tends to 0, 3x2 stays as it is, but 3xh tends to 0 and so does h2. So the limit is equal to 3x2. Hence, by substituting into the definition, we have established that

这正是我们所期待的。

This is what we were expecting.

认识到你可以自己直接将通用公式应用于示例，这应该会让你感到数学能力增强。有人指导你完成一些实际示例可能仍然会让你感到安心，但在许多情况下，你不再需要这种程度的支持。

Recognizing that you can apply general formulas directly to examples, on your own, should make you feel mathematically empowered. It might still be reassuring to have someone walk you through some worked examples, but in many cases you don’t need that level of support any more.

1.4 生成自己的练习

1.4 Generating your own exercises

正如我所说，有时大学教授只会给你少量的算例。同样，有时他们只会给你少量的练习。例如，他们可能会演示如何证明由f ( x ) = 2 x给出的函数f是连续的，1并要求你为f ( x ) = 3 x写一个类似的证明。他们可能不会要求更多，但他们的目的是让你了解如何为f ( x ) = 4 x和f ( x ) = 265 x等写一个类似的证明。即使你能，你还是应该为几个案例写出证明，只是为了练习。在高中，你的老师可能负责决定你应该做多少练习，但教授更有可能只设置一个练习，让你自己判断是否能从发明类似的练习中受益。

Sometimes, as I said, university professors will give you only a small number of worked examples. Similarly, sometimes they will set you only a small number of exercises. They might, for instance, demonstrate how we can prove that the function f given by f(x) = 2x is continuous,1 and ask you to write a similar proof for f(x) = 3x. They might not ask for anything more, but their intention will be that you can then see how to write a similar proof for f(x) = 4x and for f(x) = 265x, and so on. Even if you can, you might be well-advised to write out a proof for a few cases anyway, just for practice. In high school, your teacher probably took responsibility for deciding how much practice you should do, but a professor is more likely to set just one exercise and leave it to you to judge whether you’d benefit from inventing similar ones.

你也许应该停下来问问自己这种证明的局限性。例如，它适用于负值吗？同样的步骤是否立即适用于f ( x ) = −10 x，还是需要进行某种调整？对于f ( x ) = 0 x呢？事实上，你能正确地概括并为f ( x ) = cx写出一个论证吗？你需要对c施加任何限制吗？数学家认为这种思维方式非常自然。他们可能总是自己这样做，而不需要别人告诉他们。你也应该这样做。

You might also be well-advised to stop and ask yourself about the limitations of such a proof. Would it, for instance, work for negative values? Would the same steps apply immediately for f(x) = −10x, or would you need to make some kind of adjustment in that case? What about for f(x) = 0x? Indeed, could you generalize properly, and write an argument for f(x) = cx? Would you need to place any restrictions on c? Mathematicians consider this kind of thinking to be very natural. They probably always did it for themselves, without having to be told to. You should too.

到目前为止，本章的结论是，如果你总是试图通过找到类似的东西并复制它来解决问题，你将无法在高级数学中取得成功。在某些情况下，如果你不加思索地复制思考，你最终可能会写出无意义的东西，因为在示例中成立的某些属性在你的问题中不成立。在其他情况下，复制可能只是效率低下——你选择的第一种方法可能工作得很好，但花费的时间是其他方法的两倍。在其他情况下，可能根本没有任何例子可循。你可能必须认识到可以应用某个定义或定理，然后应用它，通过适当的替换直接从一般陈述转到你的具体情况。

The upshot of this chapter so far is that you will not succeed in upper-level mathematics if you always try to solve problems by finding something that looks similar and copying it. In some cases, if you copy without thinking, you could end up writing nonsense because some property that holds in the worked example does not hold in your problem. In other cases, copying might just be inefficient—the first approach you choose might work perfectly well but take twice as long as a different method. In still other cases, there might not be any examples to follow at all. You might have to recognize that a particular definition or theorem can be applied, then apply it, going straight from the general statement to your specific case via appropriate substitutions.

这使得高级数学比你以前遇到的数学更具挑战性。你必须更加仔细地注意你的符号操作是否对你正在处理的示例有效。这并不总是那么容易，但你可以通过问自己第 1.2 节末尾的问题来练习。

This makes upper-level mathematics more demanding than mathematics you have encountered before. You have to attend more carefully to whether your symbolic manipulations are valid for the example that you are working with. This is not always easy, but again you can practice by asking yourself the questions at the end of Section 1.2.

1.5 写出计算结果

1.5 Writing out calculations

如果你读过这本书的目录页，你会发现有一整章专门讨论数学写作。我不会在这里多说什么，但我有一些评论与我们在讨论计算过程时特别相关。

If you’ve read the Contents pages of this book, you will have noticed that there is an entire chapter devoted to writing mathematics. I’m not going to say much about this here, but I have a few comments that are particularly relevant while we’re talking about calculation procedures.

可能有些程序你可以愉快地记住所有内容，只写下最少的工作内容，但有些程序你容易出错，因此值得一步一步地完成，并写下所有内容。如果有人告诉你应该始终写下所有的工作内容，那么现在正是开始放弃这个想法的好时机。数学的一大优点是它非常可压缩：我们可以通过在心理上“分块”其组成部分来理解复杂的概念。例如，在展开括号时，你可能最初学会了写出所有内容，如下所示：

There are probably some procedures for which you can happily keep everything in mind and write down only minimal working, but others for which you tend to make errors so that it is worth doing one step at a time and writing everything down. If you have been told that you should always write out all of your working, this would be a good time to begin letting go of that idea. One of the great things about mathematics is that it is very compressible: we can understand complex ideas by mentally “chunking” their components. For example, when expanding brackets, you probably originally learned to write everything out, like this:

但是现在你可能已经在脑子里想了很多，只需写下这些：

But now you probably do much of it in your head and just write this:

这样做可以帮助您更快地进行大量计算，从而帮助您关注您正在尝试解决的整体问题。

Doing so helps you to do lots of calculations faster, which helps you to keep your eye on whatever overall problem you are trying to solve.

在较低级别的考试中，为了满足考官的要求，你可能愿意写出一定数量的计算，但你仍然可以自己思考你真正需要什么。在较高级别的考试中，你会发现你的教授有时会把常规计算视为理所当然；他们会“跳过一些步骤”，并希望你能够自己填写。例如，为了回到代换积分，我很乐意写下：

At lower-levels, it may be in your interest to write out a certain amount of working in order to satisfy an examiner, but you can still think for yourself about what you actually need. At upper-levels, you will find that your professors sometimes take routine calculations for granted; they will “skip steps” and expect you to be able to fill them in for yourself. For instance, to go back to integration by substitution, I am happy to just write down:

我可以在脑中快速进行积分，因为我知道我在寻找可以微分x cos( x2 )的某个值。我知道答案会是 sin( x2 )之类的东西，所以我会先把它写下来。然后我可以看到，如果我微分 sin( x2 )（使用链式法则），我会得到 2 x cos( x2 )，所以我只需要将 sin( x2 )除以 2 就可以得到我想要的结果。如果您还没有这样做，您可以尝试使用本章前面提到的积分的类似思维。

I can do the integration quickly in my head because I know that I am looking for something that differentiates to x cos (x2). I know that the answer will be something like sin (x2) so I’d write that down first. I can then see that if I differentiate sin (x2) (using the chain rule), I get 2x cos (x2), so I just need to divide the sin (x2) by 2 to get what I want. If you haven’t done so already, you might try using similar thinking for the integral as mentioned earlier in this chapter.

任何一种计算都可以用代换式u = x 2完全写出来（如果你不确定，可以试一试，你会发现你写的或多或少就是我刚刚讲过的推理）。如果我在讲一门新生微积分课程，我可能希望学生把所有内容都写出来。但是，如果我讲的是其他课程，我会希望我的学生能够在脑海中完成这种事情。如果他们只是写下答案，我可能不会介意；他们很可能会把它作为某个更大问题的一部分，如果他们选择不包含所有细节，他们对更大问题的解决方案会更简洁。如果我需要在讲座中进行这种计算，我很可能只会写下答案并希望学生能够自己检查其正确性。如果你习惯于将数学视为可压缩的，你应该对此感到满意。

Either calculation can be written out fully using the substitution u = x2 (if you’re unsure about this, try it, and you’ll find that what you write is more or less exactly the reasoning I just went through). If I were lecturing a freshman Calculus course, I might expect a student to write everything out. If I were lecturing anything other than that, however, I would expect my students to be able to do this kind of thing in their heads. I probably wouldn’t mind if they just wrote down the answer; chances are they’d be doing it as part of some larger problem, and their solutions to the larger problem would be more concise if they chose not to include every last detail. It’s certainly likely that if I needed this calculation in a lecture, I would just write down the answer and expect students to be able to check its correctness for themselves. If you get used to seeing mathematics as compressible, you should be fine with this.

不过，我要强调的是，如果你的老师让你把你的工作全部写出来，他们并没有说错。这样做当然有好处：它允许你检查你的工作是否有错误，并在你回到问题时记住你当时的想法。但压缩也很重要，判断什么能让你的总体论点对读者最清楚也很重要。我们将在整本书中回顾这些主题。

I should stress, however, that your teachers haven’t said anything wrong if they’ve told you to write out your working in full. Doing so certainly has benefits: it allows you to check your work for errors and to remember what you were thinking when you come back to a problem. But compression is also important, as is making judgments about what will make your overall argument clearest to a reader. We will return to these themes throughout the book.

1.6 检查错误

1.6 Checking for errors

如果你已经掌握了数学知识，那么你可能犯过很多数学错误。有些错误可能很小，比如漏写一个常数，或者不小心把“+”写成了“-”。有些错误你会马上注意到，而有些错误会让你困惑很久。例如，当我上高中时，有一次我完全搞不懂为什么一个简单的代数题会出错。我的老师让我看了几天，然后笑了（不是恶意的），并指出我加了应该乘的地方。我有点愚蠢的感觉被宽慰感大大抵消了，因为我没有发疯，没有从某种深刻的角度理解整个问题。无论如何，你可能已经养成了检查工作中是否存在微小操作错误的习惯，这很好。

If you’ve got this far in mathematics, you have probably made lots of mathematical errors. Some of these will have been small, like missing a constant or accidentally writing a “+” instead of a “−”. Some you will have noticed straightaway, others you will have been confused by for much longer. When I was in high school, for instance, I was once totally mystified about why a simple piece of algebra wasn’t coming out right. My teacher let me look at it for a couple of days before he laughed (not unkindly) and pointed out that I was adding where I should have been multiplying. The feeling that I had been a bit daft was greatly outweighed by relief that I had not gone mad and failed to understand the whole problem in some profound way. At any rate, you are probably in the habit of checking your work for minor manipulation errors, which is good.

然而，有些错误更为严重。在我们关于因式分解二次函数的例子中，错误表明该人未能理解该方法的工作原理。您应该留意此类问题，并检查每一步是否真的按照您的想法进行。当然，您可能会尝试这样做，但仍然得不到预期的答案。当这种情况发生时，不要害怕与他人讨论它。我从学生那里得到的很多问题都是“我知道这行不通，但我找不到错误。”当我们解决问题时，他们通常会学到很多东西，通常是因为他们意识到他们在没有意识到的情况下做出了假设。对某些属性或原理的认识增强意味着您可以在更多情况下识别它，并可以在进一步思考中积极使用它。

Some errors, however, are more serious. In our example about factorizing the quadratic, the error indicates that the person has failed to understand why the method works. You should be on the lookout for such problems, and check that each step really works in the way that you think. Of course, you might try to do that, but still not get the expected answer. When that happens, don’t be afraid to talk to someone about it. A lot of the queries I get from students are along the lines of “I know this isn’t working but I can’t find the mistake.” They often learn a lot when we sort it out, usually because they recognize that they were making an assumption without being aware of it. Increased awareness of some property or principle means that you can recognize it in more situations and can use it actively in further thinking.

其他错误并不严重，但会让教授很恼火，因为它们看起来很马虎。当学生给出他们本应意识到不可能正确的答案时，就会发生这种情况。如果答案是一个数字，那么它可能太大或太小。这类错误的一个常见来源是计算器。与所有计算设备一样，计算器速度快但功能笨拙。它们会给出你所提问题的答案，不管这是否是你想要问的问题。如果你按错了键，或者你不太清楚计算器如何处理某些类型的输入，或者你在需要弧度时却以度为单位，计算器将无法识别这些。它会尽职尽责地给你它认为你要求的结果。只有你才能判断输出是否合理。

Other errors are not serious but are annoying to professors because they look sloppy. These occur when students give solutions that they should have recognized could not possibly be right. If the answer is a number, perhaps it is way too large or way too small. One common source of errors like that is the calculator. Calculators, like all computing devices, are fast but stupid. They will give you the answer to the question you asked, whether or not this is the question you intended to ask. If you hit the wrong key, or you don’t quite know how your calculator handles certain kinds of input, or you are working in degrees when you want radians, your calculator won’t know that. It will dutifully give you what it thinks you asked for. Only you can judge whether the output is plausible.

但这种事情也可能以其他方式发生。有时学生给出的答案甚至不是正确的数学对象类型。他们给出了一个数字，而答案应该是一个向量，或者给出了一个函数，而答案应该是一个数字，或者诸如此类的东西。这种情况可能以相当直接的方式发生：假设要求学生求f ′(2)，他们找到了f ′( x )（一个函数），但忘记用 2 代入x来求最终答案（一个数字）。这种情况也可能以复杂的方式发生，有时表明学生并没有真正理解问题，并且抄袭了一个表面上看起来相似但并未达到要求的程序。我将在第 2 章中讨论如何识别和避免此类错误。

But this sort of thing can happen in other ways too. Sometimes students give an answer that is not even the right type of mathematical object. They give a number when the answer should be a vector, or a function when the answer should be a number, or something like that. This can happen in pretty straightforward ways: say that students are asked to find f′(2) and they find f′(x) (a function) but forget to substitute in 2 for x to find the final answer (a number). It can also happen in complex ways, and is sometimes an indication that a student hasn’t really understood a question, and has copied a procedure that looks superficially similar but does not achieve what is required. I’ll talk about recognizing and avoiding that kind of mistake in Chapter 2.

与此同时，我给学生们提一条建议，尤其是在考试时。如果你做了一些计算，并且知道你的答案一定是错的，那就写一条简短的注释来表明这一点：比如“一定是错的，因为太小了”。这样，至少给你打分的人知道你在思考问题的含义。显然，如果你能指出错误发生在哪里就更好了，如果你能改正就更好了。但是，如果你不能在有限的时间内做这些事情，你至少可以证明你知道一个合理的答案是什么样的。

In the meantime, here’s a piece of advice I give to students, especially for exams. If you have done some calculations and you know your answer must be wrong, write a quick note to indicate this: something like “must be wrong because too small.” At least then the person grading your work knows that you were thinking about the meaning of the question. Obviously, it’s better if you can indicate where the mistake has happened, and even better if you can fix it. But, if you can’t do those things in the time available, you can at least demonstrate that you know what a reasonable answer would look like.

1.7 数学不仅仅是程序

1.7 Mathematics is not just procedures

本章一直都在讨论计算程序。但我想回到这个观点：知道如何应用这些程序只是理解数学的一部分。这是一个重要部分，但大多数人都能认识到学习机械地应用一个程序和理解它为什么有效之间的区别。机械地学习有一些优点：它通常很快而且相对简单。但它也有缺点：如果你机械地学习程序，就更容易忘记它们、误用它们和混淆它们。正确理解事物为什么起作用通常更难、更耗时，但由此产生的知识更容易记住，也更有利于灵活和准确的推理。

This chapter has been all about calculational procedures. But I want to come back to the idea that knowing how to apply such procedures is only one part of understanding mathematics. It is an important part, but most people can recognize the difference between learning to apply a procedure mechanically, and understanding why it works. Learning mechanically has some advantages: it is generally quick and relatively straightforward. But it also has disadvantages: if you learn procedures mechanically, it is easier to forget them, to misapply them, and to mix them up. Developing a proper understanding of why things work is generally harder and more time-consuming, but the resulting knowledge is easier to remember and more supportive of flexible and accurate reasoning.

无论你之前的经历如何，你几乎肯定有一些事情你理解得很深刻，而有些事情你只是在程序上学到的。例如，你也许可以解释为什么我们当我们“将 5 向左移动”以解方程x + 3 = 2 x − 5 时，“改变符号”。您可以解释说，我们实际上在做的是将 5 添加到两边，并且因为之前两边相等，并且我们对两边做了同样的事情，所以它们现在仍然相等。这表明您理解得很好，因为您不仅知道我们做了某些事情，还知道为什么这些事情是合理的。您可以给出一个真正数学的解释，因此比“书上是这么说的”或“老师告诉我的”更好。

Whatever your previous experience, you almost certainly have some things that you understand deeply and some things that you have only learned procedurally. For instance, you could probably explain why we “change signs” when we “move the 5 to the left” in order to solve the equation x + 3 = 2x − 5. You might explain that what we’re really doing is adding 5 to both sides and that, because the two sides were equal before and we’ve done the same thing to both, they’re still equal now. This demonstrates good understanding because you know not only that we do certain things, but also why these things are reasonable. You can give an explanation that’s genuinely mathematical, and is thus better than “that’s what it says in the book” or “that’s what my teacher told me.”

很难声称对某些事物有“全面”的理解，因为各种数学概念之间有如此多的联系，以至于任何人都很难说他们熟悉所有这些概念（尤其是在一个新数学不断涌现的世界里——参见第 14 章）。例如，如果你关注了关于导数定义的讨论，你应该能够解释为什么f ( x ) = x 3的导数是f ′( x ) = 3 x 2。这将是一个很好的解释，但它本身并不能告诉我们这个结果与函数图像的关系，或者为什么f ( x ) = x n的导数在许多其他情况下应该是f ′( x ) = nx n −1。它也没有告诉我们为什么数学家首先使用这个定义。（也许你知道为什么。如果不知道，请思考一下，在某处查找它，并在微积分课程中寻找它。）

It’s hard to claim a “full” understanding of something, because there are so many links between various pieces of mathematics that it would be tough for anyone to say that they are familiar with all of them (especially in a world where new mathematics is being developed all the time—see Chapter 14). For example, if you followed the discussion about the definition of the derivative, you should be able to explain why the derivative of f(x) = x3 is f′(x) = 3x2. This would be a good explanation but it wouldn’t, on its own, tell us how this result relates to the graphs of the functions, or why the derivative of f(x) = xn should in many other cases be f′(x) = nxn−1. It also doesn’t tell us why mathematicians use that definition in the first place. (Perhaps you know why. If not, think about it, look it up somewhere, and look out for it in your Calculus courses.)

事实上，你应该小心不要对自己的理解过于自信，即使是简单的数学。有些东西你可能早就知道，可以自信地使用，但你无法像你想象的那样解释清楚。例如，你知道当我们将两个负数相乘时，我们会得到一个正数。但你真的知道为什么吗？你能给出一个解释来说服一个持怀疑态度的 13 岁孩子吗？同样，你知道 5 0 = 1，但为什么会这样呢？你知道我们“不能除以 0”，但为什么呢？为什么我们不能直接说 1/0 = ∞？如果你想用“就是这样”来回答这些问题，请注意，所有这些事情都是有原因的，即使你还不知道。你可能想看看进一步的阅读建议，以了解专业数学家会如何回答。

In fact, you should beware of being too confident about your understanding, even for straightforward mathematics. There might be things that you’ve known for a long time and can use confidently, but that you can’t explain as well as you’d think. For instance, you know that when we multiply two negative numbers together we get a positive one. But do you really know why? Could you give an explanation that would convince a skeptical 13 year-old? Similarly, you know that 50 = 1, but why is this the case? You know that we “can’t divide by 0” but, again, why? Why can’t we just say that 1/0 = ∞? If you are tempted to answer any of these questions by saying “that’s just how it is,” be aware that there are reasons for all of these things, even if you don’t yet know them. You might like to see the further reading suggestions to find out how professional mathematicians would answer.

与此同时，你知道自己只能从程序上理解其他事情。也许你可以使用二次公式，但你很难解释它为什么有效（我们将在第 5 章中讨论这个问题）。也许你擅长分部积分，但你没有最模糊的概念是公式从何而来。也许你可以使用简谐运动的公式，但你不知道这些符号在告诉你什么，或者为什么使用这些方程来捕捉这种类型的运动是合理的。高等数学的一大优点是，你可以期待对许多这样的公式和关系的解释。

In the meantime, there will be other things that you know you only understand procedurally. Perhaps you can use the quadratic formula, but you’d be hard pressed to explain why it works (we’ll look at this in Chapter 5). Perhaps you’re good at integration by parts, but you haven’t the faintest idea where the formula comes from. Perhaps you can work with the formulas for simple harmonic motion, but you don’t really know what the symbols are telling you or why it’s reasonable to use those equations to capture that type of motion. One great thing about advanced mathematics is that you can expect explanations of many such formulas and relationships.

事实上，很多数学家会告诉你，机械地学习程序是不好的——你应该一直努力深入理解。这是一个善意的说法，但有点不切实际。首先，在很多情况下，在特定阶段你无法真正理解。例如，极限出现在一些微积分课程中，但处理得相当不正式。在高级课程中，你将学习极限的正式定义，你将学习如何应用它以及如何使用它来证明各种定理。但这个定义在逻辑上很复杂，如果你和大多数人一样，学习如何使用它需要花费一些精力。当你能做到时，你会认识到你的理解已经提高，但你可能会认为你的教授没有早点介绍它是对的。

Indeed, plenty of mathematicians will tell you that learning procedures mechanically is bad—that you should always be striving for a deep understanding. This is a well-intentioned claim, but it is a bit unrealistic. For a start, there are plenty of situations in which good understanding is not really accessible to you at a given stage. Limits, for example, appear in some Calculus courses, but are treated fairly informally. In upper-level courses, you will learn a formal definition of limit, and you will learn how to apply it and how to use it to prove various theorems. But the definition is logically complex and, if you are like most people, it will cost you some effort to learn how to work with it. When you can, you will recognize that your understanding has improved, but you will probably think that your professors were right not to introduce it earlier.

这种说法也是不切实际的，因为有关程序的机械知识可能非常有用。生活中经典的例子就是驾驶汽车或操作电脑。也许你至少可以做其中一件事，但你并不真正了解内燃机的工作原理，也不知道计算机如何将你的按键转换成屏幕上显示的字母。你可以获得这种理解，但即使没有，你在生活中也可能过得很好。在数学中，有许多类似的情况。有时我们出于务实的原因不去了解某些事情的细节——只是没有时间。有时我们不去了解它们，因为它们很繁琐，研究它们会分散我们理解程序实现的目标的注意力。在你的专业学习期间仍然会出现这样的情况，但你会开始看到越来越多的数学知识背后的理论。

The claim is also unrealistic because mechanical knowledge of procedures can be very useful. The classic real-life examples are driving a car or operating a computer. Probably you can do at least one of these things, but you have no real idea how an internal combustion engine works or how a computer turns your keystrokes into letters that appear on the screen. You could acquire that understanding, but you’ll likely do just fine in life if you don’t. In mathematics, there are many analogous situations. Sometimes we don’t learn about the details of something for pragmatic reasons—there just isn’t time. Sometimes we don’t learn about them because they are fiddly and because studying them would distract us from understanding what a procedure achieves. There will still be situations like this during your major, but you will start to see more and more of the theory underlying mathematical knowledge.

有时人们不尝试发展深刻的理解，因为他们不需要它来完成他们想要完成的任务。众所周知，当数学教授试图促进对程序工作原理的理解时，工程专业的学生会感到恼火；他们会说“告诉我们该怎么做！”如果你是一个实践型的人，你可能会忍不住说类似的话，至少在你的纯数学课程中是这样。在应用数学中在数学（力学、统计学、决策数学等）领域，人们往往更注重解决问题，而较少关注发展抽象理论。但是，即使在这些学科中，你会发现数学家们也非常关心你应该理解为什么你的计算是合理的。这部分是为了避免犯本章讨论的错误，部分是为了让你能够更灵活地调整程序以解决新问题，部分只是为了享受其中的乐趣。

Sometimes people don’t try to develop deep understanding because they don’t need it for the tasks they want to accomplish. Engineering students famously get annoyed when mathematics professors try to promote understanding of why procedures work; they say “Just tell us what to do!” If you’re of a practical bent, you will probably be tempted to say something similar, at least in your pure mathematics courses. In applied mathematics (mechanics, statistics, decision mathematics, and so on), there does tend to be more focus on solving problems and less on developing abstract theories. But, even in those subjects, you will find that mathematicians care very much that you should understand why your calculations are reasonable. This is partly so that you can avoid making mistakes like those discussed in this chapter, partly so that you can be more flexible in adapting procedures to new problems, and partly just for the joy of it.

我当然认为，只要有可能，你就应该深入理解数学程序的工作原理以及数学概念之间的相互关联。这种理解更有力、更令人难忘，获得这种理解虽然很辛苦，但非常令人满意。尽管如此，我还是希望你最终能从程序上学到一些东西，要么因为这是唯一可行的方法，要么因为你对某个科目并不真正感兴趣，但你确实想通过考试。我的观点是，只要你意识到自己可能容易犯某些类型的错误，那就没问题。正如本书中的许多建议一样，这相当于对自己的学习负责。

I certainly think that, wherever possible, you should aim for a deep understanding of why mathematical procedures work and why mathematical concepts are related to each other as they are. Such understanding is more powerful and more memorable, and acquiring it is hard work but very satisfying. Nonetheless, I expect that you will end up learning some things procedurally, either because that’s the only way that’s accessible, or because you’re not really interested in a particular subject but you do want to pass the exam. My view is that, as long as you are aware that you might be vulnerable to certain kinds of error, that’s fine. As with many suggestions in this book, this amounts to taking responsibility for your own learning.

概括

SUMMARY

• 在学习高级课程之前，您应该复习一下标准程序的知识，因为教授希望您能够流利地使用这些程序。

• Before taking upper-level courses, you should brush up your knowledge of standard procedures because professors will expect you to be able to use these fluently.

• 随着您的进步，您将需要承担更多责任来决定应用哪种程序；通过做一些没有告诉您具体要做什么的来源的练习来练习这一点可能是个好主意。

• As you progress, you will be expected to take more responsibility for deciding which procedure to apply; it might be a good idea to practice this by working on exercises from sources that do not tell you exactly what to do.

• 您还需要以合理的方式调整程序，并找出如何应用定理或定义，而不必见过许多实际的例子。

• You will also be expected to adapt procedures in sensible ways, and to work out how theorems or definitions can be applied without necessarily having seen many worked examples.

• 你可能只会得到少量的练习；设计你自己的类似练习可能是明智的。

• You might be given only a small number of exercises; it might be sensible to invent your own similar ones for practice.

• 如果你总是试图通过寻找类似的东西并复制它来解决问题，那么你将无法在高级数学中取得成功。你必须比这更加深思熟虑。

• You will not succeed in upper-level mathematics if you always try to solve problems by finding something that looks similar and copying it. You have to be more thoughtful than that.

• 并不总是需要完整地写出计算结果。你的教授有时会跳过一些步骤，如果这样做可以让整体解决方案更清晰，你也可以这样做。

• It is not always necessary to write out calculations in full. Your professors will sometimes skip steps, and you might want to do the same if it makes an overall solution clearer.

• 尝试通过检查您的答案在问题情况下是否合理来避免计算器错误。此外，考虑一下您期望答案是什么类型的对象（数字、函数等）。

• Try to avoid calculator errors by checking whether your answer is plausible given the problem situation. Also, think about what type of object (a number, a function, etc.) you are expecting your answer to be.

• 数学不只是程序。熟练掌握程序固然重要，但在许多情况下，你应该努力更深入地理解程序的工作原理。

• Mathematics is not just about procedures. Fluency with procedures is important, but in many cases you should aim for a deeper understanding of why procedures work.

进一步阅读

FURTHER READING

要获得如何成为更有效的数学问题解决者的指南，请尝试：

For a guide to becoming a more effective mathematical problem solver, try:

• Krantz, SG (1997)。《问题解决技巧》。普罗维登斯，罗德岛：美国数学学会。

• Krantz, S. G. (1997). Techniques of Problem Solving. Providence, RI: American Mathematical Society.

• Mason, J.、Burton, L. 和 Stacey, K. (2010)。《数学思维》（第二版）。Harlow：Pearson Education。

• Mason, J., Burton, L., & Stacey, K. (2010). Thinking Mathematically (2nd Edition). Harlow: Pearson Education.

• Pólya, G. (1957)。《如何解决它：数学方法的新方面》（第二版）。新泽西州普林斯顿：普林斯顿大学出版社。

• Pólya, G. (1957). How to Solve It: A New Aspect of Mathematical Method (2nd Edition). Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press.

要了解数学家如何以复杂的方式思考数字和算术，请尝试：

For insights into how mathematicians think in a sophisticated way about numbers and arithmetic, try:

• Gowers, T. (2000)。数学：非常简短的介绍。牛津：牛津大学出版社。

• Gowers, T. (2000). Mathematics: A Very Short Introduction. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

想要更深入地思考学校数学，请尝试：

For ways of thinking more deeply about school mathematics, try:

• Usiskin, Z.、Peressini, A.、Marchisotto, EA 和 Stanley, D. (2003)。《高中教师数学：高级视角》。Upper Saddle River，新泽西州：Prentice Hall。

• Usiskin, Z., Peressini, A., Marchisotto, E.A., & Stanley, D. (2003). Mathematics for High School Teachers: An Advanced Perspective. Upper Saddle River, NJ: Prentice Hall.

要了解儿童对数学概念的更多理解，请尝试：

For more on childrens’ understandings of mathematical concepts, try:

• Ryan, J. 和 Williams, J. (2007)。4-15岁儿童数学：从错误和误解中学习。梅登黑德：开放大学出版社。

• Ryan, J. & Williams, J. (2007). Children’s Mathematics 4–15: Learning from Errors and Misconceptions. Maidenhead: Open University Press.

第 2 章

抽象对象

CHAPTER 2

Abstract Objects

本章介绍如何从抽象对象的角度思考数学。一些抽象对象（例如数字和函数）是熟悉的；其他抽象对象（例如二元运算和对称性）则不熟悉。本章解释了为什么能够将概念视为组织成层次结构的对象很重要。它指出了不掌握这一点的学生可能犯的错误，并强调了一些在学习抽象纯数学课程时特别有用的思维方式。

This chapter explains how to think of mathematics in terms of abstract objects. Some abstract objects, such as numbers and functions, will be familiar; others, such as binary operations and symmetries, will not. This chapter explains why it is important to be able to think of concepts as objects that are organized into hierarchical structures. It points out things that can go wrong for students who do not master this, and highlights some ways of thinking that are particularly useful when studying abstract pure mathematics courses.

2.1 数字作为抽象对象

2.1 Numbers as abstract objects

本章讨论的是抽象的数学对象。以数字 5 为例。当你第一次开始处理数字 5 时，可能与计数事物集合（橙子、木块、单面立方体等）有关。因此，5 与说“1、2、3、4、5”并指向这些东西的过程有关。然而，在某个时候，你不再需要指向实际的物理对象。事实上，你根本不需要思考某个东西的5 ，而是能够将 5 视为一个独立的事物。这听起来无伤大雅，但却是人类智慧的一项了不起的壮举，而且对于数学成功至关重要，因为这意味着你可以将抽象对象 5 与可能冗长的计数过程分离开来。

This chapter is about abstract mathematical objects. Take the number 5, for instance. When you first started dealing with the number 5, it was probably in the context of counting sets of things (oranges, wooden blocks, unifix cubes, or whatever). 5 was thus associated with the process of saying “1, 2, 3, 4, 5,” and pointing at these things. At some point, however, you stopped needing to point at actual physical objects. In fact, you stopped needing to think about five of something at all, and became able to think about 5 as a thing in its own right. This sounds innocuous but it is an incredible feat of the human intellect, and one that is vital to success in mathematics because it means that you can divorce the abstract object 5 from the potentially lengthy process of counting.

要了解为什么它如此重要，请思考一下你所知道的关于 5 的所有事情。你知道 5 + 2 = 7，5 + 5 = 10，5 × 5 = 25，等等。你在阅读时有没有想过任何物理对象那些？即使你想到了，那可能也不是 25 个橙子。那么这样如何：你还可以使用与 5 相关的知识快速得出以前从未想过的其他结果。例如，你可以满怀信心地断言 6015 + 5 = 6020。你可能以前从未想过这个特定的总和，但你可以非常轻松地做到这一点。我敢打赌你没有想过 6020 个橙子。数字 5 的力量不仅来自于指代五个物理事物的集合，还来自于它以高度可预测的方式与其他数字交互的事实。

To see why that’s so significant, think about all the things you know about 5. You know that 5 + 2 = 7, that 5 + 5 = 10, that 5 × 5 = 25, and so on. Did you think about any physical objects when you were reading those? Even if you did, it probably wasn’t 25 oranges. And how about this: you can also use your 5-related knowledge to quickly derive other results that you have never thought about before. You can assert with total confidence that 6015 + 5 = 6020, for instance. You’ve probably never thought about that particular sum before, but you can do so very easily. And I bet you didn’t think about 6020 oranges. The number 5 gets its power not only from referring to sets of five physical things, but also from the fact that it interacts with other numbers in highly predictable ways.

这一点之所以如此重要，是因为计数需要时间。它比仅仅处理数字关系的事实要慢得多。通过计数来求出 6015 + 5 需要很长时间。你可能甚至不想计算 13 + 18，因为这需要一段时间，而且你知道自己很容易出错。如果你不得不计算，因为你不知道很多算术事实，或者因为你无法轻易地从中得出新的事实，你可能会认为算术是不可能的。这听起来很牵强，但数学教育研究表明，情况确实如此。当小学生算术成绩不好时，通常是因为他们没有注意到并建立这些规律。相反，他们试图通过计数来完成大部分算术。他们试图通过数到 13 再数到 18，然后数出全部来求 13 + 18。这还不是最糟糕的情况：想象一下尝试 31-14。如果一个学生将 31-14 视为计数指令，那么他手头上就有很多工作要做。计数很快就会变得异常繁琐，要想取得进步，就必须停止将 5 视为计数指令，开始将其视为以某种方式与其他数字和运算交互的对象。

The reason this is so important is that counting takes time. It is much slower than just manipulating facts about number relationships. Finding 6015 + 5 by counting would take ages. You probably wouldn’t even want to count for 13 + 18, say, because it would take a while and because you know you would be error-prone. If you had to count, because you didn’t know many arithmetic facts or because you couldn’t easily derive new facts from them, you would probably come to think that arithmetic was impossible. This sounds far-fetched, but research in mathematics education reveals that this is exactly what happens. When young pupils do not do well in arithmetic, it is often because they fail to notice and build on these regularities. Instead, they try to do most of their arithmetic by counting. They try to find 13 + 18 by counting to 13 and counting to 18 and then counting the whole lot. And this isn’t the worst case: imagine trying it for 31 − 14. A student who sees 31 − 14 as an instruction to count has a lot of work on their hands. Counting quickly becomes impossibly cumbersome, and to make progress it is critical to stop thinking of 5 as an instruction to count, and start thinking of it as an object that interacts in certain ways with other numbers and operations.

成功的人确实注意到了这些算术规律；他们建立了一个庞大且高度互联的已知事实系统，从中他们可以快速而自信地得出新的事实。那些学习本科数学的人还要应对分数、小数、函数、代数和一大堆其他东西的引入，这些东西在第一次出现时会让许多学生感到困惑。因此，处于你这个位置的人能够思考比数字抽象得多的对象，这种技能将对你的高级课程大有裨益。然而，毫不奇怪，你必须更快、更灵活地做到这一点，并且要处理更复杂的对象。本章将介绍如何有效地做到这一点。

Those who succeed do notice these arithmetic regularities; they build up a large and highly interconnected system of known facts from which they can rapidly and confidently derive new ones. Those who study undergraduate mathematics also cope with the introduction of fractions, decimals, functions, algebra, and a whole host of other things that confuse many students when they first appear. People in your position are thus able to think about objects that are much more abstract than numbers, and this skill will serve you well in upper-level courses. Unsurprisingly, however, you will have to do it more rapidly, more flexibly, and with considerably more complex kinds of objects. This chapter is about how to do so effectively.

2.2 函数作为抽象对象

2.2 Functions as abstract objects

我们先从另一个可以用不同方式思考的概念开始：函数。当你第一次遇到函数时，它可能是接受输入并对其进行处理以产生输出的“机器”。你的工作是接受给定的输入（例如 6），“执行”函数（例如，乘以 2 并加 1）并报告答案。你需要能够接受简单的输入并遵循一些指令，但仅此而已。

We’ll start with another concept that can be thought of in different ways: functions. When you first met functions, it was probably as “machines” that take inputs and do something to them to produce outputs. Your job was to take a given input (say, 6), “perform” the function (say, multiply by 2 and add 1) and report the answer. You needed to be able to take a simple input and follow some instructions, but that’s it.

后来，你被要求做更复杂的事情。在某个时候，你可能会被要求查看输入和输出表并计算出函数可能是什么。要做到这一点，你必须知道你应该假设存在一些对每个输入执行相同操作的底层过程，并且你必须思考这个过程可能是什么。你可能还会被要求找到反函数，这再次要求能够将函数设想为一个过程，这次是为了想象将其反转。

Later, you were asked to do more sophisticated things. At some point you were probably asked to look at a table of inputs and outputs and work out what the function could be. To do this you had to know that you were supposed to assume the existence of some underlying process that does the same thing to every input, and you had to think about what that process could be. You might have been asked to find inverse functions, too, which again demands being able to conceive of a function as a process, this time in order to imagine reversing it.

最后，您学会了做需要将函数视为一个对象的事情，而不是将其视为将数字发送给其他数字的过程。从某种意义上说，这是相当自然的。例如，从语言学上讲，我们谈论“函数sine x ”。在这样的短语中，函数是一个名词——语言将其视为一个对象。从图形上讲，这也是相当自然的。我们习惯于看到正弦函数的图形，这种表示法使我们自然而然地将函数视为一个统一的对象。1

Finally, you learned to do things that demand thinking of a function, not as a process sending numbers to other numbers, but as an object in its own right. In some senses this is fairly natural. Linguistically, for instance, we talk about “the function sine x.” In such phrases, the function is a noun—the language treats it as an object. Graphically, it is quite natural too. We’re accustomed to seeing a graph of the sine function, and this representation makes it natural to think of the function as a single unified object.1

从其他意义上讲，将函数视为对象可能感觉不太自然。例如，考虑微分的过程。微分将一个函数作为输入，对其进行一些处理，然后给出另一个函数作为输出。例如，如果我们取由f ( x ) = x 3给出的函数并对其进行微分，我们将得到函数f ′( x ) = 3 x 2 。如果我们取由g ( x ) = e 5 x给出的函数并对其进行微分，我们将得到函数g ′( x ) = 5e 5 x。从这个意义上讲，微分可以被认为是一个更高级的过程。函数将数字作为输入并返回数字作为输出，而微分则将函数作为输入并返回函数作为输出。您可能会发现寻找将过程视为对象的其他情况很有帮助，我们将在本章后面回顾这个想法。

In other senses, treating a function as an object might feel less natural. Consider, for instance, the process of differentiation. Differentiation takes a function as an input, does something to it, and gives another function as an output. For instance, if we take the function given by f(x) = x3 and differentiate it, we get the function f′(x) = 3x2. If we take the function given by g(x) = e5x and differentiate it, we get the function g′(x) = 5e5x. In this sense, differentiation can be thought of as a higher-level process. Where a function would take numbers as inputs and return numbers as outputs, differentiation takes functions as inputs and returns functions as outputs. You might find it helpful to look out for other cases where processes are treated as objects, and we’ll come back to this idea later in the chapter.

2.3 那到底是什么样的物体？

2.3 What kind of object is that, really?

无论你到目前为止学过什么数学，你都会熟悉各种不同类型的数学对象。除了数字和函数，你可能还了解向量、矩阵、复数等等。你可能对这些的思考非常灵活。你可能知道各种关系和相关程序。但是，你在将这些对象视为对象时有多灵活？在继续之前，我们会考虑这个问题。

Whatever mathematics you’ve studied so far, you will be familiar with a variety of different types of mathematical object. As well as numbers and functions, you might know about vectors, matrices, complex numbers, and so on. You’re probably very flexible in thinking about these. You probably know about all sorts of relationships and associated procedures. But how flexible are you in thinking about these objects as objects? We’ll think about this before we move on.

首先问自己，10 是什么类型的对象？这不是一个陷阱问题。显然，它是一个数字。那么，它是一个分数吗？如果你的直觉是说“不是”，那么停下来想想你会如何回答这个替代问题：正方形是长方形吗？对于第二个问题，许多小孩子会说“不是”——你可能明白为什么。但是，正方形是长方形，因为它具有成为长方形所需的所有属性。它碰巧也具有额外的属性，但从数学上讲，这与问题无关。现在，你能看出这与关于 10 的问题之间的相似之处吗？我们通常不把 10 写成分数，但我们很容易就能做到。首先，它是 10/1。或者它是 20/2，或者 520/52，或者任何其他数字。它也是一个整数，但这再次意味着它具有成为分数所需的属性，还有一些额外的属性。

First ask yourself, what kind of object is 10? This is not a trick question. It’s a number, obviously. Now, is it a fraction? If your instinct is to say “no,” stop and think about how you would answer this alternative question: Is a square a rectangle? To this second question, lots of young children say “no”—you can probably see why. However, a square is a rectangle because it has all the properties it needs in order to be a rectangle. It happens to have extra properties too but, mathematically, that’s irrelevant to the question. Now, can you see the analogy between this and the question about 10? We don’t normally write 10 as a fraction, but we easily could. It’s 10/1, for a start. Or it’s 20/2, or 520/52, or any number of other things. It’s a whole number as well, but again this means that it has the properties needed to be a fraction, plus some extra ones.

按照你在高级课程中听到的方式来说，10 是一个整数。整数是“整数”的正确数学用语，所有整数的集合用ℤ表示，它来自德语单词“Zahlen”，意为数字。我们写 10 ∈ ℤ表示“10 是整数集的一个元素”。（10 也是一个自然数，2其中自然数 1、2、3… 用ℕ表示。）10 也是一个有理数，其中有理数是可以写成p / q形式的数，其中p和q都是整数（且q不为零）。3我们刚刚看到了以这种形式写出 10 的一些方法。所有有理数的集合用 表示，它来自“商”这个词。用数学术语来说，我们说ℤ是的子集，这意味着ℤ中的所有内容也都在（当然，还包含更多内容）。我们有时将其写为⊆ 。请注意， ⊆ 符号类似于 ≤ 符号，但曲线更弯曲。你能看出为什么这是一种明智的符号选择吗？数学家喜欢这种规律性。

To state this as you’ll hear it in upper-level courses, 10 is an integer. Integer is the proper mathematical word for “whole number,” and the set of all integers is denoted by ℤ, which comes from the German word “Zahlen,” meaning numbers. We write 10 ∈ ℤ to mean “10 is an element of the set of integers.” (10 is a natural number too,2 where the natural numbers 1, 2, 3 … are denoted by ℕ.) 10 is also a rational number, where rational numbers are those that can be written in the form p/q, where both p and q are integers (and q is not zero).3 We just saw some ways to write 10 in this form. The set of all rational numbers is denoted by , which comes from the word “quotient.” In mathematical terms, we say that ℤ is a subset of , which means that everything in ℤ is also in ( contains a lot more stuff too, of course). We sometimes write this as ℤ ⊆ . Notice that the ⊆ symbol is like the ≤ symbol but curvy. Can you see why this is a sensible choice of notation? Mathematicians like this kind of regularity.

所以，10 是有理数。那么，它是复数吗？是的。10 可以写成 10 + 0 i。它是一个非常好的复数——它恰好是一个整数，也是一个有理数，也是一个实数。顺便说一下，所有复数的集合的符号是，所有实数的集合的符号是。这并不奇怪。

So, 10 is a rational number. Now, is it a complex number? Yes. 10 can be written as 10 + 0i. It’s a perfectly good complex number—it just happens to be an integer, and a rational number, and a real number as well. By the way, the notation for the set of all complex numbers is , and the notation for the set of all real numbers is . No big surprises there.

现在，这种事情经常发生。我们经常会认为物体属于某一类型，这取决于当时哪种类型更有启发性。此外，分析物体类型可以阐明不同符号集合的含义。例如，这些物体是什么类型的？

Now, this kind of thing happens quite a lot. Often we can think of objects as being of one type or another depending on which is more illuminating at the time. Furthermore, analyzing object types can clarify the meaning of different collections of symbols. For instance, what types of object are these?

你可以理智地回答说它们都是积分。你可能会想补充说，第一个是定积分，第二个是不定积分。但我们可以通过进一步思考来获得更多见解。如果我们进行计算以找到定积分，我们会得到

You could sensibly answer by saying that they’re both integrals. You might think to add that the first is a definite integral and the second is an indefinite integral. But we can get more insight by thinking a bit further. If we do the calculations to find the definite integral, we get

这是一个数字。它应该是，因为定积分给出了两个指定端点之间图形下的面积。4因此，在一个重要的从某种意义上说，是一个数字。它看起来不像一个数字——它看起来更像是一个做某事的指令。但我们已经看到，在一个层面上看起来像指令或过程的东西可以在更复杂的层面上被认为是对象（对你来说，5 + 3 曾经是一个计数指令，但现在不再是了）。这个定积分是一种表示数字 140 的奇特方式。当然，它还带有大量关于这个数字与特定函数之间关系的额外信息。

This is a number. It would be, because a definite integral gives us the area under a graph between the two specified endpoints.4 So, in an important sense, is a number. It doesn’t look like a number—it looks more like an instruction to do something. But we’ve seen that things that look like instructions or processes at one level can be thought of as objects at a more sophisticated level (for you, 5 + 3 was once an instruction to count, but it isn’t any more). This definite integral is a fancy way of representing the number 140. Of course, it also carries with it a lot of extra information about the relationship between this number and a particular function.

那么，不定积分呢？如果我们在这里进行积分，我们得到

Now, what about the indefinite integral? If we do the integration here we get

你可能已经写过很多次这种东西，以至于你已经不再思考它的含义，所以现在让我们这样做。显然，这个计算的结果不是一个数字。它甚至不是一个函数，因为c代表一个任意常数。所以，事实上，计算的结果是一个无限的函数集：所有形式为f ( x ) = x 3 + 4 x + c的东西。从代数上讲，这是有道理的，因为如果我们对其中任何一个函数求导，我们都会得到 3 x 2 + 4。从图形上讲，这是有道理的，因为所有这些函数都是彼此的垂直平移，所以它们在任何地方都有相同的梯度。然而，从对象类型的角度来看，它和定积分之间的差异是巨大的。这两个积分在页面上看起来非常相似，事实上，我们要经过同样的过程来计算其中任何一个。但定积分是一个数字，而不定积分是一组无限的函数。

You’ve probably written this sort of thing so many times that you’ve stopped thinking about what it means, so let’s do that now. Clearly the result of this calculation is not a number. It is not even a single function, because the c represents an arbitrary constant. So, in fact, the result of the calculation is an infinite set of functions: all the things of the form f(x) = x3 + 4x + c. Algebraically this makes sense because, if we differentiate any of these functions, we get back 3x2 + 4. Graphically it makes sense because all of these functions are vertical translations of each other, so they have the same gradient everywhere. Considered in terms of object types, however, the difference between this and the definite integral is huge. The integrals look very similar on the page, and indeed we go through the same sort of process to calculate either one of them. But the definite integral is a number and the indefinite integral is an infinite set of functions.

2.4 作为程序结果的对象

2.4 Objects as the results of procedures

这种洞察力非常有用。特别是，它与第 1 章中关于学生在练习中给出错误类型的物体的评论有关。回想一下，我说过这种情况有时似乎会发生当人们尝试将问题中的一组符号与笔记中某处的一组类似符号进行匹配时。积分示例表明，页面上看起来非常相似的东西可以代表截然不同的对象。

This sort of insight can be very useful. In particular, it is related to the comments in Chapter 1 about students giving the wrong kind of object in response to an exercise.
