Recall I said that this sometimes seems to happen when people try to match a set of symbols in a question with a similar set of symbols somewhere in their notes. The integrals example shows that things that appear very similar on the page can represent dramatically different objects.

为了让您了解这种情况在高级数学中是如何发生的，我将描述一道我的很多学生都做错的题目，正是由于这种原因。该问题的结构如下：

To give you a sense of how this can happen in upper-level mathematics, I’ll describe a question that a lot of my students got wrong, for exactly this kind of reason. The question was structured like this:

计算 dim(ker( Φ ))，其中Φ : 4 → 3由矩阵给出

Find dim(ker(Φ)) where Φ: 4 → 3 is given by the matrix

如果你还没有学过“线性代数”这门课，你不会理解这一点，所以我会用对象类型来解释，让你明白我的学生哪里做错了。我会把它分开来解释，让它更容易理解，但它可能看起来很抽象，所以当你学过这门课后，你可能想再读一遍。

You won’t understand this if you haven’t yet studied a course called Linear Algebra, so I’ll explain just enough for you to see what went wrong for my students, couching my explanation in terms of object types. I’ll split this up to make it easier, but it might seem very abstract, so you might want to read it again when you’ve taken such a course.

• 我们先从Φ (读作“phi”)开始。这里， Φ是一种称为线性变换的函数。它不以数字作为输入和输出，而是以 4 分量向量（形式为 ( a, b, c, d ) 的事物）作为输入，并以 3 分量向量（形式为 ( a, b, c ) 的事物）作为输出。这就是Φ : 4 → 3 的含义。

• We’ll start with Φ (pronounced “phi”). Here, Φ is a kind of function known as a linear transformation. Instead of taking numbers as inputs and outputs it takes 4-component vectors (things of the form (a, b, c, d)) as inputs and gives 3-component vectors (things of the form (a, b, c)) as outputs. That’s what Φ: 4 → 3 means.

• ker ( Φ ) 是Φ核的缩写，它是所有 4 分量输入向量的集合，其中Φ给出输出向量 (0,0,0)（一些 4 分量向量被发送到 (0,0,0)，一些则没有）。因此，ker ( Φ ) 是一组 4 分量向量。

• ker (Φ) is an abbreviation for the kernel of Φ, which is the set of all the 4-component input vectors for which Φ gives the output vector (0,0,0) (some of the 4-component vectors get sent to (0,0,0), some don’t). Because of this, ker (Φ) is a set of 4-component vectors.

• 现在，我们可以讨论一组向量（例如 ker ( Φ )）的基，其中基是少数几个向量，我们可以将它们以各种组合相加来“构建”所有其他向量。因此，ker ( Φ ) 的基是另一个可能更小的 4 分量向量集。

• Now, it turns out that we can talk about something called a basis for a set of vectors such as ker (Φ), where a basis is a small number of vectors which we can add together in various combinations to “build” all the others. So a basis for ker (Φ) is another, possibly smaller, set of 4-component vectors.

• 最后，dim 表示维度，即我们需要建立基础的向量数量。这样做的结果是整个问题的答案应该是一个数字（再次阅读问题以确保您能看到这一点）。

• Finally, dim means dimension, which is the number of vectors we need to make a basis. The upshot of this is that the answer to the overall question should be a number (read the question again to make sure you can see this).

我的大多数学生在找到 ker( Φ )的基之后就停在那里，错过了最后一步。这意味着他们的答案是错误的：他们给出了一组向量，而他们应该给出一个数字。对所发生事情的一个善意解释是他们忘记了最后一步。不过，这似乎不太可能——最后一步只是计算你有多少个向量，而答案最多可能是四个（你会在线性代数中找到原因）。所以这并不难。事实上，它比大多数其他步骤都容易。我认为实际发生的情况是他们并没有真正理解这个问题；他们没有考虑他们期望的对象类型，而是在笔记中找到了一个涉及类似符号布局的示例，并复制了它。不幸的是，这个示例一定是关于寻找基础的，这对这个问题很有用，但不足以完全回答它。

Most of my students found a basis for ker(Φ) and stopped there, missing off the final step. This meant that their answers were wrong: they gave a set of vectors when they should have given a single number. A charitable interpretation of what happened is that they forgot to do the last step. This doesn’t seem very likely, though—the last step just involves counting how many vectors you have, and the most the answer could possibly be is four (you’ll find out why in Linear Algebra). So it’s not exactly difficult. In fact, it is easier than most of the other steps. I think that what actually happened is that they didn’t really understand the question; instead of thinking about what type of object they were expecting, they found a worked example in their notes that involved a similar symbol layout, and copied that. Unfortunately, the worked example must have been about finding a basis, which is useful for this question but is not enough to fully answer it.

因此，如果不能完全理解，就会导致答案不准确，因为它不是正确的对象类型。对于数学家来说，这种差异非常重要。因此，随着你专业的发展，调整思维是个好主意，这样你就不会太关注符号相似性，而会更多地关注底层对象和结构。

Thus, failing to fully understand can lead to an answer that cannot be right because it is not the right type of object. To mathematicians, such differences are very important. So, as you progress through your major, it is a good idea to adjust your thinking so that you focus less on notational similarities and more on underlying objects and structures.

2.5 对象的层次组织

2.5 Hierarchical organization of objects

数学在使用抽象概念方面并非独一无二。其他各种领域都有抽象概念：例如“引力”、“正义”和“愤怒”。显然，没有人见过“引力”。但数学可能是独一无二的，或者至少是极端的，因为它的抽象对象被组织成层次结构。

Mathematics is not unique in its use of abstract concepts. All kinds of other fields have them: things like “gravity” and “justice” and “anger.” No-one’s ever seen “a gravity,” obviously. But mathematics might be unique, or at least extreme, in the extent to which its abstract objects are organized into hierarchical structures.

我们刚刚在 dim(ker( Φ ))问题中看到了这一点的例证。请注意，除非您知道什么是基础，并且知道核是可以有基础的东西，否则关于维度的总体问题就没有意义。除非您理解变换是使用向量作为输入和输出的函数，否则核的概念就没有意义。等等。因此，可以将这些概念视为堆叠在一起，如下页的图表所示。理解较低的概念是理解较高概念的必要条件。

We’ve just seen an illustration of this in the question about dim(ker(Φ)). Notice that the overall question about dimension doesn’t make sense until you know what a basis is and know that a kernel is something that can have a basis. The idea of kernel doesn’t make sense until you understand transformations as functions that work with vectors as inputs and outputs. And so on. The concepts could thus be thought of as stacked on top of each other, as illustrated in the diagram on the next page. Understanding the lower ones is necessary in order to make sense of the higher ones.

举一个更熟悉的例子，考虑一下微分。除非你了解函数，否则微分的概念是没有意义的，而要理解函数，你需要了解数字。同样，这些概念可以被认为是堆叠在一起的，因为我们可以通过理解一个层次上的对象与较低层次上的对象之间的关系来理解它们。这就是我所说的数学是分层的。

For a more familiar example, consider differentiation. The idea of differentiation doesn’t make sense unless you understand about functions, and to make sense of functions you need to know about numbers. Again, these concepts can be thought of as stacked on top of each other, because we can make sense of objects at one level by understanding how they relate to objects at lower levels. This is what I mean by mathematics being hierarchical.

现在，有时学习在这样一个层次结构中的新级别上工作很困难，因为它涉及学习使用新类型的对象。这可能涉及压缩一个过程，以便您可以将其视为一个对象，就像在关于数字和函数的开场讨论中一样。这种压缩可能很困难，因为您必须依靠自己的努力：您无法真正应用更高级别的过程，除非您能够将现有事物视为一个对象，但实际上没有必要思考直到你想将它用作更高层次过程​​的输入之前，你都无法将现有事物视为对象。因此，在学习更高层次的工作时，你可能会经历一个阶段，能够“推动符号”并得到正确的答案，但并不真正理解你所做的为什么有意义。如果你坚持下去，这个阶段可能会过去，但如果你能将困惑的根源确定为引入新的对象类型，你可能会更快地理解。

Now, sometimes learning to work at a new level in such a hierarchy is hard, because it involves learning to work with a new type of object. This might involve compressing a process so you can think about it as an object, as in the opening discussions about numbers and functions. Such compression can be difficult because you have to pull yourself up by your own bootstraps: you can’t really apply a higher-level process until you can think about the existing thing as an object, but there’s no real need to think about the existing thing as an object until you want to use it as an input for a higher-level process. As a result, when learning to work at a higher level, you might go through a phase of being able to “push the symbols around” and get correct answers, without really understanding why what you’re doing makes sense. This phase will probably pass if you persevere, but you might be able to understand more quickly if you can identify the source of your confusion as the introduction of a new object type.

话虽如此，我并不是说随意摆弄符号本质上有什么错误。数学力量的源泉之一就是我们这样做的能力。重申之前的观点，我不需要收集 6015 个橙子和另外 5 个橙子来计算出 6015 + 5 是多少——我可以使用符号系统的规律，然后继续操作。能够“忘记它是什么”并根据标准规则操作符号是非常有用的，我将在第 4 章、第 5 章和第6章中进一步讨论这一点。但是，正如我上面所解释的那样，如果您只会摆弄符号，那么您就很容易犯某些错误。因此，通常也值得努力培养基于对象的理解。

That said, I do not mean to argue that there is anything inherently wrong with pushing symbols around. One source of power in mathematics is our ability to do exactly that. To reiterate an earlier point, I don’t need to gather 6015 oranges and another 5 oranges to work out what 6015 + 5 is—I can use the regularities of the symbol system and just get on with manipulating. It’s extremely useful to be able to “forget what it’s all about” and manipulate symbols according to the standard rules, and I will discuss this further in Chapters 4, 5, and 6. As I’ve explained above, though, if symbol-pushing is all you can do, then you’re vulnerable to certain kinds of error. So it’s often worth aiming to develop an object-based understanding as well.

2.6 将流程转化为对象

2.6 Turning processes into objects

在本科数学课程中，你会遇到许多新过程，有时你需要很快开始将它们视为对象。例如，如果你学习抽象代数或群论，你会遇到陪集的概念。你将首先通过一个过程体验陪集——你将了解如何计算不同群中某些元素的陪集。但是，可能就在下一节课中，你的教授就会将这些陪集视为对象。具体来说，他或她可能会对这些陪集执行运算——将它们相加或诸如此类。如果你仍将“陪集”一词与计算过程联系起来，你就会不知所措，就像 8 岁的孩子在尝试计算所有数时会对 19 加 27 感到不知所措一样。因此，为这些从过程到对象的转换做好准备是个好主意。

In undergraduate mathematics you will encounter many new processes, and sometimes you will be expected to start treating these as objects very quickly. For instance, if you study something called Abstract Algebra or Group Theory, you will come across the idea of a coset. You will first experience cosets via a process—you’ll be shown how to calculate cosets of certain elements in various groups. But, probably in the very next lecture, your professor will treat these cosets as objects. In particular, he or she might perform operations on these cosets—add them together or whatever. If you’re still associating the word “coset” with the calculation process, you’ll be flummoxed, in exactly the same way that 8 year-olds would be flummoxed about adding 19 and 27 if they were still trying to count everything. Thus, it’s a good idea to be ready for these process-to-object transitions.

为了说明这一点，以下是一些可能有助于您更好地理解微分示例的内容。在某个时候，您将学习微分方程（如果您正在学习后期课程，您可能已经开始学习了微积分课程）。要理解微分方程是什么，我们可以将其与普通代数方程进行比较。在求解普通方程时，我们用x表示解，同时进行一些代数运算，并且我们期望解是数字。5

To illustrate how, here is something that might help you to better understand the differentiation example. At some point, you will study differential equations (you might have started already if you are taking the later courses in a Calculus sequence). To understand what differential equations are, we can compare them with ordinary algebraic equations. When solving an ordinary equation, we use x to stand for a solution while we do some algebra, and we expect the solutions to be numbers.5

微分方程则不同。它们不是将未知数x与其自身的各种幂联系起来（例如），而是将未知函数y = f ( x ) 与其自身的各种导数联系起来（有时还与x的其他函数联系起来）。因此，微分方程可能如下所示：

Differential equations are different. Instead of relating an unknown number x to various powers of itself (for instance), they relate an unknown function y = f(x) to various derivatives of itself (and sometimes to other functions of x). So a differential equation might look like this:

此类方程的解将是一个函数：满足微分方程的任何函数y = f ( x )。这是有道理的，因为y是x的函数，d y /d x也是，d 2 y /d x 2也是。所以我们实际上要做的就是将这三个函数的某个组合相加得到零。如果您不以这种方式意识到这一点，您最终可能会学习很多解决微分方程的方法，而无法真正理解它们的作用。如果您记得为什么微分方程的解应该是一个函数，您的理解可能会更好。

The solution to such an equation will be a function: any function y = f(x) that satisfies the differential equation. This makes sense because y is a function of x, and so is dy/dx, and so is d2y/dx2. So all we’re really doing is saying that adding together some combination of these three functions gives zero. If you’re not aware of it in this way, you can end up learning a lot of procedures for solving differential equations without really understanding what these achieve. Your understanding will probably be better if you remember why the solution to a differential equation should be a function.

2.7 新对象：关系和二元运算

2.7 New objects: relations and binary operations

在学习新数学时，如果涉及将现有过程视为对象，语言通常会帮到我们。例如，老师们到处说“函数正弦x ”。然而，在其他情况下，我们以其他方式创建新对象，有时语言就没那么有用了，因为我们视为对象的东西最初看起来可能太大或太分散，无法以有意义的方式被认为是“事物”。

In cases where learning new mathematics involves treating existing processes as objects, the language often helps us out. Teachers go around saying “the function sine x,” for instance. However, in other cases we create new objects in other ways, and sometimes the language is not so helpful, because the things we treat as objects can initially seem too big or too spread out to be thought of as “things” in a meaningful way.

一个很好的例子就是“=”（“等于”）的概念。事实上，年幼的孩子往往把“=”理解为做某事的指令。他们看到 5 + 8 =？，就把“=”理解为“请计算答案”。这似乎没什么问题，但实际上可能存在问题。对“=”的含义有这种概念的孩子往往会感到非常困惑6 + ? = 20 之类的问题，因为“指令”放错了地方（他们可能会给出答案 26——你能明白为什么吗？）。6 + 14 = 14 + 6 之类的陈述让他们更加困惑，因为在这种情况下似乎“没什么可做”。

An excellent example of this is the notion of “=” (“equals”). Young children, in fact, tend to read “=” as an instruction to do something. They see 5 + 8 =? and treat the “=” as though it can be read as “calculate the answer, please.” This might not seem problematic, but it really can be. Children with this conception of what “=” means tend to get very confused by problems like 6 + ? = 20, because the “instruction” is in the wrong place (they might give the answer 26—can you see why?). They get even more confused by statements like 6 + 14 = 14 + 6, because in such cases there appears to be “nothing to do” at all.

成功的学生会了解到“=”只是表示一边的东西与另一边的东西完全相同，尽管这些可能以不同的形式表达。尽管如此，你可能会惊讶地发现数学家们把“=”本身当作一个数学对象。具体来说，它是关系的一个例子。现在，似乎没有必要给它起这样的名字。例如，说“等于是一种关系”似乎并没有让我们在解方程时有更多的能力——你已经这样做了很多年，却没有这方面的知识。那么数学家为什么要这样做呢？好吧，将“=”视为一个对象让我们可以问它与其他关系有何异同。正如5与2的相似之处在于它是质数，但不同之处在于它是奇数一样，我们可以将“=”与其他关系进行比较，比如“<”。例如，请注意，虽然“=”对数字和函数都有意义，但“<”是否有意义并不明确。说x 2 < sin x是什么意思？我们可以选择以某种方式定义函数的“小于”，但如何定义并不明显。这是一个区别：有些关系对各种类型的对象都能自然起作用，有些则不行。另一个区别是关系“=”是我们所说的对称。我们知道如果a = b那么我们也有b = a 。对于“<”来说，情况当然不是这样，即使它有定义。对于数字来说，如果a < b则b < a永远不会成立。

Successful students learn that “=” just means that the stuff on one side is exactly the same as the stuff on the other side, although these might be expressed in different forms. Nonetheless, it might surprise you to learn that mathematicians treat “=” as a mathematical object in its own right. Specifically, it is an example of a relation. Now, there might seem to be no need to give it such a name. Saying “equals is a relation” doesn’t seem to give us any more power in solving equations, for instance—you’ve been doing that for years without this knowledge. So why would mathematicians do it? Well, considering “=” as an object allows us to ask how it is similar to, and different from, other relations. Just as 5 is similar to 2 in that it is prime but different in that it is odd, we can compare “=” with other relations, such as “<”. Notice, for instance, that while “=” is meaningful for both numbers and functions, it’s really not clear that “<” is. What would it mean to say that x2 < sin x? We could choose to define “less than” for functions in a certain way, but how to do so isn’t obvious. That’s one difference: some relations work naturally on various types of object and some don’t. Another difference is that the relation “=” is what we call symmetric. We know that if a = b then we also have b = a. This certainly isn’t the case for “<”, even when it is defined. For numbers, it is never true that if a < b then b < a.

这里要注意的重要一点是，我们在讨论“=”和“<”时就好像它们是对象一样，并询问它们的属性：“=”是对称的，“<”不是；如果我们谈论函数，“=”是定义明确的，“<”不是。

The important thing to notice here is that we are talking about “=” and “<” as though they were objects, and asking about their properties: “=” is symmetric, “<” is not; “=” is well-defined if we are talking about functions, “<” is not.

这样做的结果是，在某个时候，在一门叫做“基础”或“数学思维”或“推理入门”的课程中，你的教授会写这样的话：“对于每个a和b，如果a = b则b = a ”，你的本能会想知道为什么这个人会说一些你已经知道多年的事情，就好像它对你来说是新东西一样。这不是他们的本意。他们所做的是将你多年来所了解的东西视为一个独立的对象，以便他们可以将其属性与同一类型的其他对象的属性进行比较（并且可能继续证明一些关于所有具有某些属性的对象的一般定理）常见的情况）。处理这个问题需要一点智力训练。有一段时间你的大脑不会允许你将“=”视为一个对象，因为它看起来太奇怪了。但是一旦你掌握了窍门，你就会看到这种事情在数学中随处可见。

The upshot of this is that at some point, in a course called Foundations or Mathematical Thinking or Introduction to Reasoning, your professor will write something like “For every a and b, if a = b then b = a,” and your instinct will be to wonder why this person is saying something you’ve known for years as though it’s supposed to be new to you. That’s not their intention. What they’re doing is treating something you’ve known about for years as an object in its own right, so that they can compare its properties with those of other objects of the same type (and perhaps go on to prove some general theorems about objects that all have some property in common). It takes a bit of intellectual discipline to deal with this. For a while your brain won’t want to let you think of “=” as an object because it just seems too weird. But once you get the hang of it you will see this kind of thing happening all over mathematics.

为了进一步说明，我再举一个例子：一种称为二元运算的对象类型。加法就是二元运算的一个例子。它需要两个对象（因此称为“二进制”）并对它们执行某些操作（因此称为“运算”）以得出另一个同类型的对象。将“+”视为二元运算意味着将其视为一个独立的对象。同样，如果我们将其与其他二元运算进行比较，我们就会明白为什么这可能很有用。其他一些我们早已熟悉的二元运算是“-”、“×”和“÷”。这些运算与二元运算“+”有何相似和不同之处？其中一种方式是“+”是可交换的，这意味着对于任意两个数字a和b，我们总是有a + b = b + a。对于“-”来说也是如此吗？当然不是。例如，7 - 3 与 3 - 7 不同。所以减法不是可交换的。乘法是可交换的吗？除法呢？

To illustrate further, I’ll give another example: a type of object called a binary operation. Addition is an example of a binary operation. It takes two objects (hence “binary”) and does something with them (hence “operation”) to give another object of the same kind. Thinking of “+” as a binary operation means thinking of it as an object in its own right. Again, we can see why this might be useful if we compare it with other binary operations. Some other long-familiar binary operations are “−”, “×”, and “÷”. In what ways are these similar to and different from the binary operation “+”? One way is that “+” is commutative, which means that for any two numbers a and b, we always have a + b = b + a. Is that true for “−”? No, certainly not. For instance, 7 − 3 is not the same as 3 − 7. So subtraction is not commutative. Is multiplication commutative? How about division?

顺便说一句，这里还有另一个机会可以注意到，页面上看起来相似的东西可能代表着截然不同的对象。我们可以写 3 < 7 和 3 − 7，它们看起来并没有太大的不同——每个都是两个数字，中间有一个符号。但第一种情况下的符号表示一种关系，整个表达式是关于两个对象之间关系的陈述。第二种情况下的符号表示二元运算，整个表达式是一个数字。这完全不是一回事。

Here, incidentally, is another opportunity to notice that things that look similar on the page might represent dramatically different kinds of object. We can write 3 < 7 and 3 − 7, and they don’t look that different—each has two numbers with a symbol between them. But the symbol in the first case represents a relation, and the whole expression is a statement about a relationship between the two objects. The symbol in the second case represents a binary operation, and the whole expression is a number. That’s not the same kind of thing at all.

2.8 新对象：对称性

2.8 New objects: symmetries

新类型的对象既可以是几何的，也可以是代数的，而对称性就是其中一种类型的对象。您可能第一次接触对称性的概念是在一堂课上，这堂课涉及将镜子转向某些图表，并注意到照镜子时似乎可以恢复原状。在某个时候，您可能还会转动图表本身，并注意到，比如说，旋转 90° 会让您恢复一个与原始图表相同的图表。那时，您必须实际做一些事情，以某种方式与特定图表交互，以思考对称性。

New types of object can be geometric in origin as well as algebraic, and one such type of object is a symmetry. You probably first met the idea of symmetry in a lesson that involved turning a mirror around on some diagrams and noticing when looking in the mirror seemed to give back the original. At some point, you probably also turned the diagrams themselves around and noticed that, say, turning through 90° gave you back a diagram that looked the same as the original. At that point, you had to actually do something, interact with a particular diagram in some way, to think about symmetry.

如今，你可以将对称性视为一种属性。你可以说“正方形有四条反射对称线”和“图 2 具有 3 阶旋转对称性”。在这些句子中，你将图表（或假想正方形）视为一个对象，并提供有关其属性的信息，因为这些属性与各种对称性有关。但请注意，这里的语言已经开始有所改变。我们可以谈论对称类型，就好像对称性有多种类型，如奶酪。这让它听起来至少像是一种东西（外星人无法仅从语言中分辨出哪种奶酪类型和哪种对称类型指的是真实的物理对象）。然而，数学家更进一步，将单个“对称性”视为独立的数学对象。

These days, you can talk about symmetry as a property. You can say things like “A square has four lines of reflection symmetry,” and “Figure 2 has rotational symmetry of order 3.” In these sentences, you’re treating the diagram (or the imaginary square) as an object, and you’re giving information about its properties as these relate to various types of symmetry. Notice, though, that the language has begun to change a bit here. We can talk about types of symmetry, as though symmetry comes in various kinds, like cheese. That makes it sound at least like a type of stuff (aliens wouldn’t be able to tell just from the language which of types of cheese and types of symmetry refer to real, physical objects). Mathematicians go one step further, though, and treat individual “symmetries” as mathematical objects in their own right.

要理解这一点，最好先从旋转对称开始思考。更具体地说，思考旋转。此时语言开始真正发挥作用。您可以说“绕点 (0,0) 旋转 60 度”，您当然知道这是什么意思。您可能也同意“平移”和“反射”。对于后者，您必须想象翻转一张纸，而不仅仅是滑动它，但没关系。您可能还可以想象通过一个接一个地进行旋转来组合旋转。事实上，您可以想象将旋转与反射、旋转与平移或平移与反射结合起来。

To understand this it is probably a good idea to start by thinking about rotational symmetry. More specifically, to think about rotations. At this point the language really starts to help. You can say things like “a rotation through 60 degrees about the point (0,0)” and you certainly know what that means. You’re also probably okay with “a translation” and “a reflection.” For the latter, you have to imagine turning a piece of paper over rather than just sliding it around, but that’s okay. You can probably also imagine combining rotations by doing one after the other. Indeed, you can probably imagine combining a rotation with a reflection, or a rotation with a translation, or a translation with a reflection.

当然，只有当这些运动能恢复初始配置时，将它们称为对称才有意义。例如，如果我们想象一个铺满正六边形的无限平面，那么一种对称就是绕三个六边形相交点旋转 120°。另一种对称就是沿与六边形一条边平行的方向平移三倍于该边的距离。这两种运动都会恢复初始配置，而且，如果我们一个接一个地“执行”这些对称，我们就会得到另一个对称。因此，我们不仅将对称视为对象，还将它们视为可以通过更高级过程组合的对象，这种过程可以非正式地表达为“先做一件事，再做另一件事”。形式上，这种组合称为合成，这并非巧合：它就像合成函数一样，因为这种对称性也可以被认为是一种函数，它将平面上的每个点都发送到另一个点。你可能会注意到，合成相当于对对称性——如果我们将两个对称性组合起来，就会得到另一个对称性。这个二元运算是可交换的吗？

Of course, it only makes sense to refer to these motions as symmetries if they give us back the initial configuration. For instance, if we imagine an infinite plane tiled with regular hexagons, then one symmetry will be a rotation through 120° about a point where three hexagons meet. Another symmetry will be a translation through a distance that is three times the length of one side of a hexagon, in a direction parallel to that side. Either of these motions gives back the initial configuration and, further, if we “perform” these symmetries one after another, we get another one. So we’re not just treating symmetries as objects, we’re treating them as objects that can be combined via a higher-level process that could be expressed informally as something like “do-one-then-the-other.” Formally, this combining is called composition, which is not a coincidence: it is just like composing functions, because a symmetry of this kind can also be thought of as a function that takes every point on the plane and sends it to another point. Composition, you might notice, amounts to a binary operation on symmetries—if we compose two symmetries, we get another one. Is this binary operation commutative?

要了解数学家如何更广泛地使用这些想法，请考虑一个更简单配置的对称性：一个等边三角形。如果我们想要讨论三角形的对称性，给它们命名会有所帮助。假设我们用R表示绕三角形中心顺时针旋转 120°。我们还不如用R 2表示顺时针旋转 240°，因为这相当于执行两次R（“将R与自身复合”）。需要注意的一点是，如果我们执行R然后执行R 2，我们会回到开始的地方，因此有一种表示“开始的地方”或“什么都不做”的方法也会很方便。数学家通常将此称为id或I （身份变换的缩写）。然后我们有了反射。如果我们将三角形的顶部顶点标记为 1，然后按顺时针方向将其他顶点标记为 2 和 3，则我们可以使用r 1来表示通过顶点 1 的直线的反射，依此类推。

To see how mathematicians use these ideas more extensively, consider the symmetries of a simpler configuration: a single equilateral triangle. If we want to talk about the triangle’s symmetries, it helps to give them names. Say we use R to denote a rotation clockwise through 120° about the centre of the triangle. We might as well then use R2 to denote a rotation clockwise through 240°, because it amounts to the same thing as doing R twice (“composing R with itself”). One thing to notice is that if we perform R then perform R2 we get back to where we started, so it would also be handy to have a way of representing “where we started” or “do nothing.” Mathematicians usually call this id or I (short for the identity transformation). Then we have the reflections. If we label the triangle so the top vertex is number 1 and then go around clockwise numbering the others 2 and 3, we could use r1 to denote reflection in the line through vertex 1, and so on.

一旦我们理清了这个问题，我们就可以编制一个所有可能对称组合的输出列表。例如，如果我们先执行R然后再执行r 1，我们最终得到的配置与我们刚刚执行r 2 时得到的配置相同（检查一下——从纸上剪出一个三角形可能会有帮助）。如果我们愿意，我们可以将所有这些组合记录在一个表中：

Once we’ve sorted that out we can compile a list of the outputs of all possible combinations of symmetries. For example, if we do R then r1, we end up in the same configuration as if we’d just done r2 (check—cutting a triangle out of paper might help). If we want, we can record all these combinations in a table:

完成这些之后，我们可以不再思考三角形，而只思考对称性相互作用的方式。这类似于当我们不再思考五个橙子的集合，而只思考数字 5 如何与其他数字相互作用时发生的情况。本质上，我们所做的是构建一种新的算术。这种新算术中的对象是三角形的对称性，通过组合运算组合在一起。请注意，这种新算术在某种意义上比普通算术“更小”。我们不需要涉及无数个对象（数字）和几种运算（加法、减法等），而只有六个对象（对称性）和一种运算（组合）。

Having done that, we can stop thinking about the triangle and just think about the ways in which the symmetries interact with each other. This is similar to what happens when we stop thinking about sets of five oranges and just think about how the number 5 interacts with other numbers. In essence, what we’ve done is construct a new kind of arithmetic. The objects in this new arithmetic are symmetries of the triangle, combined via the operation of composition. Notice that this new kind of arithmetic is, in some sense, “smaller” than ordinary arithmetic. Instead of involving infinitely many objects (numbers) and several operations (addition, subtraction, etc.), we have just six objects (symmetries) and one operation (composition).

这种思维方式在抽象代数和群论中很常见，但在数学的其他领域也经常出现。我们考虑一种类型的对象，考虑如何根据它们的属性比较这些对象，考虑如何将它们组合起来以获得相同类型的新对象。如果你能记住这一点，你可能会发现抽象代数并不像它乍一看那么抽象。你还会发现自己在思考各种类型的数学陈述方面获得了一些能力。我们将在下一章中讨论如何做到这一点。

This type of thinking happens a lot in Abstract Algebra and Group Theory, but also in other areas of mathematics. We think about a type of object, we think about how we might compare such objects in terms of their properties, and we think about ways of combining them to get new objects of the same kind. If you can keep that in mind, you’ll probably find that Abstract Algebra isn’t as abstract as it first appears. You’ll also find that you’ve gained some power in thinking about mathematical statements of various types. We’ll consider how in the next chapter.

概括

SUMMARY

• 数学概念（例如数字和函数）通常首先通过涉及物理对象的动作来接触。后来，人们学会将这些概念视为过程，最终视为对象。

• Mathematical concepts such as numbers and functions are often first encountered via actions involving physical objects. Later, people learn to think of these concepts as processes, and eventually as objects.

• 从数字与其他数字和运算的相互作用的角度来思考数字是至关重要的，因为计数需要时间。

• Thinking of numbers in terms of the way they interact with other numbers and operations is essential because counting takes time.

• 可以将微分理解为对函数进行操作的更高级过程，这有助于理解微分方程。

• It is possible to understand differentiation as a higher-level process that operates on functions, which helps in understanding differential equations.

• 页面上看起来相似的符号表达式可能代表非常不同类型的对象。这些区别对数学家来说很重要。

• Symbolic expressions that look similar on a page might represent very different types of objects. These distinctions are important to mathematicians.

• 未完全理解问题的学生有时会给出不可能正确的答案，因为它甚至不是正确的对象类型。

• Students who do not fully understand a question sometimes give an answer that cannot possibly be right because it is not even the right type of object.

• 数学对象可以被认为是按层次组织的。

• Mathematical objects can be thought of hierarchically organized.

• 当涉及将过程本身视为一个对象时，学习更高层次的对象可能会很困难；在高级课程中，你有时会发现新过程很快被视为新对象。

• Learning about objects at a higher level can be difficult when it involves thinking of a process as an object in its own right; in upper-level courses, you will sometimes find that new processes get treated as new objects very rapidly.

• 学习将关系、二元运算和对称性等概念视为对象可能需要一些智力训练，但这样做是有意义的，因为我们可以比较它们的属性。

• It might take some intellectual discipline to learn to think of concepts such as relations, binary operations, and symmetries as objects, but it makes sense to do so because we can compare their properties.

• 如果我们有一组对象，其中任意两个对象可以组合起来得到另一个相同类型的对象，那么我们就有办法构建一种新的算法。

• If we have a set of objects any two of which can be combined to give another of the same kind, we have a way to construct a new arithmetic.

进一步阅读

FURTHER READING

如果想以通俗易懂的方式了解数学家如何思考高等数学中的抽象概念，请尝试：

For an accessible introduction to the ways in which mathematicians think about abstract concepts in advanced mathematics, try:

• Gowers, T. (2002)。数学：非常简短的介绍。牛津：牛津大学出版社。

• Gowers, T. (2002). Mathematics: A Very Short Introduction. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

• Katz, BP 和 Starbird, M. (2012)。提炼思想：数学思维导论。美国数学协会。

• Katz, B. P. & Starbird, M. (2012). Distilling Ideas: An Introduction to Mathematical Thinking. Mathematical Association of America.

• Stewart, I. (1995).现代数学概念。纽约：Dover Publications。

• Stewart, I. (1995). Concepts of Modern Mathematics. New York: Dover Publications.

如果想更像教科书一样介绍数字和公理系统的形式思想，请尝试：

For a more textbook-like introduction to formal ideas about numbers and axiomatic systems, try:

• Krantz, SG (2002)。高等数学要素（第二版）。佛罗里达州博卡拉顿：Chapman & Hall/CRC。

• Krantz, S. G. (2002). The Elements of Advanced Mathematics (2nd Edition). Boca Raton, FL: Chapman & Hall/CRC.

• Liebeck, M. (2011)。纯数学简介（第 3 版）。佛罗里达州博卡拉顿：CRC Press。

• Liebeck, M. (2011). A Concise Introduction to Pure Mathematics (3rd Edition). Boca Raton, FL: CRC Press.

• Stewart, I. & Tall, D. (1977)。《数学基础》。牛津：牛津大学出版社。

• Stewart, I. & Tall, D. (1977). The Foundations of Mathematics. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

要了解儿童对数学概念的更多理解，请尝试：

For more on childrens’ understandings of mathematical concepts, try:

• Ryan, J. 和 Williams, J. (2007)。4-15岁儿童数学：从错误和误解中学习。梅登黑德：开放大学出版社。

• Ryan, J. & Williams, J. (2007). Children’s Mathematics 4–15: Learning from Errors and Misconceptions. Maidenhead: Open University Press.

第三章

定义

CHAPTER 3

Definitions

本章讨论定义在数学理论中的地位。它将定义与公理和定理进行比较，并解释可能影响定义制定方式的因素。它讨论了数学定义与字典定义的不同之处，并描述了理解熟悉和不熟悉概念的定义的策略。

This chapter is about the place of definitions in mathematical theory. It compares definitions with axioms and theorems, and explains factors that might affect how a definition is formulated. It discusses ways in which mathematical definitions differ from dictionary definitions, and describes strategies for understanding definitions of both familiar and unfamiliar concepts.

3.1 公理、定义和定理

3.1 Axioms, definitions, and theorems

在上一章中，我指出，我们常常可以将数学概念视为独立的对象。在尝试理解各种数学语句时，以这种方式思考会很有用，在本章中，我将解释这如何应用于定义。在接下来的章节中，我将解释它如何应用于定理和证明。

In the previous chapter, I argued that we can often think about mathematical concepts as objects in their own right. It can be useful to think in this way when trying to understand mathematical sentences of various kinds, and in this chapter I will explain how this applies in relation to definitions. In the following chapters I will explain how it applies in relation to theorems and proofs.

首先，我们要确保自己知道公理、定义和定理是什么，并特别关注它们的区别（我们将在第 5 章中讨论证明）。这值得花点时间，因为本科生通常说不出它们的区别，即使他们已经主修数学一年或更长时间，并在讲义中多次写过这些词。我的描述将相当不正式——我相信逻辑学家会给出更复杂的解释。但它们应该足以让你关注它们在数学理论中的地位。

We’ll begin by making sure we know what axioms, definitions, and theorems are, focusing in particular on how they differ (we will deal with proofs in Chapter 5). This is worth a moment, because undergraduate students often can’t say what the differences are, even when they have been a mathematics major for a year or more and have written these words dozens of times in their lecture notes. My descriptions will be fairly informal—I’m sure a logician would give a more sophisticated explanation. But they should be enough to focus your attention on the status of each within mathematical theory.

3.2 什么是公理？

3.2 What are axioms?

公理是我们同意做出的假设，通常是因为大家都认为它是合理的。例如，实数的一个公理是，对于每两个实数a和b，a + b = b + a。如我在第 2 章中所说，这称为交换性（加法），其他二元运算不一定也具备此属性。这是值得费心把它写下来的一个原因。另一个原因是数学家喜欢公开他们的假设。在这种情况下，这似乎不值得，因为显然每个人都同意。但有时两个人会无意中假设不同的、更微妙的公理成立，然后被彼此的说法弄糊涂。为了避免这种情况，很好的数学习惯是预先清楚地陈述所有的公理。

An axiom is an assumption that we agree to make, usually because everyone agrees that it is sensible. For instance, one axiom for the real numbers is that for every two real numbers a and b, a + b = b + a. As I said in Chapter 2, this is called commutativity (of addition), and this property is not necessarily shared by other binary operations. That’s one reason to bother writing it down. Another reason is that mathematicians like to get their assumptions out in the open. This might hardly seem worth it in cases like this, where everyone obviously agrees. But there can be cases in which two people inadvertently assume that different, more subtle axioms hold, and then get confused by each other’s claims. To avoid this, it’s good mathematical practice to state all our axioms clearly up front.

在本次讨论中，需要记住的一件重要事情是，我们不会试图证明公理。公理是我们都同意假设为真的东西，这样我们就可以继续使用它来证明更有趣的事情。（我在这里稍微简化了一下——有关公理、定义和证明之间关系的进一步讨论，请参阅第 5 章。）

In the context of this discussion, one important thing to remember is that we do not try to prove axioms. An axiom is something that we all agree to assume is true so that we can get on with using it to prove more interesting things. (I’m simplifying a bit here—see Chapter 5 for further discussion about the relationship between axioms, definitions, and proof.)

3.3 什么是定义？

3.3 What are definitions?

与公理不同，定义与某事是否真实无关。它只是告诉我们一个数学词的含义。定义可能定义一种对象，也可能定义一种属性；下面你可以看到一些插图。试着理解每一个，但如果你不理解也不要担心，因为我们只是暂时看看它们的结构。稍后我们将详细了解它们的含义。

Unlike an axiom, a definition has nothing to do with something being true. It just tells us what a mathematical word means. A definition might define a type of object, or it might define a property; below you can see some illustrations. Have a go at understanding each one, but don’t worry if you don’t, because we’re just looking at their structure for the time being. Later on we’ll look at the meanings in detail.

定义：当且仅当存在整数k使得n = 2 k 时，数n为偶数。

Definition: A number n is even if and only if there exists an integer k such that n = 2k.

定义：函数f : →为增函数当且仅当对于每个x 1 , x 2 ∈使得x 1 < x 2，有f ( x 1 ) ≤ f ( x 2 )。

Definition: A function f : → is increasing if and only if for every x1, x2 ∈ such that x1 < x2, we have f(x1) ≤ f(x2).

定义：集合S上的二元运算 ∗是可交换的当且仅当对于S中的所有元素s 1和s 2 ，s 1 ∗ s 2 = s 2 ∗ s 1。

Definition: A binary operation ∗ on a set S is commutative if and only if for all elements s1 and s2 in S, s1 ∗ s2 = s2 ∗ s1.

定义：集合X ⊆为开集合当且仅当对于每个x ∈ X存在d > 0 使得 ( x − d , x + d ) ⊆ X。

Definition: A set X ⊆ is open if and only if for every x ∈ X there exists d > 0 such that (x − d, x + d) ⊆ X.

请注意，在每个定义中，只定义了一件事。例如，第一个定义将偶数定义为数字的属性；第二个定义将增加定义为函数的属性。还要注意，数学的层次性在定义中非常明显。为了理解交换律的含义，我们需要了解集合和二元运算。

Notice that in each definition, just one thing is being defined. The first, for instance, defines even as a property of numbers; the second defines increasing as a property of functions. Notice also that the hierarchical nature of mathematics is very visible in definitions. In order to understand what commutative means, we need to know about sets and binary operations.

现在，本质上，我刚才说的是，定义告诉我们一个词的意思，你已经知道了，因为你已经使用字典很长时间了。但是字典定义和数学定义之间有两个非常非常重要的区别。如果你想理解高等数学，理解这些区别至关重要。

Now, essentially, what I’ve just said is that a definition tells us what a word means, which you already know because you’ve been using dictionaries for a very long time. But there are two very, very important differences between dictionary definitions and mathematical definitions. If you want to understand advanced mathematics, it is vital that you understand these differences.

第一个区别是，当数学家陈述一个定义时，他们真的是这个意思。他们并不是说这可以很好地描述大多数情况，而是指在某些地方可能存在例外。字典定义并不是这样运作的。如果你拿两本字典来查找一个日常概念，无论是具体概念（如“桌子”）还是抽象概念（如“正义”），你会认为它们的定义相同吗？可能不会。事实上，你可能期望能够在世界上找到满足一个定义但不满足另一个定义的事物。或者找到你想称之为“桌子”或“正义”但实际上并不满足任何一个定义的东西。1或者找到某种东西，尽管它有定义，但人们仍不同意。

The first difference is that when mathematicians state a definition, they really mean it. They don’t mean that this is a good description of the majority of cases, but that there might be exceptions out there somewhere. This is not the way dictionary definitions work. If you took two dictionaries and looked up an everyday concept, either a concrete one (like “table”) or an abstract one (like “justice”), would you expect the definitions to be identical? Probably not. Probably, in fact, you would expect to be able to find things in the world that satisfy one definition but not the other. Or to find something that you would want to call a “table” or “justice” but that didn’t really satisfy either definition.1 Or to find something for which, even though there is a definition, people would disagree.

现在，将这与你拿起一本数学书并查找“偶数”定义时的情况进行比较。你期望能够找到一个不满足定义的偶数吗？或者一个满足定义的非偶数？绝对不是。例外根本不存在。你不可能找到一个大到不能被 2 整除的偶数，或者类似这样的数字那。2如果你拿了两本教科书，你可能不会期望这两个定义的表述方式完全相同，但你会期望它们在逻辑上是等价的。也就是说，你会期望所有且只有满足第一个定义的东西也会满足第二个定义。所以，这就是一个区别：数学定义的意思完全准确，完全符合它们所说的。没有例外，可能存在不同的表述，但这些必须在逻辑上等价。

Now, compare this with what would happen if you took a mathematics book and looked up a definition of “even number.” Would you expect to be able to find an even number that did not satisfy the definition? Or a non-even number that did, nonetheless, satisfy the definition? Absolutely not. Exceptions simply don’t exist. It’s not like you could find a number so big that it could be even without being divisible by 2, or something like that.2 If you took two textbooks, you might not expect the two definitions to be phrased in exactly the same way, but you would expect them to be logically equivalent. That is, you would expect that all and only the things that satisfy the first definition would also satisfy the second. So, that’s one difference: mathematical definitions mean exactly, exactly what they say. There are no exceptions, and different phrasings might exist but these must be logically equivalent.

另一个区别部分是第一个区别的结果，即数学定义具有可操作性，而字典定义则不能。这意味着它们包含一些我们可以在代数或逻辑论证中实际操纵的信息。我将在本章后面描述我的意思。

The other difference, which is partly a consequence of the first, is that mathematical definitions are operable in a way that dictionary definitions are not. This means that they contain some information that we can actually manipulate in an algebraic or logical argument. I’ll describe what I mean by this later in this chapter.

最后一点是，我们不会“证明”定义。我们无法证明，因为没有什么可证明的：定义只是捕捉我们都同意使用一个词来表示完全相同事物的惯例。教授可能会在某个时候向你解释定义如何捕捉直观的想法，但这与证明它不同。

A final point here is that we do not “prove” definitions. We can’t, because there’s nothing to prove: definitions just capture conventions in which we all agree to use a word to mean exactly the same thing. A professor might, at some point, explain to you how a definition captures an intuitive idea, but this isn’t the same as proving it.

3.4 什么是定理？

3.4 What are theorems?

剩下的就是定理了。定义说明了我们用描述数学对象或属性的词来表达的意思，而定理则告诉我们两种或多种类型的对象和属性之间的关系；它假设我们已经知道这些对象和属性是什么。为了说明这一点，下面是一些定理。3有些你会理解，有些你不会，但是我们现在只看一下它们的结构。

That just leaves theorems. Whereas a definition states what we mean by a word describing a mathematical object or property, a theorem tells us about a relationship between two or more types of objects and properties; it assumes that we already know what those objects and properties are. To illustrate, here are some theorems.3 Some you will understand, and some you won’t, but again we’re just looking at their structure for now.

定理：如果l、m和n是连续整数，则乘积lmn可以被 6 整除。

Theorem: If l, m, and n are consecutive integers, then the product lmn is divisible by 6.

定理：如果f是偶函数，则就是奇函数。

Theorem: If f is an even function, then is an odd function.

定理：如果ax 2 + bx + c = 0，则

Theorem: If ax2 + bx + c = 0, then

定理：如果ϕ : U → V是线性变换，则 dim(ker( ϕ )) + dim(im( ϕ )) = dim( U )。

Theorem: If ϕ : U → V is a linear transformation, then dim(ker(ϕ)) + dim(im(ϕ)) = dim(U).

希望您能看出这些与定义有何不同。例如，在第二个定义中，假设我们已经知道函数 even、odd和 d f /d x的含义。这里没有定义这些；相反，我们被告知它们之间的一般关系。

Hopefully you can see how these differ from definitions. In the second one, for instance, it is assumed that we already know the meaning of function, even, odd, and df/dx. None of these is being defined here; instead we are being told about a general relationship between them.

当然，如果你不知道所有单词和符号的含义，你可能会觉得你不理解这个定理。但请注意，即使你不理解一个定理，你也应该能够认识到它有一个类似定理的结构。上述定理都以这种形式写出：

Of course, if you don’t know the meanings of all the words and symbols, you will probably feel that you don’t understand the theorem. Notice, however, that even if you don’t understand a theorem, you should be able to recognize that it has a theorem-like structure. The above theorems are all written in this form:

如果这件事是真的，那么另一件事也是真的。

If this thing is true, then this other thing is true as well.

在每种情况下，与“如果”相关的部分称为前提、假设或假说（我知道用多个词来表达同一个意思有点烦人——对此我深表歉意）。与“那么”相关的部分称为结论。在现实生活中，情况实际上并没有这么简单，因为有几种表述定理的方式不会使“如果……那么……”结构如此明显。我将在第 4 章中进一步讨论这一点。

In each case, the bit that goes with the if is called the premise or the assumption or the hypothesis (I realize it’s a bit annoying having multiple words for the same thing—sorry about that). The bit that goes with the then is called the conclusion. It’s actually not quite this simple in real life, because there are a few ways of phrasing theorems that don’t make the “if…then…” structure so obvious. I’ll discuss that further in Chapter 4.

从某种意义上说，定理类似于公理：它们告诉我们关于概念之间关系的真实情况。不同之处在于，我们要费尽心思去证明定理。有时我们这样做是因为定理远非显而易见（上述所有定理对你来说都是显而易见的吗？）。但有时，定理显然是正确的，我们这样做的原因更微妙，即证明它们可以让我们看到它们如何结合在一起形成一个连贯的理论。我将在第 5 章中对此进行更多讨论。

In one sense, theorems are similar to axioms: they tell us true things about relationships between concepts. The difference is that we go to the trouble of proving theorems. Sometimes we do this because theorems are far from obvious (do all of the above theorems seem obviously true to you?). Sometimes, though, theorems are pretty obviously true, and we do it for the more subtle reason that proving them allows us to see how they all fit together to form a coherent theory. I’ll have more to say about this in Chapter 5.

然而，在我们继续之前要注意的一件事是，从表面上看，公理、定义和定理看起来都很相似。事实上，我曾经有一位学生告诉我，他认为定义和定理“差不多”就是因为这个原因。你可以在讲义中分辨出哪个是哪个，因为公理将被标记为“公理”，定义将被标记为“定义”，定理将被标记为“定理”（认真的说）。4但它们的长度通常差不多，而且通常包含单词和符号的组合，因此在页面上看到它们并不会告诉你它在数学理论中的逻辑地位。希望你能看到公理、定义和定理的逻辑结构在重要方面有所不同，并且它们各自具有不同的地位。记住这一点，你将能够更好地跟踪数学课程的整体结构。

One thing to notice before we move on, however, is that on a surface level, axioms, definitions, and theorems all look similar. Indeed, I once had a student tell me that he thought definitions and theorems were “kind of the same” for this reason. You will be able to tell which is which in your lecture notes because the axioms will be labeled “Axiom,” the definitions will be labeled “Definition,” and the theorems will be labeled “Theorem” (seriously).4 But they’re often of similar lengths and they usually involve a combination of words and symbols, so seeing one on a page would not tell you about its logical status within a mathematical theory. Hopefully you can see that the logical structures of axioms, definitions, and theorems differ in important ways, and that they each have a different status. Bear this in mind and you’ll be better able to keep track of the global structures of your mathematics courses.

3.5 理解定义：偶数

3.5 Understanding definitions: even numbers

本书这部分的其余章节将讨论与定义、定理和证明交互的方式。在本章中，我们将重点介绍如何通过抽象对象的思维来理解定义。我们将从一个非常简单的定义开始。

The remaining chapters in this part of the book will address ways of interacting with definitions, theorems, and proofs. In this chapter, we will focus on understanding definitions by thinking in terms of abstract objects. We’ll consider a very simple definition to start off with.

定义：一个数如果能被 2 整除，那么它就是偶数。

Definition: A number is even if it is divisible by 2.

“嗯，是的，”你会想，“显然如此。”但事实上，你的教授可能不会这样写这个定义。你更有可能看到类似这样的内容（如上所示）：

“Well, yes,” you’ll be thinking, “obviously.” In fact, though, this is probably not how your professor will write this definition. You’re more likely to see something like this (as it was presented above):

定义：当且仅当存在整数k使得n = 2 k 时，数n为偶数。

Definition: A number n is even if and only if there exists an integer k such that n = 2k.

你可能会认为这过于复杂了。但它也有一些优点。首先是精确度。我们可以通过比较学生在尝试定义偶数时写的内容来看到这一点。他们倾向于说“偶数是可以被 2 整除的数”。显然，这抓住了关键思想，但不太精确。首先，“它” 是什么？显然，“它” 应该是一个数字，但这个数字没有被正确引入。相比之下，更好的定义明确地告诉我们，我们正在处理一个数字，并给它一个名字，n。另一方面，学生定义包含“是何时”的说法。这听起来很笨拙，在数学和其他领域也是如此。在数学中，如果你发现自己写“它”或“是何时”，你可能应该考虑重新措辞（有关提高数学写作水平的大量信息，请参阅第 8 章）。

You could be forgiven for thinking that this over-complicates things. But it has some advantages. The first is precision. We can see this by comparing with the kind of thing that students sometimes write when they try to define even. They tend to say things like “Even is when it’s divisible by 2.” Clearly that captures the key idea, but it isn’t very precise. For a start, what is “it?” Clearly “it” is supposed to be a number, but this number isn’t introduced properly. In contrast, the better definition tells us explicitly that we are dealing with a number and gives it a name, n. For another thing, the student definition contains the locution “is when.” This tends to sound clunky, in mathematics but also in other fields. In mathematics, if you find yourself writing “it” or “is when,” you should probably consider rephrasing (for lots of information on improving your mathematical writing, see Chapter 8).

第二个优点是前面提到的：可操作性。我们可以用数学定义来证明事物。更好的定义为我们提供了一种捕获和操纵偶数的方法，因为它以代数形式说明了可整除性的含义。例如，我们可以用它来证明偶数的任何整数倍也必须是偶数，也许可以这样写：

The second advantage is the one mentioned earlier: operability. We can operate with mathematical definitions to prove things. The better definition gives us a way of capturing and manipulating even numbers because it states what divisibility means in algebraic terms. We could, for instance, use it to prove that any integer multiple of an even number must also be even, perhaps by writing something this:

声明：偶数的任何整数倍也是偶数。

Claim: Any integer multiple of an even number is also even.

证明：假设n是偶数。

Proof: Suppose that n is an even number.

那么（根据定义）存在一个整数k使得n = 2 k。

Then (by definition) there exists an integer k such that n = 2k.

现在，让z成为任意整数。

Now, let z be any integer.

则zn = z (2k )。

Then zn = z(2k).

但我们可以将其重写为zn = 2( zk )。

But we can rewrite this as zn = 2(zk).

现在zk是一个整数，所以zn是偶数，因为它可以写成所需的形式。

Now zk is an integer, so zn is even because it can be written in the required form.

如果我们使用的是不精确的学生定义，我们可能会有同样的想法。但更好的版本通过提供一些符号，为我们编写这样的论证提供了帮助。我将在第 5 章、第 6 章和第8 章中进一步讨论这一点（第 5 章还提供了有关我们为什么要费心证明如此明显的事情的信息）。

We could have the same ideas if we were working with the imprecise student definition. But the better version gives us a leg-up for writing arguments like this by providing some notation. I’ll discuss this further in Chapters 5, 6, and 8 (Chapter 5 also has information on why we would bother proving such an obvious thing).

回到我们对定义本身的讨论，思考它如何应用于特定的数学对象并不困难。整个定义“关于”整数——整数。我们可以通过思考它如何应用于其中一些数字，轻松地检查该定义是否与对均匀性的非正式理解相对应。例如对于偶数 24，k为 12。对于偶数 0，k为 0。对于偶数 156 206 749 386，我懒得去计算k是多少，但我确信如果必须的话我可以做到——合适的k肯定存在。

Returning to our discussion of the definition in itself, it is not difficult to think about how it applies to particular mathematical objects. The whole definition is “about” integers—whole numbers. We can easily check that the definition corresponds to an informal understanding of evenness, by thinking about how it applies to some of these numbers. For the even number 24, the k is 12. For the even number 0, the k is 0. For the even number 156 206 749 386, I can’t be bothered to work out what the k is, but I’m convinced that I could do it if I had to—an appropriate k certainly exists.

然而，通过考虑偶数，我们只完成了一半的工作。我们期望该定义对每个偶数都成立，事实也确实如此。但同样重要的是，我们希望它排除所有非偶数。在这种情况下，这也很容易考虑。对于数字 3，没有合适的整数k。对于数字 −10.2，没有合适的整数k，等等。因此，我们可以确信我们理解了该定义，并且它以合理的方式捕捉了偶数的概念。

By thinking about even numbers, though, we’ve only done half of the job. We expect the definition to hold for every even number, and it does. But, just as importantly, we expect it to exclude all the numbers that are not even. This, too, is easy to think about in this case. For the number 3, there is no appropriate integer k. For the number −10.2, there is no appropriate integer k, and so on. Thus we can satisfy ourselves that we understand the definition, and that it captures the notion of evenness in a reasonable way.

3.6 理解定义：增函数

3.6 Understanding definitions: increasing functions

前面的例子很简单，因为整数非常熟悉。现在，我们将考虑一种情况，其中的想法同样熟悉且自然，但定义稍微复杂一些。我们将使用函数的递增定义。

The previous illustration was straightforward because integers are very familiar. We will now think about a case in which the idea is, again, familiar and natural, but the definition is a bit more complicated. We’ll use the definition of increasing for functions.

您可能对函数增加的含义有相当清晰的认识。这个想法很可能会让您想到一张图，也许是这样的：

Probably you have a pretty clear idea of what it ought to mean for a function to be increasing. It’s likely that the idea brings to mind a graph, perhaps one that looks like this:

考虑到这一点，让我们来看看这个定义。

With that in mind, let’s look at the definition.

定义：函数f : →为增函数当且仅当对于每个x 1 , x 2 ∈使得x 1 < x 2，有f ( x 1 ) ≤ f ( x 2 )。

Definition: A function f: → is increasing if and only if for every x1, x2 ∈ such that x1 < x2, we have f(x1) ≤ f(x2).

弄清楚这与图形的关系是个好主意。首先，定义讨论了一个将实数映射到实数的函数f （这就是f : → 的含义）。这就是笛卡尔图旨在展示的内容：对于x轴上的任何给定（实数）输入，它们允许我们在y轴上读取一个（实数）输出。接下来，定义引入了两个实数并将它们称为x 1和x 2（x 1 , x 2 ∈表示x 1和x 2是 的元素）。我们想把它们放在图表上，但首先我们必须弄清楚在哪里。我们有两个合理的候选者：它们可以是输入（在x轴上）或输出（在y轴上）。当数学家命名事物时，这些名字通常是合理的，这里我们有一个叫做x某物的东西，所以可以肯定它们的位置在x轴上。我们可以通过查看定义的其余部分来确认这一点，其中涉及对每个元素取f。我们得到的唯一其他信息是，我们正在考虑x 1 < x 2的情况，因此让我们将它们置于该配置中，并标记它们的f值：

It’s a good idea to work out how this relates to the graph. First, the definition talks about a function f that maps real numbers to real numbers (that’s what f: → means). That’s what Cartesian graphs are designed to show: for any given (real number) input on the x-axis, they allow us to read a (real number) output on the y-axis. Next, the definition introduces two real numbers and calls them x1 and x2 (x1, x2 ∈ means that x1 and x2 are elements of ). We’d like to put these on the diagram, but first we have to work out where. We have two sensible candidates for this: they could be inputs (on the x-axis) or outputs (on the y-axis). When mathematicians name things, the names are usually sensible, and here we have things called xsomething, so it’s a good bet that the place for them is on the x-axis. We can confirm this by looking at the rest of the definition, which involves taking f of each one. The only other information we’re given is that we’re considering cases where x1 < x2, so let’s put them in that configuration, and label their f-values:

现在，定义表明，只要x 1 < x 2，我们就应该有f ( x 1 ) ≤ f ( x 2 )。从图中看，情况确实如此。但从技术上讲，我们只考虑了一对数字x 1和x 2，而定义对每一对数字都有所说明。但图形表示对于思考一般概念很有用：我们可以想象x 1和x 2在x轴上滑动（当然，保持x 1 < x 2），并思考f ( x 1 ) 和f ( x 2 ) 会发生什么。这样做应该说服你，这个定义符合我们对这个特定函数的直觉。你会怎么做才能说服自己，它符合我们对一般增函数的直觉？是的——想象一下函数的图形也在变化。

Now, the definition says that whenever we have x1 < x2, we should have f(x1) ≤ f(x2). That certainly seems to be the case in the picture. Technically, though, we’ve only thought about one pair of numbers x1 and x2, and the definition says something about every such pair. But graphical representations are useful for thinking about general ideas: we can imagine x1 and x2 sliding around on the x-axis (keeping x1 < x2, of course) and think about what would happen to f(x1) and f(x2). Doing this should convince you that the definition is in accord with our intuition for this particular function. What would you do to convince yourself that it is in accord with our intuition for increasing functions in general? Yep—imagine the graph of the function changing, too.

因此，我们已经检查过，对于我们认为应该归类为递增的函数，该定义似乎成立。不过，和以前一样，我们还应该检查，对于我们认为不应该归类为递增的函数，该定义不成立。例如，该定义不适用于下面显示的函数，因为我们有x 1 < x 2，但没有f ( x 1 ) ≤ f ( x 2 )。事实上，如果我们想象滑动x 1和x 2，我们就会发现我们永远不会有f ( x 1 ) ≤ f ( x 2 )。

So, we have checked that the definition seems to hold for functions that we think should be classified as increasing. As before, though, we should also check that it does not hold for functions that we think should not be classified as increasing. For instance, the definition does not hold for the function shown below, because we have x1 < x2 but we don’t have f(x1) ≤ f(x2). Indeed, if we imagine sliding x1 and x2 around, we can see that we never have f(x1) ≤ f(x2).

我们还应该努力思考更复杂的情况。例如，考虑下图所示的函数。

We should also make some effort to think about more complicated cases. Consider, for example, the function represented in the diagram below.

这里我们有x 1 < x 2，但没有f ( x 1 ) ≤ f ( x 2 )。然而在这种情况下，如果我们想象滑动x 1和x 2，保持x 1 < x 2，我们会发现在某些地方确实有f ( x 1 ) ≤ f ( x 2 )。根据我们的定义，这意味着什么？再仔细阅读一下，我们会发现它说“对于每个 x 1，x 2 ∈使得x 1 < x 2，我们有f ( x 1 ) ≤ f ( x 2 )”。你不会惊讶地发现，当数学家说“每个”时，他们真的是这个意思。在这种情况下，所需的关系并不总是成立，因此函数不满足定义，也就不是递增的。5

Here we have x1 < x2 but we don’t have f(x1) ≤ f(x2). However, in this case, if we imagine sliding x1 and x2 around, keeping x1 < x2, we find that in some places we do have f(x1) ≤ f(x2). What does that mean, in terms of our definition? Reading it again carefully, we find that it says “for every x1, x2 ∈ such that x1 < x2, we have f(x1) ≤ f(x2).” You won’t be surprised to learn that when mathematicians say “every,” they really mean it. In this case, the required relationship does not always hold, so the function does not satisfy the definition, so it is not increasing.5

你能明白为什么说不增加而不是减少很重要吗？在数学中，对立面的作用方式与日常对话中看起来的方式不同。一些不增加的函数实际上是在减少。然而，一些不增加的函数有更复杂的行为。我们将在第 3.10 节中回到这一点。

Can you see why it is important to say not increasing rather than decreasing? In mathematics, opposites don’t work the same way as they appear to in everyday conversation. Some functions that are not increasing are, indeed, decreasing. However, some functions that are not increasing have more complicated behaviors. We’ll come back to this point in Section 3.10.

3.7 理解定义：交换性

3.7 Understanding definitions: commutativity

到目前为止，我们已经了解了两个适用于熟悉对象（分别是数字和函数）的定义。您还会遇到一些更难理解的定义，因为它们适用于不太熟悉的对象。以下是一个例子。

At this point, we’ve seen two definitions that apply to familiar objects (numbers and functions, respectively). You’ll also meet definitions that are harder to think about because they apply to less familiar objects. Here is an example.

定义：集合S上的二元运算 ∗是可交换的当且仅当对于所有元素s 1，s 2 ∈ S， s 1 ∗ s 2 = s 2 ∗ s 1。

Definition: A binary operation ∗ on a set S is commutative if and only if for all elements s1, s2 ∈ S, s1 ∗ s2 = s2 ∗ s1.

如果你在学习高级课程之前阅读了这篇文章，那么你只是从第 2 章的中间部分开始了解二元运算和交换律。你可能还没有完全理解这些信息，即使你理解了，你也很难理解这个定义。尽管如此，我们可以用同样的思维来理解它。

If you’re reading this before taking upper-level courses, then you’ve only known about binary operations and commutativity since the middle of Chapter 2. You may not have fully understood that information and, even if you did, you have much less to draw on in making sense of this definition. Nonetheless, we can apply the same sort of thinking to it.

首先，与前面的定义一样，我们可以回忆一下二元运算的一个具体例子，并弄清楚它与定义。和前面一样，让我们​​从我们知道是交换的开始：加法。加法用“+”表示，但是我们的定义中没有“+”。但是，二元运算有一个通用名称：在这个定义中，它被称为“∗”。这与其他定义中使用的符号相同。我们有一个名为n的一般数字（我们在思考中用一些特定的数字替换了它），以及一个名为f的一般函数（我们在思考中用一些特定的函数替换了它）。这里，我们有一个名为“∗”的一般二元运算，（现在）我们在思考中用特定的二元运算“+”替换它。

First, as with the previous definitions, we can call to mind a particular example of a binary operation and work out how it relates to the definition. As before, let’s start with one that we know is commutative: addition. Addition is denoted by “+”, but there is no “+” in our definition. However, there is a general name for a binary operation: in this definition it is called “∗”. This is the same kind of notational device as was used in the other definitions. We had a general number called n (which we replaced in our thinking with some particular numbers), and a general function called f (which we replaced in our thinking with some particular functions). Here, we have a general binary operation called “∗”, which (right now) we are replacing in our thinking with the particular binary operation “+”.

定义将此二元运算描述为“在集合S上”。这是什么意思呢？如果我们向前看，我们会发现我们正在处理S的两个元素（称为s 1和s 2），我们将使用二元运算将它们结合起来。当我们处理“+”时，我们可以将s 1和s 2视为整数，因此将S视为所有整数的集合ℤ是有意义的。然后，像往常一样，我们应该确定定义以我们期望的方式适用于我们的二元运算。在这种情况下确实如此：对于所有元素s 1，s 2 ∈ ℤ，s 1 + s 2 = s 2 + s 1。然后，和以前一样，我们可以继续思考更多的例子。例如，二元运算“×”在集合ℤ上也是交换的。对从到的所有函数集进行二元运算“+”也是如此（对于任何两个函数f和g，f + g = g + f）。像往常一样，考虑非示例也是一个好主意。例如，正如我们在第 2 章中看到的那样，二元运算减法在整数上不交换：存在整数对s 1和s 2 ，使得s 1 − s 2 ≠ s 2 − s 1。像往常一样，仔细思考一下这如何表明整数上的减法不满足定义。

The definition describes this binary operation as being “on a set S.” What could that mean? If we look ahead, we see that we’re dealing with two elements of S (called s1 and s2) and we’ll be combining them with the binary operation. When we’re dealing with “+”, we could treat s1 and s2 as integers, so that it makes sense to think of S as the set of all integers, ℤ. Then, as usual, we should establish that the definition applies to our binary operation in the way we expect. In this case it does: for all elements s1, s2 ∈ ℤ, s1 + s2 = s2 + s1. Then, as before, we can go on to think about more examples. For instance, the binary operation “×” is also commutative on the set ℤ. So is the binary operation “+” on the set of all functions from to (for any two functions f and g, f + g = g + f). As usual, it is also a good idea to think about non-examples. For instance, as we saw in Chapter 2, the binary operation subtraction is not commutative on the integers: there exist pairs of integers s1 and s2 such that s1 − s2 ≠ s2 − s1. As always, think carefully about how this shows that subtraction on the integers does not satisfy the definition.

对于更奇特的例子，我们可以考虑更新类型的对象。我们可以考虑通过二元运算组合对称性，如第 2 章中所述。我们没有为这种二元运算引入任何特殊符号，因此不妨使用一般符号“∗”。考虑等边三角形的对称性，回想一下，我们有r 1 ∗ R 2 ≠ R 2 ∗ r 1，因此等边三角形对称性集合上的组合不满足定义，因此不满足交换律。如果你了解矩阵，你可能还知道矩阵加法在所有 2 × 2 矩阵的集合上是交换的，但矩阵乘法不满足。再次检查这些知识是否与定义相符。

For more exotic examples, we can think about newer types of object. We might think about symmetries combined via the binary operation of composition, as in Chapter 2. We didn’t introduce any special notation for this binary operation, so we might as well use the general one “∗”. Considering the symmetries of the equilateral triangle, recall that we have r1 ∗ R2 ≠ R2 ∗ r1, so composition on the set of symmetries of the equilateral triangle does not satisfy the definition and thus is not commutative. If you know about matrices, you might also know that matrix addition is commutative on the set of all 2 × 2 matrices, but that matrix multiplication is not. Again, check to see exactly how this knowledge fits with the definition.

3.8 理解定义：开集

3.8 Understanding definitions: open sets

我们现在研究了如何理解熟悉概念的定义以及你最近遇到的概念的定义。你还会发现你的教授为全新的概念引入了定义。以下是这样的一条定义，你可能会在名为“分析”或“度量空间”或“拓扑”之类的课程中遇到它：

We’ve now looked at understanding definitions for familiar concepts and for concepts that you’ve more recently encountered. You will also find that your professors introduce definitions for totally new concepts. Here is such a definition, which you might meet in a course called something like Analysis or Metric Spaces or Topology:

定义：集合X ⊆为开集当且仅当对于每个x ∈ X存在一个数d > 0 使得 ( x − d, x + d) ⊆ X。

Definition: A set X ⊆ is open if and only if for every x ∈ X there exists a number d > 0 such that (x − d, x + d) ⊆ X.

这里定义的单词是open。大多数人都知道open与门、商店、罐头、信封、餐馆或纸板箱的关系。不幸的是，这些都不能提供太多关于这个词在应用于实数子集时应该意味着什么的直觉。不过不用担心，因为我们仍然可以使用上面使用的策略来理解这个新含义。

The word being defined here is open. Most people know what open means in relation to doors or shops or tins or envelopes or restaurants or cardboard boxes. Unfortunately, none of these provides much intuition for what this word ought to mean when applied to subsets of the real numbers. Not to worry, though, because we can still understand this new meaning by using the strategies we worked with above.

首先，让我们选择一个例子来思考。我们需要实数的一个子集（回想一下这就是X ⊆的意思），在这个阶段没有必要让生活变得复杂，所以我会选择一个非常简单的例子：包含 2、5 和其间所有数字的集合。数学家用 [2, 5] 来表示（方括号表示包括端点）。如果我们愿意，我们可以使用数字线来表示它：

First, let’s select an example to think with. We need a subset of the reals (recall that’s what X ⊆ means), and there is no sense in making life unnecessarily complicated at this stage, so I will pick a nice simple one: the set containing 2, 5, and all the numbers in between. Mathematicians denote this by [2, 5] (the square brackets mean that the endpoints are included). If we want, we can represent this using a number line:

在左侧的图中，包含的端点用彩色圆点表示。当然，这有点误导，因为它们使端点看起来“很大”，但实际上并非如此。在右侧的图中，端点的包含用方括号表示，就像代数符号一样。这不太美观，而且仍然无法处理点无限小的情况。但人类擅长将图表视为代表理想化情况，因此两者都可以。

In the diagram on the left, the included endpoints are represented using colored-in dots. These are a bit misleading, of course, because they make the endpoints look “big” when they’re not. In the diagram on the right, the inclusion of the endpoints is represented by using square brackets as in the algebraic notation. This is not quite so pretty, and it still doesn’t cope with the points being infinitely small. But human beings are good at thinking about diagrams as representing idealized situations, so either will be fine.

现在我们可以通过确定集合X = [2, 5]是否满足定义来判断它是否是开放的。定义表明，对于每个x ∈ X，都有正确的东西。你可以尝试一次思考X中的所有x，但我不建议这样做。通常，先思考其中一个，然后再弄清楚这种想法是否具有普遍性以及如何具有普遍性，这样会更容易。所以让我们选择一个x并给它贴上标签：

Now we can ask whether or not the set X = [2, 5] is open, by ascertaining whether or not it satisfies the definition. The definition says that for every x ∈ X, something is true. You could try to think about all the x’s in X at once, but I’d advise against that. Usually it’s easier to start by thinking about one of them and then work out whether and how that thinking generalizes. So let’s pick an x and label it:

请注意，在选择这个x 时，我避开了端点，而是选择了一个偏离中心的点。我这样做是因为我试图从没有特殊属性的x开始，以便最大限度地提高我的想法推广到X中大多数其他点的可能性。如果我愿意，我可以把x看作一个特定的数字（比如说 4）。但让我们看看我们是否可以不用那么具体。

Notice that in picking this x I’ve avoided the endpoints, and I’ve chosen a point that’s off-center. I’ve done this because I’m trying to start with an x that has no special properties, in order to maximize the chances that my thinking will generalize to most of the other points in X. I could, if I wanted to, think of the x as a particular number (4, say). But let’s see if we can get away without being quite that specific.

定义的其余部分表示“存在一个数d > 0，使得 ( x − d, x + d) ⊆ X ”。首先，显然我们需要知道 ( x − d, x + d)的含义。它与符号 [2, 5] 非常相似；( x − d, x + d)表示x − d和x + d之间的所有数，不包括端点x − d和x + d。在数轴上，可以表示如下。请注意，在如何表示距离、点等方面有一些余地。

The rest of the definition says “there exists a number d > 0 such that (x − d, x + d) ⊆ X.” First, clearly we need to know what (x − d, x + d) means. It’s very similar to the notation [2, 5]; (x − d, x + d) means all the numbers between x − d and x + d without the endpoints x − d and x + d. On a number line, that could be represented as below. Notice that there is some leeway in how to represent distances, points, and so on.

其次，我们想弄清楚这个d与 [2, 5] 是否开放的问题有什么关系。我们知道d是一个大于 0 的数字，但仅此而已。不过，这也没关系——我们可以挑选一个看起来随机的d并思考它是否符合我们的要求。如果我选​​择一个d，我可以像下图这样标记x − d和x + d。

Second, we’d like to work out what this d could be in relation to the question of whether [2, 5] is open. We know d is a number greater than 0, but that’s all. Again, though, this doesn’t matter—we can pick some random-looking d and think about whether or not it does what we want. If I choose a d, I can label x − d and x + d as on the diagram below.

对于这个d ，右边有一点 ( x − d, x + d ) 超出了X。但我们能得出定义不成立的结论吗？答案是“不”，因为这个定义只是说“存在一个数d > 0 ，即 ( x − d, x + d ) ⊆ X。”这并不是说这必须适用于所有可能的d，只是说必须至少有一个。而且确实存在：如果我们选择一个稍微小一点的d，我们可以确保 ( x − d, x + d ) ⊆ X：

For this d, there’s a bit of (x − d, x + d) on the right that goes outside X. Can we conclude, though, that the definition is not satisfied? The answer is “no,” because this definition just says “there exists a number d > 0 such that (x − d, x + d) ⊆ X.” It doesn’t say that this has to work for every possible d, just that there has to be (at least) one. And there is: if we choose a d that is a bit smaller, we can make sure that (x − d, x + d) ⊆ X:

好的，很好。不过，这只是针对x的一个值，我们的定义是“对于每个 x ∈ X ，存在一个数字d > 0 ，使得 ( x − d, x + d ) ⊆ X。”但是，这种想法确实可以推广到所有“像”我们的初始x 的点，因为它们位于区间内部（即不在端点）。即使我们取一个非常非常接近端点的x ，我们也可以选择一个足够小的d来确保 ( x − d , x + d ) ⊆ X。

Okay, good. That was just for one value of x, though, and our definition says “for every x ∈ X there exists a number d > 0 such that (x − d, x + d) ⊆ X.” However, this thinking does generalize to all the points that are “like” our initial x in the sense that they are in the interior of the interval (that is, not at the endpoints). Even if we take an x that is really, really close to an endpoint, we can pick a d that is small enough to ensure that (x − d, x + d) ⊆ X.

这样就只剩下端点本身了。例如，如果x = 2，我们能选择一个合适的d吗？在这种情况下，答案是否定的。无论我们将d弄得多小，( x − d, x + d )的“左半部分”总是6在X之外。类似的论点也适用于区间的另一端。因此，存在一些点x ∈ X，对于这些点，不存在适当的d。因此定义不满足，并且集合X = [2, 5] 不是开放的。

That just leaves us with the endpoints themselves. If we have x = 2, for instance, can we select an appropriate d? The answer in this case is no. No matter how small we make d, the “left-hand half” of (x − d, x + d) will always6 be outside X. A similar argument applies at the other end of the interval. So there are points x ∈ X for which there does not exist an appropriate d. So the definition is not satisfied, and the set X = [2, 5] is not open.

同样的思路也适用于任何形式为 [ a, b ] 的集合。事实上，我们可以先取一个名为 [ a, b ] 的集合，然后画出我们的第一个图，就像这样：

The same kind of thinking applies to any set of the form [a, b]. Indeed, we could have just taken a set called [a, b] in the first place, and drawn our first diagram like one of these:

这是视觉表示的优势——我们经常可以使用它们来支持泛化。

This is an advantage of visual representations—we can often use them to support generalization.

然而，我们还没有找到一个开集的例子。但我们可以利用我们刚刚学到的知识来构造一个。只有区间的端点给我们带来了麻烦；在所有内部点，我们都可以按照定义要求去做。所以我们可以通过以下方式构造一个开集去掉端点。如果我们取一个形式为 ( a, b ) 的集合X，那么对于每个x ∈ X，都存在一个数d > 0 ，使得 ( x − d , x + d ) ⊆ X 。因此，任何形式为 ( a, b )的集合都是开放的。

However, we haven’t actually found an example of an open set yet. But we can use what we just learned to construct one. It was only the endpoints of the interval that gave us any bother; at all the interior points, we could do what the definition required. So we can construct an open set by just taking the endpoints off. If we take a set X of the form (a, b), then for every x ∈ X there does exist a number d > 0 such that (x − d, x + d) ⊆ X. So any set of the form (a, b) is open.

你可能想知道，形式为 ( a, b )的集合称为开区间，形式为 [ a, b ]的集合称为闭区间。7您可能还想知道，当我们谈论数学集合时​​，开放和封闭在日常意义上并不是对立的，就像当我们谈论数学函数时，增加和减少在日常意义上并不是对立的一样。事实上，我们可以构造既开放又封闭的集合，以及既不开放也不封闭的集合。当您学习高等数学时，请为这种事情做好准备。

You might like to know that a set of the form (a, b) is called an open interval and a set of the form [a, b] is called a closed interval.7 You might also like to know that when we are talking about mathematical sets, open and closed are not opposites in the everyday sense, just as when we are talking about mathematical functions, increasing and decreasing are not opposites in the everyday sense. In fact, we can construct sets that are both open and closed, and sets that are neither open nor closed. Be ready for this kind of thing when you are studying advanced mathematics.

这个定义比其他定义更难处理，这也是我们预料到的，因为我们开始时并不知道开放是什么意思。当我们没有相关示例的先验知识时，我们必须以更具探索性的方式工作，选择一个对象来思考并询问它是否满足定义。在此过程中，我们可能必须做出很多选择（选择哪个集合，选择其中的哪个数字，选择其中一个时要有多具体，等等）。这可能会让您想知道应该如何选择示例对象。例如，也许您更有可能选择一个仅包含有限数量点的集合X，如 {0, 1, 2}。我想说的是：没关系。面对这种情况时，最好选择一个对象并思考它，而不是坐在那里怀疑如何选择一个“好”的对象。如果您选择的对象具有您想要的属性，那就太好了。如果没有，也很好。在后一种情况下，您已经了解了一些新定义不适用的对象，并且您可能还了解了一些可以构造新定义适用的对象的知识。在学习新数学时，您必须愿意亲自动手；尝试许多可能有帮助的东西。当您建立各种类型的示例对象库时，您将能够更好地使用它们来帮助您理解新定义。

This definition was harder to work with than the others, which is what we’d expect because we didn’t know what open meant when we started. When we have no prior knowledge of relevant examples, we have to work in a more exploratory way, picking an object to think about and asking whether it satisfies the definition. In doing so, we might have to make a lot of choices (which set to pick, which number to pick within it, how specific to go in choosing either one, and so on). This might make you wonder how you should go about choosing example objects. Perhaps, for instance, you’d have been more likely to choose a set X that just contained a finite number of points, like {0, 1, 2}. What I’d say is: that’s fine. When faced with such situations, it’s better to pick an object and think about it than to sit there paralysed with doubt about how to pick a “good” one. If the one you choose has the property you’re looking for, great. If it doesn’t, also great. In the latter case, you’ve learned something about objects to which the new definition does not apply, and you might also have learned something that will allow you to construct one to which it does. You have to be willing to get your hands dirty when learning new mathematics; to try out lots of things that might help. As you build up a bank of example objects of various types, you’ll get better at using them to help you understand new definitions.

3.9 理解定义：极限

3.9 Understanding definitions: limits

我们已经了解了简单、熟悉的概念的定义，以及更难思考的定义，因为它们涉及您最近遇到的概念，或者可能根本没有遇到过。您可能还会遇到一些定义，这些定义您对相关对象有相当好的理解，但定义非常复杂，很难将两者联系起来。经典的例子是极限的定义：

We’ve now looked at definitions of simple, familiar concepts, and definitions that are harder to think about because they involve concepts that you’ve met more recently or, perhaps, not at all. You might also come across definitions for which you have a pretty good existing understanding of the relevant objects, but for which the definition is sufficiently complicated that it’s hard to relate the two. The classic example is the definition of limit:

定义： 当且仅当 ∀ ε > 0 ∃ δ > 0 使得如果 0 < | x − a | < δ则 | f ( x ) − L | < ε。

Definition: if and only if ∀ε > 0 ∃δ > 0 such that if 0 < |x − a| < δ then |f(x) − L| < ε.

我第一次看到这个公式时觉得它很棒——它看起来像象形文字，正是那种很容易让不学数学的人印象深刻的东西。但我花了很长时间才明白它是如何捕捉极限概念的，而且我从未见过一个学生觉得它很容易。我不会在这里给出解释，因为那会造成很大的干扰，但极限概念非常重要，当引入这个定义时，你应该坚持下去。

When I first saw this I thought it was great—it looks like hieroglyphics and is just the sort of thing that easily impresses people who don’t study mathematics. But it took me a long time to understand how it captures the notion of a limit, and I’ve never met a student who finds it easy. I won’t give an explanation here as that would constitute a big interruption, but the limit concept is very important and you should persevere when this definition is introduced.

当然，你的教授会解释这一点。实际上，当教授介绍一个新定义时，通常会给出几个符合该定义的例子，也许还会给出一个不符合该定义的例子。他们可能会详细解释，准确说明该定义在每种情况下的适用方式，也可能不会。无论哪种方式，他们都希望你超越这一极少数的例子来思考；考虑其他满足和不满足该定义的对象，并确保你理解原因。他们可能不会告诉你他们希望你这样做。这种思维方式对数学家来说非常自然，以至于他们往往会忘记它并不是每个人都能理解的。如果你想成为一名优秀的数学家，养成这种习惯很有用。

Your professor will explain it, of course. In practice, what usually happens when a professor introduces a new definition is that they then give a couple of examples of objects for which it holds, and perhaps an example of an object for which it doesn’t. They might explain in detail, showing exactly how the definition applies in each case, or they might not. Either way, they will expect you to think beyond this very small number of examples; to consider other objects that do and don’t satisfy the definition, and to make sure you understand why. They probably won’t tell you that they expect you to do this. This kind of thinking is so natural to mathematicians that they tend to forget that it’s not obvious to everyone. If you want to be a good mathematician, it’s a useful habit to develop.

3.10 定义和直觉

3.10 Definitions and intuition

在上文中，我讨论了定义可能与你对各种概念的现有直觉理解相对应的方式。但应该清楚的是，直觉在某种程度上是一种个人事物。虽然在很多情况下你的直觉可能与别人的直觉非常吻合，但并不能保证总是如此。这对于理解如何与数学定义互动非常重要，在本节中我将解释如何互动。

In the sections above I’ve discussed ways in which definitions might correspond with your existing, intuitive understandings of various concepts. But it should be clear that intuition is a somewhat personal thing. While your intuition might coincide with someone else’s pretty well in a lot of cases, there’s no guarantee that it always will. This turns out to be very important for understanding how to interact with mathematical definitions, and in this section I’ll explain how.

首先，考虑下面的函数。8

To begin, consider the function below.8

直观地看，你会说这个函数是增加的还是不增加的？无论你怎么想，你能看到别人可能会不同意你的观点吗？

Intuitively, would you say that this function is increasing, or not increasing? Whatever you think, can you see that someone else might disagree with you?

作为数学家，我们不必担心这种不确定性，因为我们通过查看定义来做出这样的决定。这里再次说明：

As mathematicians, we do not have to worry about this sort of uncertainty because we make such decisions by looking at the definition. Here it is again:

定义：函数f : →为增函数当且仅当对于每个x 1 , x 2 ∈使得x 1 < x 2，有f ( x 1 ) ≤ f ( x 2 )。

Definition: A function f: → is increasing if and only if for every x1, x2 ∈ such that x1 < x2, we have f(x1) ≤ f(x2).

这个函数是递增的，因为，只要我们把x 1 , x 2 ∈放在x 1 < x 2 的位置，就有f ( x 1 ) ≤ f ( x 2 )。请注意，小于或等于中的或等于在这里很重要。在这种情况下，我们有时会有f ( x 1 ) = f ( x 2 )。这在我们之前的函数中没有发生过，它强调了思考示例如何变化的重要性。

This function is increasing because, anywhere we put x1, x2 ∈ such that x1 < x2, we have f(x1) ≤ f(x2). Notice that the or equal to in the less than or equal to is important here. In this case we do sometimes have f(x1) = f(x2). This didn’t happen with our earlier functions, and it highlights the importance of thinking about how an example might vary.

根据你最初的回答，你可能不喜欢这个函数在数学上被归类为递增函数。你可能倾向于说它没有递增“因为有常数位”，并且你可能会对自己的直觉反应在某种意义上是错误的这一想法感到不舒服。事实上，你可能倾向于认为这个定义一定是错误的。如果是这样，试着接受这种感觉，不要被它所干扰，因为这就是本节的内容。

Depending on your initial answer, you might not like the fact that this function is mathematically classified as increasing. You might have been inclined to say that it is not increasing “because of the constant bit,” and you might feel uncomfortable with the idea that your intuitive response was, in some sense, wrong. You might, in fact, be inclined to think that the definition must be wrong. If so, try to sit with that feeling without being disturbed by it, because that’s what this section is about.

另一方面，也许那个例子根本没有让你感到困扰。如果是这样，那这个怎么样？

On the other hand, perhaps that example didn’t disturb you at all. If that’s the case, how about this one?

此函数也是增函数。对于每个满足x 1 < x 2的x 1 , x 2 ∈ ，我们有f ( x 1 ) ≤ f ( x 2 )，正如所要求的。碰巧在处处都有f ( x 1 ) = f ( x 2 )，但这没关系，定义允许这种可能性。事实上，正如您现在可能预料的那样，出于同样的原因，这个常数函数在数学上也被归类为减函数（减函数的定义与您想象的完全一样）。大多数人对此感到非常不安。这与他们的直觉反应相去甚远，让他们认为数学家们一定是集体疯了。然而事实并非如此，我现在将解释原因，并给出几个不同的原因。

This function is increasing too. For every x1, x2 ∈ such that x1 < x2, we have f(x1) ≤ f(x2), as required. We happen to have f(x1) = f(x2) everywhere, but that’s fine; the definition allows that possibility. In fact, as you might now be anticipating, this constant function is mathematically classified as decreasing too, for the same sort of reason (the definition of decreasing is exactly what you’d think it would be). Most people are really disturbed by this. It is far enough from their intuitive response to make them think that mathematicians must have collectively gone mad. This is not the case, however, and I’ll explain why now, giving a couple of different reasons.

第一个原因是，当人们直观地使用一个词时，他们使用的方式往往会有细微的差异。你可能倾向于将某个函数归类为增加，但其他人可能不同意。这意味着你归类为增加的函数集可能与其他人归类为增加的函数集重叠，如下所示：

The first reason is that, when people use a word intuitively, there tend to be small differences in how they do so. You might be inclined to classify a particular function as increasing, but someone else might disagree. This means that the set of functions that you would classify as increasing might overlap with someone else’s like this:

你和另一个人对“中心”或“明显”的例子意见一致，但对“边界”附近的例子意见不一。现在，数学家不喜欢这种情况。事实上，他们厌恶它。他们喜欢确定每个数学词的含义，这样他们就可以确保每个人在使用它时都在谈论相同的对象。这就是为什么他们强加一个定义：决定一种精确的方式来捕捉含义，并同意他们都将遵守它。在这样做时，他们会尝试确保定义涵盖了每个人都同意的所有情况。然而，他们也重视简单和优雅。所以，有时，他们最终得到的定义实际上与每个人的自然反应略有不同。也许定义的集合与我们两个人的想法重叠，如下所示：

You and this other person agree about the “central’ or “obvious” examples, but disagree about examples near the “boundaries.” Now, mathematicians don’t like this sort of situation. They abhor it, in fact. They like to be certain about the meaning of each mathematical word, so that they can be sure that everyone is talking about the same objects when they use it. That’s why they impose a definition: to decide on a precise way of capturing the meaning, and to agree that they’ll all abide by it. When doing so, they try to ensure that the definition captures all the cases for which everyone agrees. However, they also value simplicity and elegance. So, sometimes, they end up with a definition that is actually a little bit different from everyone’s natural response. Maybe the defined set overlaps with the ideas of our two people like this:

这解释了增加的定义所发生的情况。我们不想说“一个函数是增加的当且仅当它通常从左到右上升”，因为这样不太精确。我们也不想说“一个函数是增加的当且仅当对于每个x 1 , x 2 ∈ ，如果x 1 < x 2，我们有f ( x 1 ) ≤ f ( x 2 ) ，除非对于每个x 1 , x 2 ∈ ，我们有f ( x 1 ) = f ( x 2 ) ，在这种情况下它就是常数”，因为这样不太优雅。

This explains what has happened with the definition of increasing. We wouldn’t want to say “A function is increasing if and only if it is generally going up from left to right,” because that wouldn’t be very precise. We also wouldn’t want to say “A function is increasing if and only if for every x1, x2 ∈ such that x1 < x2, we have f(x1) ≤ f(x2), unless we have f(x1) = f(x2) for every x1, x2 ∈ , in which case it’s just constant,” because that wouldn’t be very elegant.

事实上，关于如何制定定义的历史决定可能比这更微妙，这给我们带来了定义有时有点奇怪的第二个原因。数学家通常不会仅仅为了定义一个词而试图确定它的确切含义。他们通常试图用它来制定定理和相关证明。因此，定义的制定可能取决于如何方便地陈述一个漂亮、优雅、真实的定理。这方面的经典例子涉及欧拉公式，该公式与多面体的顶点数 ( V )、边数 ( E ) 和面数 ( F ) 有关。公式为V − E + F = 2，您可以检查这是否适用于标准情况，例如立方体、四面体或您能想到的任何其他多面体（试试看）。但是，它不适用于像这样的固体（中间有一个洞）：

In fact, historical decisions about how to formulate a definition can be more subtle than this, which brings us to the second reason why definitions are sometimes a bit strange. Mathematicians aren’t usually trying to decide on the precise meaning of a word just for the sake of it. They’re usually trying because they want to use it in formulating a theorem and an associated proof. Thus the formulation of the definition might depend on what is convenient for being able to state a nice, elegant, true theorem. The classic illustration of this involves Euler’s formula relating the number of vertices (V), the number of edges (E), and the number of faces (F) for a polyhedron. The formula is V − E + F = 2, and you can check that this applies in standard cases like a cube or a tetrahedron or any other polyhedron you can think of (try it). However, it does not apply for a solid like this (with a hole through the middle):

那么，问题来了，我们该怎么做呢？我们是不是应该说“算了，没关系”，然后放弃这个适用于很多情况的优雅公式？还是说“好吧，那我们就定义多面体，这样它就可以排除这种情况了？”或者我们定义一类特殊的多面体，这个公式确实适用于它？数学家们在每次面临这种选择时，不会做出相同的决定，但他们肯定会考虑到这些因素。

The question, then, is what to do. Do we say “Oh well, never mind,” and give up on that lovely elegant formula that applies in so many cases? Or do we say “Right, well then, we’ll just define polyhedron so that it excludes such cases?” Or do we define a special class of polyhedra for which the formula does apply? Mathematicians don’t make the same decision each time they are faced with this sort of choice, but they certainly take such considerations into account.

如果你对数学家如何制定定义感兴趣，你可能需要留意数学史或数学哲学等选修课程。即使这个讨论对你目前的品味来说有点太哲学了，你也需要意识到后果。你需要意识到，你偶尔会遇到与你的直觉理解不太相符的数学定义。觉得这有点奇怪是完全可以的，但你必须处理这个问题。数学家们出于合理、明智的理由做出了集体决定。这些理由可能不是你立即就能看出来的，但如果某个术语的数学定义与你的直觉不符，那么你的直觉就需要修正了。

If you are interested in how mathematicians formulate definitions, you should probably look out for optional courses in things like History of Mathematics or Philosophy of Mathematics. Even if this discussion is a bit too philosophical for your present tastes, however, you need to be aware of the consequences. You need to be aware that you will occasionally come across a mathematical definition that does not quite correspond with your intuitive understanding. It is perfectly okay to find this a bit weird, but you have to deal with it. Mathematicians have made their collective decisions for good, sensible reasons. Those reasons might not be immediately apparent to you but, if the mathematical definition of a term does not match your intuition, it’s your intuition that needs fixing up.

在本章的最后，我想说的是，如果增加/减少的事情仍然困扰着你，你可能想知道数学家也使用以下定义：

I’ll end this chapter by saying that if the increasing/decreasing thing is still bothering you, you might like to know that mathematicians also use the following definition:

定义：函数f : →严格递增当且仅当对于每个x 1 , x 2 ∈使得x 1 < x 2，我们有f ( x 1 ) < f ( x 2 )。

Definition: A function f: → is strictly increasing if and only if for every x1, x2 ∈ such that x1 < x2, we have f(x1) < f(x2).

思考一下这与你的直觉有何关联，你就会恢复对数学家良好判断力的信心。

Thinking about how that relates to your intuition should restore your faith in mathematicians’ good sense.

概括

SUMMARY

• 公理是数学家一致同意的假设。定义指定了数学词汇的含义。定理是关于两种或多种类型的对象和/或属性之间关系的陈述。

• An axiom is an assumption that mathematicians agree to make. A definition specifies the meaning of a mathematical word. A theorem is a statement about a relationship between two or more types of objects and/or properties.

• 我们不证明公理或定义（尽管教授可能会解释定义如何体现直观的想法）；我们证明定理。
