• We do not prove axioms or definitions (though a professor might explain how a definition captures an intuitive idea); we do prove theorems.

• 数学定义是精确的，不允许有例外，并且它们通常提供我们可以用来构建证明的代数符号。

• Mathematical definitions are precise, they do not admit exceptions, and they often provide algebraic notation which we can use to construct proofs.

• 要理解定义，思考它适用的对象和不适用的对象是很有用的。教授们可能希望你这样做，即使他们没有这么说。

• To understand a definition, it is useful to think about objects to which it does apply and objects to which it does not. Professors will probably expect you to do this, even if they do not say so.

• 通常可以通过构建可能适用的例子然后进行检查来理解完全不熟悉的定义的含义。

• It is often possible to understand the meaning of a completely unfamiliar definition by constructing examples to which it might apply, then checking.

• 数学中对立面的作用方式与日常对话中不同；一个函数可能同时增加和减少，或者既不增加也不减少。

• Opposites do not work the same way in mathematics as they do in everyday conversation; a function might be both increasing and decreasing, or neither increasing nor decreasing.

• 定义不一定与概念的直观含义相对应，尤其是对于“边界”情况。你应该警惕这一点；如果定义与你的直觉不符，你的直觉就需要相应地进行修改。

• Definitions do not necessarily correspond to intuitive meanings of concepts, especially for “boundary” cases. You should be alert to this; if a definition does not match your intuition, your intuition needs to be amended accordingly.

进一步阅读

FURTHER READING

有关定义及其在数学理论中的位置的更多信息，请尝试：

For more on definitions and their place within mathematical theory, try:

• Houston, K. (2009).如何像数学家一样思考。剑桥：剑桥大学出版社。

• Houston, K. (2009). How to Think Like a Mathematician. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.

• Katz, BP 和 Starbird, M. (2012)。提炼思想：数学思维导论。美国数学协会。

• Katz, B. P. & Starbird, M. (2012). Distilling Ideas: An Introduction to Mathematical Thinking. Mathematical Association of America.

如果想从教科书上了解本章的数学概念，请尝试：

For a textbook introduction to mathematical concepts from this chapter, try:

• Krantz, SG (2002)。高等数学要素（第二版）。佛罗里达州博卡拉顿：Chapman & Hall/CRC。

• Krantz, S. G. (2002). The Elements of Advanced Mathematics (2nd Edition). Boca Raton, FL: Chapman & Hall/CRC.

• Liebeck, M. (2011)。纯数学简介（第 3 版）。佛罗里达州博卡拉顿：CRC Press。

• Liebeck, M. (2011). A Concise Introduction to Pure Mathematics (3rd Edition). Boca Raton, FL: CRC Press.

• Stewart, I. & Tall, D. (1977)。《数学基础》。牛津：牛津大学出版社。

• Stewart, I. & Tall, D. (1977). The Foundations of Mathematics. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

有关在证明中使用定义的更多信息，请尝试：

For more on working with definitions within proofs, try:

• Solow, D. (2005).如何阅读和做证明。新泽西州霍博肯：John Wiley。

• Solow, D. (2005). How to Read and Do Proofs. Hoboken, NJ: John Wiley.

第 4 章

定理

CHAPTER 4

Theorems

本章旨在理解简单和复杂的定理。前半部分讨论了通过研究满足定理前提的示例并考虑结论对这些示例的意义来加深理解的方法。后半部分讨论了写定理的逻辑语言，描述了这种语言的日常用法和数学用法之间的差异，并强调了解释定理陈述时要记住的事情。

This chapter is about understanding both straightforward and complicated theorems. The first half discusses ways to develop understanding by examining examples that satisfy the premises of the theorem, and considering what the conclusion means for these examples. The second half discusses the logical language in which theorems are written, describes differences between everyday and mathematical uses of this language, and highlights things to remember when interpreting theorem statements.

4.1 定理和逻辑必然性

4.1 Theorems and logical necessity

回想一下第 3 章，定理告诉我们数学对象和属性之间的关系。它们不同于定义，因为定义只告诉我们一个词的含义。它们在更微妙的哲学意义上也有所不同：定义是一种惯例——数学家们确定一个一致的含义，但他们可以选择另一个——而定理则不是。一旦定义确定，定理就会在逻辑上必然出现。例如，一旦我们决定将偶数定义为可被 2 整除的数字，我们就必须得出结论，任何两个偶数之和也是偶数。我们对这种结果没有任何选择。

Recall from Chapter 3 that theorems tell us about relationships between mathematical objects and properties. They differ from definitions, because definitions tell us the meaning of just one word. They also differ in a more subtle philosophical sense: where definitions are a matter of convention—mathematicians settle on one agreed meaning, but they could have chosen another—theorems are not. Once definitions are settled, theorems follow by logical necessity. For instance, once we have decided to define even numbers as numbers that are divisible by 2, we must conclude that the sum of any two even numbers is also even. We don’t have any choice about that kind of consequence.

在第 3 章中，我们研究了如何使用各种不同的对象表示来理解定义。我们可以将类似的策略应用于定理，但需要额外考虑为什么该陈述是正确的。以下是第 3 章中的定理列表。在本章中，我们将集中讨论前两个定理。我们将不证明我们不会讨论它们，但我们会思考如何获得有助于构建证明的想法。我们不会研究第三个；我想在第 5 章中再讨论它。但是，我们将快速浏览第四个，以展示我们如何在概念不熟悉时以对象类型来思考。

In Chapter 3, we looked at understanding definitions by using various different representations of objects. We can apply a similar strategy for theorems, with the additional requirement that we should think about why the statement is true. Below is the list of theorems from Chapter 3. In this chapter, we will concentrate on the first two. We will stop short of proving them, but we will think about how to get ideas that could be helpful in constructing a proof. We will not study the third one; I want to come back to that in Chapter 5. We will, however, have a quick look at the fourth one, to show how we can think in terms of object types even when the concepts are unfamiliar.

定理：如果l、m和n是连续整数，则乘积lmn可以被 6 整除。

Theorem: If l, m, and n are consecutive integers, then the product lmn is divisible by 6.

定理：如果f是偶函数，则就是奇函数。

Theorem: If f is an even function, then is an odd function.

定理：如果ax 2 + bx + c = 0，则

Theorem: If ax2 + bx + c = 0, then

定理：如果Φ : U → V是线性变换，则 dim(ker( Φ )) + dim(im( Φ )) = dim( U)。

Theorem: If Φ: U → V is a linear transformation, then dim(ker(Φ)) + dim(im(Φ)) = dim(U).

在本章的最后，我将更广泛地讨论逻辑语言在定理和数学中的使用。这很重要，因为逻辑语言在日常生活中的使用方式与数学家的使用方式有所不同。意识到这一点很重要，这样你才能正确地解释数学陈述，才能使你自己的数学写作准确。

At the end of the chapter, I will discuss the use of logical language in theorems and in mathematics more broadly. This is important because the way that logical language is used in everyday life is somewhat different from the way that it is used by mathematicians. It is important to be aware of this so that you can correctly interpret mathematical statements, and so that you can make your own mathematical writing accurate.

我应该说，虽然我把我们所有的陈述都称为定理，但有时也会用几个词来代替。其中一些是命题、引理、主张、推论1，以及显然包罗万象的结果。引理通常用于证明一个小定理，然后用来证明一个更大、更重要的定理。推论用于证明一个大定理的相当直接的结果。我认为其他术语或多或少可以互换，尽管有些教授可能会用它们来做细微的区分——如果你不确定，可以问。这种区别对于想要帮助学生的教授来说很重要学生能够辨别整个课程的结构（哪些是重要的，哪些是辅助的）。但这不是我在这里要做的事情，因此，为了简单起见，我将它们统称为定理。

I should say that although I’ve called all of our statements theorems, there are several words that sometimes get used instead. Some of these are proposition, lemma, claim, corollary1, and the apparently all-encompassing result. Lemma is usually used for a small theorem that will then be used to prove a bigger, more important one. Corollary is used for a result that follows as a fairly immediate consequence of a big theorem. The other terms are more or less interchangeable, I think, though it might be that some professors use them to make subtle distinctions—ask if you’re not sure. Such distinctions can be important to a professor who wants to help students discern the structure of a whole course (what’s important, what’s ancillary). But that’s not what I’m doing here so, for simplicity, I’ll just call them all theorems.

4.2 关于整数的一个简单定理

4.2 A simple theorem about integers

我们在第 3 章中观察到，我们所有的定理都具有这种结构：

We observed in Chapter 3 that all our theorems have this structure:

如果这件事是真的，那么另一件事也是真的。

If this thing is true, then this other thing is true as well.

需要了解的一件重要事情是，数学家将此类陈述解释为隐含“始终”。例如，第一个定理应解释为，如果l、m和n是连续整数，则乘积lmn始终可以被 6 整除。第二个定理应解释为，如果f是偶函数，则 d f /d x始终是奇函数。从技术上讲，数学家实际上应该这样写：

One important thing to know is that mathematicians interpret such statements as having an implicit “always.” For instance, the first theorem should be interpreted to mean that if l, m, and n are consecutive integers, then the product lmn is always divisible by 6. The second one should be interpreted to mean that if f is an even function, then df /dx is always an odd function. Technically, mathematicians should really write things like this:

定理：对于所有整数l、m和n，如果l、m和n是连续的，则乘积lmn可以被 6 整除。

Theorem: For all integers l, m, and n, if l, m, and n are consecutive, then the product lmn is divisible by 6.

然而，这会使一切变得有点冗长，而且由于每个人都熟悉标准解释，所以人们很少这样做。

However, that makes everything a bit longer and, because everyone is familiar with the standard interpretation, people rarely do it.

一旦我们知道了这一点，第一定理就很容易理解了，因为它是关于整数的。你可能觉得你不用做任何事情就能理解它，即使你不确定它为什么是正确的。但是，我想提出几点。首先，请注意前提介绍了我们将要使用的对象，并告诉我们我们将对它们的属性做出哪些假设。在这种情况下，对象是三个整数，唯一的属性是它们是连续的。结论告诉我们从前提中逻辑上得出的东西。它没有告诉我们为什么会这样，只是告诉我们确实如此。在这里，结论说我们的三个连续整数的乘积总是可以被 6 整除。

Once we know this, the first theorem is simple to understand because it is about integers. You probably feel that you understand it without having to do anything, even if you’re not sure why it’s true. However, there are a couple of points I’d like to make. First, notice that the premise introduces the objects we will be working with, and tells us what we’re going to assume about their properties. In this case, the objects are three integers, and the only property is that they are consecutive. The conclusion tells us something that follows logically from the premise. It doesn’t tell us why it follows, just that it does. Here, the conclusion says that the product of our three consecutive integers will always be divisible by 6.

这意味着我们可以通过选择三个连续的整数并将它们相乘来思考这个定理。例如，如果我们将 4、5 和 6 相乘，我们会得到 120，这当然可以被 6 整除。不过，它总是可以被 6 整除，因为 6 是我们一开始是这样。所以这不是一个很有启发性的例子。7、8 和 9 怎么样？如果我们将它们相乘，我们得到 504，我们可以轻松检查 504 可以被 6 整除。我们也可以尝试其他三个连续数字的集合，记住 −21、−20、−19 是一组完美的三个连续整数，−1、0、1 也是如此。当你想正确理解定理时，考虑这些不太明显的情况很重要。

This means that we can think about this theorem by picking three consecutive integers and multiplying them together. For instance, if we multiply together 4, 5, and 6, we get 120, which is certainly divisible by 6. It was always going to be, though, because 6 was one of the factors we started with. So that wasn’t a very illuminating example. How about 7, 8, and 9? If we multiply those together we get 504, and we can easily check that 504 is divisible by 6. We could try other sets of three consecutive numbers too, remembering that −21, −20, −19 is a perfectly good set of three consecutive integers, as is −1, 0, 1. It is important to consider less obvious cases like these when you want to develop a proper understanding of a theorem.

现在，我并不是提倡你花很长时间将连续整数的三元组相乘。一遍又一遍地进行同样的计算可能不会让你了解为什么这个定理是正确的，而且肯定会很无聊。考虑用其他方式来表示对象可能会更有用。在这种情况下，我们可以考虑数轴上的连续整数：

Now, I’m not advocating that you should spend ages multiplying together triples of consecutive integers. Doing the same calculation over and over again probably wouldn’t lead to any insight into why the theorem is true, and certainly would get boring. It might be more useful to consider alternative ways of representing the objects. In this case, we could think about consecutive integers on a number line:

替代表示有时会突出数学情况的不同方面。这是否有助于您注意到任何可能有用的东西？我们将在第 5 章讨论证明时回顾这一点。

Alternative representations sometimes highlight different aspects of a mathematical situation. Does this one help you notice anything that might be useful? We’ll come back to this in Chapter 5, when we look at a proof.

4.3 关于函数和导数的一个定理

4.3 A theorem about functions and derivatives

现在我们先讨论第二条定理：

For now, we will move on to the second theorem:

定理：如果f是偶函数，则 d f / d x是奇函数。

Theorem: If f is an even function, then df / dx is an odd function.

这里还有更多工作要做，因为对象和属性更加抽象。但是，前提再次介绍了我们正在使用的对象，并告诉我们它们具有哪些属性。这里它只介绍了一个对象，一个名为f的函数，并告诉我们它是偶数。偶数是一个数学属性，因此它有一个定义，如果我们查找它，我们会发现：

Here there is more work to do, because the objects and properties are more abstract. Again, however, the premise introduces the objects we’re working with and tells us what properties they have. Here it introduces just one object, a function called f, and tells us that it is even. Even is a mathematical property so it has a definition, and if we look it up we find this:

定义：函数f是偶函数当且仅当对于每个x，f (− x ) = f ( x )。

Definition: A function f is even if and only if for every x, f(−x) = f(x).

我要强调的是，当你不知道或记不住某件事的意思时，你必须查找定义。如果你不这样做——如果你允许自己如果只基于对概念的模糊和不明确的理解来进行研究，你就不可能很好地理解定理。

I should stress that you must look up definitions whenever you don’t know or can’t remember what something means. If you don’t—if you allow yourself to proceed with only a vague and woolly understanding of a concept—you are very unlikely to develop a good understanding of the theorem.

在这种情况下，我们的函数f具有属性2对于每个x，f (− x ) = f ( x )。即使您之前不熟悉这个属性，您也可能会想到一些具有此属性的函数。例如，由f ( x ) = x 2给出的f具有此属性。由f ( x ) = cos x给出的f也是如此。从这些例子中，我们可以轻松地构建更多： f ( x ) = x 2 + 1、 f ( x ) = 3 cos x等等。

In this case, our function f has the property2 that for every x, f(−x) = f(x). Probably you can think of some functions with this property, even if you weren’t previously familiar with it. For instance, f given by f(x) = x2 has it. So does f given by f(x) = cos x. From these examples we can easily build more: f(x) = x2 + 1, f(x) = 3 cos x, and so on.

这里可以使用另一种表示方法，因为我们习惯于用图形来思考。如果你以前学过偶函数，你可能知道偶函数关于y轴对称。如果你不知道，你可以通过查看下图并思考x的所有可能值来了解为什么它是正确的。你也可以为我们刚刚列出的特定函数考虑类似的图表。

An alternative representation is useful here, because we are accustomed to thinking about graphs. If you have studied even functions before, you might know that an even function is symmetric about the y-axis. If you didn’t know that, you can probably see why it is true by looking at the diagram below and thinking about all the possible values of x. You could also think about similar diagrams for the particular functions we just listed.

因此，思考例子和图表可以帮助我们理解前提。但结论呢？这里的结论是 d f / d x是一个奇函数。首先，我们可以确保我们知道现在有什么对象。从第 2 章中，你应该熟悉这样的想法：当f是函数时， d f / d x也是函数。不过，也许我们需要查找odd的定义：

Thinking about examples and graphs can thus help us to understand the premise. But what about the conclusion? The conclusion here says that df / dx is an odd function. First, we can make sure that we know what objects we now have. From Chapter 2, you should be comfortable with the idea that when f is a function, so is df / dx. Perhaps, though, we need to look up the definition of odd:

定义：函数f为奇函数当且仅当对于每个x，f (− x ) = − f ( x )。

Definition: A function f is odd if and only if for every x, f(−x) = −f(x).

这看起来与even的定义非常非常相似，因此请确保您能看出差异在哪里。不要对这种事情漠不关心——有时移动一个符号就会产生很大的不同。

That looks very, very similar to the definition for even, so make sure you can see where the difference is. Don’t be blasé about this kind of thing—sometimes shifting one symbol makes all the difference.

和前面一样，我们可以检查结论是否对满足前提的某些对象成立。假设我们取f ( x ) = x 2。那么 d f / d x = 2 x。这是否满足奇数的定义？是的，因为 2(− x ) 总是等于 −(2 x )。我们可以用图形来思考这个问题：

As before, we can check that the conclusion seems to hold for some of the objects that satisfy the premise. Suppose we take f(x) = x2. Then df / dx = 2x. Does that satisfy the definition of odd? Yes, it does, because 2(−x) is always equal to −(2x). We can think about this graphically:

其他偶函数的导数也会发生同样的事情（试试看）。但是，与前一个定理一样，我们可以整天构造偶函数、对它们进行微分并检查导数是否为奇数，而无法深入了解为什么结论总是成立。对于这个定理，如果你查看偶函数的图形并将导数视为梯度，你也许能够有所了解。但不幸的是，指着图形（“看！”）通常不被认为是证明事物的好方法。和以前一样，我们将在第 5 章中回顾这一点。

The same thing happens for the derivatives of other even functions (try it). As with the previous theorem, though, we could go on all day constructing even functions and differentiating them and checking that the derivative is odd, without getting any insight into why the conclusion always holds. For this theorem, you might be able to get an insight if you look at graphs of even functions and think about derivatives as gradients. Unfortunately, though, pointing at a graph (“Look!”) isn’t usually considered a good way of proving things. As before, we’ll come back to this in Chapter 5.

4.4 一个不太熟悉对象的定理

4.4 A theorem with less familiar objects

现在我们将讨论第四个定理，这个定理会更难，因为对象可能完全不熟悉。如果你还没有上过一门叫做“线性代数”的课程，试着了解一下这部分内容，但如果你没有掌握细节也不要担心。重点是你应该了解这个定理涉及的对象——一个映射、向量集和三个数字——以及我们如何构建这些对象的一般表示。（如果您发现自己完全不理解本节，请继续阅读本章的其余部分，因为它涉及更简单的想法。）

We will now consider the fourth theorem, which will be harder because the objects might be entirely unfamiliar. If you have not yet taken a course called Linear Algebra, try to get a sense of this section but don’t worry if you don’t grasp the detail. The main point is that you should understand what objects the theorem is about—a map, sets of vectors, and three numbers—and how we might construct general representations of these. (If it turns out that you don’t understand this section at all, do continue to the rest of the chapter, as it deals with simpler ideas.)

以下是该定理的再次陈述：

Here is the theorem statement again:

定理：如果Φ : U → V是线性变换，则 dim(ker( Φ )) + dim(im( Φ )) = dim( U )。

Theorem: If Φ: U → V is a linear transformation, then dim(ker(Φ)) + dim(im(Φ)) = dim(U).

和往常一样，我们将从前提开始。这里的前提引入了一个对象Φ : U → V，并告诉我们这是一个线性变换。和以前一样，符号Φ : U → V表示Φ是一个特定函数的名称，它将集合U中的每个元素映射到集合V中的一个元素。在这种情况下，U和V将是向量空间，即向量集（具有一些特殊属性）。所以我们可以用这样的图表来想象这种情况：

As usual, we will begin with the premise. Here the premise introduces an object Φ: U → V, and tells us that this is a linear transformation. As before, the notation Φ: U → V means that Φ is the name of a particular function that maps each element of the set U to an element of the set V. In this context U and V would be vector spaces, which are sets of vectors (with some particular properties). So we might imagine the situation using a diagram like this:

标有“ Φ ”的弯曲箭头表示Φ是从U到V的映射。该图的下部列出了U和V中的一些实际向量，直箭头表示Φ将U中的特定向量发送到V中的特定向量的方式（例如，Φ ( u 2 ) = v 1）。我使用了三个点的集合来表示可能还有更多未显示的向量。我还为U和V分别包含了一个零向量（您将了解到每个向量空间都必须有一个零向量）。请注意，没有什么可以阻止U中的多个向量映射到V中的同一个向量，并且没有必要将V中的每个向量映射到同一个向量。

The curved arrow labeled “Φ” indicates that Φ is a map from U to V. The lower part of the diagram lists some actual vectors in U and V, and the straight arrows represent the way that Φ sends particular vectors in U to particular vectors in V (for example, Φ(u2) = v1). I’ve used sets of three dots to indicate that there might be lots more vectors that are not shown. I’ve also included a zero vector for each of U and V (you will learn that every vector space has to have a zero vector). Notice that there’s nothing to stop multiple vectors in U mapping to the same vector in V, and that it’s not necessary that every vector in V gets mapped to.

因此，该图表示定理前提中描述的情况。结论是

Thus the diagram represents the situation described in the theorem premise. The conclusion says that

暗淡( ker ( Φ )) +暗淡(im( Φ )) =暗淡( U )。

dim(ker(ϕ)) +dim (im(Φ)) = dim(U).

与第 2 章一样，“dim” 是维度的缩写，“ker” 是核的缩写。此外，“im” 是图像的缩写，并且这些表达式中使用的括号可以读作“of”（例如，我们将f ( x ) 读作“ x的f ”）。因此，结论可以大声读作：

As in Chapter 2, “dim” is an abbreviation for dimension and “ker” is an abbreviation for kernel. Also, “im” is an abbreviation for image, and brackets used in expressions like these can be read as “of” (as is the case when we read f(x) as “f of x”). So the conclusion can be read out loud as:

phi 的核的维数加上 phi 的图像的维数等于U的维数。

The dimension of the kernel of phi plus the dimension of the image of phi is equal to the dimension of U.

我们可以通过查找一些定义将其与我们的图表联系起来。内核的定义是：

We can relate this to our diagram by looking up some definitions. The definition of kernel says:

定义：假设Φ : U → V是线性变换。那么

ker( Φ ) = { u ∈ U | Φ ( u ) = 0 V }。

Definition: Suppose Φ: U → V is a linear transformation. Then

ker(Φ) = {u ∈ U|Φ(u) = 0V}.

这意味着 ker( Φ ) 是U中所有满足ϕ ( u )= 0V的向量u的集合；也就是说，U中所有Φ映射到V中的零向量的向量。我们的图表显示了U中一些映射到0V 的向量，因此这些向量都将在 ker( Φ ) 中。

This means that ker(Φ) is the set of all vectors u in U such that ϕ(u) = 0V; that is, all the vectors in U that Φ maps to the zero vector in V. Our diagram shows some vectors in U that map to 0V, so these would all be in ker(Φ).

图像的定义是：

The definition of image says:

定义：假设Φ : U → V是线性变换。则im

( Φ ) = { v∈V | v = Φ ( u ) ，其中u∈U }。

Definition: Suppose Φ: U → V is a linear transformation. Then

im(Φ) = {v ∈ V|v = Φ(u) for some u ∈ U}.

这意味着 im( Φ ) 是V中所有向量v的集合，其中v等于U中某个向量u的Φ ( u ) ；也就是说，V中所有被来自U的某些东西“击中”的向量。我们的图表显示了V中一些被某些东西击中的向量，因此这些向量将出现在 im( Φ ) 中。

This means that im(Φ) is the set of all vectors v in V such that v is equal to Φ(u) for some vector u in U; that is, all the vectors in V that get “hit” by something coming from U. Our diagram shows some vectors in V that get hit by something, so these would be in im(Φ).

因此 ker( Φ ) 是U中的一组向量，im( Φ ) 是V中的一组向量。回想一下，U也是一组向量，结论将每个向量集的维数联系起来。建立维数的定义需要做更多工作，但（如第 2.4 节中所述），维数可以非正式地描述为“构建”所有其他向量所需的向量数量。这意味着 dim(ker( Φ ))、dim(im( Φ )) 和 dim( U ) 都是数字，而该定理的结论是将这些数字联系起来的陈述。

So ker(Φ) is a set of vectors in U, and im(Φ) is a set of vectors in V. Recall that U is a set of vectors too, and the conclusion relates the dimensions of each of these sets of vectors. Setting up a definition of dimension requires more work, but (as in Section 2.4), dimension can be described informally as the number of vectors you need to be able to “build” all the others. This means that dim(ker(Φ)), dim(im(Φ)), and dim(U) are all numbers, and the conclusion of this theorem is a statement relating these numbers.

这个解释涉及很多对象，你可能觉得它相当抽象。当你完整地学习这个主题时，你会学到很多向量空间和线性变换的具体例子，所以你将能够从这些例子以及这些一般表示的角度来思考它。

This explanation involved a lot of objects and you might have found it rather abstract. When you study this topic in full, you will learn about lots of specific examples of vector spaces and linear transformations, so you will be able to think about it in terms of those examples as well as in terms of these general representations.

4.5 逻辑语言：“如果”

4.5 Logical language: “if”

我发现思考对象常常能让我把新的陈述与我现有的知识联系起来。然而，我们也可以通过思考它们的逻辑结构来理解陈述。为此，我们需要注意逻辑语言的数学用法，我们将在本章的其余部分开始这个过程。我们将首先更仔细地研究if这个词在数学中的用法。

I find that thinking about objects often allows me to link new statements to my existing knowledge. However, we can also work towards understanding statements by thinking about their logical structures. To do so, we need to pay attention to mathematical uses of logical language, a process we will begin in the remainder of this chapter. We will start by looking more carefully at ways in which the word if is used in mathematics.

首先，考虑一个语句“如果 A 则 B”。这个语句有时写成“ A ⇒ B ”，大声读出来是“ A 意味着 B ”。使用箭头可以更清楚地表明我们可以认为这个语句有一个方向，这很重要，因为我们可能会遇到A ⇒ B为真语句但B ⇒ A不为真的情况。有时两个蕴涵都成立，例如以下情况：

First, consider a statement “If A then B.” This is sometimes written as “A ⇒ B,” which is read out loud as “A implies B.” The use of an arrow makes it clearer that we can think of this statement as having a direction, which is important because we might have a situation in which A ⇒ B is a true statement but B ⇒ A is not. Sometimes both implications do hold, as in this case:

x为偶数 ⇒ x 2为偶数。（真）

x is even ⇒ x2 is even. (true)

x 2为偶数 ⇒ x为偶数。（真）

x2 is even ⇒ x is even. (true)

然而，有时一个是正确的，而另一个则不正确，就像这种情况：

However, sometimes one is true but the other is not, as in this case:

这些陈述实际上有些不精确，因为我们没有指定对象x的类型。您可能假设在平方的情况下它必须是整数，在不等式的情况下它必须是实数，因为这是有意义的。但为了更清楚，我们可以这样写：

These statements are actually somewhat imprecise, because we have not specified what type of object x is. You probably assumed that it must be an integer in the squaring case and a real number in the inequalities case, since that would make sense. But, to be clearer, we could write things like:

这样做可以更容易地看出为什么这个特定的陈述是错误的：有些实数小于 5 但不小于 2。但是数学家在以笔记形式书写或预期解释很明显时有时会省略这样的短语。

Doing so makes it easier to see why this particular statement is false: there are some real numbers that are less than 5 but not less than 2. But mathematicians sometimes omit such phrases when writing in note form or when the intended interpretation is obvious.

当数学家想要同时讨论这两个蕴涵时，他们会使用双箭头表示“等同于”，或者写成“当且仅当”或其缩写“iff”。因此，以下是关于整数的相同（真实）陈述的不同写法：

When they want to discuss both implications at once, mathematicians use a double-headed arrow meaning “is equivalent to,” or write “if and only if” or its abbreviation “iff.” So these are different ways of writing the same (true) statement about integers:

x为偶数 ⇔ x 2为偶数。

x is even ⇔ x2 is even.

当且仅当x 2为偶数时， x才是偶数。

x is even if and only if x2 is even.

x为偶数当且仅当x 2为偶数。

x is even iff x2 is even.

我们之前在定义中看到过“当且仅当”这个短语。这里再举一个例子：

We have seen the phrase “if and only if” before, in our definitions. Here is one again:

定义：当且仅当存在整数k使得n = 2 k 时，数n为偶数。

Definition: A number n is even if and only if there exists an integer k such that n = 2k.

思考这个短语，将其定义拆分开来并分别写出每个含义可能会更有启发：

To think about the phrase, it might be illuminating to split up this definition and write each implication separately:

如果存在整数k使得n = 2 k ，则数n为偶数。

A number n is even if there exists an integer k such that n = 2k.

仅当存在整数k使得n = 2 k 时，数n才是偶数。

A number n is even only if there exists an integer k such that n = 2k.

这与我在第 3 章中的观点相关，我们希望我们的定义能够“捕捉”偶数，并排除非偶数。你能明白怎么做吗？

This is related to my point in Chapter 3 that we want our definition to “catch” the numbers that are even, and to exclude those that aren’t. Can you see how?

关于“ A当且仅当B ”形式的陈述，最后要注意的一点是，如果我们想证明它，我们可以采用两种方法之一。我们可以构造一个所有行都等价的证明，或者分别证明两个陈述A ⇒ B和B ⇒ A。第 6 章和第 8 章将更详细地讨论关于证明构造和编写的问题。

One final thing to note about a statement of the form “A if and only if B” is that, if we want to prove it, we can take one of two approaches. We can either construct a proof in which all the lines are equivalent to each other, or prove the two statements A ⇒ B and B ⇒ A separately. Issues about proof construction and writing are discussed in more detail in Chapters 6 and 8.

4.6 逻辑语言：“如果”的日常用法

4.6 Logical language: everyday uses of “if”

当我们考虑上一节中简单的数学语句时，“if”和“⇒”的用法听起来很简单。但我想提请大家注意两个潜在的混淆来源。

The uses of “if” and “⇒” sound straightforward when we are considering simple mathematical statements like those in the previous section. But I would like to draw your attention to two potential sources of confusion.

首先，需要进行一些思考，弄清楚“如果”和“仅当”中的哪一个对应于哪个蕴涵。你应该思考一下，也许可以思考哪一个可以替换这两个版本的相同（真实）语句中的“蕴涵”箭头：

First, some thought is necessary to sort out which of the “if” and the “only if” corresponds to which implication. You should think about this, perhaps by thinking about which one could replace the “implies” arrow in these two versions of the same (true) statement:

其次，事实证明，人们在日常生活中并不总是以数学方式解释“如果”。在日常对话中，我们往往说话不太准确，依靠上下文来帮助听众做出我们想要的解释。例如，假设有人对你说，

Second, it turns out that people do not always interpret “if” in a mathematical way in everyday life. In everyday conversation, we tend to speak rather imprecisely, relying on the context to help our listener make the interpretation we intend. For instance, imagine someone says to you,

如果你清理好汽车，那么你可以在周五晚上出去。

If you clean the car then you can go out on Friday night.

您可以从中合理地推断出，如果您不清洗汽车，那么您就不能在星期五晚上外出。显然，这就是说话者的意图。而其他人可以推断出，如果您在星期五被允许外出，那么您一定已经清洗了汽车。但事实上，这两个在逻辑上都不等同于原始陈述。也许最简单的理解方法是将逻辑与我们关于不平等的简单陈述并行看待：

You could reasonably infer from this that if you don’t clean the car then you can’t go out on Friday night. Clearly that is what the speaker intends. And someone else could infer that if you were allowed out on Friday, then you must have cleaned the car. But, in fact, neither of these is logically equivalent to the original statement. Perhaps the easiest way to see this is to look at the logic in parallel with our simple statements about inequalities:

每种情况下的第二和第三条陈述在逻辑上与第一条陈述并不相同。或者，你可以考虑一下日常情况，发现原始陈述根本没有提到如果你不清洁汽车会发生什么，所以如果你不清洁汽车但仍然被允许下车，就不会出现矛盾。从技术上讲，与你讨价还价的人应该说：

The second and third statements in each case are not logically the same as the first. Alternatively, you could think about the everyday situation, and see that the original statement says nothing at all about what happens if you don’t clean the car, so there would be no contradiction if you didn’t clean it but you were still allowed out. Technically, the person bargaining with you should really say:

如果且仅当您清洁了汽车后，您才可以在周五晚上出去。

You can go out on Friday night if and only if you clean the car.

当然，没有人会这样说话。这意味着你在准确解释逻辑语句方面可能没有你想象的那么熟练。不过，以数学正确的方式使用逻辑语言并不太难，因为在某些情况下，预期的自然语言解释与数学解释相同。考虑一下这句话：

Of course, no-one talks like that. Which means that you might have less practice than you think at accurately interpreting logical statements. Using logical language in a mathematically correct sense is not too hard, though, because there are cases in which the intended natural language interpretation is the same as the mathematical one. Consider this statement:

如果约翰来自卡迪夫，那么约翰就来自威尔士。

If John is from Cardiff then John is from Wales.

听到这句话的人都不会想到会得出以下这两个结论：

No-one hearing this would dream of inferring either of these:

如果约翰不是来自卡迪夫，那么约翰就不是来自威尔士。

If John is not from Cardiff then John is not from Wales.

如果约翰来自威尔士，那么约翰就来自卡迪夫。

If John is from Wales then John is from Cardiff.

但这些推论与我们在清洁汽车的陈述中看到的推论类似。确保你能明白是怎么回事。

But these inferences are analogous to those we looked at for the statement about cleaning the car. Make sure you can see how.

在卡迪夫情况下，该语句的自然解释与数学解释相同。我们还可以用它来说明关于不同蕴涵的逻辑等价性的一般观点。对于任何形式为A ⇒ B的语句，我们可以考虑三个相关语句，分别称为其逆命题、逆命题和逆否命题。以下是每个语句的含义，以卡迪夫示例为例：

In the Cardiff case, the natural interpretation of the statement is the same as the mathematical one. We can also use it to illustrate a general point about logical equivalence of different implications. For any statement of the form A ⇒ B we can consider three related statements called its converse, inverse, and contrapositive. This is what each one means, using the Cardiff example for illustration:

使用一个简单的数学例子来表达每个数字的含义：

This is what each one means using one of our simple mathematical examples instead:

这应该有助于您记住，如果A ⇒ B是真实陈述，则它的逆否命题也将为真（事实上，它们在逻辑上是等价的），但它的逆命题和它的逆元命题可能不为真。

This should help you remember that if A ⇒ B is a true statement, then its contrapositive will also be true (in fact, they are logically equivalent), but its inverse and its converse might not be.

最后，我要指出的是，你的教授在定理和证明中会谨慎使用“如果”和“当且仅当”，但在定义中可能不会那么谨慎。在定义中，他们可能只写“如果”，而不是“当且仅当”。这样做的原因与日常交流相同：每个人都知道，在定义中，这就是意图。

Finally, I should point out that your professor will be careful about uses of “if” and “if and only if” in theorems and proofs, but perhaps not so careful in definitions. In a definition, they might just write “if” instead of “if and only if.” This works for the same reason that everyday communication works: everyone knows that, in a definition, this is what is intended.

4.7 逻辑语言：量词

4.7 Logical language: quantifiers

接下来我想讨论一下“对于所有”和“存在”这两个短语。这些被称为量词，因为它们告诉我们正在谈论的东西有多少它们在数学中非常常见，所以我们用符号来表示它们：我们用“∀”（全称量词）表示“对于所有”，用“∃”（存在量词）表示“存在”。

Next I want discuss the phrases “for all” and “there exists.” These are called quantifiers, because they tell us how many of something we’re talking about. They are so common in mathematics that we have symbols for them: we use “∀” (the universal quantifier) to mean “for all” and “∃” (the existential quantifier) to mean “there exists.”

在简单的语句中，量词很容易想到。以下是一个简单的量化语句：

In simple statements, quantifiers are easy to think about. Here is a simple quantified statement:

在这个陈述中，我们写成 ∀ x ∈ ℤ来精确指定我们正在谈论的对象。我们可以只写 ∀ x，有时人们在陈述涉及的数字（或其他对象）的类型很明显时会这样做。但这样做可能会产生歧义。在这种情况下，该陈述也可能是关于实数或复数的，这引发了该陈述的真实性问题：“∀ x ∈ ℤ , x 2 ≥ 0”为真，“∀ x ∈ , x 2 ≥ 0”不为真。因此，具体一点是一种很好的做法。

In this statement, we write ∀x ∈ ℤ to specify exactly which objects we are talking about. We could just write ∀x, and sometimes people do when it is obvious what kind of numbers (or other objects) a statement is about. But doing so could be ambiguous. In this case, the statement could just as well be about real or complex numbers, which raises issues of the truth or otherwise of the statement: “∀x ∈ ℤ, x2 ≥ 0” is true, “∀x ∈ , x2 ≥ 0” is not. So it is good practice to be specific.

虽然我们在第 3 章中练习了一些定义，但更复杂的量化语句可能更难思考。以下是其中之一，用文字和缩写形式写成3形式，使用新的符号（在这种情况下可能更自然地读作“对于每个”）：

More complicated quantified statements can be harder to think about, although we had some practice with the definitions in Chapter 3. Here is one of these, written in words and in an abbreviated3 form using the new symbol (which might be more naturally read as “for every” in this case):

定义：函数f : →为增函数当且仅当对于每个x 1 , x 2 ∈使得x 1 < x 2，有f ( x 1 ) ≤ f ( x 2 )。

Definition: A function f: → is increasing if and only if for every x1, x2 ∈ such that x1 < x2, we have f(x1) ≤ f(x2).

定义（缩写）： f：→递增当且仅当∀ x 1，x 2 ∈使得x 1 < x 2，f ( x 1 ) ≤ f ( x 2 )。

Definition (abbreviated): f: → is increasing if and only if

∀x1, x2 ∈ such that x1 < x2, f(x1) ≤ f(x2).

这是一个涉及存在量词的简单量化语句：

Here is a simple quantified statement involving the existential quantifier:

这是一个正确的陈述，因为当数学家说“存在”时，他们的意思是“至少存在一个”。这里，有两个不同的整数x满足这个陈述。在其他情况下，可能有数百个。学生们有时会觉得奇怪，我们说“存在”而不指定数量，因为如果我们确切知道有多少，不说出来似乎很不礼貌。然而，高等数学至少部分是关于概念之间的一般关系，而不是寻找“答案”本身。如果我们看看我们的另一个定义（再次以文字和缩写形式显示），我们可以看到为什么使用“存在”而不进行额外说明是有意义的其他原因：

This is a true statement, because when mathematicians say “there exists,” they mean “there exists at least one.” Here, there are two different integers x that satisfy the statement. In other cases, there might be hundreds. Students sometimes find it strange that we say “there exists” without specifying how many because, if we know exactly how many there are, it seems rude not to say so. However, advanced mathematics is at least partly about general relationships between concepts, rather than about finding “answers” as such. We can see other reasons why it makes sense to use “there exists” without extra specification if we look at another of our definitions (again shown both in words and in an abbreviated form):

定义：当且仅当存在整数k使得n = 2 k 时，数n为偶数。

Definition: A number n is even if and only if there exists an integer k such that n = 2k.

定义（缩写）： n ∈ ℤ为偶数当且仅当 ∃ k ∈ ℤ使得n = 2 k。

Definition (abbreviated): n ∈ ℤ is even if and only if ∃k ∈ ℤ such that n = 2k.

此定义为我们提供了一种确定数字是否为偶数的统一方法。为了做出该决定，我们不在乎特定的k是什么，我们只关心是否存在。它还允许我们对所有偶数进行一般论证。我们可以这样开始：“假设n为偶数，所以 ∃ k ∈ ℤ使得n = 2 k ”（与我们在第 3.5 节中的论证进行比较）。在这种情况下，我们不想指定k是什么，因为我们希望随后的论证具有一般性，即它适用于满足条件的任何数字。

This definition gives us an agreed way of deciding whether a number is even or not. To make that decision, we do not care what the particular k is, we just care whether or not there is one. It also allows us to make general arguments about all even numbers. We might start by saying “Suppose n is even, so ∃k ∈ ℤ such that n = 2k” (compare with our argument in Section 3.5). In this case, we don’t want to specify what the k is because we want the ensuing argument to be general in the sense that it applies to any number that satisfies the condition.

4.8 逻辑语言：多重量词

4.8 Logical language: multiple quantifiers

一些数学陈述有多个量词。以下定义（同样是缩写版本）可能被描述为双重量化或具有两个嵌套量词：

Some mathematical statements have more than one quantifier. The following definition (again with an abbreviated version) might be described as doubly quantified or as having two nested quantifiers:

定义：集合X ⊆为开集合当且仅当对于每个x ∈ X存在d > 0 使得 ( x − d , x + d ) ⊆ X。

Definition: A set X ⊆ is open if and only if for every x ∈ X there exists d > 0 such that (x − d, x + d) ⊆ X.

定义（缩写）： X ⊆为开放当且仅当 ∀ x ∈ X ∃ d > 0 使得 ( x − d, x + d ) ⊆ X。

Definition (abbreviated): X ⊆ is open if and only if ∀ x ∈ X ∃d > 0 such that (x − d, x + d) ⊆ X.

当一个语句有多个量词时，它们出现的顺序非常重要。在这种情况下，定义是“对于每个x，存在一个d ”，在第 3 章中，我们设想取一个特定的x值并找到合适的d。我们知道，如果我们采用了不同的x，我们可能需要不同的d（可能是一个较小的 d ，如下面右图所示）。

When a statement has more than one quantifier, the order in which they appear is really important. In this case, the definition says “for every x, there exists a d” and in Chapter 3, we imagined taking a particular x value and finding an appropriate d. We know that if we had taken a different x, we might have needed a different d (perhaps a smaller one, as in the right-hand diagram below).

如果定义改为“每个x都存在一个d ”，数学家会将其理解为我们可以为每个x选择一个d。这完全不是一回事。

If the definition instead said “there exists a d for every x,” mathematicians would read that as meaning that we could select a single d that works for every x. That is not the same thing at all.

为了检查你对此的理解，请考虑以下两个陈述。一个是真的，另一个是假的。哪个是哪个？

To check your understanding of this, consider the following two statements. One is true, and the other is false. Which is which?

发现这很困难是正常的，因为在日常生活中我们可能不会区分这两个陈述。甚至在不知不觉中，我们都会做出看起来最现实的解释，而忽略逻辑正确性。因此，大多数人必须集中精力一段时间，才能掌握如何阅读字面意思并做出数学上正确的解释。（如果你不确定哪个陈述是正确的，请再考虑一下，然后问导师或教授。）

It is normal to find this difficult, because in everyday life we would probably not distinguish between these two statements. Without even realizing it, we would make the interpretation that seems most realistic, disregarding logical correctness. Most people therefore have to concentrate for a while before they get the hang of reading what is literally there and making the mathematically correct interpretation. (If you are unsure which statement is true, think about it some more then ask a tutor or professor.)

使用“⇒”、“∀”和“∃”等符号通常会缩短我们的数学句子。我发现使用在页面上看起来更短的东西更容易，所以我一直很喜欢这些符号，而且我倾向于在教学早期就介绍它们。其他教授认为学习新符号会干扰学生对数学思想的注意力，所以他们倾向于用文字写出所有内容。还有一些人用文字写出大多数内容，但使用其他类型的缩写。有时这只是一个风格问题，但有时是一个数学问题——不同的符号或缩写突出了数学的不同方面，有些方面可能被认为值得在某些课程中进行详细研究，但在其他课程中则不值得。所以你可能会在你的专业期间看到各种各样的写作风格。我的建议是注意课程教授似乎喜欢什么风格，并采用这种风格，但不要过分沉迷于它。归根结底，数学正确性清晰度才是最重要的，因此，只要您的论点合理且写得好，您就可以使用不同的缩写。

Using symbols like “⇒”, “∀”, and “∃” often shortens our mathematical sentences. I find it easier to work with something that looks shorter on the page, so I have always liked these symbols, and I tend to introduce them early on in my teaching. Other professors think that learning the new symbols interferes with students’ concentration on the mathematical ideas, so they tend to write everything out in words. Still others write most things in words but make other types of abbreviation. Sometimes this is just a style issue, but sometimes it is a mathematical one—different symbols or abbreviations highlight different aspects of the mathematics, and some aspects might be considered worthy of detailed study in some courses but not in others. So you will probably see a variety of writing styles during your major. My advice would be to pay attention to what style the course professor seems to favor, and to adopt that style without being obsessive about it. At the end of the day, mathematical correctness and clarity is what counts, so you can abbreviate differently provided that your arguments are sound and well-written.

4.9 定理重述

4.9 Theorem rephrasing

虽然我在本章中以“如果……那么……”的形式写了定理，但你也可能会看到不同的表述。以下是一些常见的表述：

Although I have written the theorems in this chapter in the form “If …then …,” you might also see different phrasings. Here are some common ones:

定理：如果f是偶函数，则就是奇函数。

Theorem: If f is an even function, then is an odd function.

定理：设f为偶函数，则为奇函数。

Theorem: Suppose that f is an even function. Then is an odd function.

定理：每个偶函数都有一个奇导数。

Theorem: Every even function has an odd derivative.

这些都会被解释为同一件事：每个情况下的前提是函数是偶函数，结论是其导数是奇函数。我们不只是选择一种形式并坚持使用这种形式似乎很奇怪，但有时，一个版本或另一个版本听起来更自然，所以数学家喜欢这种灵活性。

These would all be interpreted to mean the same thing: the premise in each case is that the function is even, and the conclusion is that its derivative is odd. It might seem strange that we don’t just pick one form and stick to it but, sometimes, one version or another sounds more natural, so mathematicians like to have this flexibility.

你还将看到不同类型的定理。例如，存在定理如下：

You will also see theorems of different types. There are, for instance, existence theorems like this one:

定理：存在一个数x使得x 3 = x。

Theorem: There exists a number x such that x3 = x.

证明此类定理的一种方法是生成一个满足该定理的对象：在本例中，数字 1 即可。这并不总是那么容易，但重要的是要认识到它可能很容易，因为有时学生在做复杂的事情时会陷入困境，而一个简单的答案就可以了。

One way to prove a theorem like this is just to produce an object that satisfies it: the number 1 would do, in this case. It’s not always that easy, but it’s important to recognize that it might be, because sometimes students tie themselves in knots doing complicated things when a simple answer would do.

还有一些关于不存在的定理，例如这个：

There are also theorems about non-existence, like this one:

定理：不存在最大的素数。

Theorem: There does not exist a largest prime number.

事实上，只要稍加思考，非存在定理就可以用我们的标准形式重新表述。例如，这个可以用全称量词来写：

In fact, with a bit of thought, non-existence theorems can be restated in our standard form. This one, for instance, could be written with a universal quantifier:

定理：对于每个素数n ，都存在一个素数p使得p > n。

Theorem: For every prime number n there exists a prime number p such that p > n.

然后它可以被改写成我们最初的形式：

Then it could be rephrased into our initial form:

定理：如果n是素数，则存在另一个素数p使得p > n。

Theorem: If n is a prime number then there exists another prime number p such that p > n.

当我们想要开始证明某件事时，这些改写可能性非常有用：有时用不同的方式改写可以让我们得到关于值得尝试的合理事物的不同想法。然而，我们经常可以改写这一事实并不意味着你可以草率地写数学文章。草率的改写很容易改变陈述的逻辑意义。一旦你能够熟练地以数学方式使用逻辑语言，你就会发现你可以切换形式而不会破坏其含义。在那之前，你应该仔细考虑逻辑的精确性。

These rephrasing possibilities can be very useful when we want to start proving something: sometimes rewriting in a different way can give us different ideas about sensible things to try. However, the fact that we can often rephrase does not mean that you can be sloppy about your mathematical writing. Sloppy paraphrasing can easily change the logical meaning of a statement. Once you become fluent in using logical language in a mathematical way, you will find that you can switch forms without doing violence to the meaning. Until that point you should think carefully about logical precision.

4.10 理解：逻辑形式和含义

4.10 Understanding: logical form and meaning

逻辑术语具有精确含义的一大好处是，它为我们带来了很多机械推理能力。例如，如果我们知道A ⇒ B和B ⇒ C，那么我们可以推断出A ⇒ C。即使A、B和C是我们从未见过且不理解的非常复杂的对象，我们也可以做到这一点。同样，如果我们想证明A ⇒ B形式的陈述，但进展不大，我们可以记住逆否命题（非B ⇒ 非A）始终等同于原命题，并尝试证明这一点。

One great thing about having precise meanings for logical terms is that it buys us a lot of mechanistic reasoning power. For instance, if we know that A ⇒ B and that B ⇒ C, then we can deduce that A ⇒ C. We can do this even if A, B, and C are about really complicated objects that we’ve never met before and we don’t understand. Similarly, if we would like to prove a statement of the form A ⇒ B, but we are not making much progress, we can remember that the contrapositive (not B ⇒ not A) is always equivalent to the original, and try proving that instead.

这就是我说我们可以通过观察语句的逻辑结构来获得有价值的理解的意思。如果我们注意涉及“如果”或量词的结构，我们可以利用这些推理中的规律性。这（至少部分）是人们在谈论形式工作时的意思：我们可以专注于句子的逻辑形式，暂时忽略其有意义的内容。当然，我们不必忽略含义，对于上述大部分讨论，您可能也在考虑含义。但注意逻辑形式对于正确理解至关重要。有些学生在这方面很松懈；在阅读数学时，他们主要看符号，忽略或略过单词。这会使他们的理解有误，写作不准确，因为他们混淆了重要的量词或含义。例如，我最近的一次考试中有一道题要求学生陈述这个定理：

This is what I mean when I say that we can develop valuable understanding by looking at the logical structure of a statement. If we pay attention to constructions involving “if” or quantifiers, we can make use of such regularities in our reasoning. This is (at least partly) what people mean when they talk about formal work: we can concentrate on the logical form of a sentence and temporarily ignore its meaningful content. We don’t have to ignore the meaning, of course, and for most of the above discussion you were probably thinking about meanings as well. But attending to logical form is vital for proper understanding. Some students are lax about this; when reading mathematics, they look mostly at the symbols, ignoring or glossing over the words. This can make their understanding faulty and their writing inaccurate, because they mix up important quantifiers or implications. For instance, a question on one of my recent examinations required students to state this theorem:

罗尔定理：设f : [ a, b ] →在 [ a, b ]上连续，在 ( a, b ) 上可微，且f ( a ) = f ( b )。则 ∃ c ∈ ( a, b ) 使得f ′( c ) = 0。

Rolle’s Theorem: Suppose that f: [a, b] → is continuous on [a, b] and differentiable on (a, b) and that f(a) = f(b). Then ∃c ∈ (a, b) such that f′(c) = 0.

一些学生犯了错误，写了如下内容：

A few students made errors, writing things like this:

罗尔定理：设f : [ a, b ] →在 [ a, b ]上连续，在 ( a, b ) 上可微，则f ( a ) = f ( b ) 且 ∃ c ∈ ( a, b ) 使得f ′( c ) = 0。

Rolle’s Theorem: Suppose that f: [a, b] → is continuous on [a, b] and differentiable on (a, b). Then f(a) = f(b) and ∃c ∈ (a, b) such that f′(c) = 0.

通过查看它们的逻辑形式，我们可以看出它们是不同的：正确版本中的一个前提出现在第二个版本中，而作为结论的一部分出现（仔细查看以确保你能看到这一点）。显然，这必须产生非常重要的区别，因此错误版本不可能在逻辑上等同于正确版本。尽管如此，它仍然可能是一个有效的定理。然而，在这种情况下，它不是，我们可以通过例子来思考。在错误的版本中，前提引入了一个函数f，该函数在一个区间上定义，并且在这个区间上连续且可微。结论声称函数值在区间的端点相等，但这不可能以有效的方式从前提中得出，因为有许多函数和区间满足前提但没有这个属性。例如，f ( x ) = x 2在 [0, 2] 上是连续的，在 (0, 2) 上是可微的，但f (0) = f (2)肯定不是这样的。我明白学生一开始可能会写出错误的版本，但正在思考其写作含义的人在重读时应该能够识别此类错误。

We can see that these are different by looking at their logical forms: one of the premises in the correct version appears instead as part of the conclusion in the second (look carefully to make sure that you can see this). Clearly that must make a very important difference, so the incorrect version cannot possibly be logically equivalent to the correct version. Nonetheless, it might still be a valid theorem. In this case, however, it isn’t, which we can see by thinking in terms of examples. In the incorrect version, the premises introduce a function f that is defined on an interval and is continuous and differentiable on this interval. The conclusion claims that the function values are equal at the endpoints of the interval, but this cannot possibly follow in a valid way from the premises, because there are many functions and intervals that satisfy the premises but do not have this property. For example, f(x) = x2 is continuous on [0, 2] and differentiable on (0, 2), but it certainly isn’t the case that f(0) = f(2). I can see how a student might write the incorrect version in the first place, but someone who is thinking about the meaning of their writing should recognize such errors when rereading.

这让我们回到这样一个观点：逻辑形式和示例对象都有助于数学理解，尽管关注其中任何一个都有不同的优点和缺点。如果你主要看例子，你可能会觉得自己理解了，但你可能无法理解陈述的完整概括性，或者很难看清整个课程的逻辑结构。如果你主要看形式论证，你可能会看到一切在逻辑上是如何结合在一起的，但你可能会发现自己抱怨它非常抽象，你真的不明白发生了什么。你对这些问题的体验可能因课程而异，因为有些教授会给出很多例子并画出很多图表，而其他教授则会给出更正式的演示。如果教授的方法与你喜欢的理解方式不符，你可能会发现加强对示例对象和形式工作之间联系的理解很有用。在这本书中，我们已经做了很多这样的工作；在第 1 部分的剩余部分中，我们将逐步将重点转向有效地使用形式数学。

This brings us back to the idea that both logical form and example objects can contribute to mathematical understanding, though focusing on each has different advantages and disadvantages. If you look mainly at examples, you might feel that you understand, but you might fail to appreciate the full generality of a statement or find it difficult to see the logical structure of a whole course. If you look mainly at formal arguments, you might be able to see how everything fits together logically, but you might find yourself complaining that it is very abstract and that you don’t really understand what is going on. Your experience of these issues will probably vary from course to course, because some professors give lots of examples and draw lots of diagrams, whereas others give a much more formal presentation. If a professor’s approach does not match your preferred way of developing understanding, you might find it useful to strengthen your understanding of the links between the example objects and the formal work. In this book, we have done a lot of that already; in the remainder of Part 1, we will shift our focus progressively towards working effectively with formal mathematics.

概括

SUMMARY

• 定理的前提介绍了定理所涉及的对象并告诉我们它们的属性。结论告诉我们从前提中逻辑上可以得出的结论（它并没有告诉我们为什么可以得出，只是告诉我们确实可以得出）。

• The premise of a theorem introduces the objects the theorem is about and tells us about their properties. The conclusion tells us something that follows logically from the premises (it doesn’t tell us why it follows, just that it does).

• 我们可以通过思考定理如何应用于实例来加深对定理的理解。思考一系列实例通常是一个好主意；不同的表示方法也可能有用。

• We can develop understanding of theorems by thinking about how they apply to examples. It is often a good idea to think about a range of examples; different representations might be useful too.

• 查看大量的例子并不一定能让我们了解为什么定理的结论总是成立，而这才是数学家真正感兴趣的。

• Looking at lots of examples does not necessarily give any insight into why the conclusion of a theorem must always hold, which is what mathematicians are really interested in.

• “若A则B ”形式的语句有时写为“ A ⇒ B ”（“ A蕴涵B ”）。有时“ A ⇒ B为真，但B ⇒ A不为真”。要谈论两个方向，我们说“当且仅当”或使用符号“⇔”。

• Statements of the form “If A then B” are sometimes written as “A ⇒ B” (“A implies B”). Sometimes “A ⇒ B is true but B ⇒ A is not. To talk about both directions, we say “if and only if” or use the symbol “⇔.”

• 在日常生活中，人们使用“if”不准确；而在数学中，他们不会这样做。如果你想正确地解释数学陈述，意识到这一区别很重要。

• In everyday life, people use “if” imprecisely; in mathematics they do not. It is important to be aware of this distinction if you want to interpret mathematical statements correctly.

• 我们用符号“∀”表示“对于所有”，用符号“∃”表示“存在”。这些被称为量词，它们经常出现在数学语句中。当使用多个量词时，它们的顺序非常重要。

• We use the symbol “∀” for “for all” and the symbol “∃” for “there exists.” These are called quantifiers, and they appear frequently in mathematical statements. When more than one quantifier is used, their order is very important.

• 并非所有定理都以“如果A则B ”的形式写出。有些定理具有不同的结构或表述方式。解释时应小心谨慎，因为一个小小的变化可能会极大地改变含义。

• Not all theorems are written in the form “If A then B.” Some have different structures or are phrased differently. You should be careful when paraphrasing because a small change can dramatically alter the meaning.

• 通过观察逻辑形式和研究定理与示例对象的关系，可以培养理解力。这些策略是互补的，教授们的侧重点各不相同。

• Understanding can be developed by looking at logical form and by examining how a theorem relates to example objects. These strategies are complementary and professors vary in which they emphasize.

进一步阅读

FURTHER READING

要进一步了解数学语句的逻辑结构，请尝试：

For more on understanding the logical structures of mathematical statements, try:

• Houston, K. (2009).如何像数学家一样思考。剑桥：剑桥大学出版社。

• Houston, K. (2009). How to Think Like a Mathematician. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.

• Allenby, RBJT (1997)。数字与证明。牛津：Butterworth Heinemann。

• Allenby, R.B.J.T. (1997). Numbers & Proofs. Oxford: Butterworth Heinemann.

• Vivaldi, F. (2011)。数学写作：本科课程。在线网址：http://www.maths.qml.ac.uk/~fv/books/mw/mwbook.pdf。

• Vivaldi, F. (2011). Mathematical Writing: An Undergraduate Course. Online at http://www.maths.qml.ac.uk/~fv/books/mw/mwbook.pdf.

• Velleman, DJ (2004)。如何证明：一种结构化方法。剑桥：剑桥大学出版社。

• Velleman, D.J. (2004). How to Prove It: A Structured Approach. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.

• Epp, SS (2004)。离散数学及其应用。Belmont, CA: Thompson-Brooks/Cole。

• Epp, S.S. (2004). Discrete Mathematics with Applications. Belmont, CA: Thompson-Brooks/Cole.

第五章

证明

CHAPTER 5

Proof

本章讲述数学家为何努力证明事物，以及他们如何证明。它描述了常见的本科证明任务和解决这些任务的有用策略。它还解释了为什么数学家有时会要求学生证明显而易见的事情，以及当你遇到一个显然正确但结果却是错误的结果时如何应对。

This chapter is about why mathematicians make the effort to prove things, and how they do so. It describes common undergraduate proof tasks and useful strategies for tackling these. It also explains why mathematicians sometimes ask students to prove obvious things, and how to respond when you come across a result that seems obviously true but that turns out to be false.

5.1 高中数学中的证明

5.1 Proofs in high school mathematics

多年来，您一直在构建数学证明。例如，为了证明方程x 2 − 20 x + 10 = 0 的解为和，您需要编写如下代码：

You have been constructing mathematical proofs for many years. For instance, to do the calculations needed to prove that the solutions to the equation x2 − 20x + 10 = 0 are and , you would write something like this:

此计算使用的方法大家都同意是有效的，因此它涵盖了证明解决方案确实如所声称的那样所需的一切。为了使其看起来更像上层证明，我们可以将其重写如下：

This calculation uses methods that everyone agrees are valid, so it captures everything we need for a proof that the solutions really are as claimed. To make it look more like an upper-level proof, we could rewrite it like this:

声明：如果x 2 − 20 x + 10 = 0 则或。

Claim: If x2 − 20x + 10 = 0 then or .

证明：假设x 2 − 20 x + 10 = 0。

Proof: Suppose that x2 − 20x + 10 = 0.

然后利用二次公式，

Then, using the quadratic formula,

这个版本明确地陈述了主张，以前提（“假设x 2 − 20 x + 2 = 0”）开头，并使用一些文字来证明那些更复杂或不太明显的步骤。

This version explicitly states the claim, begins with the premise (“Suppose that x2 − 20x + 2 = 0”), and contains a few words to justify those steps that are more sophisticated or less obvious.

我的观点是，证明本身并没有什么神秘之处。大多数高中数学确实不是以这种方式呈现的，但大多数数学也可以这样呈现。我之所以这么说，是因为在高级课程中，你遇到的很多数学知识都会以这种形式呈现；你的讲义将充满定理和证明。这似乎是一个相当突然的变化，一些学生认为证明是一门神秘的黑暗艺术，只有非常有特权的人才能接触到。事实并非如此。在上述情况下，它真正涉及的只是以更专业的数学方式写作——如果你愿意的话，写作方式可以不那么像学生，而更像教科书。

My point is that there is nothing inherently mysterious about proofs. It is certainly true that most high school mathematics is not presented in this way, but it’s also true that most of it could be. I say this because, in upper-level courses, lots of the mathematics you meet will be presented in this form; your lecture notes will be full of theorems and proofs. This might seem rather an abrupt change, and some students get the idea that proof is a mysterious dark art to which only the very privileged have access. It isn’t. In cases like the one above, all it really involves is writing in a more mathematically professional way—writing less like a student and more like a textbook, if you like.

这并不是要贬低本科生在处理证明时面临的真正困难。显然，上面的例子很简单，而高级课程要求你理解和构建的证明通常（尽管并非总是）要困难得多。你可能需要一段时间才能习惯以这种方式呈现的数学，并更专业地编写自己的数学。但没有理由认为你无法做到这一点，本章讨论了一些你可以注意的事情，以便快速习惯它。

This is not to belittle the genuine difficulties that undergraduate students face when handling proofs. Obviously the example above is a simple one, and the proofs you are asked to understand and construct in upper-level courses will often (though not always) be much harder. It might take you a while to get used to digesting mathematics presented in this way, and to writing your own mathematics more professionally. But there is no reason to think you won’t manage it, and this chapter discusses some things you could pay attention to in order to get used to it quickly.

5.2 证明定义得到满足

5.2 Proving that a definition is satisfied

经常有人要求你做的一件事是证明一个数学对象满足一个定义。不过，问题不会这样表述。它只会说这样的话：“证明集合 (2,5) 是开放的。”你必须将其解释为“证明集合 (2,5) 满足开放的定义”，并回顾开放集的定义，以确保你清楚这涉及什么。这听起来很简单，但我经常看到面对“证明集合 (2,5) 是开放的”这样的指令，学生不知道该怎么做。如果你不知道如何开始解决任何证明问题，你的第一个想法应该是，定义说了什么？

One thing you’ll often be asked to do is to prove that a mathematical object satisfies a definition. The question won’t be phrased like that, though. It will just say something like, “Prove that the set (2,5) is open.” You will have to interpret this to mean “Prove that the set (2,5) satisfies the definition of open,” and review the definition of open set to make sure you are clear about what this involves. That sounds simple, but I have often seen students who, faced with an instruction like “Prove that the set (2,5) is open,” don’t know what to do. If you don’t know how to start on any proof problem, your first thought should often be, what does the definition say?

我们看到了相关的定义，它说：

We have seen the relevant definition, which says:

定义：集合X ⊆为开放当且仅当 ∀ x ∈ X ∃ d > 0 并且 ( x − d, x + d ) ⊆ X。

Definition: A set X ⊆ is open if and only if ∀x ∈ X ∃d > 0 such that (x − d, x + d) ⊆ X.

在第 3 章中，我们确信 (2,5) 满足这个定义。但是我们应该如何写出证明呢？通常最好的建议是遵循定义本身的结构。我们想要证明 (2,5) 是开放的，所以我们想要证明对于每个x ∈ (2,5)，存在d > 0 使得 ( x − d, x + d ) ⊆ (2,5)。当我们想要证明某个东西对于某个集合中的每个x都为真时，我们通常通过引入一个证明来开始我们的证明，如下所示：

In Chapter 3 we convinced ourselves that (2,5) does satisfy this definition. But how should we write a proof? Often the best advice is to follow the structure of the definition itself. We want to prove that (2,5) is open, so we want to show that for every x ∈ (2,5) there exists d > 0 such that (x − d, x + d) ⊆ (2,5). When we want to show something is true for every x in some set, we usually start our proof by introducing one, like this:

声明：（2,5）是一个开集。

Claim: (2,5) is an open set.

证明：设x ∈ (2,5) 为任意数。

Proof: Let x ∈ (2,5) be arbitrary.

这里，任意意味着我们取任意的x，而不是某个特定的 x 或具有特殊属性的 x 。没有必要这样写——很多人会直接写“让x ∈ (2,5)”——但它确实强调了随后的论证适用于集合中的任何x 。

Here, arbitrary means that we are taking any old x, not some specific one or one with special properties. It is not necessary to write this—lots of people would just write “Let x ∈ (2,5)”—but it does emphasize that the ensuing argument will work for any x in the set.

现在我们需要证明存在一个合适的d。在第 3 章中，我们通过思考一个图表说服了自己这是可能的。这对于非正式理解来说很好，但在编写证明时我们应该更精确。这样做不需要很复杂，因为证明某物存在的最简单方法就是产生一个。在这种情况下，我们需要产生一个适用于我们的x 的d。这个d将依赖于x，而做到这一点的一种方法是选择d作为两个距离 5 − x和x − 2中的最小值（想想为什么）。所以我们可以这样写出其余的证明：

Now we need to show the existence of an appropriate d. In Chapter 3, we convinced ourselves that this was possible by thinking about a diagram. That’s fine for informal understanding, but when writing proofs we should be more precise. Doing so need not be complicated, because the simplest way to show the existence of something is to produce one. In this case, we need to produce a d that will work for our x. This d will depend on x, and one way to do it is to pick d to be the minimum of the two distances 5 − x and x − 2 (think about why). So we might write the rest of our proof like this:

声明：（2,5）是一个开集。

Claim: (2,5) is an open set.

证明：设x ∈ (2,5) 为任意数。

Proof: Let x ∈ (2,5) be arbitrary.

令d为 5 − x和x − 2中的最小值。

Let d be the minimum of 5 − x and x − 2.

然后 ( x − d, x + d ) ⊆ (2,5)。

Then (x − d, x + d) ⊆ (2,5).

所以 ∀ x ∈ (2,5) ∃ d > 0 使得 ( x − d, x + d ) ⊆ (2,5)

So ∀x ∈ (2,5) ∃d > 0 such that (x − d, x + d) ⊆ (2,5)

所以 (2,5) 是一个开集。

So (2,5) is an open set.

请注意，此证明反映了定义的顺序和结构。我们为所有x展示一些东西，因此我们从任意一个开始。我们展示对于这个x，存在一个合适的d，因此我们生成一个。因此，证明的结构对数学家来说是显而易见的，所以你实际上不需要写出“所以 ∀ x ∈ (2,5)…”这句话，但你可能会发现它对你自己思考很有帮助。

Notice that this proof reflects the order and structure of the definition. We are showing something for all x, so we start with an arbitrary one. We are showing that for this x, an appropriate d exists, so we produce one. Because of this, the structure of the proof will be obvious to a mathematician, so you don’t really need to write the line “So ∀x ∈ (2,5)…,” but you might find it helpful for your own thinking.

有些人倾向于在证明中附上图表，而有些人则不这样做。这是因为图表虽然能说明问题，但不是必需的，也不能代替正确地写出证明；数学家希望看到书面论证与适当的定义有明确的联系。话虽如此，我曾经在考试中给过分，因为有人通过绘制图表表现出了一些理解，即使他们没有成功地将其变成完整的书面证明。这种情况发生的程度可能取决于主题，以及你的教授希望如何平衡概念理解的证据和写出好证明的能力的证据。

Some people tend to include diagrams along with proofs like this, and some don’t. That’s because diagrams can be illuminating, but they are not necessary, and they are not a substitute for writing a proof out properly; mathematicians want to see a written argument that is clearly linked to the appropriate definition. That said, I have been known to give points in an exam when someone has shown some understanding by drawing a diagram, even if they haven’t succeeded in turning this into a full written proof. The extent to which this happens will probably depend on the subject matter and on the way your professor wants to balance evidence of conceptual understanding with evidence of ability to write good proofs.

5.3 证明一般性命题

5.3 Proving general statements

数学教授会希望你构造特定对象满足特定定义的证明，他们希望你找到标准问题或方程的解，如二次公式所示。但他们通常对一般结果更感兴趣：对一整类对象都成立的定理。幸运的是，你也有过这种证明所需的推理经验。例如，你可能见过这样的练习：

Mathematics professors will want you to construct proofs that specific objects satisfy specific definitions, and they will want you to find solutions to standard problems or equations, as in the quadratic formula illustration. But they are often more interested in general results: in theorems that hold for a whole class of objects. Fortunately, you’ve had experience of the reasoning needed for this type of proof, too. For instance, you might have seen an exercise like this:

证明 cos(3 θ ) = 4 cos 3 θ − 3 cos θ。

Show that cos(3θ) = 4 cos3θ − 3 cosθ.

“展示” 是一个很大的启示——数学家将其用作“证明”的同义词。请注意，虽然没有明确说明，但其目的是证明该方程对θ的每个可能值都成立。这个练习可以用标准三角恒等式来解决，在回答中你可能会写出一系列方程。同样，这些方程也可以写成定理和证明的形式：

The “show” is a big giveaway—mathematicians use it as a synonym for “prove.” And notice that, although this is not explicitly stated, the idea is to show that the equation holds for every possible value of θ. The exercise can be tackled using the standard trigonometric identities, and in answering it you would probably write a series of equations. Again, these could be written in the form of a theorem and proof:

定理：对于每个θ ε，cos(3 θ ) = 4 cos 3 θ − 3 cos θ。

Theorem: For every θ ∈ , cos(3θ) = 4 cos3 θ − 3 cos θ.

证明：设θ ∈任意，则

Proof: Let θ ∈ be arbitrary. Then

因为这个论证对θ的每个值都成立，所以我们证明了一个恒等式（如果某物在所有情况下都相等，则我们说它等于其他东西）。当数学家想要指出一个方程是恒等式时，他们有时会使用带一条横线的等号，像这样：cos(3 θ ) ≡ 4 cos 3 θ − 3 cos θ。上面证明中的所有等号都可以用这个符号替换，但是该证明以“让θ ∈任意”开头，使一般性变得清晰。顺便说一句，你不需要在最后写上“按要求”。有时人们会就此打住，有时他们会画一个小方块，有时他们会写上“QED”。

Because this argument holds for every value of θ, we have proved an identity (we say something is identically equal to something else if it is equal in all cases). When mathematicians want to draw attention to the fact that an equation is an identity, they sometimes use an equals sign with an extra bar, like this: cos(3θ) ≡ 4 cos3 θ − 3 cos θ. All of the equals signs in the proof above could be replaced with this symbol, but instead the proof makes the generality clear by starting with “Let θ ∈ be arbitrary.” Incidentally, you don’t need to write “as required” at the end. Sometimes people just stop, sometimes they draw a little square, and sometimes they write “QED.”

因为它适用于θ的所有值，所以这个论证在逻辑上不同于我们对二次方程的论证——我们可以写下“ x 2 − 20 x + 10 = 0”，但我们知道有很多x值不成立。我们刚刚证明的定理的普遍性使它更像第 4 章中的定理，并且在数学上更有趣。但是，我们可以通过检查二次公式本身来查看类似级别的普遍性。二次公式在数学上真正有趣的地方在于它总是有效。当你停下来思考它时，你会发现它非常强大。我们有一个简单的公式，可以让我们找到无穷多个方程的解。当我们想要解一个方程时，我们只需将适当的数字代入公式，30 秒后我们就知道答案。我知道你已经完全习惯了数学就是这样的——你知道各种东西的一大堆公式，所以你可能一点也不惊讶。但必须有人发现这些公式。第一个发现这些公式的人不是从课本上读到的，也不是老师教的——他们是自己算出来的。以二次公式为例，某些类型的二次方程的显式解出现在公元七世纪，而我们所知道的公式出现在十七世纪。所以，当你解二次方程时，你使用的知识是人类大约 400 年来才掌握的。你在本科阶段学到的很多东西都是更新的。

Because it applies to all values of θ, this argument is logically different from what we did with the quadratic equation—we can write down “x2 − 20x + 10 = 0” but we know that there are lots of values of x for which this does not hold. The generality of the theorem we just proved makes it more like those in Chapter 4, and more mathematically interesting. We can, however, look at a similar level of generality by examining the quadratic formula itself. What’s really mathematically interesting about the quadratic formula is that it always works. When you stop to think about it, this is very powerful. We have a simple formula that allows us to find solutions to infinitely many equations. When we want to solve one, we just substitute the appropriate numbers into the formula, and 30 seconds later we know the answers. I realize that you are completely accustomed to mathematics being like this—you know a whole host of formulas for all kinds of things, so you are probably not amazed by it at all. But someone had to discover those formulas. The first people to do this didn’t read them in a textbook or get told them by a teacher—they worked them out for themselves. In the case of the quadratic formula, explicit solutions for some types of quadratic equation appeared in the seventh century, and the formula as we know it appeared in the seventeenth century. So, when you solve a quadratic equation you are using knowledge that has only been available to humanity for around 400 years. And much of what you’ll learn as an undergraduate is much newer.

无论如何，高等数学不太强调使用公式进行具体计算，而更强调理解这些公式的来源并证明它们总是有效的。你可能已经看到了二次公式有效的证明。但是，如果你倾向于忽略考试中不会出现的内容，你可能没有注意到，所以我们现在就来看一个。我们在第4 章中陈述了相应的定理：

In any case, in advanced mathematics there is less emphasis on using formulas to do specific calculations, and more emphasis on understanding where those formulas come from and proving that they always work. You might already have seen a proof that the quadratic formula works. But, if you tend to ignore things that will not be on an exam, you might not have noticed, so we will look at one now. We stated the appropriate theorem in Chapter 4:

定理：如果ax 2 + bx + c = 0，则

Theorem: If ax2 + bx + c = 0, then

事实上，我们可以通过指定x为复数来改进这一点，并写出：

In fact, we can improve this by specifying that x is a complex number, and write:

定理：假设x ∈ 。

Theorem: Suppose that x ∈ .

如果ax 2 + bx + c = 0，则

If ax2 + bx + c = 0, then

证明：假设x ∈。那么

Proof: Suppose that x ∈ . Then

关于这个证明，需要注意的一点是，它与三角恒等式的证明不同，因为我们使用符号“=”和“⇒”，这反映了我们要证明的结构。对于三角恒等式，我们证明一个等式总是成立。因此，我们从等式的一侧开始，并表明我们可以通过一系列等式得到另一侧。对于二次公式，我们证明如果原始方程成立，则 x必须取某些值。因此，我们从整个方程开始，并在每一步中表明当前方程的正确性意味着下一个方程的正确性。

One thing to notice about this proof is that it differs from that for the trigonometric identity in the way we use the symbols “=” and “⇒”, and that this reflects the structure of what we are proving. For the trigonometric identity, we were proving that an equation always holds. Thus we began with one side of the equation and showed that we could get to the other side through a series of equalities. For the quadratic formula, we are proving that if the original equation holds, then x must take on certain values. Thus we start with the whole equation, and show at each step that the truth of the current equation implies the truth of the next one.

另一件需要注意的事情是，你可能发现自己反复阅读了证明的各个部分好几遍。特别是，你可能会发现更容易看出

Another thing to notice is that you probably found yourself reading back and forth over parts of the proof a few times. In particular, you might have found it easier to see that

从右到左（相乘）而不是从左到右。事实上，从下到上阅读可能比从上到下更容易检查代数运算。这可能会让你想知道我们为什么这样写。原因是我们希望逻辑与整个定理“流动”。定理说，如果ax 2 + bx + c = 0，那么关于x值的结论就会随之而来。我们希望我们的证明能够反映出这种结构：从前提开始，然后继续通过采取有效的步骤直到得出结论。我们将在第 8 章中回顾关于证明顺序的问题。

by going from right to left (multiplying out) rather than from left to right. Indeed, it may be easier to check the algebraic manipulations by reading from bottom to top than from top to bottom. That might make you wonder why we write it this way around. The reason is that we want the logic to “flow” in relation to the whole theorem. The theorem says that if ax2 + bx + c = 0, then the conclusion about the x values follows. We want our proof to reflect that structure: to start with the premise and to proceed by taking valid steps until we reach the conclusion. We will come back to issues about order in proofs in Chapter 8.

5.4 使用定义证明一般定理

5.4 Proving general theorems using definitions

另一项常见的数学任务是证明如果一个定义得到满足，那么另一个定义也得到满足。相当多的定理相当于一个可以这样证明的陈述，因此通常可以通过写下前提的定义、写下结论的定义，然后找出如何在两者之间找到平衡来取得进展。

Another common mathematical task is to prove that if one definition is satisfied, then so is another one. Quite a few theorems amount to a statement that can be proved like this, so it is often possible to make progress by writing down what the premises mean in terms of definitions, writing down what the conclusion means in terms of definitions, then working out how to get between the two.

这里我们来看一个使用第 4 章中介绍的导数定义的例子：

Here we will look at an illustration that uses the definition of the derivative, which was introduced in Chapter 4:

定义： 假设存在这个极限

Definition: provided this limit exists

使用这种符号，导数的求和规则可以表述如下：

Using this notation, the sum rule for derivatives could be stated like this:

定理：假设f和g都是可微的。那么

Theorem: Suppose that f and g are both differentiable. Then

我知道你可能认为这个定理显然是正确的。如果是这样，你应该问问自己，你是否有充分的理由这样认为，或者你只是习惯了它。证明它，一如既往，等于证明结论符合前提。在这种情况下，前提是f和g都是可微的，这意味着它们都有导数，这意味着它们的导数由定义定义。也就是说，我们假设

I realize that you probably think of this theorem as obviously true. If so, you should ask yourself whether you have a good reason for thinking that, or whether you’ve just got used to it. Proving it amounts, as always, to showing that the conclusion follows from the premise. In this case, the premise is that f and g are both differentiable, which means that they both have derivatives, which means that their derivatives are defined by the definition. That is, we will assume that

我们想证明结论成立，即

We’d like to prove that the conclusion holds, that is, that

请注意，在左侧，f + g被视为一个需要微分的函数。在右侧，函数f和g分别被微分，然后将得到的导数相加。因此，符号反映了加法和微分运算顺序的差异，而该定理实际上表明，这个顺序并不重要：我们用两种方式得到相同的东西。

Notice that on the left, f + g is treated as a single function that will be differentiated. On the right, each of the functions f and g is differentiated separately, and the resulting derivatives are added together. The notation thus reflects a difference in the order of the addition and differentiation operations, and the theorem really says that this order does not matter: we get the same thing both ways.

为了开始证明，我们也可以根据定义更精确地陈述结论：

To get started on a proof, we can state the conclusion more precisely in terms of the definitions too:

希望您能看出这里没什么可做的，因为从前提到结论只有一步之遥。我们可以写出类似这样的内容：

Hopefully you can see that there isn’t much to do here, because it is a very short step from the premises to the conclusion. We can write something like this:

定理：假设f和g都是可微的。那么

Theorem: Suppose that f and g are both differentiable. Then

证明：假设f和g是可微的。

Proof: Suppose that f and g are differentiable.

然后

Then

请注意，第一步和最后一步直接使用了定义中的等式；中间步骤需要一些思考。还请注意，在编写这样的详细证明时，我们通常在每个步骤只执行一次操作。对于明显的操作有一些回旋余地，但通常我们会小心避免将任何事情视为理所当然。你的教授可能会以略有不同的方式呈现这种事情，使用替代符号或考虑特定点的导数而不是考虑整个函数。不过，主要观点是：我们通常可以通过根据相关定义写下前提和结论，然后寻找介于两者之间的方法来取得进展。

Notice that the first and last steps make direct use of the equality in the definition; it is the intermediate steps that require some thinking. Notice also that when writing detailed proofs like this, we often perform only one manipulation at each step. There is a bit of leeway for obvious manipulations, but generally we are careful to avoid taking anything for granted. Your professor might present this kind of thing in a slightly different way, using alternative notation or considering the derivatives at a specific point rather than considering whole functions. The main point stands, though: we can often make progress by writing down the premises and conclusion in terms of the relevant definitions, then looking for a way to get between the two.

5.5 定义和其他表述

5.5 Definitions and other representations

通常，一旦所有内容都以定义的形式写下来，就很清楚如何开始证明。但在某些情况下，需要更多的创造力——你必须有一个好主意。我们已经研究过一种获得想法的方法：查看一些示例对象，也许使用各种表示形式。在这里，我将结合前面章节中的一些定理讨论这一策略。

Often, once everything is written down in terms of definitions, it is fairly clear how to get started on a proof. In some cases, though, a bit more creativity is required—you have to have a good idea. We’ve already looked at one way to get ideas: look at some example objects, perhaps using a variety of representations. Here I’ll discuss this strategy in relation to some theorems from earlier chapters.

首先，考虑这个定理：

First, consider this theorem:

定理：如果l、m和n是连续整数，则乘积lmn可以被 6 整除。

Theorem: If l, m, and n are consecutive integers, then the product lmn is divisible by 6.

在第 4 章中，我们研究了满足前提的对象（连续整数l、m和n），并检查它们是否也满足结论（乘积lmn可以被 6 整除）。但我评论说，我们可以整天做这样的乘法，却无法了解为什么这个定理必须是正确的，或者我们如何证明它。

In Chapter 4, we looked at objects that satisfy the premise (consecutive integers l, m, and n) and checked that they also satisfy the conclusion (that the product lmn is divisible by 6). But I commented that we could keep doing such multiplications all day without getting any insight into why the theorem must be true or how we might prove it.

为了尝试构造一个证明，我们可以采用用定义来陈述一切的策略。这里的前提是三个整数是连续的，这从符号l、m和n中看不出来。我们可以将数字称为l、l + 1 和l + 2，这样我们就可以将它们相乘并查看结果：

To try to construct a proof, we can apply the strategy of stating everything in terms of definitions. Here the premise is that the three integers are consecutive, which is not obvious from the notation l, m, and n. We could call our numbers l, l + 1, and l + 2 instead, which gives us the option of multiplying them together and seeing what we get:

我不知道你的情况，但这对我没什么帮助。我无法以任何明显的方式重新排列最后一个表达式，以便得出 6 的因数。不过值得一试——有时这样的操作会揭示一个明显的因数。

I don’t know about you, but that doesn’t help me much. I can’t rearrange the last expression in any obvious way that will allow me to pull out a factor of 6. It was worth a try though—sometimes such manipulations will reveal an obvious factor.

但是，我们也可以尝试使用结论。在这种情况下，我们想要证明lmn可以被 6 整除，从质因数分解的角度来看，这意味着它必须可以被 2 整除并且可以被 3 整除。这更有帮助，对我来说，数字线是思考它的有用表示。

We can, however, try working with the conclusion as well. In this case, we want to prove that lmn is divisible by 6 which, thinking in terms of prime factorizations, means that it has to be divisible by 2 and divisible by 3. This is more helpful, and for me the number line is a useful representation for thinking about it.

看着数轴，我可以“看到” l、m和n中至少有一个数字能被 2 整除——每隔一个数字都是偶数，所以要么l和n都是偶数，要么m是偶数。出于类似的原因， l、m和n中恰好有一个必须是 3 的倍数。所以数字lmn必须是 3 的倍数。这解释了为什么结果是正确的，我们可以写出这样的证明：

Looking at the number line, I can “see” that at least one of the numbers l, m, and n must be divisible by 2—every second number is even, so either l and n are both even or m is even. And exactly one of l, m, and n must be a multiple of 3, for a similar reason. So the number lmn must be a multiple of 3. This explains why the result is true, and we might write a proof like this:

定理：如果l、m和n是连续整数，则乘积lmn可以被 6 整除。

Theorem: If l, m, and n are consecutive integers, then the product lmn is divisible by 6.

证明：假设l，m， n是连续整数。

Proof: Suppose that l, m, and n are consecutive integers.

则l、m和n中至少有一个能被 2 整除。

Then at least one of l, m, and n is divisible by 2.

此外，l、m和n中恰好有一个能被 3 整除。

Also, exactly one of l, m, and n is divisible by 3.

因此，乘积lmn可以被 2 整除，也可以被 3 整除。

Hence the product lmn is divisible by 2 and is divisible by 3.

因此乘积lmn可以被 6 整除。

So the product lmn is divisible by 6.

这是一个完美的证明。有时学生认为它不够好——他们认为它不够长，不够复杂，或者没有包含足够的代数。但证明只是一个逻辑论证，它阐明了为什么一个定理是正确的。有时这样的论证必须很复杂，因为涉及很多逻辑环节。但有时没有太多环节，证明可以非常简单。

This is a perfectly good proof. Sometimes students think it isn’t—they think it isn’t long enough, or isn’t complicated enough, or doesn’t contain enough algebra. But a proof is just a logical argument that makes clear why a theorem is true. Sometimes such arguments have to be complicated because a lot of logical links are involved. But sometimes there aren’t many links, and a proof can be very simple.

接下来，考虑这个定理：

Next, consider this theorem:

定理：如果f是偶函数，则就是奇函数。

Theorem: If f is an even function, then is an odd function.

在第 4 章中，我建议用图表来思考这个定理，这样你就能了解为什么它是正确的。下面是一张带有一些额外标签的图表，可能会有所帮助：

In Chapter 4 I suggested that thinking about this theorem in terms of a graph might give you some insight into why it is true. Here is a diagram with some extra labels that might help:

您可能会发现这些证据非常有说服力。但这还不足以作为证明，因为证明应该表明定理如何从定义或其他可接受的结果中演绎得出。从这个角度来说，前提意味着对于每个x，f (− x ) = f ( x )，结论意味着f ′(− x ) = − f ′( x )（我发现对于这种问题使用这种替代导数符号更容易）。我们想从前提得出结论，而最明显的方法是对等式f (− x ) = f ( x ) 的两边进行微分。虽然事先并不十分清楚这种方法是否可行，但我们必须做点什么，而且这是显而易见的值得一试的方法。

You might find this pretty compelling evidence. But it isn’t enough for a proof, because a proof is supposed to show how a theorem follows deductively from definitions or other accepted results. In those terms, the premise means that for every x, f(−x) = f (x), and the conclusion means that f′(−x) = −f′(x) (I find it easier to use this alternative derivative notation for this kind of question). We would like to go from the premise to the conclusion, and the obvious way to do this is to differentiate both sides of the equation f(−x) = f(x). It’s not quite clear in advance whether that will work, but we have to do something and it is the obvious thing to try.

右边的导数显然就是f ′( x )。根据链式法则，左边的导数显然是 − f ′(− x )。如果不是，注意到f (− x ) = f ( g ( x )) 可能会有所帮助，其中g ( x ) = − x，所以f ′(− x ) = f ′( g ( x )) g ′( x ) = f ′(− x ) · (−1) = − f ′(− x )。无论如何，稍微重新整理一下确实能给我们想要的结论。然后就是把论证写清楚的问题，我们可以这样做：

The derivative of the right-hand side is clearly just f′(x). It might be obvious to you that the derivative of the left-hand side is −f′(−x) by the chain rule. If not, it might help to notice that f(−x) = f(g(x)) where g(x) = −x, so f′(−x) = f′(g(x))g′(x) = f′(−x) · (−1) = −f′(−x). In any case, a bit of rearranging does indeed give us the desired conclusion. Then there is the question of writing the argument clearly, which we might do like this:

定理：如果f是偶函数，则f ′ 是奇函数。

Theorem: If f is an even function, then f′ is an odd function.

证明：假设f是偶函数。

Proof: Suppose that f is an even function.

那么对于每个x我们有f (− x ) = f ( x )。

Then for every x we have f(−x) = f(x).

对两边求导可得出 − f ′(− x ) = f ′( x )。

Differentiating both sides gives −f′(−x) = f′(x).

因此，对于每个x，f ′(− x ) = − f ′( x )。

So, for every x, f′(−x) = −f′(x).

因此，正如要求的那样， f ′ 是一个奇函数。

So f′ is an odd function, as required.

5.6 证明、逻辑推理和对象

5.6 Proofs, logical deductions, and objects

在偶函数及其导数的例子中，你可能已经看过证明并且想过，那么为什么要费心用图表来思考呢？证明使用了简单的代数和已知规则——直接使用它们肯定更快吧？对此，我想说：你是对的——采用这种方法通常非常明智。在某些情况下，使用定义和定理以及代数和逻辑确实可以很快得到证明。此外，不明确考虑对象的其他表示形式可能是一个明显的优势。例如，考虑一下我们在本章开头看到的关于三角恒等式和二次公式的证明。在那些情况下，你可以考虑一些例子——特定的方程和解，或者特定的角度或余弦图——但你几乎肯定没有。你很好地应对了抽象的符号表示，以至于你可能根本不觉得自己在做任何非常抽象的事情。

In the example about even functions and their derivatives, you might have looked at the proof and thought, why bother thinking in terms of a diagram, then? The proof uses straightforward algebra and known rules—surely it’s quicker just to use those straightaway? To this I would say: you’re right—it is often very sensible to take that approach. In some cases using definitions and theorems and algebra and logic does lead very quickly to a proof. Moreover, it can be a distinct advantage not to think explicitly about other representations of the objects. Consider, for instance, the proofs we looked at near the beginning of this chapter about trigonometric identities and the quadratic formula. In those cases, you could have thought about examples—particular equations and solutions, or particular angles or cosine graphs—but you almost certainly didn’t. You coped just fine with the abstract symbolic representations, so much so that you probably didn’t feel that you were doing anything very abstract at all.

事实上，你甚至可以做得更好：你可以在不知道任何对象是什么的情况下进行操作。如果有人告诉你每个 bloober 都是一个 cobo，而每个 cobo 都是一个 turit，你可以立即推断出每个 bloober 都是一个 turit。你只是使用逻辑推理来做到这一点。如果有人告诉你 bloobers 大于 zocks，而 zocks 大于 ngurns，那么你可以自信地说 bloobers 大于 ngurns。在这种情况下，你使用了逻辑推理加上你对“大于”如何运作的知识（用数学术语来说，“大于”关系是传递的）。你不知道 bloobers 、 cobos 、 turits 、 zocks 和 ngurns 是什么，但这不会给你带来任何问题。

In fact, you can do even better than that: you can operate in situations where you have no idea what any of the objects are. If you’re told that every bloober is a cobo and every cobo is a turit, you can deduce immediately that every bloober is a turit. You just used logical reasoning to do that. If you’re told that bloobers are bigger than zocks and zocks are bigger than ngurns, you can confidently say that bloobers are bigger than ngurns. In that case, you used logical reasoning plus your knowledge about how “bigger than” works (in mathematical terms, the relation “is bigger than” is transitive). You have no idea what bloobers and cobos and turits and zocks and ngurns are, but this presents you with no problem whatsoever.

因此，你很可能只需关注形式、逻辑论证，而不必明确思考语句所指的对象，就能学到很多本科数学知识。当然，你需要正确地解释和使用逻辑语言：正如第 4 章末尾所讨论的那样，你应该小心使用蕴涵和量词，并确保你不会无意中使用逆蕴涵和量词。或定理的逆而不是定理本身。记住这一点很重要，因为有些学生尝试正式工作但做得不是很好。他们没有很好的逻辑推理能力（他们会犯我们将在第 8 章中详细讨论的错误），他们随机尝试操作，不太了解这些操作是否有用，也没有太多思考每个步骤是否有效。然而，有些人非常擅长正式工作，因为他们具有良好的逻辑推理能力，并且他们开发了一种“符号直觉”，告诉他们哪些操作可能有用，哪些逻辑推论可能导致所需的结果。如果他们关注特定课程或主题中的常见证明结构，他们可能会特别擅长（有关更多信息，请参阅第 6 章）。

So it might well be that you can learn a lot of your undergraduate mathematics by paying attention solely to formal, logical arguments, without having to think explicitly about the objects referred to by the statements. Of course, you need to interpret and use logical language correctly: as discussed at the end of Chapter 4, you should take care with implications and quantifiers, and make sure that you don’t inadvertently use the converse or the inverse of a theorem rather than the theorem itself. It is important to remember this because some students try to work formally but aren’t very good at it. They don’t have good logical reasoning skills (they make mistakes like those we’ll discuss in more detail in Chapter 8) and they try manipulations at random, without much sense of whether these are likely to be productive and without much reflection on whether each step is valid. However, some people get really good at formal work, because they have good logical reasoning skills and because they develop a sort of “symbolic intuition” that tells them which manipulations are likely to be useful and which logical deductions are likely to lead to the required result. They might be especially good if they have paid attention to common proof structures within a particular course or topic (for more on this, see Chapter 6).

就我个人而言，我确实经常喜欢思考数学论证适用的对象。我发现图表表示尤其能让我直观地感觉到事物必须是这样的，我发现这有助于重建我记不清的定义、定理或证明。不过，我知道，用形式化的方式捕捉直观的、基于对象的推理并不总是那么容易。考虑相关对象的全部变化范围并将直观理解转化为适当的符号表示需要一些工作。

Personally, I do often like to think about the objects to which mathematical arguments apply. I find that diagrammatic representations in particular give me an intuitive sense that things must be the way they are, and I find this helpful for reconstructing definitions, theorems, or proofs that I can’t quite remember. I’m aware, though, that it’s not always easy to capture intuitive, object-based reasoning in formal terms. It takes some work to consider the full range of variability in the relevant objects and to translate intuitive understanding into the appropriate symbolic notation.

结果是，如果你期待我说正式或直觉策略是“最好的”，那你就会失望。每种策略都有不同的优点和缺点，成功的数学家通常知道两种策略都存在。他们可能会从一种开始——也许是因为整体个人偏好，或者因为他们倾向于以这种策略思考特定的数学主题——并尝试一段时间，然后在遇到困难时切换到另一种策略。如果他们也遇到困难，他们可能会切换回来，也许会有一些新的见解，这意味着第一种策略现在会更好。我们真的不知道他们怎么知道什么时候切换（他们可能也不知道——专家可能非常不善于反思他们的专业知识的性质）。我们确实知道，当一种特定的策略显然没有用时，专家不会浪费时间去抨击它。他们往往会意识到自己处于这种情况，并采取一些措施摆脱它。这可能意味着要改变策略，或者停下来弄清楚困难的确切性质，以便修改现有的策略，或者休息一下，喝杯咖啡喝杯咖啡，或者决定和别人讨论一下。成为一名优秀的数学问题解决者确实需要愿意坚持下去，但也需要能够认识到什么时候一种方法不起作用。

The upshot of this is that if you’re expecting me to say that either formal or intuitive strategies are “best,” you’re going to be disappointed. Each has different advantages and disadvantages, and successful mathematicians are usually aware that both strategies exist.
