They might start with one—perhaps because of overall personal preference or because that’s just how they tend to think for that particular mathematical topic—and try that for a bit, then switch to the other one if they get stuck. And if they get stuck with that one too, they might switch back, perhaps with some new insight that means the first strategy will now work better. We don’t really know how they know when to switch (they probably don’t know either—experts can be very bad at reflecting on the nature of their expertise). We do know that experts do not waste time bashing away at one particular strategy when it’s clearly not getting them anywhere. They tend to recognize when they’re in that situation, and do something to get out of it. That might mean switching strategy, or pausing to clarify the exact nature of the difficulty so that the existing strategy can be amended, or having a break and a cup of coffee, or deciding to talk it through with someone else. Being a good mathematical problem solver does involve being willing to persevere, but it also involves being able to recognize when an approach isn’t working.

5.7 证明显而易见的事情

5.7 Proving obvious things

在本章的剩余部分中，我们将较少地讨论证明的机制，而更多地讨论我们为什么要费心去做这件事（除了提出一个逻辑上正确的论点的一般满足感之外）。

In the remainder of this chapter, we will look less at the mechanics of proving, and more at the issue of why we bother with it anyway (beyond the general satisfaction of putting together a logically correct argument).

许多高等数学的入门书会告诉你，我们证明某些事物是因为我们想要绝对确定它们是正确的。这是正确的，但有点不诚实，因为数学家也会要求学生证明他们（学生）已经确定的事情。例如，你已经确定当我们将两个偶数相加时，我们会得到另一个偶数。看到这个证明不会让你更加确定，这是正确的。有时乍一看似乎是正确的数学主张结果却并非如此——我们将在下一节中讨论其中的一些。所以我们必须小心。但你也会发现，作为数学专业的学生，​​教授会期望你花费大量精力来证明你已经知道的事情。事实上，数学家们自己也花费了相当多的时间在类似的活动上。

Lots of introductory books on advanced mathematics will tell you that we prove things because we want to be absolutely certain that they are true. That is correct but it is a bit disingenuous, because mathematicians also ask students to prove things that they (the students) are already certain about. For instance, you are already certain that when we add together two even numbers, we get another even number. Seeing a proof of this will not make you any more certain of it, and rightly so. Sometimes mathematical claims that appear at first to be true do turn out not to be—we’ll look at some of those in the next sections. So we do have to be careful. But you’ll also find that as a mathematics major, professors will expect you to expend quite a bit of effort proving things that you already know. Indeed, mathematicians themselves collectively spend a fair amount of time in similar activity.

有些人会这样解释，教授希望你练习写出简单事物的严格证明，这样当你继续处理更复杂的事情时，你就可以自信地运用你的证明技巧。这也是事实，这当然是一个合理的理由。然而，这仍然不是全部事实，因为它没有解释为什么数学家自己做这种事，也没有让学生做这种事。

Some people will explain this by saying that professors want you to practice writing rigorous proofs of simple things, so that you can use your proving skills confidently when you go on to work with more complicated things. That is also true, and it’s certainly a sensible reason to do it. It’s still not the whole truth, however, because it doesn’t explain why mathematicians do this kind of thing for themselves as well as making students do it.

一个更好的理由是，数学家不仅重视知道一个定理是正确的，还重视理解它如何融入形成连贯理论的更广泛的相关结果网络。他们不只是想证明两个偶数之和是偶数，他们还想看看这与我们证明两个奇数之和是偶数的方式有何关系，或者我们证明任何两个能被 3 整除的数字之和也能被 3 整除的方式有何关系。他们想用类似的术语来表述所有的东西，这样他们就能看到整个理论之间的关系在本例中，是关于数字的可分性的理论。这样做需要指定定义，我们可以从中建立许多不同的证明，并研究如何呈现这些证明，以便它们之间的结构关系清晰。

A better reason is that mathematicians value not just knowing that a theorem is true, but also understanding how it fits into a broader network of connected results that forms a coherent theory. They don’t just want to prove that the sum of two even numbers is even, they want to see how that is related to the way in which we prove that the sum of two odd numbers is even, or the way in which we prove that the sum of any two numbers that are divisible by 3 is also divisible by 3. They want to formulate the whole lot in similar terms, so that they can see relationships across a whole theory about, in this case, divisibility properties of numbers. Doing so entails specifying definitions from which we can build up lots of different proofs, and working out how to present those proofs so that the structural relationships between them are clear.

事实上，数学的发展不仅仅是建立一套连贯的理论。理想情况下，数学家喜欢在极少数初始公理和定义的基础上建立一个非常庞大的理论。这被视为一个重要的智力目标：如果我们可以证明某件事是定理，我们就不会把它假设为公理。这听起来像是一个明确而合理的目标，但它的一些后果可能会让数学专业的新生感到困惑。举例来说，在某个时候（可能是在名为“基础”或“分析”之类的课程中），教授会向你展示与实数相关的公理、定义和属性的列表。这个列表将包括以下内容：

Indeed, there is more to the development of mathematics than just assembling a coherent theory. Ideally, mathematicians like to build up a very large theory on the basis of a very small number of initial axioms and definitions. This is seen as an important intellectual goal: we do not want to assume something as an axiom if, in fact, we can prove it as a theorem. This sounds like a clear and sensible aim, but some of its consequences can come across as confusing to new mathematics majors. To illustrate, at some point (probably in a course called something like Foundations or Analysis), a professor will present you with a list of axioms, definitions, and properties associated with the real numbers. This list will include things like this:

定义：当且仅当b − a > 0 时，我们说a < b。

Definition: We say a < b if and only if b − a > 0.

然后教授会要求你证明如下的事情：

The professor will then ask you to prove things like this:

声明：如果 0 < − a则a < 0。

Claim: If 0 < −a then a < 0.

这看起来可能有点奇怪。你可能会看着公理、定义和属性，认为它们是显而易见的，然后看着你被要求证明的东西，也认为那是显而易见的——事实上，就像公理、定义和属性一样显而易见。这样的经历会产生一些有趣的情感后果：你会看到学生们到处愤怒地说“我不敢相信他们竟然要求我证明我从六岁就知道的东西，这是在侮辱我的智商！”

This might seem a bit weird. You will probably look at the axioms, definitions, and properties and think they’re obvious, and then look at the thing you’re asked to prove and think that’s obvious too—just as obvious as the axioms, definitions, and properties, in fact. Such an experience has some entertaining emotional consequences: you’ll see students going around being outraged and saying things like “I can’t believe they’re insulting my intelligence by asking me to prove things I’ve known since I was six!”

事实上，你的教授们要求你证明这种事情并不是为了表明你知道它。他们知道你知道它。他们要求你证明它是为了表明你的思维足够严谨，可以将陈述视为定理，而定理只能基于一组有限的公理、定义和属性来建立。锻炼这种纪律实际上相当困难；当你试图构建这样的证明时，你会发现自己很容易假设各种其他“显而易见”的事情不在列表中。所以尽量不要对这样的任务不耐烦——如果你以正确的方式思考它们，它们就是一种有趣且有价值的智力锻炼。

In fact, your professors are not asking you to prove this kind of thing to show that you know it. They know that you know it. They’re asking you to prove it to show that you are disciplined enough in your thinking to treat a statement as a theorem that can be established on the basis of only a restricted set of axioms, definitions, and properties. It’s actually quite difficult to exercise this discipline; when you try to construct such proofs, you will find yourself tempted to assume all sorts of other “obvious” things that aren’t on the list. So try not to get impatient with tasks like this—if you think about them in the right way, they constitute an interesting and valuable intellectual exercise.

5.8 相信违反直觉的事物：调和级数

5.8 Believing counterintuitive things: the harmonic series

在上一节中，我提到过，有些数学结果乍一看似乎是正确的，但仔细检查后发现并非如此。这些事情有时被称为违反直觉的，意思是它们违背了（大多数人的）直觉。它们的存在是数学家们小心翼翼地正确证明事物的原因之一：有时每个人都相信某件事，但后来却发现它是错误的。我将在本节和下一节中给出我最喜欢的几个例子，并使用它们来说明您应该如何应对这种事情的一些一般性观点。

In the last section I mentioned that some mathematical results appear at first to be true but, on careful inspection, turn out not to be. These things are sometimes referred to as counterintuitive, meaning that they go against (most people’s) intuition. Their existence is one reason why mathematicians take care to prove things properly: sometimes everyone believes something which later turns out to be just wrong. I will give a couple of my favorite illustrations in this section and the next, and will use them to make some general points about how you should respond to this kind of thing.

第一个例子涉及无限和

The first illustration involves the infinite sum

这被称为无穷级数，有时也被称为级数。需要注意的一点是省略号（“…”）非常重要。它可以读作“等等”，意思是“永远等等”。如果你省略它，数学家会认为你的意思是在停止的地方停止。

This is called an infinite series, or sometimes just a series. One thing to note is that the ellipsis (the “…”) is very important. It can be read as “and so on” and it means “and so on forever.” If you omit it, mathematicians will think you mean to stop wherever you stop.

这个特殊的级数被称为调和级数，显而易见的问题是，它加起来等于多少？数学家通过考虑部分和来思考这个问题，之所以这样称呼，是因为每个部分和只涉及有限数量的项。以下是前几个部分和：

This particular series is called the harmonic series, and the obvious question is, what does it add up to? Mathematicians think about this by thinking about partial sums, so called because each one involves only a finite number of the terms. Here are the first few partial sums:

您可能想再计算一些，以了解正在发生的事情。我们也可以以图形方式表示这些部分和，通过绘制s n对n，如下图所示（顺便注意，此图有点而不是曲线，因为和仅针对整数定义）：

You might like to calculate a few more, to get a feel for what is happening. We could also represent these partial sums graphically, by plotting sn against n, as in the graph below (notice, by the way, that this graph has dots and not a curve, because the sums are only defined for whole numbers):

现在，假设我们一直这样下去。你认为无穷级数加起来会是多少？

Now, suppose we go on forever. What do you think the infinite series will add up to?

大多数人会说“可能是 5”或“肯定小于 10”。他们错了。答案是这个和是无限大的。它大于 5，大于 10，也大于任何你能说出的数字。我们可以用以下方法证明这一点。

Most people say something like “maybe 5” or “certainly less than 10.” They are wrong. The answer is that the sum is infinitely large. It is bigger than 5, and bigger than 10, and bigger than any other number you care to name. We can demonstrate this as follows.

首先，请注意第一项 1 大于第二项等于第三项本身不大于或等于，但如果我们取接下来的两个项，我们会得到：肯定大于所以我们要再加一半（加上一点额外的）。同样，对于接下来的四个项，所以我们再加一半。我们可以根据需要多次添加另一半，方法是取接下来的八个项，然后是接下来的十六个项，然后是接下来的三十二个项，依此类推。有时人们会写出类似这样的东西来表示论点：

First, note that the first term, 1, is greater than The second term is equal to The third term is not greater than or equal to on its own, but if we take the next two terms we get something that is: is definitely bigger than So we are adding another half (plus a bit extra). Similarly, for the next four terms, So we are adding another half. And we can keep adding another half as many times as we like, by taking the next eight terms, then the next sixteen, then the next thirty-two, and so on. Sometimes people write things like this to represent the argument:

因为我们可以继续添加更多的一半，所以总和大于 5、10 等等。我们需要大量的项才能使总数大于 100，但没关系，因为我们有无限多的项。

Because we can keep adding more halves, the sum is bigger than 5, and 10, and so on. We need an awful lot of terms before the total is bigger than, say, 100, but that’s okay because we’ve got infinitely many of them.

事实上，你应该从中学到一件事：无穷大真的很大。这些项真的很小，但它们的数量如此之多，以至于它们加起来无论如何都是无穷大。大多数人对此感到惊讶，并觉得通过查看上述论点，他们学到了一些真正新的东西。事实上，当你主修数学时，你会学到比这个更奇怪的无穷级数。它们被称为条件收敛级数，（在我看来）它们是本科数学中最有趣的东西之一。留意它们。

In fact, that’s one thing that you should learn from this: infinity is really big. The terms are really small, but there are so many of them that they add up to something infinitely big anyway. Most people find this surprising, and feel that they’ve learned something genuinely new by looking at the argument above. In fact, while you are a mathematics major, you will learn about infinite series that behave even more strangely than this one. They are called conditionally convergent series and (in my opinion) they’re one of the most interesting things in undergraduate mathematics. Look out for them.

另一件需要学习的事情是，直觉上“显而易见”的事情有时会被证明是完全错误的，尤其是当它们涉及无限过程时。在这种情况下，我们通过查看几个术语并绘制图表得到的直觉具有严重的误导性。这并不意味着你应该停止使用图表或相信你的直觉；它只是意味着你应该适当谨慎地这样做。

The other thing to learn is that things that are intuitively “obvious” sometimes turn out to be completely false, especially when they involve infinite processes. In this case, the intuition we got from looking at a few terms and drawing a graph was badly misleading. That doesn’t mean you should stop using graphs or trusting your intuition; it just means you should do so with appropriate caution.

5.9 相信违反直觉的事物：地球和绳子

5.9 Believing counterintuitive things: Earth and rope

下一个例证使用了不同的数学：简单的几何和代数。我第一次看到这个是在我读博士的时候；我的几个研究生物学的朋友说，有人告诉他们这个令人难以置信的事情，并问我这是否是真的。事实证明这是真的，我将以我第一次看到它的方式，以问题的形式呈现它。

The next illustration uses different mathematics: simple geometry and algebra. I first saw this when I was a PhD student; a couple of my friends who were doing biology said that someone had told them this unbelievable thing, and asked me whether it was true. It turns out that it is, and I’ll present it in the way I first saw it, as a question.

首先，想象一下地球，想象它不是到处都是高低不平的山脉等，而是一个漂亮、光滑的球体。想象我们拿一根绳子，把它绕在赤道上。我们拉绳子，让它绷紧，让它紧贴赤道。

First, imagine the Earth, and imagine that instead of being all bumpy with mountains and so on, it is a nice, smooth sphere. Imagine that we get a rope and put it around the equator. We pull it so that it is taut; so that it fits snugly.

现在想象一下，我们在绳子上加一米——只有一米。然后我们把它绕地球一圈，这样它在每个点上的高度都是一样的。

Now imagine that we add a meter—just one meter—to our rope. Then we shuffle it out all the way around the Earth, so that it is the same height above the surface at every point.

问题是：绳子距离地球表面有多远？

The question is: How far is the rope from the surface of the Earth?

大多数人会说：“哦，非常小的东西，比如几分之一毫米。”这是一种直觉的自然反应，因为地球是真的很大，而一米相比之下真的很小，所以增加一米似乎几乎没有什么区别。

Most people say “Oh, something really small, like a fraction of a millimeter.” This is an intuitively natural response, because the Earth is really big, and a meter is really small by comparison, so it seems like adding a meter should make hardly any difference.

事实上，答案是大约16厘米。

In fact, the answer is about 16 centimeters.

如果你以前没见过这个，你可能会对这个答案持怀疑态度。但它是正确的，而且我们证明这一点所需的数学非常简单。下面是证明形式，附带一些图表。

If you haven’t seen this before, you will probably be skeptical about this answer. But it is correct, and the mathematics we need to prove this is very straightforward. Here it is, in the form of a proof with some accompanying diagrams.

证明：我们将始终以米为单位进行工作。

Proof: We will work in meters throughout.

设地球半径为R。

Let the radius of the Earth be denoted by R.

那么地球的周长为C = 2 πR。

Then the circumference of the Earth is C = 2πR.

增加一米绳子会使新的周长变为C ′ = 2 πR ′ = 2 πR + 1。

Adding a meter of rope gives a new circumference of C′ = 2πR′ = 2πR + 1.

求解新的半径R ′，我们得到

Solving to find the new radius R′ we get

因此新的半径R ′ 等于原半径R加上 1/2 π米。

Thus the new radius R′ is equal to the original radius R plus 1/2π meters.

1/2 π ≈ 0.16，所以新的半径比原来的半径长约 16 厘米，这意味着绳子现在距离地球表面 16 厘米。

1/2π ≈ 0.16, so the new radius is about 16 cm longer than the original, meaning that the rope is now 16 cm above the surface of the Earth.

再次，大多数人给出的直觉答案是完全错误的。不过这个案例似乎更糟；它似乎让人们震惊，因为他们对自己的第一直觉非常肯定。有些人甚至坚持认为证明中一定有错误。没有。这是完全正确的，你应该（像证明一样）检查所有步骤以确保你确信这一点。

Once again, the intuitive answer that most people give is completely wrong. This case seems worse though; it seems to shake people up because they were so certain about their first intuition. Some people even go so far as to insist that there must be a mistake in the proof. There isn’t. It’s completely correct, and you should (as always with proofs) check all the steps to make sure you are convinced of this.

那么，面对这种违反直觉的结果，你该如何应对呢？你可以认为这太令人不安了，不再去想它。但那样会错失发展思维的宝贵机会。我会告诉你我做了什么，向你展示我的意思。首先，我说服自己，这个论证确实有效——我仔细检查，确保我没有犯一些愚蠢的代数错误或类似错误。然后我想，好吧，如果这是真的，那么我的直觉一定有问题，所以我的直觉需要修正。我需要找到一种不同的方式来思考这个问题，这样答案看起来就不会那么奇怪了。

So how should you respond to such a counterintuitive result? You could decide it’s just too disturbing, and not give it any more thought. But that would be missing a valuable opportunity to develop your thinking. I’ll tell you what I did, to show you what I mean. First, I convinced myself that the argument really did work—I checked carefully that I’d not made some daft algebraic error or anything like that. Then I thought, well, if this is true, then there must be something wrong with my intuition, so my intuition needs fixing up. I needed to find a different way to think about the problem so that the answer did not seem so strange.

经过一番思考，我意识到，如果你考虑一下地球表面的 1 英里，问题似乎就大不相同了。如果你将绳子在这一英里的距离上抬高 16 厘米，你需要添加多少新绳子？显然，几乎不需要——地球太大了，以至于在这段距离上看起来几乎是平的。事实上，在 100 英里甚至更长的距离上，情况可能也是如此。所以我发现，我可以想象绕着地球旅行，到处将绳子抬高 16 厘米，并在旅途中只添加我需要的绳子。即使在很长的距离上，我也只需要增加一点点，所以现在看起来更合理的说法是，我可能只需要一米就可以把绳子全部抬高。

After some thought, I realized that the problem seems quite different if you think, for instance, about just a mile of the Earth’s surface. If you lift the rope up by 16 cm over that mile, how much new rope do you need to add? Hardly any, obviously—the Earth is so big that it looks practically flat over that distance. In fact, the same would probably be true over 100 miles, or even more than that. So I found that I could imagine traveling around the Earth, lifting the rope up by 16 cm everywhere and adding just the rope I need as I go. I only need to add a tiny amount even over a long distance, so it now looks much more plausible that I might only need a meter to do the raising all the way around.

我发现这种替代观点让我感觉到正确答案并非完全不合理（如果它对你不起作用，你能想出另一种可行的替代方案吗？）。关键是，我之所以能想出这个答案，是因为我刻意努力想出如何将我的直觉思维与数学上正确的论证相协调。我认识到我的直觉一定有问题，并找到了一种方法使它与数学保持一致，从而改善了两者之间的联系，并增加了我将来在相关情况下使用直觉推理的可能能力。

I found that this alternative point of view made me feel that the correct answer is not wholly unreasonable (if it doesn’t work for you, can you come up with another alternative that does?). The point is that I came up with it because I made a deliberate effort to work out how to reconcile my intuitive thinking with the mathematically correct argument. I recognized that there must be a problem with my intuition, and I found a way to bring it into line with the mathematics, thus improving the connections between the two and increasing my likely power in using intuitive reasoning about related situations in future.

在本节和上一节中，我谈了很多关于反直觉结果的内容。但我并不是说你的直觉在一切事情上都是错的。大多数时候，你的数学经验会引导你找到正确的直觉解决方案（当然，也可能有相当多的将它们变成证明需要一些工作）。我想说的是，数学中确实存在这样的惊喜，你应该对它们保持警惕。这有点像第 3 章中关于定义的信息，我说一个定义在大多数情况下可能意味着你认为它应该意味着的意思，但可能存在“边界”情况，在这些情况下它并不像你期望的那样适用。就是这样。偶尔你的直觉会是错误的，你应该准备付出一些努力来修复它。

In this section and in the previous one, I’ve said a lot about counterintuitive results. But I’m not saying that your intuition is going to be wrong about everything. Most of the time your mathematical experience will lead you to correct intuitive solutions (though, of course, there might be quite a bit of work to do to turn them into proofs). What I am saying is that mathematics does contain surprises like these, and that you should be alert for them. This is a bit like the message about definitions in Chapter 3, where I said that a definition probably means what you think it ought to mean in most cases, but that there might be “boundary” cases where it doesn’t apply quite as you’d expect. This is like that. Occasionally your intuition will be wrong, and you should be prepared to put in a bit of effort to fix it up.

5.10 我的整个专业都是证明吗？

5.10 Will my whole major be proofs?

正如我在本章开头所说，你在专业学习期间遇到的许多数学知识将以定理和证明的形式呈现。有些课程将更多地介绍如何执行标准计算或解决标准问题，但你会发现你的教授会提供大量证明，他们也希望你写出相当多的证明。有些人觉得这相当令人生畏。他们习惯于学习如何应用程序，他们发现每个证明似乎都不同，他们想知道他们将如何掌握所有呈现的证明，更不用说他们将如何学会构建自己的证明。这是一种自然反应，但在第 1 部分的剩余部分中，我希望让你相信它并不像乍一看那么难。

As I said at the beginning of this chapter, lots of the mathematics you meet during your major will be presented in the form of theorems and proofs. Some courses will be more about learning to perform standard calculations or to solve standard problems, but you will find that your professors present a lot of proofs and that they expect you to write a fair few too. Some people find this rather intimidating. They are accustomed to learning how to apply procedures, they see that every proof seems different, and they wonder how they will ever get to grips with all the presented proofs, never mind how they will learn to construct their own. This is a natural reaction, but in the remainder of Part 1 I hope to convince you that it isn’t as hard as it might seem at first.

话虽如此，当你开始学习你的专业时，你可能必须增强自己在面对难题时坚持不懈的意愿。我的高中老师在这方面教了我很多。当我去问他一个我被难住的问题时，他常常会透过眼镜看着我说：“哦，去吧，再想想，阿尔科克，我相信只要你努力，你就能做到的。”大多数时候，他是对的。更重要的是，我了解到，如果我继续思考一会儿，或者将这个问题放下一天然后再回来，我通常可以取得进步。作为一名数学专业的学生，​​你可能会发现你经常花半个小时或更长时间来解决一个问题，而且随着你的进步，时间会越来越长。这并不意味着你在这个级别的数学上还不够好（见第 13 章）。事实上，如果你在这半小时内做了明智的事情，你将做的不仅仅是给出一个解决方案；你将会复习现有的知识，了解标准程序的适用范围等等。

That said, when you start your major, you will probably have to increase your willingness to persevere in the face of difficult problems. My high-school teacher taught me a lot about this. More often than not, when I went to ask him about a question I was stuck with, he would look at me over the top of his glasses and say, “Oh, go away and think about it some more, Alcock, I’m sure you can do it if you try.” Most of the time, he was right. More importantly, I learned that if I kept thinking for a bit longer, or had a break from the problem for a day then came back to it, often I could make progress. As a mathematics major you might find that you are regularly working on a single problem for half an hour or more, and that the length of time increases as you progress. That doesn’t mean you’re not good enough for mathematics at this level (see Chapter 13). In fact, if you’re doing sensible things during the half hour, you will be doing a lot more than producing a single solution; you’ll be revising existing knowledge, learning about the range of applicability of standard procedures, and so on.

您还将练习我们在本章中讨论过的开始证明的策略：根据相关定义编写所有内容，并思考示例对象以查看是否能给您带来任何启发。这些是非常通用的策略，因此它们可以应用于几乎所有问题。我们还看到，人们通常可以根据定义的结构来建模证明的结构。在第6 章中，我们将做更多的事情，讨论证明不同类型陈述的策略，以及在您陷入僵局时通常有用的技巧。

You’ll also be practising the strategies for getting started on a proof that we’ve discussed in this chapter: writing everything in terms of the relevant definitions, and thinking about example objects to see whether that gives you any insight. These are extremely general strategies, so they can be applied to almost any problem. We’ve also seen that one can often model the structure of a proof on the structure of a definition. In Chapter 6, we’ll do a lot more than this, discussing strategies for proving different types of statement, and tricks that are often useful if you find yourself at an impasse.

概括

SUMMARY

• 很多高等数学将以定理和证明的形式写成。这与高中数学没有太大区别，因为很多高中数学都可以用这些术语重新表述。

• Much advanced mathematics will be written in the form of theorems and proofs. This is not that different from high school mathematics, because much high school mathematics could be reformulated in these terms.

• 通常可以通过根据相关定义写出前提和结论来开始证明。

• It is often possible to get started on a proof by writing the premises and conclusions in terms of the relevant definitions.

• 编写证明时，最好使其结构能够反映相关定义或定理的结构。

• It is good practice to write a proof so that its structure reflects the structure of the relevant definition or theorem.

• 构造证明需要一定的创造力。有时可以通过检查相关示例的不同表示来获得一个好主意。

• Constructing a proof can require some creativity. Sometimes it is possible to get a good idea by examining different representations of relevant examples.

• 可以采用正式的方法来构建证明，即从逻辑结构的角度进行思考，也可以采用非正式的方法，即在转化为正式论证之前从例子的角度进行思考。每种方法都有优点和缺点。

• It is possible to approach proof construction formally, thinking in terms of logical structures, or informally, thinking in terms of examples before translating into a formal argument. Each approach has advantages and disadvantages.

• 数学家有时会证明一些显而易见的东西，以便了解它们如何结合在一起。亲自证明这些事情可以让你锻炼从少量假设出发进行工作所需的智力训练。

• Mathematicians sometimes prove obvious things in order to see how they fit together. Proving such things yourself allows you to practice the intellectual discipline needed for working from a small number of assumptions.

• 通常你的直觉是正确的，但数学中确实包含一些有趣的反直觉结果。当你遇到其中之一时，你应该利用它作为提高直觉理解的机会。

• Usually your intuition will be correct, but mathematics does contain some interesting counterintuitive results. When you meet one of these, you should use it as an opportunity to improve your intuitive understanding.

• 证明有时看起来很困难，因为它们看起来都不一样。要掌握数学的这一方面，您需要应用合理的策略来开始，并坚持不懈。

• Proofs sometimes appear difficult because they all look different. To master this aspect of mathematics, you will need to apply sensible strategies to get started, and to persevere.

进一步阅读

FURTHER READING

有关基于直观想法开发形式证明的介绍，请尝试：

For an introduction to developing formal proofs based on intuitive ideas, try:

• Katz, BP 和 Starbird, M. (2012)。提炼思想：数学思维导论。美国数学协会。

• Katz, B. P. & Starbird, M. (2012). Distilling Ideas: An Introduction to Mathematical Thinking. Mathematical Association of America.

有关为给定的逻辑语句适当构建证明的更多信息，请尝试：

For more on constructing proofs appropriately for given logical statements, try:

• Allenby, RBJT (1997)。数字与证明。牛津：Butterworth Heinemann。

• Allenby, R.B.J.T. (1997). Numbers & Proofs. Oxford: Butterworth Heinemann.

• Solow, D. (2005).如何阅读和做证明。新泽西州霍博肯：John Wiley & Sons, Inc.

• Solow, D. (2005). How to Read and Do Proofs. Hoboken, NJ: John Wiley & Sons, Inc.

• Velleman, DJ (2004)。如何证明：一种结构化方法。剑桥：剑桥大学出版社。

• Velleman, D.J. (2004). How to Prove It: A Structured Approach. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.

对于基于问题的公理系统、序列、级数和函数的介绍，请尝试：

For a question-based introduction to working with axiomatic systems, sequences, series, and functions, try:

• Burn, RP (1992)。数字和函数：分析步骤。剑桥：剑桥大学出版社。

• Burn, R.P. (1992). Numbers and Functions: Steps into Analysis. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.

有关提供对一般结果的见解的示例和图表，请尝试：

For examples and diagrams that provide insight into general results, try:

• Nelsen, RB (1993)。无字证明：视觉思维练习。华盛顿特区：美国数学协会。

• Nelsen, R.B. (1993). Proofs Without Words: Exercises in Visual Thinking. Washington, DC: Mathematical Association of America.

要了解关于学生对证明的理解的数学教育研究成果，请尝试：

For an introduction to mathematics education research results on students’ understandings of proof, try:

• Reid, DA 和 Knipping, C. (2010)。数学教育中的证明：研究、学习和教学。鹿特丹：Sense Publishers。

• Reid, D.A. & Knipping, C. (2010). Proof in Mathematics Education: Research, Learning and Teaching. Rotterdam: Sense Publishers.

第六章

证明类型和技巧

CHAPTER 6

Proof Types and Tricks

本章解释并说明了几种常见的证明结构。它描述了本科生有时会感到困惑的证明方面，并解释了这种困惑产生的原因以及如何克服它。它还指出了您可能在各种课程的证明中看到的一些常见技巧，并提供了如何处理新颖证明任务的指导。

This chapter explains and illustrates some common proof structures. It describes aspects of proving that undergraduates sometimes find confusing, and explains why this confusion arises and how it can be overcome. It also points out some common tricks that you might see in proofs across a variety of courses, and gives guidance on how to approach novel proof tasks.

6.1 一般证明策略

6.1 General proving strategies

在第 4 章中，我讨论了两种加深对定理理解的策略：

In Chapter 4, I discussed two strategies for developing understanding of a theorem:

• 注意定理的逻辑形式，仔细阅读每个句子。

• Pay attention to the theorem’s logical form, reading each sentence carefully.

• 思考满足前提的数学对象的例子，并考虑它们与结论的关系。

• Think about examples of mathematical objects that satisfy the premises and consider how these relate to the conclusion.

在第 5 章中，我讨论了高等数学中证明的含义、谨慎证明的原因以及一些特定的证明。阅读证明时，您可能关注每个证明的实质内容——所使用的思想以及它们如何推广。但是，我还提到了一些在尝试构建证明时通常有用的策略：

In Chapter 5, I discussed the meaning of proof in advanced mathematics, some reasons for proving things carefully, and some particular proofs. When reading the proofs, you probably focused on the substance of each one—on the ideas used and on how they might generalize. However, I also mentioned some strategies that are generally useful when trying to construct a proof:

• 根据相关定义写出前提和结论。

• Write the premises and conclusion in terms of the relevant definitions.

• 思考该定理适用的数学对象的例子，或许是以不同的表示形式。

• Think about examples of mathematical objects to which the theorem applies, perhaps in terms of different representations.

在这两种情况下，第一个建议对应于一种正式策略，而第二个建议对应于一种更不正式、更直观的策略。但应该清楚的是，这些实际上都只是解决数学问题的一般策略。这正是我们所期望的，因为构建证明只是一种特殊类型的数学问题。还应该清楚的是，学生永远不应该坐在问题（证明或其他）前说“我不知道该怎么做”。特别是，学生不应该坐在证明问题前想“我做不到，因为我没有人告诉我该怎么做”。数学专业的学生应该表现出一些主动性，尝试任何这些策略都比什么都不做要好。

In both cases, the first suggestion corresponds to a formal strategy and the second to a more informal, intuitive strategy. But it should be clear that these are really all just general strategies for mathematical problem solving. That is what we would expect, since constructing a proof is just a particular type of mathematical problem. It should also be clear that a student should never sit in front of a problem (proof or otherwise) and say “I don’t know what to do.” In particular, a student should not sit in front of a proof problem and think “I can’t do this because I haven’t been shown how.” Mathematics majors are expected to show some initiative, and trying any of these strategies will be better than doing nothing.

然而，在学习构造和理解证明时，了解一些经常出现并且经常有用的标准证明类型和标准技巧也会有所帮助。如果你对这些很警惕，你会发现你可以看到各种课程中数学论证之间的关系，当你遇到困难时，你可以想出一些可能让你取得进步的想法。本章是关于这些证明类型和技巧的。

However, when learning to construct and understand proofs, it also helps to be aware that there are some standard proof types and standard tricks that will often appear and will often be useful. If you are alert to these, you should find that you can see relationships between mathematical arguments across a variety of courses and that, when you get stuck, you can think up ideas that might allow you to make progress. This chapter is about these proof types and tricks.

6.2 直接证明

6.2 Direct proof

第一种标准证明类型称为直接证明。在直接证明中，我们首先假设前提成立，然后通过一系列有效的操作或逻辑推理得出所需的结论。到目前为止，本书中的大多数证明都是这样的。以下是我们已经研究过直接证明的一些定理：

The first standard proof type is known as direct proof. In a direct proof we start by assuming that the premise(s) hold and move, via a sequence of valid manipulations or logical deductions, to the desired conclusion. Most of the proofs in this book so far have been like this. Here are some theorems for which we’ve already studied a direct proof:

定理：如果n是偶数，则n的任何整数倍都是偶数。

Theorem: If n is an even number, then any integer multiple of n is even.

定理：如果x 2 − 20 x + 10 = 0 则或

Theorem: If x2 − 20x + 10 = 0 then or

定理：（2,5）是一个开集。

Theorem: (2,5) is an open set.

定理：对于每个θ ε ，cos(3 θ ) = 4 cos 3 θ − 3 cos θ。

Theorem: For every θ ∈ , cos(3θ) = 4 cos3 θ − 3 cosθ.

定理：如果ax 2 + bx + c = 0，则

Theorem: If ax2 + bx + c = 0, then

定理：假设f和g都是可微的。那么

Theorem: Suppose that f and g are both differentiable. Then

定理：如果l、m和n是连续整数，则乘积lmn可以被 6 整除。

Theorem: If l, m, and n are consecutive integers, then the product lmn is divisible by 6.

定理：如果f是偶函数，则就是奇函数。

Theorem: If f is an even function, then is an odd function.

在这里停下来想一想。你能不看就写出这些陈述的证明吗？如果你不能立即做到这一点，你能记住我们在每种情况下如何进行的要点并重建其余部分吗？如果你给自己一分钟时间，我敢打赌你能记住比你最初想象的更多的东西。学生们通常对自己回忆数学思想和重建围绕它们的论证的能力缺乏信心。

Stop and think for a moment here. Can you write out proofs of these statements without looking? If you can’t do it immediately, can you remember the gist of how we proceeded in each case and reconstruct the rest? If you give yourself a minute for each one, I bet you can remember more than you would initally have thought. Students often have too little faith in their own ability to recall mathematical ideas and reconstitute arguments around them.

需要注意的一件重要事情是，直接描述我们编写的最终证明，并不一定描述构造证明的过程。你也许可以写下前提，然后凭直觉去证明，但你更有可能必须尝试我在讨论这些定理时建议​​的一些事情：用定义来写所有内容，思考一些例子，也许画一个图表，等等。但是，然后你应该想出如何以一种让读者清楚其逻辑结构的方式编写最终证明。将这种写作视为一项单独的任务可能是一个好主意，这项任务值得你关注，而不仅仅是得到答案或证明。我将在第 8 章中对此进行更多讨论。

One important thing to note is that direct describes the eventual proof we write, it does not necessarily describe the process of constructing the proof. You might be able to write down the premises and just follow your nose to a proof, but it is more likely that you’ll have to try out some of the things I suggested when discussing these theorems: write everything in terms of definitions, think about some examples, maybe draw a diagram, and so on. You should then, however, work out how to write your final proof in a way that makes its logical structure clear for a reader. It is probably a good idea to treat this writing as a separate task, one that is worthy of your attention over and above simply getting to an answer or a proof. I’ll have lots more to say about this in Chapter 8.

需要注意的第二件事是直接证明可以有更复杂的结构。最明显的结构出现在案例证明中，这意味着：我们将要处理的案例分成合理的组，并在主证明中分别处理每个案例。例如，考虑我们在第 3 章中研究过的分段定义的递增函数：

A second thing to note is that direct proofs can have somewhat more complicated structures within them. The most obvious such structure occurs in a proof by cases, which means what it sounds like it means: we divide up the cases we’re dealing with into sensible groups and work with each one separately within the main proof. Consider, for instance, the piecewise-defined increasing function we looked at in Chapter 3:

看图，我们可以想象我们可以让x 1和x 2滑动，但只要我们保持x 1 < x 2，我们就始终有f ( x 1 ) ≤ f ( x 2 )。然而，在证明中，我们不能谈论“滑动”，我们必须更加精确。事实上，x 1和x 2只能位于相对于函数部分的六个不同位置之一，其中三个如下所示（其他位置是什么样的？）：

Looking at the diagram, we were able to imagine that we can let x1 and x2 slide around but, as long as we keep x1 < x2, we always have f(x1) ≤ f(x2). In a proof, though, we can’t talk about “sliding things around,” we have to be more precise. In fact, x1 and x2 can only be in one of six different positions relative to the sections of the function, three of which are shown here (what are the others like?):

在证明中，我们可以将每种情况作为单独的案例来处理。对于这三种情况，证明可能如下所示。其余情况是什么，你会写什么？

In a proof, we can deal with each of these situations as a separate case. For these three cases, a proof might look like that given below. What would the remaining cases be and what would you write?

定理：

Theorem:

正在增加。

is increasing.

证明：

Proof:

情况 1：

假设x 1 < x 2 < 0。

则f ( x 1 ) = x 1 + 1 < x 2 + 1 = f ( x 2)。

Case 1:

Suppose that x1 < x2 < 0.

Then f(x1) = x1 + 1 < x2 + 1 = f(x 2).

情况 2：

假设x 1 < 0 ≤ x 2 ≤ 1。

则f ( x 1 ) = x 1 + 1 < 0 + 1 = 1 = f ( x 2 )。

Case 2:

Suppose that x1 < 0 ≤ x2 ≤ 1.

Then f(x1) = x1 + 1 < 0 + 1 = 1 = f(x2).

情况 3：

假设x 1 < 0 且x 2 > 1。

则f ( x 1 ) = x 1 + 1 < 0 + 1 = 1 < x 2 = f ( x 2 )。

…

Case 3:

Suppose that x1 < 0 and x2 > 1.

Then f(x1) = x1 + 1 < 0 + 1 = 1 < x2 = f(x2).

…

对于每种情况，我都使用了等式和不等式链，一端是f ( x 1 )，另一端是f ( x 2 )；你应该确保你能准确地看到链中每个等式或不等式为什么有效。我喜欢这样的等式和不等式链，因为它们与定理的结论有明确的联系（它们表明在每种情况下f ( x 1 ) < f ( x 2 )），而且我认为它们很优雅。如​​果你愿意，你可以分别写下f ( x 1 ) 和f ( x 2 )，然后比较它们。不过，你最终会写得更多。

For each case I have used chains of equalities and inequalities with f(x1) on one end and f(x2) on the other end; you should make sure that you can see exactly why each equality or inequality in the chain is valid. I like chains of equalities and inequalities like these because they are clearly linked to the conclusion of the theorem (they show that f(x1) < f(x2) in each case) and because I think they’re elegant. If you prefer, you could write down what f(x1) is and what f(x2) is separately and then compare them. You’ll end up writing more, though.

那么什么时候应该考虑通过案例证明呢？有时你会发现你必须这样做。例如，在这个例子中，我们没有太多选择；f ( x ) 的值根据x 1和x 2的位置而不同，所以我们必须分别处理这些情况。在其他情况下，可能没有必要使用案例证明，但它可能很方便，因为存在某种自然的划分，可能是正数和负数之间，或者奇数和偶数之间。最后，如果你认为你可以为定理适用的某些对象构建论证，但不适用于其他对象，那么可能值得开始通过案例证明。开始总比没有好，一旦你为一个案例写下了论证，你可能会发现反思它会给你如何继续的想法。

So when should you consider a proof by cases? Sometimes you will find that you have to. In this illustration, for instance, we don’t have much choice; the f(x) values are different depending upon the positions of x1 and x2, so we have to handle these cases separately. In other situations, it might not be necessary to use a proof by cases, but it might be convenient anyway because there is some sort of natural split, perhaps between positive and negative numbers, or between odd and even ones. Finally, it might be worth starting a proof by cases if you think that you can construct an argument for some of the objects to which the theorem applies but not for others. A start is better than nothing and, once you’ve got an argument written down for one case, you might find that reflecting on it gives you ideas about how to continue.

最后一条建议是，如果你已经制作了案例证明，或者你正在看别人制作的证明，最好问一下是否可以减少案例数量。例如，您分别处理了x < 0、x = 0 和x > 0 这三种情况，但您可以重写该公式，只对x < 0 和x ≥ 0 分别使用一个参数。当然，您不必这样做 — 如果您的证明有效，那就没问题。但请记住，数学家也重视优雅，简洁有助于优雅，因此这是一个值得追求的目标。

One final tip is that, if you have produced a proof by cases, or if you’re looking at one produced by someone else, it might be a good idea to ask whether the number of cases could be reduced. Perhaps, for instance, you’ve separately treated the three cases x < 0, x = 0, and x > 0, but you could rewrite with just one argument for x < 0 and one for x ≥ 0. You don’t have to do this, of course—if your proof is valid as it is, that’s fine. But remember that mathematicians also value elegance, and brevity contributes to elegance so it’s a worthwhile aim.

6.3 反证法

6.3 Proof by contradiction

我要讲的第二种证明方法是反证法。这是一种间接证明，之所以这样称呼，是因为我们不直接从前提得出结论。相反，我们暂时假设我们想要的结论（或其中的一部分）是错误的，并表明这会导致矛盾。由此我们可以推断出临时假设一定是错误的，因此想要的结论是正确的。这听起来相当复杂，但你在日常生活中习惯于非正式地进行这种论证。这是一个简单的例子：

The second type of proof I want to talk about is proof by contradiction. This is a type of indirect proof, so called because we do not proceed directly from the premises to the conclusion. Instead, we make a temporary assumption that our desired conclusion (or some part of it) is false, and we show that this leads us to a contradiction. From this we can deduce that the temporary assumption must have been wrong, and thus that the desired conclusion is true. This sounds rather convoluted, but you’re accustomed to making this kind of argument informally in everyday life. Here’s a simple case:

你的朋友：丹整个周末都待在赫里福德的家里。

Your friend: Dan was at home in Hereford all weekend.

您：他不在，我星期六下午在考文垂见过他。

You: No he wasn’t, I saw him in Coventry on Saturday afternoon.

这里你隐含地使用了反证法。暂时假设丹在赫里福德。你的论点是，如果我们做出这个假设，那么我们可以推断他不在考文垂（如果你愿意，这使用了“定理”，即人们不能同时出现在两个地方）。但这与你在考文垂见过他的事实相矛盾。所以他当时在赫里福德的假设一定是错误的。

Here you are implicitly using a proof by contradiction. The temporary assumption is that Dan was in Hereford. Your argument says that if we make that assumption, then we can deduce that he wasn’t in Coventry (if you like, this uses the “theorem” that people can’t be in two places at the same time). But this is contradicted by the fact that you saw him in Coventry. So the assumption that he was in Hereford must have been wrong.

接下来，我们来看一个数学例子，它涉及有理数的定义。我们在第 2 章中非正式地介绍了它，以及表示所有有理数集合的符号。更正式地说，我们有：

Next, we will look at a mathematical example, which involves the definition of rational number. We introduced this informally in Chapter 2, along with the notation to denote the set of all rational numbers. More formally we have:

定义： x ∈当且仅当 ∃ p, q ∈ ℤ（其中q ≠ 0）使得x = p/q。

Definition: x ∈ if and only if ∃ p, q ∈ ℤ (with q ≠ 0) such that x = p/q.

下面的定理和证明使用符号 ∉ 表示“不是元素”，在这种情况下，y ∉表示y是无理数。定理和证明都隐含地假设我们正在处理的所有数字都是实数（这在早期有理数和无理数的工作中很常见）。与任何定理和证明一样，你应该仔细阅读所有内容，检查你是否理解每一步的内容。

The theorem and proof below use the symbol ∉ to mean “is not an element of,” and in this case y ∉ means that y is an irrational number. The theorem and proof both implicitly assume that all the numbers we are working with are real (this is common in early work with rational and irrational numbers). As with any theorem and proof, you should read everything carefully, checking that you understand what is going on in each step.

定理：若x ∈且y ∉则x + y ∉ 。

Theorem: If x ∈ and y ∉ then x + y ∉ .

证明：设x ∈，则 ∃ p , q ∈ ℤ（其中q ≠ 0）满足x = p/q。

Proof: Let x ∈ , so ∃ p, q ∈ ℤ (with q ≠ 0) such that x = p/q.

令y∉。​

Let y ∉ .

假设矛盾的是x + y ∈ 。

Suppose for contradiction that x + y ∈ .

这意味着 ∃ r, s ∈ ℤ（其中s ≠ 0）使得x + y =

This means that ∃ r, s ∈ ℤ (with s ≠ 0) such that x +y =

但随后

But then

现在rq − ps ∈ ℤ且sq ∈ ℤ因为p, q, r, s ∈ ℤ。

Now rq − ps ∈ ℤ and sq ∈ ℤ because p, q, r, s ∈ ℤ.

同样，sq ≠0，因为q ≠0且s ≠0。

Also sq ≠ 0 because q ≠ 0 and s ≠ 0.

所以y ∈ 。

Soy ∈ .

但这和定理前提相矛盾。

But this contradicts the theorem premise.

所以必定是x + y ∉ 。

So it must be the case that x + y ∉ .

在此证明中，暂时的假设是这样的：

In this proof, the temporary assumption is this one:

假设矛盾的是x + y ∈ 。

Suppose for contradiction that x + y ∈ .

通过做出这个暂时的假设，我们通过合理使用定义和代数，得出了这一结论：

Making that temporary assumption leads us, by some sensible use of definitions and algebra, to this line:

所以y ∈ 。

So y ∈ .

这（如上所述）与定理前提相矛盾，因此我们可以得出结论，我们暂时的假设一定是错误的，如下所示：

This (as stated) contradicts the theorem premise, so it allows us to conclude that our temporary assumption must have been wrong, like this:

所以必定是x + y ∉ 。

So it must be the case that x + y ∉ .

应该清楚的是，为了正确理解这样的证明，你必须做比在早期数学中可能要做的更多的事情。在在高中，你的大部分数学阅读都会涉及检查一些代数。在这里，你必须更加老练。你当然应该检查以确保你能够看到代数是如何工作的，并且没有错误。但这并不是像这样的证明中真正起作用的地方。要完全理解它，你需要了解它的整体结构。你需要能够识别在哪里做出了哪些假设，识别矛盾出现在哪里以及究竟是什么被矛盾，并理解它们如何结合在一起以证明定理是正确的。

It should be clear that in order to properly understand a proof like this, you have to do more than you might have had to do in earlier mathematics. In high school, most of your mathematical reading will have involved checking some algebra. Here, you have to be more sophisticated. You certainly should check to make sure that you can see how the algebra works and that there are no mistakes. But that’s not really where the action is in a proof like this. To fully understand it, you need to understand its global structure. You need to be able to identify what assumptions are made where, identify where the contradiction arises and what exactly is being contradicted, and understand how it all fits together to prove that the theorem is true.

你会在各种各样的课程中看到反证法，而最先出现的证明之一可能就是无理数证明。如果你仔细思考这个问题，你就会发现它远非显而易见。有理数有很多。例如，在 1 到 2 之间，我们可以开始列出，当然还有类似的东西因此，当我们说是无理数时，我们是在做出一个非常强烈的声明：在所有这些可能性中，没有一个完全等于这包括所有非常不明显的例子，如 29 365 930 375/16 406 749 305。我们也许可以通过考虑这样的例子得到一个很好的近似值，但我们永远得不到确切的数字。你可以想象，当人们第一次发现这一点时可能会非常沮丧。

You will see proofs by contradiction in a variety of courses, and one of the first will probably be a proof that is irrational. If you think about this properly, you might be able to see that it is very far from obvious. There are lots of rational numbers. Between 1 and 2, for instance, we could start listing , and of course there are also things like Hence, when we say that is irrational, we are making a very strong claim: from all these possibilities, there is not a single one that is exactly equal to That includes all the very non-obvious examples like 29 365 930 375/16 406 749 305. We might be able to get a good approximation by considering such examples, but we will never get the exact number. You can imagine that people might have been pretty upset when they first found this out.

现在，我不会向你们展示一个不合理的证明。这是一个经典的证明，你们在数学专业肯定会看到它，我不想抢你们教授的风头。但我想用这个想法来讨论反证法的用法，并重温前面章节中的一些观点。

Now, I’m not going to show you a proof that is irrational. It’s a classic proof, you’ll certainly see it during a mathematics major, and I don’t want to steal your professor’s thunder. But I want to use the idea to discuss the use of proof by contradiction, and to revisit some points from earlier chapters.

首先，请注意，尽管无理的断言听起来像是关于特定数字的陈述，但它实际上是关于无限多事物的陈述。它可以改写为：

First, notice that although the claim that is irrational sounds like a statement about a particular number, it is really a statement about infinitely many things. It can be rephrased as:

不存在形式为p/q的数等于。

There is no number of the form p/q that is equal to .

反过来，这可以用我们的标准定理形式重新表述为：

This, in turn, can be rephrased in our standard theorem form as:

如果x ∈ ，则

If x ∈ , then

正如我在第 4 章末尾所说，学会识别语句在逻辑上等价和不等价非常重要。确保你能看出这种情况下等价性。

As I said at the end of Chapter 4, it’s important that you learn to recognize when statements are and are not logically equivalent. Make sure you can see the equivalence in this case.

这个定理的反证法首先假设有一个有理数等于，然后证明这会导致矛盾。看到证明时请注意这种结构，并且像往常一样思考该证明如何概括。我这样说是为了重申第 1 章中的观点：在没有仔细思考每个步骤在新情况下是否真的成立的情况下抄袭数学论证是危险的。我认识的一位数学教授喜欢先证明是无理数，然后设置一个问题，让学生证明是无理数，然后证明是无理数。你注意到最后一点了吗？是的，无论证明做什么，其中一定有一个步骤不适用于但是，我的朋友告诉我，很多学生尽管如此，还是高高兴兴地抄袭了的证明。你不想成为那样的学生，所以停下来思考一下。

A proof by contradiction for this theorem would start by assuming that there is a rational number equal to and show that this leads to a contradiction. Look out for this structure when you see a proof and, as ever, think about how the proof would generalize. I say this to reiterate a point from Chapter 1: it is dangerous to copy a mathematical argument without thinking carefully about whether each step really holds in a new situation. One mathematics professor I know likes to demonstrate that is irrational then set a problem in which she asks students to prove that is irrational, then that is irrational. What do you notice about the last one? Yep, whatever the proof does, there must be a step in it that does not work for But, my friend tells me, lots of students merrily copy out the proof for nonetheless. You don’t want to be one of those students, so stop and think.

最后我想说的是，数学家在介绍这个证明时表现得有点不正常。正如我在第 5 章中所说，数学家通常喜欢使用陈述的一般版本。在这种情况下，你可能会认为他们不会费心去研究，而是直接去证明真实且更一般的定理：

A final point I want to make is that mathematicians behave in a slightly out-of-character way when introducing this proof. As I said in Chapter 5, mathematicians usually like to work with general versions of statements. You would think, in this case, that they wouldn’t bother working with and would instead go straight to proving the true and more general theorem:

定理：如果k为素数，则是无理数。

Theorem: If k is prime then is irrational.

他们通常不会。他们通常从案例开始。我认为这部分是因为问题的几何根源，部分是因为它通常在学生的专业早期出现，数学家认为从具体案例开始会更容易。这可能是真的，但一如既往，你应该自己考虑概括。

They don’t, usually. They usually start with the case. I think this is partly because of the geometric roots of the problem, and partly because it usually comes up early in a student’s major and mathematicians think it will be easier to start with a specific case. That’s probably true but, as ever, you should think about generalizations for yourself.

那么，什么时候应该尝试用反证法呢？你的教授会在许多不同的情况下使用这种方法，所以你应该在学习过程中对此有所了解。但有时问题或定理的措辞可能会让你很自然地想到用反证法。例如，如果问题是“证明某某对象不存在”，你可以通过假设存在并表明这会导致矛盾来取得进展。如果你正在研究标准形式的定理“如果某事则某事”也可能很有用。在这里，你可以通过假设前提成立但结论不成立来取得进展，特别是如果你认为定理如此很明显，否则你根本不知道该如何开始。问问自己：“如果结论不成立，会有什么问题？”有时这可以解决问题。

So, when should you try a proof by contradiction? Your professors will use this method in many different situations, so you should get a sense of this as you go along. But sometimes the phrasing of a question or theorem might lead you to think of proof by contradiction quite naturally. For instance, if a question says “Prove that such-and-such an object does not exist,” you might make progress by assuming that one does exist and showing that this leads to a contradiction. It might also be useful if you are looking at a theorem in the standard form “If something then something else.” Here you might make progress by assuming that the premises hold but the conclusion does not, especially if you consider the theorem so obvious that you wouldn’t otherwise know how to begin. Ask yourself: “What would go wrong if the conclusion did not hold?” Sometimes that unlocks the problem.

6.4 归纳证明

6.4 Proof by induction

我要讨论的最后一种标准证明类型是归纳证明。根据你以前的经验，你可能已经遇到过这种证明。如果是这样，你会用它来证明这样的事情：

The final standard proof type I want to discuss is proof by induction. Depending on your previous experience, you may have met this already. If so, you’ll have used it to prove things like this:

如果没有，你可能没见过这个符号，所以这里简单解释一下。符号 Σ 称为“sigma”，是希腊大写字母 S，在这里用来表示从i = 1 到i = n的总和。写出来，上面的左边意味着

If not, you might not have seen this notation so here is a quick explanation. The symbol Σ is called “sigma” and is a Greek upper case letter S, used here to denote a sum from i = 1 to i = n. Written out, the left-hand side of the above means

我们在这里所做的是代入i = 1，然后代入i = 2，然后代入i = 3，依此类推，直到i = n，然后停止。

What we’ve done here is substitute i = 1, then i = 2, then i = 3, and so on, up to i = n, where we stop.

因此，我们最初的表达式实际上涵盖了无数个命题：

So our original expression actually captures infinitely many propositions:

有一个定理可以涵盖无限多的情况并不罕见——我们研究过的许多其他定理也是这样。这里的区别该陈述的形式允许我们将命题放在有序列表中，即P (1)、P (2)、P (3)、P (4)……

Having a theorem that captures infinitely many cases isn’t unusual—many of the other theorems we’ve looked at do the same. The difference here is that the form of the statement allows us to put the propositions in an ordered list P(1), P(2), P(3), P(4),….

归纳证明如下。首先我们证明P (1)。这通常很容易。然后我们做一些聪明的事情。我们不会尝试直接证明任何其他命题。相反，我们取一个一般数k并证明如果P ( k ) 为真，则P ( k + 1) 也必须为真。这给了我们P (1) ⇒ P (2)，并且由于我们已经证明了P (1)，我们可以得出结论P (2) 也为真。它还给了我们P (2) ⇒ P (3)，因此我们可以得出结论P (3) 也为真。你明白了。我们已经建立了一个无限命题链，这些命题都是真的，因为第一个命题为真，并且蕴涵都为真：

Proof by induction works as follows. First we prove P(1). This is often easy. Then we do something clever. We don’t try to prove any of the other propositions directly. Instead, we take a general number k and prove that if P(k) is true, then P(k + 1) must be true too. This gives us P(1) ⇒ P(2) and, since we’ve already proved P(1), we can conclude that P(2) is true as well. It also gives us P(2) ⇒ P(3), so we can conclude that P(3) is true as well. You get the idea. We have made an infinite chain of propositions, which are all true because the first one is true and the implications are all true:

归纳证明是学生在抽象解释时通常会觉得直观简单的那些想法之一。然而，他们经常发现在任何特定情况下都很难使用它，所以我们将仔细研究我们开始的例子。在这个例子中，很容易证明P (1) 为真：

Proof by induction is one of those ideas that students usually find intuitively straightforward when it is explained in the abstract. However, they often find it difficult to use in any particular case, so we will look closely at the example we started with. In that example, it is easy to prove that P(1) is true:

证明蕴涵P ( k ) ⇒ P ( k +1) 有点难。我们想假设P ( k ) 为真，并以此来证明P ( k +1) 为真。我现在会开始做一些粗略的工作，写一些类似的东西：

Proving that the implication P(k) ⇒ P(k + 1) is a bit harder. We would like to assume that P(k) is true and use this to prove that P(k + 1) is true. I would start doing some rough work at this point, writing something like this:

假设P ( k )，即

Will assume P(k), which means

想要证明P ( k +1)，这意味着

Want to prove P(k + 1), which means

通过重写左边，意味着我们想要

which, by rewriting the left-hand side, means we want

根据关于P ( k )的假设，这意味着我们想要

which, by the assumption about P(k), means we want

然后我只需要做一些代数运算来证明最后两件事实际上是相等的（你可能想尝试一下）。

Then I’ve just got some algebra to do to show that the last two things are, in fact, equal (you might like to try it).

然而，在这种情况下，您构建证明的思路不一定与您写出证明的方式相同。上述思路完全合乎逻辑，但这样呈现效果并不好，因为它不符合我们试图证明的结构。当我们写出P ( k ) ⇒ P ( k + 1) 的证明时，我们真正希望我们的证明从对P ( k )的明确假设开始，然后通过一些漂亮、整洁的推论得出P ( k + 1)。

This, however, is definitely a situation in which the way you think about constructing a proof is not necessarily the same as the way you should write it out. The thinking above is completely logical, but presenting it like that wouldn’t work very well because it doesn’t match the structure of what we are trying to prove. When we write out a proof that P(k) ⇒ P(k + 1), we really want our proof to start with a clear assumption of P(k) and proceed through some nice, tidy deductions to P(k + 1).

对于归纳证明，我倾向于采用一种结构非常清晰的布局。我会写类似这样的内容：

For proofs by induction, I favor a layout that makes that structure very clear. I would write something like this:

定理： ∀ n ∈ ℕ

Theorem: ∀n ∈ ℕ

证明（通过归纳）：

Proof (by induction):

假设P ( n ) 表示

Let P(n) be the statement that

注意，所以P（1）为真。

Note that so P(1) is true.

现在让k ∈ ℕ任意取值，并假设P ( k ) 为真，即

Now let k ∈ ℕ be arbitrary and assume that P(k) is true, i.e. that

然后

Then

所以

So

因此，根据数学归纳法，P ( n )为真∀n∈ℕ。

Hence, by mathematical induction, P(n) is true ∀n ∈ ℕ.

关于这一点，有几点需要注意。首先，证明只包含几个词，但这些词有助于使结构清晰。其次，所有代数都包含在一个等式链中，该链从P ( k + 1) 语句的左侧开始，到右侧结束。您可能想考虑一下，既然我们知道要做什么，为什么按此顺序进行操作是有意义的。您可能还想考虑一下，为什么链中的最后一个表达式不是必需的，但对于想要将证明链接回定理的读者来说可能很有用。

There are a couple of things to notice about this. First, the proof contains only a few words, but these help to make the structure clear. Second, all the algebra is in a single chain of equalities that starts with the left-hand side of the statement of P(k + 1) and ends with the right-hand side. You might like to think about why it makes sense to do the manipulations in this order, given that we know what we’re going for. You might also like to think about why the last expression in the chain is not necessary but might be useful for a reader who wants to link the proof back to the theorem.

一般来说，你会看到人们用归纳法写证明的方式有所不同。有些人用“后继函数”来描述整个过程，其中 1 的后继是 2，2 的后继是 3，等等。有些人在证明P (1) 时明确写出“起始情况”，在证明P ( k ) ⇒ P ( k + 1)时明确写出“归纳步骤” 。有些人不使用像P ( n ) 这样的名称，而是每次都写出确切的语句。这很好，尽管我发现明确命名可以保持结构清晰，尤其是当你试图弄清楚首先要证明什么时。有些人根本不引入k，而是始终将变量称为n。我发现这样做会让学生更容易出错，因为这意味着n以两种不同的方式使用，这会增加混淆的风险。

In general, you will see some variation in the way that people write proofs by induction. Some people frame the whole thing in terms of a “successor function,” where the successor of 1 is 2, the successor of 2 is 3, and so on. Some people explicitly write “base case” when they are proving P(1) and “induction step” when they are proving that P(k) ⇒ P(k + 1). Some people don’t use names like P(n) and instead write out the exact statement each time. That’s fine, although I find that explicit naming can keep the structure clear, especially when you’re trying to work out what you want to prove in the first place. Some people don’t introduce a k at all, but call their variable n throughout. I find that doing so makes students a bit more prone to error, as it means that n is being used in two different ways, which raises the risk of confusion.

归纳证明确实容易引起困惑，因为有很多事情需要考虑。我发现学生最常感到困惑当我们写下“假设P ( k ) 为真”时，学生们经常会想，“但这就是我们想要证明的，我们怎么可以假设呢？”事实上，在证明的这个阶段，我们并不是在证明P ( k )为真，而是在证明P ( k )⇒P ( k +1)。确保你能看到其中的区别。此外，学生有时会感到困惑，通常是因为他们在“所以它对n为真”等短语中使用了“它”这个词，从而导致写作中出现歧义。在典型的归纳证明中，“它”的含义有很多种，所以你应该更具体一些。写“所以P ( n ) 为真”是一种方法。（请注意，上面的证明中没有“它”这个词——我们对每个阶段推导的内容都非常具体。）

Confusion does tend to arise with proof by induction because there are lots of things to think about. I find that students are confused most often by the point at which we write, “Assume that P(k) is true.” Students often read this and think, “But that’s what we want to prove, how come we’re allowed to assume it?” In fact, at that stage in the proof, we are not proving that P(k) is true, we are proving that P(k) ⇒ P(k + 1). Make sure you can see the difference. Also, students sometimes confuse themselves, usually because they have allowed ambiguities to creep into their writing by using the word “it” in phrases like “so it is true for n.” There are many possible candidates for the meaning of “it” in a typical proof by induction, so you should be more specific. Writing “So P(n) is true” is one way to do that. (Notice that the proof above does not include the word “it”—we are very specific about what we have deduced at each stage.)

那么何时应该使用归纳证明呢？在某些情况下，这是显而易见的，因为你很可能在至少一门课程中有一节关于它的课程。同时，你还会遇到想要证明某件事对所有n ∈ ℕ都为真的情况，这表明归纳证明值得一试。但请注意，归纳证明适用的问题可能有很大差异。首先，没有特别的理由要求从n = 1 开始使用归纳证明。例如，你可能会被要求证明某件事对每个n ∈ ℕ都为真，并且n > 4。在这种情况下，你可以将P (5) 作为基本情况并像以前一样进行，只是在某个时候，也许是在归纳步骤中，你会发现需要n > 4 来证明你想要做的一些操作。其次，虽然你遇到的一些最先出现的问题将涉及求和，但归纳证明对许多其他类型的问题也很有用。我们真正需要的是这样一种情况：我们有无数个可以按自然数顺序列出的语句，而这可以以各种方式实现。例如，考虑以下任务：

So when should you use proof by induction? In some cases this will be obvious, because you are likely to have a section about it in at least one course. Also you will come across cases in which you want to prove that something is true for all n ∈ ℕ, which is a giveaway that induction is worth a try. Be aware, however, that problems for which induction is useful can vary quite a bit. First, there is no particular reason for a proof by induction to start at n = 1. You might be asked to prove that something is true for every n ∈ ℕ such that n > 4, for instance. In that case, you can just make P(5) your base case and proceed as before, except that at some point, perhaps in the induction step, you will find that you need n > 4 to justify some manipulation you want to make. Second, while some of the first problems you meet will involve working with a sum, proof by induction is useful for many other types of problem. All we really need is a situation in which we have infinitely many statements that can be listed in the order of the natural numbers, which can happen in all sorts of ways. For instance, consider these tasks:

证明对于每个自然数n > 10，2 n > n 3。

Prove that for every natural number n > 10, 2n > n3.

证明对于每个n ∈ ℕ，5 3 n + 2 n +1可以被 3 整除。

Prove that for every n ∈ ℕ, 53n + 2n+1 is divisible by 3.

对于第一个任务，我们将写

For the first task, we would write

令P ( n ) 表示语句 2 n > n 3。

Let P(n) be the statement that 2n > n3.

然后我们直接证明P (11) 为真，即 2 11 > 11 3。然后我们算出如何证明如果k > 10 且 2 k > k 3，则 2 k +1 > ( k + 1) 3。

Then we would prove directly that P(11) is true, i.e. that 211 > 113. Then we would work out how to prove that if k > 10 and 2k > k3, then 2k+1 > (k + 1)3.

对于第二个任务，我们将写

For the second task, we would write

设P ( n ) 表示 5 3 n + 2 n +1可以被 3 整除。

Let P(n) be the statement that 53n + 2n+1 is divisible by 3.

然后我们直接证明P (1) 为真，即 5 3 + 2 2能被 3 整除。然后我们算出如何证明如果 5 3 k + 2 k +1能被 3 整除，那么 5 3( k +1) + 2 ( k +1)+1也能被 3 整除。注意，在这种情况下，语句P ( k )不仅仅是“5 3 k + 2 k +1 ”。事实上，5 3 k + 2 k +1根本不是一个语句——我们无法证明它，因为它只是一个表达式（对于任何特定的k，它都是一个数字；你不能“证明”一个数字，而且说一个数字推断另一个数字是没有意义的）。该语句是“5 3 n + 2 n +1能被 3 整除”。

Then we would prove directly that P(1) is true, i.e. that 53 + 22 is divisible by 3. Then we would work out how to prove that if 53k + 2k+1 is divisible by 3, then 53(k+1) + 2(k+1)+1 is divisible by 3. Notice, in this case, that the statement P(k) is not just “53k + 2k+1.” In fact, 53k + 2k+1 isn’t a statement at all—we couldn’t prove it because it’s just an expression (for any particular k it is a number; you can’t “prove” a number, and it makes no sense to say that one number implies another). The statement is “53n + 2n+1 is divisible by 3.”

根据我的经验，在构造归纳证明时，是否以P ( n )的清晰陈述开始，通常会决定成败，尤其是在处理新类型的问题时。当然，这并不奇怪——在开始解决任何问题之前，你都应该始终确保自己清楚自己要做什么。无论如何，正如我在第 1 章中所说，你不会总是被告知要使用哪种方法，因此你应该留意这些不太熟悉的情况，并且你应该训练自己注意何时归纳证明可能有用。

In my experience, starting out with a clear statement of P(n) often makes the difference between success and failure in constructing a proof by induction, especially when dealing with a new type of problem. This isn’t that surprising, of course—before you start any problem, you should always make sure that you are clear about what you are trying to do. In any case, as I said in Chapter 1, you won’t always be told what method to use, so you should be on the lookout for less familiar cases like these, and you should train yourself to notice when proof by induction might be useful.

6.5 唯一性证明

6.5 Uniqueness proofs

到目前为止，我谈到的标准证明类型都非常通用。直接证明、矛盾证明和归纳证明这些术语描述了整个证明的结构，它们将出现在许多不同的本科课程中。接下来，我想讨论几个技巧，它们也非常通用，但实际上并不构成证明类型。这些技巧在逻辑上是合理的，因此原则上可以在数学的任何地方使用，但你可能会发现它们在某些科目中比在其他科目中更常见。

The standard proof types I’ve talked about so far are all very general. The terms direct proof, proof by contradiction, and proof by induction describe the structure of a whole proof, and they will appear across many different undergraduate courses. Next, I want to discuss a couple of tricks that are also quite general but that do not really constitute types of proof, as such. These tricks are logically sound so they could, in principle, be used anywhere in mathematics, but you’ll probably find that you see them more in some subjects than in others.

这些技巧之一是证明某个对象的唯一性的方法。也就是说，证明只有一个对象具有某种属性。作为一名学生，你可能会发现，对你来说，这个特定的东西肯定只有一个，这是显而易见的。在这种情况下，你必须记住，我们并不总是因为我们怀疑它们是真的而去证明它们；有时我们证明它们是为了让我们看到一切如何融入更大的理论。从这个意义上讲，你可以认为唯一性证明是解决收尾问题。

One of these tricks is a way to prove the uniqueness of some object. That is, to prove that there is exactly one object that has a certain property. As a student, you might find that it is obvious to you that there must be only one of this particular thing. In those cases you’ll have to remember that we’re not always proving things because we doubt that they’re true; sometimes we’re proving them so that we can see how everything fits into a bigger theory. In this sense, you might think of uniqueness proofs as tying up loose ends.

试图证明某事物是独一无二的，标准技巧是首先假设有两个不同的事物，然后证明它们实际上必须是相同的。下面是一个例子。它涉及加法恒等式的概念，其定义如下：

The standard trick when trying to prove that something is unique is to start by assuming that there are two different ones and prove that, in fact, they must be the same. Below is an illustration. It involves the idea of an additive identity, which is defined as follows:

定义：设S为一个集合。我们称k ∈ S是S的加法恒等式当且仅当 ∀ s ∈ S，s + k = k + s = s。

Definition: Let S be a set. We say k ∈ S is an additive identity for S if and only if ∀s ∈ S, s + k = k + s = s.

请记住仔细阅读此定义。您能想到一个数字作为集合S = ℤ的加法恒等式吗？您能想到不止一个吗？下面的定理和证明抓住了这一点，并说明了这个技巧。

Remember to read this definition carefully. Can you think of a number that would be an additive identity for the set S = ℤ? Can you think of more than one? The theorem and proof below captures this, and illustrates the trick.

定理：整数的加法恒等式是唯一的。

Theorem: The additive identity for the integers is unique.

证明：假设有两个整数 0 和 0′，它们都是整数的加法恒等式。

Proof: Suppose that there are two integers 0 and 0′ that are both additive identities for the integers.

那么，根据定义，

Then, by definition,

（1）∀ x ∈ ℤ，x + 0 = x和（2）∀ x ∈ ℤ，0' + x = x。

(1) ∀x ∈ ℤ, x + 0 = x and (2) ∀x ∈ ℤ, 0’ + x = x.

尤其，

In particular,

所以 0′ = 0，所以加法恒等式 0 是唯一的。

So 0′ = 0, so the additive identity 0 is unique.

有些人第一次遇到这种论证时会觉得有点奇怪，因为它需要引入一些你知道会与其他东西相同的东西，并暂时假装你不知道这一点。然而，我认为它相当优雅。它很简短，而且对称性很好。它也可以相当直接地推广。你能看出它如何被改编来证明整数的乘法恒等式 1 也是唯一的吗？你会发现这样的论点在涉及公理结构的语境中出现，例如抽象代数。但它们也出现在其他语境中。例如，可以证明当x → ∞ 时函数不能有两个不同的极限，方法是假设有两个极限，给它们不同的名称，然后证明它们必须相等。您可能会在名为高级微积分或分析的课程中遇到这种类型的论点。

Some people find this type of argument a bit strange when they first meet it, because it involves introducing something you know is going to be the same as something else, and temporarily pretending that you don’t know that. However, I think it is rather elegant. It is brief, and it has a nice symmetry to it. It is also quite straightforwardly generalizable. Can you see how it could be adapted to prove that the multiplicative identity 1 for the integers is also unique? You will find that such arguments crop up in contexts that involve axiomatic structures, such as Abstract Algebra. But they also crop up in other contexts. One can, for instance, prove that a function cannot have two different limits as x → ∞ by assuming that there are two limits, giving them different names, then proving that they must be equal. You’ll likely encounter that type of argument in a course called Advanced Calculus or Analysis.

其他常见技巧与此技巧具有共同的特性，即当结果显而易见时，它们可以有效应用。例如，你可能会看到一位教授证明两个数字a和b必须相等，方法是先证明a ≤ b ，然后证明a ≥ b。或者证明两个集合A和B必须相等，方法是先证明A ⊆ B，然后证明B ⊆ A。与所有证明类型和技巧一样，寻找这种规律性应该有助于你掌握整个专业。

Other common tricks share with this one the property that they can be usefully applied when a result seems obvious. For instance, you might see a professor prove that two numbers a and b must be equal to each other by proving first that a ≤ b then that a ≥ b. Or proving that two sets A and B must be equal to each other by proving first that A ⊆ B then that B ⊆ A. As with all proof types and tricks, looking out for this kind of regularity should help you to get to grips with your whole major.

6.6 对同一事物进行加减运算

6.6 Adding and subtracting the same thing

另一个常见的技巧是加减同一个数，以便将表达式拆分成更易于处理的部分。微分乘法规则的标准证明可以很好地说明这一点。在阅读本文之前，最好先回到第 5 章，再看看求和规则的证明，这样你就能体会到其中的对比。以下是乘法规则：

Another common trick is to add and subtract the same thing to make it possible to split up an expression into parts that are easier to work with. A good illustration of this can be seen in the standard proof of the product rule for differentiation. Before you read this, it might be a good idea to turn back to Chapter 5 and look again at the proof of the sum rule, so you can appreciate the contrast. Here is the product rule:

定理：假设f和g都是可微的。那么

Theorem: Suppose that f and g are both differentiable. Then

像往常一样，我们可以通过思考前提和结论在定义中的含义来理解这一点。这里的前提是f和g都是可微的，因此它们的导数根据定义定义为

As usual, we can understand this by thinking about what the premises and conclusion mean in terms of the definition. Here the premise is that f and g are both differentiable, so their derivatives are defined according to the definition as

结论是用定义写成的，即

The conclusion, written in terms of definitions, says that

证明这一点并不像求和规则那样简单。我们不能简单地“拆分”结论中等式的左边，即使我们这样写

Proving this will not be as straightforward as it was in the sum rule case. We can’t just “split up” the left-hand side of the equality in the conclusion, even if we write

不过，我们可以做一些有用的拆分，如果我们首先对表达式f ( x + h ) g ( x ) 进行加减，然后写成

We can, however, do some useful splitting up if we first add and subtract the expression f(x + h)g(x), and write

方法如下：

Here is how:

证明：假设f和g是可微的。那么

Proof: Suppose that f and g are differentiable. Then

这个技巧有点像上一个。在唯一性的情况下，我们引入了我们知道会与其他东西相同的东西。在这种情况下，我们引入了等于零的东西，最终以一种方便的方式将其纳入我们的计算中。另一个类似的技巧是从表达式中减去某个东西以获得更容易处理的东西，然后再将其加回去。

This trick is somewhat like the previous one. In the uniqueness case, we introduced something that we knew would turn out to be the same as something else. In this case, we introduce something that is equal to zero and that eventually gets incorporated in a convenient way into our calculations. Another similar trick involves subtracting something from an expression to get something that is easier to work with, then adding it back on later.

您将在教授提供的证明中看到此类技巧的众多变体，我希望您能意识到它们在数学上非常优雅。但是，如果您和大多数人一样，看到其他人提供的证明中如此优雅，您可能会有点担心，因为您觉得自己无法发明如此优雅的策略。我将在本章末尾谈论这一点，但首先要说一下尝试。

You will see numerous variations on such tricks in proofs presented by your professors and I hope that you will appreciate that they can be very mathematically elegant. However, if you are like most people, seeing such elegance in proofs produced by others might make you a bit concerned because you do not feel you could invent such elegant strategies yourself. I’ll say something about that at the end of this chapter, but first a word about trying things out.

6.7 尝试

6.7 Trying things out

在本章开头，我说过，学生永远不应该坐在问题面前想“我不知道该怎么做”。总有事情要尝试，要想成为一名优秀的数学家，你必须愿意尝试。事实上，你必须愿意尝试那些最终行不通的事情。根据我的经验，学生有时不愿意这样做，主要有三个原因。

At the beginning of this chapter I said that a student should never sit in front of a problem and think “I don’t know what to do.” There are always things to try and, to be a good mathematician, you must be willing to try them. In fact, you must be willing to try things that turn out not to work. In my experience, students are sometimes unwilling to do this, for three main reasons.

首先，有些学生不喜欢不知道该怎么做的不安全感。这会让他们感到紧张。他们希望提前知道怎么做会有效，有时他们会向老师寻求保证（“这是正确的做法吗？”）。一直寻求这种保证的问题在于，你永远不知道如果尝试一下，你会怎么做，这意味着你永远不会更有信心，这意味着你最终会陷入恶性循环，不得不一直寻求支持。

First, some students dislike the insecurity of not knowing exactly what to do. It makes them nervous. They want to know in advance what is going to work, and sometimes they ask for a teacher’s assurance about this (“Is this the right way to do it?”). The problem with seeking such assurance all the time is that you never find out what you could have done if you’d had a go, which means that you never get any more confident, which means that you end up in a vicious circle, having to ask for support all the time.

其次，有些学生不想浪费时间。我理解这一点——显然没有人愿意在一件事情上花费很长时间，尤其是当大学里有那么多有趣的事情要做的时候。但是，认为尝试某件最终行不通的事情就是浪费时间是一个很大的错误。学习的时间永远不会被浪费。如果你尝试了一种行不通的方法，那么只要你深思熟虑，你就会知道它为什么行不通，这意味着你对该方法的适用性有了新的了解。而且你可能会对这个问题有一些了解，这样你就会对下一步该做什么有更好的想法。当然，继续坚持一种显然行不通的方法是一个错误——研究表明，善于解决问题的人经常会停下来重新评估他们目前的方法是否对他们有任何帮助。但是不开始是一个更大的错误。

Second, some students do not want to waste time. I understand this—obviously no-one wants to spend ages on one thing, especially when there are so many interesting things to do at college. But it is a big mistake to think that trying something that turns out not to work is a waste of time. Time spent learning is never wasted. If you try a method that doesn’t work then, provided you are thoughtful about it, you learn why it doesn’t work, which means you know something new about the applicability of the method. And you might gain some insight about the problem so that you have a better idea about what to try next. Of course, it is a mistake to keep plugging away at a method that clearly isn’t working—research shows that good problem solvers stop frequently to re-evaluate whether their current approach seems to be getting them anywhere. But it’s an even bigger mistake not to start.

第三，有些学生不想弄乱自己的论文。他们想知道，一旦开始写作，他们就能继续写作，并得出一个漂亮、整洁、正确的解决方案。如果这适用于你，那么恐怕你必须克服它。真正的数学思维并不整洁。它充满了错误的开始和部分尝试，以及意识到，如果把现在似乎行不通的东西与十分钟前、昨天或上周失败的东西结合起来，实际上会成为解决方案的有用部分。如果你想不断提高自己作为数学问题解决者的水平，接受这一点非常重要。你需要在纸上进行部分解决方案的尝试，原因很简单，因为你的大脑无法同时处理很多事情。你有大量的知识存储在所谓的长期记忆中，但你的工作记忆，也就是你真正进行新思考的地方，容量非常有限。它不足以容纳有关复杂数学问题的所有信息，同时找出如何解决它。当你写下可能有助于解决问题或构建证明的表示、定义、定理或计算时，你实际上是在利用纸张来补充你的认知能力，实际上，这是通过扩展你的工作记忆容量来实现的。所以不要担心写出错误或无用的东西。你以后总是可以写出解决方案或证明的简洁版本。

Third, some students do not want to mess up their paper. They want to know that once they begin writing, they will be able to carry on writing and arrive at a nice, neat, correct solution. If this applies to you, then I’m afraid you’ll have to get over it. Real mathematical thinking is not tidy. It is full of false starts and partial attempts and realizations that what does not seem to be working just here would, in fact, form a useful part of a solution if put together with something that failed ten minutes ago, or yesterday, or last week. It is very important to embrace this if you want to keep improving as a mathematical problem solver. You need to get partial solution attempts on paper for the simple, practical reason that your brain cannot handle many things at once. You have an enormous amount of knowledge stored in what is known as your long-term memory, but your working memory, where you actually do the new thinking, has a seriously limited capacity. It will not be big enough to hold all the information about a complicated mathematical problem while simultaneously working out how to solve it. When you write down representations or definitions or theorems or calculations that might help you solve a problem or construct a proof, you are using the paper to supplement your cognitive powers by, in effect, extending the capacity of your working memory. So don’t be worried about writing things that are wrong or that turn out not to be useful. You can always write up a neat version of your solution or proof later.

6.8 “我从来没想过这一点”

6.8 “I would never have thought of that”

你的教授会解释那些冗长而逻辑复杂的证明。他们也会解释那些依赖于一些非常聪明的见解的证明。有时他们会解释那些冗长而逻辑复杂的证明，这些证明依赖于一些非常聪明的见解。这往往会让学生担心。他们会想，“好吧，我知道这是怎么回事，但我从来没有想过。”这会让他们怀疑自己数学是否足够好。但你不必担心，因为你不应该能够通过自己拥有所有原创思想来重新发明整个现代数学。即使是数学博士生也不会被期望拥有许多完全原创的见解。作为一名本科生，当面对这样的证明时，你的工作是欣赏这种聪明的见解，理解它为什么有效，思考在略微不同的情况下对它的修改可能会如何起作用，并将其与课程或专业中其他地方使用的想法联系起来。为了进一步让你放心，这里列出了你需要做的事情。

Your professors will explain proofs that are long and logically complicated. They will also explain proofs that rely on some really clever insight. Sometimes they will explain proofs that are long and logically complicated and that rely on some really clever insight. This tends to worry students. They think, “Well, okay, I can see how that works, but I would never have thought of it.” This makes them wonder whether they’re good enough at mathematics. But you shouldn’t worry, because you’re not supposed to be able to reinvent the whole of modern mathematics by having all the original ideas yourself. Even a mathematics PhD student wouldn’t be expected to have many totally original insights. As an undergraduate, when faced with a proof like this, your job is to appreciate the clever insight, to understand why it works, to think about how modifications of it might work in slightly different circumstances, and to relate it to ideas used elsewhere in the course or in your major. To reassure you further, here is a list of things that you will be expected to do.

首先，你需要进行一些常规数学计算，就像你在低级数学中看到的一样。正如我在第 1 章中所说，你应该做好准备，这些计算会比你以前经历过的计算更长、更复杂，并且如果其中的某个步骤不适用于新情况，你应该准备好调整计算过程。

First, you will be expected to do routine mathematical calculations much like those you have seen in lower-level mathematics. As I said in Chapter 1, you should be prepared for these calculations to be longer and more involved than those you have experienced before, and you should be prepared to have to adapt the calculation procedure if a step in it is not valid for a new case.

其次，你需要将所见的证明运用到密切相关的案例中。例如：

Second, you will be expected to adapt proofs that you have seen to closely related cases. For instance:

• 看到一个不合理的证明后，你可能需要证明它是不合理的。

• Having seen a proof that is irrational, you might be expected to prove that is irrational.

• 看到由f ( x ) = 3 x给出的函数f是连续的证明后，你可能需要证明由g ( x ) = −10 x给出的函数g是连续的。

• Having seen a proof that the function f given by f(x) = 3x is continuous, you might be expected to prove that the function g given by g(x) = −10x is continuous.

在这种情况下，您通常可以将看到的证明视为模板，并适当更改一些数字。但是，为了重申第 1 章中的一个要点，您不应该不假思索地这样做——您应该确保证明中的每个步骤都真正是否适用于新情况，如果不行，则准备进行细微调整。例如，在某些数字可能为零的情况下，或者在将不等式的两边除以可能为负数时，务必要小心谨慎。

In such cases, you will often be able to treat the proof you have seen like a template, and change some numbers appropriately. However, to reiterate one of the main points from Chapter 1, you shouldn’t do this thoughtlessly—you should make sure that each step in the proof really does work for the new case, and be ready to make minor adjustments if it doesn’t. It is important to be careful in cases where some number might be zero, for instance, or when dividing both sides of an inequality by a number that might be negative.

第三，你需要将你见过的证明运用到相关但不太密切的案例中。例如：

Third, you will be expected to adapt proofs you have seen to cases that are related, but not so closely. For instance:

• 看到你可能希望证明的证明

• Having seen a proof that you might be expected to prove that

• 看到有界且上界的递增序列有极限的证明后，您可能需要证明有界且下界的递减序列有极限。

• Having seen a proof that an increasing sequence that is bounded above has a limit, you might be expected to prove that a decreasing sequence that is bounded below has a limit.

在这种情况下，您看到的证明肯定会有所帮助，但您不能将其视为模板。您可能能够构造一个基本结构非常相似的证明，但您必须进一步思考才能弄清楚到底需要更改什么。

In cases like these, the proof you have seen will certainly be helpful, but you will not be able to treat it like a template. You might be able to construct a proof that is very similar in its basic structure, but you will have to think further to work out exactly what needs changing.

第四，你需要证明定义是满足的。有时，如果你的教授认为这些定义足够简单，你可能需要用你以前没见过的定义来证明。我在第 3 章中谈到了这一点。

Fourth, you will be expected to show that definitions are satisfied. You will sometimes be expected to do this with definitions you have not seen before, if your professor thinks that they are sufficiently straightforward. I talked about this in Chapter 3.

第五，你需要构造定理的证明，而这些定理你还没有看到过与之密切相关的模型。正如我所说，你可能犯的最大错误就是坐在那里想“我们还没有被展示如何做到这一点。”没有人会要求你做完全超出你能力范围的事情，而本章讲的是你可以尝试的事情。

Fifth, you will be expected to construct proofs of theorems for which you haven’t seen a closely related model. As I’ve said, the biggest mistake you could make here would be to sit around thinking “We haven’t been shown how to do this.” No-one will ask you to do things that are completely beyond you, and this chapter has been about things you might try.

第六点，也是最后一点，在考试中，你可能会被要求陈述和证明课程中一些比较有挑战性的定理。有时，问题可能会引导你逐步完成这样的证明，或者可能会提供一个相当大的提示来提醒你一个关键的想法或一个有用的技巧。有时它可能直接问，这意味着你必须能够自己记住关键的想法或有用的技巧，并重建其余部分。要做到这一点，你需要有效地阅读和理解你的讲义中的材料。如何做到这一点是下一章的主题。

Sixth and finally, on an exam you might be asked to state and prove some of the more challenging theorems from the course. Sometimes a question might lead you through such a proof in steps, or might offer a fairly big hint to remind you of a key idea or a useful trick. Sometimes it might just ask outright, which means you’ll have to be able to remember the key ideas or useful tricks for yourself and reconstruct the rest. To do so you will need to have effectively read and understood the material in your lecture notes. How to go about this is the subject of the next chapter.

概括

SUMMARY

• 直接证明通过一系列有效的操作或逻辑推理从定理的前提得出结论。

• A direct proof proceeds from the premises of a theorem to the conclusion by a sequence of valid manipulations or logical deductions.

• 案例证明通过拆分所考虑的数学对象并分别处理它们的不同集合来工作。

• A proof by cases works by splitting up the mathematical objects under consideration and dealing separately with different sets of them.

• 反证法涉及暂时假设结论或结论的某部分不正确，并表明这会导致矛盾，从而暂时的假设必定是错误的。

• A proof by contradiction involves making a temporary assumption that the conclusion or some part of it is not true, and showing that this leads to a contradiction so that the temporary assumption must have been false.

• 归纳证明通常用于证明命题P ( n ) 对每个自然数n都成立。它涉及证明一个基本情况，通常是P (1)，然后证明归纳步骤P ( k ) ⇒ P ( k + 1)。

• A proof by induction is often used to prove that a proposition P(n) holds for every natural number n. It involves proving a base case, often P(1), then proving the induction step P(k) ⇒ P(k + 1).

• 证明一个数学对象是唯一的常用策略是假设有两个不同的数学对象，然后证明它们必须相等。

• A common strategy for proving that a mathematical object is unique is to assume that there are two different ones, then show that they must be equal.

• 一些证明使用了诸如添加和减去相同事物之类的技巧，以便得到更容易处理的表达式。

• Some proofs use a trick such as adding and subtracting the same thing in order to get an expression that is easier to work with.

• 数学专业的学生必须愿意尝试各种事情；你并不总是能够提前知道某件事是否会成功。

• A mathematics student must be willing to try things out; you will not always know in advance whether something is going to work.

• 当你看到一个涉及巧妙见解的证明时，你不应该担心你不会想到它；你应该思考它为什么有效，它如何适应，以及它与你所见过的其他想法有何关联。

• When you see a proof that involves a clever insight, you should not worry that you wouldn’t have thought of it; you should think about why it works, how it might be adapted, and how it relates to other ideas you have seen.

进一步阅读

FURTHER READING

有关证明类型及其构建方法的更多信息，请尝试：

For more on types of proof and how to construct them, try:

• Solow, D. (2005).如何阅读和做证明。新泽西州霍博肯：John Wiley。

• Solow, D. (2005). How to Read and Do Proofs. Hoboken, NJ: John Wiley.

• Velleman, DJ (2004)。如何证明：一种结构化方法。剑桥：剑桥大学出版社。

• Velleman, D.J. (2004). How to Prove It: A Structured Approach. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.

• Allenby, RBJT (1997)。数字与证明。牛津：Butterworth Heinemann。

• Allenby, R.B.J.T. (1997). Numbers & Proofs. Oxford: Butterworth Heinemann.

• Houston, K. (2009).如何像数学家一样思考。剑桥：剑桥大学出版社。

• Houston, K. (2009). How to Think Like a Mathematician. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.

• Vivaldi, F. (2011)。数学写作：本科课程。在线网址：http://www.maths.qml.ac.uk/~fv/books/mw/mwbook.pdf。

• Vivaldi, F. (2011). Mathematical Writing: An Undergraduate Course. Online at http://www.maths.qml.ac.uk/~fv/books/mw/mwbook.pdf.

第 7 章

阅读数学

CHAPTER 7

Reading Mathematics

本章阐述了培养独立于书面信息（如课堂笔记）学习数学的技能的重要性。它解释了在阅读中可能有助于理解、综合和记忆的策略。它还讨论了如何在准备考试时运用这些策略。

This chapter explains the importance of developing skills in learning mathematics independently from written information such as lecture notes. It explains strategies that might be useful in reading for understanding, for synthesis, and for memory. It also discusses how to build on these strategies when preparing for exams.

7.1 独立阅读

7.1 Independent reading

你通过自学，在没有老师口头解释的情况下，学到了多少数学知识？答案可能是“相当多”，特别是如果你的高中老师经常要求你在课前学习一些东西，或者你参加了需要一些独立学习的大学先修课程。但实际上，答案也可能是“不多”。也许你的高中老师通常会在课堂上解释所有内容，你有一本或多本数学教科书，但你实际上只用它们来做题，所以你很少坐下来尝试阅读说明部分。如果你的情况如此，那么认识到你缺乏经验，并承认通过独立阅读学习新数学可能需要培养一些新技能可能很重要。

How much mathematics have you learned by reading something on your own, with no verbal explanation from a teacher? The answer might be “quite a lot,” especially if your high school teacher often asked you to study something before a class or if, say, you took an advanced placement course that involved some independent study. But it might be “not very much at all, actually.” Perhaps your high school teacher usually explained everything in class, and you had one or more mathematics textbooks but you only really used them for the problems, so that you rarely sat down and tried to read the expository sections. If this is your situation, it’s probably important to recognize your lack of experience and to acknowledge that learning new mathematics via independent reading might involve developing some new skills.

但是，你可能会问，你为什么需要通过独立阅读来学习？你的大学教授，就像高中老师一样，肯定会向你解释一切吧？嗯，是也不是。是的，因为他们会讲课，教授和其他人会帮助你当你遇到困难时（见第 10 章）。但不是这样的，你的课堂规模有时会比高中课堂规模大得多，有时你会发现教授讲得太快，你无法一次理解所有内容（见第 9 章和第13章）。这意味着你经常需要在讲座后仔细阅读你的讲义，并以此方式学习数学。

But, you might ask, why would you need to learn by reading independently? Surely your college professors, like high school teachers, will explain everything to you? Well, yes and no. Yes in the sense that they give lectures, and that professors and other people are available to help you when you get stuck (see Chapter 10). But no in the sense that your lecture classes will sometimes be much larger than your high-school classes, and you will sometimes find that the professor goes too fast for you to understand everything at the time (see Chapters 9 and 13). This means that you will often have to read your lecture notes carefully after the lecture, and learn the mathematics that way.

我自己在读本科第一年的时候在这方面就有点不顺。从高中的经历来看，我习惯于通过做练习和解决问题来学习。我的（优秀）老师会给我问题，我会去尝试，有时当我遇到困难时他会给我提示。这意味着我通过或多或少为自己发明而学到了很多东西——我弄清楚了如何应用想法，如何将它们结合起来，如何使用图表来帮助我思考事情，以及各种有用的东西。因此，我有很多解决问题的练习。我没有通过阅读来学习数学的练习。当然，我可以选择在任何时候阅读我的教科书，但这是我很少做的事情。

I myself came a bit unstuck in this respect in my first undergraduate year. From my high-school experience, I was accustomed to learning by doing exercises and solving problems.
