My (excellent) teacher would give me problems to do, and I would go away and try them, and sometimes he would give me hints when I got stuck. This meant that I learned lots of things by more or less inventing them for myself—I worked out how to apply ideas, how to combine them, how to use diagrams to help me think about things, and all sorts of useful stuff. I thus had lots of problem-solving practice. What I didn’t have was practice at learning mathematics by reading about it. Of course, I could have chosen to read my textbook at any point, but this is something I rarely did.

结果，在我读完本科第一年的时候，我发现自己很难理解很多课程，尤其是线性代数课程。我可以应用这门课程的很多程序，但我并不真正理解这些程序实现了什么。现在，我不记得是什么促使我这样做的，但最终我尝试阅读教科书的相关部分，这本书大部分时间都放在我的书架上，没有打开过。令我惊讶和高兴的是，它包含了一些很好的解释，帮助我对正在发生的事情有了正确、令人满意的理解。自然，一旦我克服了惊讶和喜悦，我只是感到尴尬——当然，这本书包含了不错的解释，这就是编写教科书的原因。

As a result, at the end of my first undergraduate year, I found myself struggling to understand a number of courses, and my Linear Algebra course in particular. I could apply a lot of the procedures for that course, but I didn’t really understand what the procedures achieved. Now, I can’t recall what prompted me to do this, but eventually I tried reading the relevant bits of my textbook, which for most of the year had sat on my shelf unopened. To my surprise and delight, it contained some good explanations that helped me to get a proper, satisfying understanding of what was going on. Naturally, once I got over the surprise and delight, I just felt embarrassed—of course the book contained decent explanations, that’s why textbooks are written.

我的观点是，你不应该期望你需要的所有信息都来自与你面对面交谈的人。你可以从写下来的东西中学到很多东西。在前面的章节中，我讨论了你可以使用的各种策略来理解书面数学，这些策略包括熟悉的计算程序形式，以及不太熟悉的定义、定理和证明形式。然而，在那些章节中，我们研究了细节。在这里，我将更广泛地讨论阅读。

My point is that you should not expect that all the information you need will come from a person physically talking to you. A lot of it you can learn from things that are written down. In earlier chapters I discussed various tactics you can use for making sense of written mathematics in the familiar form of calculational procedures, as well as in the less familiar forms of definitions, theorems, and proofs. In those chapters, however, we looked at the details. Here I will discuss reading on a larger scale.

7.2 阅读课堂笔记

7.2 Reading your lecture notes

你应该可以轻松地获得每门课程的全套讲义（但请参见第9章和第 11章）。但是，你可能不会理解这些笔记中的所有内容；在听完许多讲座后，你对新想法的理解可能只有一部分。因此，你在学习过程中应该做的一件事就是仔细阅读笔记，认真思考，并尽量理解它们。我知道这样说听起来很荒谬，但你会惊讶于有多少学生不这样做。我之所以知道这一点，是因为在我所在大学的数学学习支持中心，我经常看到学生在没有任何明显的事先努力去理解他们的笔记的情况下尝试解决问题。我和他们有过这样的对话：

You shouldn’t have any problem acquiring a full set of lecture notes for each of your courses (though see Chapters 9 and 11). Probably, however, you will not understand everything that is in these notes; you will come out of many lectures with only a partial understanding of the new ideas. One thing you should therefore do as you go along is read your notes carefully, think about them hard, and generally try to understand them. I am aware that saying that sounds ridiculous, but you would be surprised at how many students don’t do it. I know this because, in my university’s Mathematics Learning Support Centre, I regularly see students attempting problems without any apparent prior effort to understand their notes. I have conversations with them that go like this:

学生：

STUDENT:

这道题我解不了。

I can’t do this problem.

我：

ME:

嗯，我有一段时间没研究过这个了。这个词是什么意思？

Hm, I haven’t studied this for a while. What does that word mean?

学生：

STUDENT:

嗯，我不知道。

Um, I don’t know.

我：

ME:

那么，你有带上你的讲课笔记以便我们查阅吗？

Well, have you got your lecture notes with you so we can look it up?

学生：

STUDENT:

嗯，不。

Um, no.

这听起来很愚蠢，对吧？这个人试图回答一个他们不理解的问题，他们知道自己不理解，他们没有研究过帮助他们理解这个问题的材料，他们手头甚至没有这些材料。他们可能是一个天才，通常可以自己重新发明一大堆数学理论，但在这种情况下，这似乎不太可能。

It sounds daft, right? The person is trying to answer a question they don’t understand, they know they don’t understand it, they haven’t studied the materials that have been provided to help them understand it, and they don’t even have those materials to hand. It might be that they’re a genius who can usually reinvent a whole bunch of mathematical theory on their own, but in such cases this doesn’t seem likely.

不过，我能理解为什么会发生这种情况。我认为这是因为学生习惯于从老师的现场讲解中学习一切，所以他们不习惯以系统的方式阅读笔记或将其视为主要信息来源。你的教授会希望你这样做，人们会给出这样的建议：“你不能像读小说一样读教科书！”或“你应该手边拿着铅笔和纸阅读！”或“数学不是一项观赏性运动！”在我看来，这些都是明智的建议，但它们不够具体，无法作为指导方针当你试图从讲义或书中学习时，你应该真正做到这一点。所以我将提供更详细的信息，演示如何阅读不熟悉的数学文章。请稍等片刻，即使这听起来不是你需要的。我曾经与一位聪明且成功的数学学生一起经历过这种情况，当我这样做时，他的眼睛越来越睁大 - 你几乎可以看到他在想“哇，是的，我知道我应该这样做，但我想我从来没有这样做过。”从那时起，我也和其他成功的学生做过类似的事情，似乎他们中的很多人实际上阅读得并不好。因此，请阅读下一部分的足够内容来决定你的数学阅读能力是否可以提高。

I can, though, see why this happens. I think it is because students are accustomed to learning everything from a teacher’s live explanation, so they are not used to reading notes in a systematic way or to treating them as the main source of information. Your professors will expect you to do this reading, and people will give advice like “You can’t read a textbook like a novel!” or “You should read with a pencil and paper to hand!” or “Mathematics is not a spectator sport!” In my view, these are sensible suggestions, but they are not specific enough to act as guidelines for what you should actually do when trying to learn from lecture notes or a book. So I’m going to give a lot more detail, demonstrating how I would read an unfamiliar piece of mathematics. Stay with me for a moment, even if that doesn’t sound like something you need. I once went through this with a bright and successful mathematics student and, as I did so, his eyes got wider and wider—you could practically see him thinking “Wow, yeah, I can see that I should be doing that, but I guess I never do.” I’ve since done similar things with other successful students, and it does seem that a lot of them don’t actually read very well. So read enough of the next section to decide whether your mathematical reading could be improved.

7.3 阅读以理解

7.3 Reading for understanding

我们将看下面的摘录，它来自一门名为“微分方程”的课程的讲义。如果你没有学过微分方程也没关系，因为我将解释如果我处于那个位置，我将如何理解它。先浏览一下，然后阅读下面的详细解释。

We’ll look at the extract below, which comes from a set of lecture notes for a course called Differential Equations. It does not matter if you haven’t studied differential equations, because I will explain how I would make sense of this if I were in that position. Skim-read it first, then read the detailed explanation below.

2.2 齐次方程

2.2 HOMOGENEOUS EQUATIONS

形式为 的微分方程称为齐次方程。

Differential equations of the form are called homogeneous equations.

具体来说，这适用于可以写成以下形式的方程

Specifically, this applies to equations that can be written in the form

其中P和Q是x和y中的齐次表达式，且具有相同的次数。

where P and Q are homogeneous expressions in x and y and are of the same degree.

这种类型的方程可以通过代换y = vx（其中v是x的函数）转换成可分离方程。通过这种代换

Equations of this type can be transformed into separable equations by the substitution y = vx where v is a function of x. With this substitution

这样等式就变成

so that the equation becomes

可以分解为

which can be separated as

例 2.5：考虑方程

Example 2.5: Consider the equation

[笔记后面有一个框，学生应该在其中填写一些文本，可能是在讲座中，也可能是他们自己的。]

[The notes have a box after this, in which the student is supposed to fill in some text, perhaps in a lecture or perhaps on their own.]

我会告诉你当我尝试阅读这篇文章时我脑子里在想什么（我不是假装的——我读本科时并不了解微分方程，所以我已经忘记了大部分内容）。

I will tell you what went through my head as I tried to read this (I’m not faking—I wasn’t into differential equations when I was an undergraduate so I’ve forgotten most of this stuff).

第一行说

The first line says

形式为 的微分方程称为齐次方程。

Differential equations of the form are called homogeneous equations.

我注意到的第一件事是我正在看一个定义。它没有被这样标记，但是措辞和斜体字暴露了这一点。被定义的新事物是一种新型的微分方程，并且该定义确实涉及导数 d y /d x等于某个函数f ( y / x )。通常我们只看到函数写为f ( x )，因此看起来y / x部分一定是使其成为一种特殊微分方程的原因。此时我注意到的另一件事是导数是 d y /d x，这意味着我们必须能够将y本身视为x的函数。这正是我们所期望的，并且微分方程的解将是将y表示为x的函数的特定方式（参见第 2.6 节）。

The first thing I notice is that I’m looking at a definition. It isn’t labeled as such, but the phrasing and the italics give this away. The new thing being defined is a new type of differential equation, and this definition indeed involves a derivative dy/dx being equated to some function f(y/x). Normally we just see functions written as f(x), so it looks like the y/x part must be what makes this a special kind of differential equation. One other thing I notice at this point is that the derivative is dy/dx, which means that we must be able to think of y itself as a function of x. That is what we’d expect, and a solution to the differential equation will be a specific way of expressing y as a function of x (see Section 2.6).

第二行说

The second line says

具体来说，这适用于可以写成以下形式的方程

Specifically, this applies to equations that can be written in the form

其中P和Q是x和y中的齐次表达式，且具有相同的次数。

where P and Q are homogeneous expressions in x and y and are of the same degree.

这里的“具体”使我认为这肯定是一般定义的特例，我可以检查一下：左边是 d y /d x ，右边是x和y的某个函数，这正是我所期望的（大概微分方程在其他方面也可以是齐次的，但我们现阶段不考虑这些）。右边的函数以非常一般的形式写为x和y的两个函数的商，因此我不能立即清楚它与一般形式f ( y / x ) 的关系。另外，我不知道P和Q是x和y中同次的齐次表达式意味着什么。但似乎接下来会有一个例子，所以如果我继续下去，也许这两件事都会变得明显。

The “specifically” here makes me think that this must be a special case of the general definition, and I can check this: we have dy/dx on the left-hand side, and some function of x and y on the right, which is what I would expect (presumably a differential equation can be homogeneous in other ways too but we are not considering those at this stage). The function on the right-hand side is written in a very general form as a quotient of two functions of x and y, so it is not immediately clear to me how it relates to the general form f(y/x). Also, I don’t know what it means for P and Q to be homogeneous expressions in x and y that are of the same degree. But there seems to be an example coming up, so perhaps both of these things will become apparent if I carry on.

第三行说

The third line says

显然，这些旨在作为第二行中一般表达式的示例，它们确实解答了我的两个不确定性中的第二个：两种情况下的P和Q都是x和y中的表达式，并且所有项具有相同的组合度（第一种情况下为 3，第二种情况下为 2）。因此度部分是有道理的，但我仍然不确定是什么使得x 3 + 2 xy 2 + y 3成为齐次表达式。此时我可以查找或继续。我想我会继续，因为我应该考虑哪种类型的函数非常清楚。但我会记下来以后查找或询问。

Clearly these are intended to be examples of the general expression in the second line, and they do clear up the second of my two uncertainties: P and Q in both cases are expressions in x and y, and all the terms have the same combined degree (three in the first case, and two in the second). So the degree part makes sense, but I’m still not sure what makes x3 + 2xy2 + y3, for instance, a homogeneous expression. At this point I could look this up, or continue. I think I will continue, because it’s pretty clear what type of function I’m supposed to be considering. But I would make a note to look it up or ask later.

不清楚的是，在这两种情况下， P / Q是如何成为y / x的函数的。它们似乎都是y和x的函数，但这并不完全相同。也许总是可以重新排列这样的函数，将其写成y / x的函数？我无法立即看出如何使用给出的任何一个示例来做到这一点，尽管似乎可以理解，在这两种情况下， P / Q的特殊结构可能意味着这样的事情总是可能的。也许从建立y / x的简单函数开始，看看我能得到什么会更容易。尝试这样做，我可以通过平方、取倒数、将这些结果相加来制作以下函数，并取结果的倒数：

What’s not clear is how P/Q in either case is a function of y/x. They both seem to be functions of y and x, but that is not quite the same thing. Perhaps it is always possible to rearrange a function like this to write it as a function of y/x? I can’t immediately see how to do this with either of the examples given, although it seems plausible that the special structure of P/Q in both cases might mean that something like this is always possible. Perhaps it would be easier to start by building up simple functions of y/x and seeing what I can get. Trying this, I can make the following functions, by squaring, by taking a reciprocal, by adding the results of these together, and by taking the reciprocal of the result:

从这些来看，我可以使函数P / Q类似于示例中给出的函数，这似乎确实是合理的，因此我对这个阶段感到足够满意，可以继续前进。

Looking at these, it certainly seems plausible that I could make functions P/Q like those given in the example, so I’m satisfied enough at this stage to move on.

第四行（长行）是

The fourth (long) line says

这种类型的方程可以通过代换y = vx（其中v是x的函数）转换成可分离方程。通过这种代换

Equations of this type can be transformed into separable equations by the substitution y = vx where v is a function of x. With this substitution

这样等式就变成

so that the equation becomes

可以分解为

which can be separated as

在这一部分，我们似乎已经从示例转移到一般性讨论。这看起来可能相当容易理解，所以我将首先单独研究它，然后再尝试将其与示例联系起来。查看y = vx，我可以看到要找到 d y /d x，我们要对乘积进行微分，因此使用乘积规则，我们将得到v乘以x 的微分，加上x乘以v 的微分。这确实如所述，因为v是x的函数。请注意，这很重要 - 如果v只是一个常数，它将微分到 0，因此我们需要跟踪被视为什么的函数。然后我可以看看下一个等式，发现这只需用f ( v ) 替换 d y /d x。我原本以为它会被替换为f ( y / x )，但经过片刻的思考，我发现替换y = vx确实给了我们v = y / x。为了得到最后一个等式，我需要做一些代数运算，我可能会把它写出来以说服自己看起来还不错：1

In this part we seem to have moved away from the examples and back to a general discussion. It looks like it might be fairly straightforward to understand, so I will work on it in isolation first, before trying to relate it to the examples. Looking at y = vx, I can see that to find dy/dx we are differentiating a product, so using the product rule we will get v times x differentiated, plus x times v differentiated. That does indeed come out as stated, because v is a function of x. Notice that this is important—if v were just a constant, it would differentiate to 0, so we need to keep track of what is being treated as a function of what. Then I can look at the next equation and see that this simply involves replacing dy/dx with f(v). I was expecting it to be replaced with f(y/x), but with a moment’s thought I can see that the substitution y = vx does give us v = y/x. To get to the last equation I need to do a bit of algebra, which I’d probably write out to convince myself that it seems okay:1

目前我还不知道的是，这些内容如何应用于特定函数，例如上面列出的示例。我也不确定我是否真的想考虑这个问题，因为这些函数看起来相当复杂。我认为结合摘录末尾的简单得多的例子，我更有可能解决这个问题，所以我会尝试这样做：

What I don’t know at this point is how any of this would apply to particular functions like those listed as examples above. I’m not sure I really want to think about that, either, since those functions looked rather complicated. I think I’ll have a better chance of working it out in relation to the considerably simpler example at the end of the extract, so I’ll try that instead:

例 2.5：考虑方程

Example 2.5: Consider the equation

我发现这个等式并不完全是我想要的形式，但通过以明显的方式重新排列它，我可以将其变成这种形式：

I can see that this equation is not quite in the form I’ve been looking at, but by rearranging it in the obvious way I can put it into that form:

现在我想弄清楚如何将一般的求解过程应用于这个特定的微分方程。我不确定v起什么作用，但我可以暂时搁置这个担忧，直接进行代换y = vx。这意味着我可以像一般情况一样在左侧替换 d y /d x ，并在右侧用vx替换y ，得到

Now I’d like to work out how I can apply the general solution process to this particular differential equation. I’m not sure what role v is playing, but I can temporarily suspend that concern and just go ahead and make the substitution y = vx. This means that I can replace dy/dx on the left-hand side as in the general case, and also replace y by vx on the right-hand side, to give

现在我突然明白了这种替换的意义：右边所有x 2的实例都被取消，留下一个大大简化的等式：

Now I can suddenly see the point of this substitution: all the instances of x2 on the right-hand side cancel, leaving a much simplified equation:

我现在也明白了为什么我们需要P和Q具有所述形式：当它们具有所述形式时，进行这种替换将始终意味着我们最终在任何地方都得到相同的x幂，因此这种取消总是有效的。因此，这个例子已经让我对为什么一般公式是这样的有了更好的了解。然后我可以继续对这个特定情况进行代数运算，首先重新排列得到：

I can also now see why we need P and Q to have the stated form: when they do, making this substitution will always mean we end up with the same power of x everywhere, so such canceling will always work. Thus, already, this example has provided me with much improved insight into why the general formulations are as stated. Then I can go ahead and do the algebra for this particular case, first rearranging to give:

然后分离，得到：

then separating, to give:

此时我知道我可以找到两个积分，它们将给出关于x的v方程，然后我可以将其转换为关于x的y方程。您可能想在这里暂停一下并这样做。我将继续讨论我希望您观察到的关于此解释的内容。

At this point I know that I would be able to find both integrals, which would give an equation for v in terms of x, which I could then convert to find y in terms of x. You might like to pause here and do that. I will go on to discuss what I’d like you to observe about this explanation.

首先，阅读课堂笔记并不一定容易。笔记通常以相当笼统的表述开始，它们不一定能提供你可能需要的每一点解释，以便你了解所有内容是如何联系在一起的。当然，这就是你应该去听讲座的原因。毫无疑问，我提出的许多问题都会在教授的口头解释中得到回答。

The first thing is that reading lecture notes is not necessarily easy. Notes often start with rather general formulations, and they do not necessarily give every bit of explanation you might need in order to see how everything is linked together. This, of course, is why you should go to lectures. Doubtless many of the questions I raised for myself would have been answered by the professor in his verbal explanation.

第二件要注意的事情是，我的阅读过程具有一些特点。首先，它涉及确定我正在查看的内容的状态：这是一个定义、定理、例子、证明，还是更一般的东西，比如一个激励性的介绍段落？了解特定项目的状态意味着我知道可以从中期待什么样的信息。其次，当我遇到一个我不记得其含义的单词时，我会查找适当的定义或记下来以便以后再查找。第三，当我遇到一个例子时，我会检查该定义或属性是否适用。（同样，如果我遇到对早期定理的引用——“根据罗尔定理”或“来自定理 3.1”或“使用引理 2.7”——我会查找它以确保我知道它说了什么，并能明白它在当前情况下是如何应用的。）第四，我会尝试从抽象和与一些例子的关系中理解一般性陈述（另见第 2 章）。第五，如果例子很难想出，或者提供的如果有些句子看起来很复杂，我会提前看，因为教授可能在一般陈述之后的某个地方提供了一个简单的例子。这种情况经常发生。数学家知道一般陈述可能很难理解，所以他们经常在之后很快给出一个简单的例子。

The second thing to observe is that my reading process has a number of characteristics. First, it involves identifying the status of the thing I’m looking at: is this a definition, theorem, example, proof, or something more general like a motivating introductory paragraph? Knowing the status of a particular item means I know what kind of information to expect from it. Second, when I come across a word for which I can’t remember the meaning, I’ll look up the appropriate definition or make a note to do so later. Third, when I come across an example, I’ll check that the definition or property does seem to apply. (Similarly, if I come across a reference to an earlier theorem—“by Rolle’s Theorem” or “from Theorem 3.1” or “using Lemma 2.7”—I’ll look that up to make sure I know what it says and can see how it applies in the current situation.) Fourth, I’ll try to understand a general statement both in the abstract and in relation to some examples (see also Chapter 2). Fifth, if examples are hard to think of or if the provided ones look complicated, I’ll look ahead, because perhaps the professor has provided a simple example somewhere after the general statement. This happens a lot. Mathematicians know that general statements can be hard to understand, so they often give a straightforward example fairly soon afterwards.

这种阅读的总体特点是，有些内容需要回顾，有些内容需要展望；我跳来跳去的次数比阅读其他类型的文本要多得多。我希望能够描述我如何知道何时做什么——当我认为合理地认为“好吧，没关系，我现在继续读下去，看看下面几行是否有意义”时。但恐怕我真的不知道我是如何做出这些决定的——我认为我更多地是基于对我需要什么的感觉，而不是基于告诉我如何表现的规则。尽管如此，我希望看到我阅读过程的图示可以帮助您了解如何理解讲义。现在似乎是提醒您第 3 章中的一条建议的好时机：您必须阅读这些文字。你真的必须这样做。想想如果您只是跳到前面去寻找最近的计算，您会错过该摘录中的多少信息。

An overall characteristic of this reading is that some of it involves looking back and some of it involves looking ahead; I jump around much more than I would do if I were reading a different kind of text. I’d like to be able to describe how I know when to do what—when I consider it reasonable to think “Well, never mind, I’ll move on now and see if that makes sense a few lines further down.” But I don’t really know how I make those decisions, I’m afraid—I think I do it more on the basis of a feeling about what I need rather than a rule that tells me how to behave. Nonetheless, I hope that seeing an illustration of my reading process might help you see what you could do to make sense of lecture notes. And this seems like a good time for a reminder of a piece of advice from Chapter 3: you must read the words. You really must. Think how much information you’d have missed from that extract if you’d just skipped ahead to find the nearest calculation.

7.4 综合阅读

7.4 Reading for synthesis

当我说综合阅读时，我的意思是阅读以了解整个课程中涵盖的数学知识是如何结合在一起的。从实用角度来说，这是可取的，因为它将帮助你消化材料以准备考试。从智力角度来说，这也是可取的，因为数学的乐趣之一在于看到整个数学理论领域中的关系。

When I say reading for synthesis, I mean reading to understand how the mathematics covered in a whole course fits together. This is desirable pragmatically because it will help you to digest the material in preparation for an exam. It’s also desirable intellectually, because one of the joys of mathematics lies in seeing the relationships within a whole area of mathematical theory.

在某种程度上，了解课程如何结合在一起是很自然的——你会注意到各种计算之间存在相似之处，一些定理是使用早期定理证明的，等等。事实上，如果你认真听讲（见第 9 章），你会发现你的教授提供了很多信息来帮助你识别这种联系。尽管如此，你也许可以通过在这个方向上做出一些明显的努力来提高你对正在发生的事情的整体掌握。我有一些关于你如何做到这一点的具体建议；如果你在课程进展过程中遵循这些建议，你会发现你已经建立了在开始准备考试之前，准备好一套好的复习笔记。

To some extent, getting a sense of how a course fits together will be natural—you will notice that there are similarities between various calculations, that some theorems are proved using earlier theorems, and so on. Indeed, if you are listening properly (see Chapter 9) you will find that your professor gives a lot of information to help you recognize this kind of link. Nonetheless, you might be able to improve your overall grasp of what’s going on by making some overt effort in this direction. I have some specific suggestions regarding how you might do this; if you follow these suggestions as a course progresses, you will find that you’ve already built up a good set of revision notes by the time you want to start your exam preparation.

第一个策略是持续总结课堂笔记的内容。课程开始时，您可能会获得类似这样的内容，形式为目录页或课程大纲（现在很多教授都提供某种形式的印刷笔记，这种情况越来越普遍）。但是，目录页可能不是您想要的，因为它将包括章节标题和副标题，但不包含定义和定理等的实际内容。我的意思是可能看起来更像这样（我想象这是关于关系的笔记部分的开头）：

The first strategy is to keep a running summary of what is in the lecture notes. You might be provided with something like this at the beginning of a course, in the form of a contents page or a course outline (this is getting more common now that so many professors provide some form of printed notes). However, a contents page probably isn’t quite what you want, because it will include chapter headings and subheadings but not the actual content of definitions and theorems, and so on. I mean something that might look more like this (I’m imagining this is the beginning of a section of notes that is about relations):

定义：关系（一般关系的符号为～）

Definition: relation (notation for general relation is ~)

关系的例子（=、< 等）

Examples of relations (=, <, etc.)

定义：对称关系 ( a ~ b ⇒ b ~ a )

Definition: symmetric relation (a ~ b ⇒ b ~ a)

示例（= 对称，< 不对称）

Examples (= symmetric, < not symmetric)

定义：自反关系（a ~ a）

Definition: reflexive relation (a ~ a)

示例 (= 反身，< 非反身)

Examples (= reflexive, < not reflexive)

定义：传递关系（a ~ b和b ~ c ⇒ a ~ c）

Definition: transitive relation (a ~ b and b ~ c ⇒ a ~ c)

示例（= 和 < 均为及物动词）

Examples (both = and < transitive)

我在这里使用了一种我从未在为别人写的数学文章中采用过的缩写方式（有关正式写作的讨论，请参阅第 8 章）。我为自己总结，因此我只包含足够的信息来提醒自己每个数学部分的含义。我了解了项目的状态（它是一个定义、一个定理、一组示例等？）以及一个简短的注释来提醒我至少一些主要思想。如果您非常感兴趣，您可能希望用页码补充这种总结，以便您可以轻松地在总结和笔记之间移动。

I’m abbreviating here in a way that I never would in a piece of mathematical writing for someone else (see Chapter 8 for a discussion of formal writing). I’m summarizing for myself, so I’m including just enough information to remind myself what each bit of mathematics is about. I’ve got the status of the item (is it a definition, a theorem, a set of examples, etc.?) and a brief note to remind me of at least some of the main ideas. If you’re feeling super-keen, you might like to supplement this sort of summary with page numbers so that you can easily move between the summary and your notes.

除了总体总结之外，你可能还想保留一个单独的定义列表。这可以在做习题集等时为你节省大量时间。出于第 3 章中讨论的原因，你需要经常使用定义，如果你一直需要搜索笔记要找到它们，你会浪费很多时间。你确实需​​要确保你的定义在逻辑上绝对正确，所以在这种情况下，我会把每一个定义都完整地写出来（目的与总结列表不同：准确而不是简洁）。把定义列表放在笔记的前面，然后你就可以轻松参考它。你也可以保留一个定理列表，如果它看起来有用的话。我个人会把它与定义列表分开，因为定义和定理在数学理论中的地位不同。但你可能会发现不同的方法适用于不同的课程。

As well as an overall summary, you might also like to keep a separate definitions list. This can save you a lot of time when doing problem sets and the like. For the reasons discussed in Chapter 3, you will need to use definitions frequently and, if you keep having to search through your notes to find them, you’ll waste a lot of time. You do need to make sure your definitions are absolutely logically correct, so in this case I would write each one out in full (the aim is different from that of the summary list: accuracy instead of brevity). Keep the definitions list at the front of your notes and then you can refer to it easily. You might also keep a theorems list, if that looks like being useful. Personally I would keep this separate from the definitions list, because of the different status of definitions and theorems within mathematical theory. But you might find that different approaches work in different courses.

制作简短列表应该可以帮助您了解课程内容，而不会陷入细节。这对您来说可能足够了，特别是如果您本来就是列表制作者的话。就我个人而言，我可以使用列表，但我真正喜欢的是好的图表。因此，我倾向于使用概念图（您可能听说过它们被称为蜘蛛图或思维导图）。例如，这是我为最近的多元微积分课程制作的概念图的一部分（您可能不知道方框中所有文字的含义，但它应该可以让您了解我如何布置这些东西）：

Making abbreviated lists should help you to get an overview of what’s in a course without getting bogged down in the detail. This might be enough for you, especially if you are a list-maker anyway. Personally, I’m okay with lists but what I really like is a good diagram. As a result, I tend to prefer concept maps (you might have heard these called spider diagrams or mind maps). Here, for instance, is part of a concept map I made for my recent course in Multivariable Calculus (you might not know what all the writing in the boxes means, but it should give you an idea about how I lay such things out):

我在一次复习课上把这个画在学生面前。我一点一点地画出分支，希望这能让学生更清楚地认识到，虽然这门课程“很大”，但可以从关键主题的角度来思考，也可以从实现类似目标的不同程序的角度来思考。

I drew this in front of the students during a revision lecture. I drew the branches bit by bit, and my hope is that this made clearer to the students that, although the course was “large,” it could be thought of in terms of key topics, and in terms of different procedures that achieve similar aims.

多元微积分（通常）涉及一些定理和证明以及计算导数和积分的大量程序。从这个意义上说，它有点像混合体。概念图对于规划完全基于理论证明的纯数学课程甚至更有用，因为这样人们就可以使用箭头来捕捉逻辑依赖关系；指示哪些定义和定理用于证明哪些其他定理。例如，这是名为“分析”的课程中连续性主题的概念图的一部分。在这幅图中，我还使用了不同的形状来表示定义（椭圆形）、示例（八边形）和定理（矩形）：

Multivariable Calculus (usually) involves some theorems and proofs and numerous procedures for calculating derivatives and integrals. It is a bit of a hybrid in that sense. Concept maps can be even more useful for mapping out a fully theoretical proof-based pure mathematics course, because then one can use arrows to capture logical dependence; to indicate which definitions and theorems are used to prove which other theorems. Here, for example, is part of a concept map for the continuity topic in a course called Analysis. In this one, I also used different shapes for the definitions (ovals), examples (octagons), and theorems (rectangles):

我在课程开始时分发了整张地图的复印件，以便学生能够跟踪课程的进展。据我所知，没有多少教授会这样做。事实上，我可能对我的学生不利，因为也许学生自己制作地图会更好为自己绘制概念图。制作一个好的概念图当然比制作一个好的列表更难。如果是列表，你只需按照出现的顺序记录课程内容，然后由你的教授决定。如果是概念图，你必须寻找与什么相关的内容，并可能决定哪些链接值得记录。这正是你的教授希望你做的事情。

I gave out copies of the whole map at the beginning of the course so that students could keep track of the build-up of the course. As far as I know, not many professors do this sort of thing. In fact, I might have done my students a disservice, because maybe it is better for a student to produce a concept map for themselves. Certainly making a good concept map is harder than making a good list. In the case of a list, you’ll just be recording what’s in the course in the order in which it appears, and your professor decides that. In the case of a concept map, you’ll have to look for what is linked to what, and probably make some decisions about which of those links are worth recording. That’s exactly the sort of thing your professors would want you to do.

最后，既然我在谈论综合阅读，我想说一下突出显示和颜色编码。许多学生似乎有点沉迷于荧光笔。他们的笔记的每一页都有突出显示，有时还使用各种颜色。他们使用突出显示似乎不是为了表示“这很重要”，而是为了表示“我见过这一行！”我不认为这有什么不对——我个人不喜欢它，因为我认为它使页面看起来花哨且难以阅读，但我可以看到有些人可能认为它有吸引力。但如果我认为学生错过了使用突出显示来表达某种含义的机会，我会感到担忧。例如，也许可以用粉红色突出显示所有定义，用绿色突出显示所有定理。或者不是按状态而是按概念进行组织：也许用橙色表示微分，用蓝色表示积分。在我看来，这种策略可能以某种有用的方式促进记忆。用不同颜色的墨水写不同部分的笔记也是如此；如果您要使用颜色，那么可能值得建立一个系统。

Finally, while I’m talking about reading for synthesis, I’d like to say a word about highlighting and color-coding. A lot of students seem to be somewhat addicted to highlighters. Their notes have highlighting all over every page, sometimes in a variety of colors. They seem to use highlighting not to mean “this is important” so much as “I have seen this line!” I don’t suppose there’s anything wrong with that—I personally don’t like it because I think it makes the pages look garish and hard to read, but I can see that some people might think it attractive. But I would be concerned if I thought that a student had missed an opportunity to use the highlighting to mean something. Perhaps, for instance, to highlight all the definitions in pink and all the theorems in green. Or to organize, not by status, but by concept: differentiation in orange and integration in blue, perhaps. It seems to me that such a strategy might facilitate memory in some useful way. The same goes for writing different bits of notes in different colored ink; if you’re going to use color, it’s probably worth having a system.

7.5 使用总结进行复习

7.5 Using summaries for revision

我过去常常发现列表和概念图在复习时非常有用。在我读本科的第一年，我养成了将每门课程浓缩成一张纸上的列表的习惯。有时我必须先浓缩成两面，然后再进一步浓缩；这样做意味着要缩减很多内容，同时保留足够的信息，让我知道每件事的意思。但这并不难——我不必用放大镜阅读最终的列表。我直到后来才开始使用概念图，但当我攻读硕士学位时，我专攻纯数学，在每门课程结束时，我都会制作一张概念图，并将其贴在冰箱或厨房橱柜门上或某个我经常会用到的地方。会一直看到它。我不确定是一开始就制作地图有帮助，还是一直看到它有帮助，但整个过程确实让我更好地感觉到我熟悉了整个课程的结构。这些天我通常建议学生不仅要做一些总结，还要以特定的方式使用它。这就是我的建议。

I used to find lists and concept maps very useful at revision time. During my first undergraduate year, I developed a habit of condensing each course into a list on one side of paper. Sometimes I had to condense to two sides first and then condense further; doing so meant abbreviating a lot, while retaining enough information that I would know what everything meant. But it wasn’t that hard—I didn’t have to read the eventual list with a magnifying glass. I didn’t start using concept maps until a bit later, but by the time I did my masters degree I was specializing in pure mathematics, and at the end of every course I would make a concept map and stick it up on the fridge or a kitchen cupboard door or somewhere where I would see it all the time. I’m not sure whether it was making the map in the first place that helped, or seeing it all the time, but the whole process certainly gave me a better sense that I was familiar with the structure of the whole course. These days I usually advise students not only to make some kind of summary, but also to use it in a particular way. Here is that advice.

当你想要开始复习时，先通读一下你的总结，然后在每一项旁边写一个勾号（✓）来表示你对它没意见，或者写一个问号来表示你大概明白了但不太确定，或者写一个叉号来表示你对它的内容一无所知。这样做可能有点令人担忧，因为你一开始会有很多问号和叉号。但这比欺骗自己你了解和不知道的事情要好，因为它让你能够有效地改善情况。然后问自己：你应该在哪些项目上努力？很多学生说“那些带叉号的项目”。这是一个明智的直觉答案，但我认为它不太可能发挥最大作用。我认为你应该在带问号的项目上努力，原因有二。首先，你已经对这些项目有所了解，所以你很可能会取得进步。这意味着您将相当快地将事情添加到检查堆中，这是个好主意，因为（如第 13 章中进一步讨论的）最好是很好地了解某些事情，而不是糟糕地了解所有事情。这也会让你感觉良好，从而让你更有动力。其次，当您处理带问号的项目时，一些带叉号的项目将变成问号，而您根本不需要执行任何操作。发生这种情况是因为您正在增加自己的知识库，因此一些以前看似毫无意义的事情最终开始变得容易理解。当然，在某个时候，您可能仍会对所有您尚不知道的事情感到有些沮丧。如果发生这种情况，您可以随时通过处理已检查的项目来让自己振作起来。

When you want to start revising, go through your summary and, next to each item, write either a check (✓) to indicate that you are fine with it, or a question mark to indicate that you sort of get it but you’re not really sure, or a cross to indicate that you haven’t a clue what it’s about. Doing this might be a bit alarming, because you’ll start out with a fair number of question marks and crosses. But it’s better than deluding yourself about what you do and don’t know, because it puts you in a position to work effectively to improve the situation. Then ask yourself: which items should you work on? Quite a lot of students say “those with crosses.” That’s a sensible intuitive answer, but I do not think it is likely to be maximally effective. I think you should work on the items with question marks, for two reasons. First, you already know a bit about these, so you are likely to make progress. This means that you will add things to the checks pile reasonably fast, which is a good idea because (as discussed further in Chapter 13) it might be better to know some things well rather than knowing everything badly. It’ll also make you feel good, which will keep you more motivated. Second, as you work on the items with question marks, some of the things with crosses will become question marks without you having to do anything at all. This happens because you are increasing your knowledge base, so some of the things that previously seemed meaningless start to seem accessible after all. Of course, at some point you might still get a bit depressed about all the things you don’t know yet. If that happens, you can always cheer yourself up by working on your checked items for a while.

现在，这些策略对我有用，我并不是说它们一定对你有用。我不知道它们的平均效果如何。也许你已经有了比这些更有效的策略，尽管在这种情况下，你应该考虑它们是否能很好地转移到高级数学上。我确实认为，听听那些对成功人士有用的方法可能是个好建议，所以也问问你的教授或导师他们的想法。

Now, these are strategies that worked for me, and I’m not claiming that they will necessarily work for you. I don’t know how effective they are on average. It might be that you already have strategies that are more effective than these although, in that case, you should think about whether they will transfer well to upper-level mathematics. And I do think it’s probably good advice to listen to things that have worked for people who’ve been successful, so ask your professors or tutors what they think too.

7.6 阅读记忆

7.6 Reading for memory

毫无疑问：在学习专业时，你必须记住很多东西。当然，数学的一个优点是，很多时候这都是毫不费力的。当你很好地理解了数学知识时，你通常可以立即记住它，因为似乎一切都自然而然地必须如此。即使是复杂的事情，我发现我经常可以通过从更熟悉的信息中推导出我需要的东西来重建它。但你必须参加考试，这意味着在某个时候，你必须掌握大量的数学知识。在本节中，我将讨论实现这一点的一些方法。

No two ways about it: when studying for a major you are going to have to remember a lot. One glorious thing about mathematics, of course, is that much of the time this will be effortless. When you understand a piece of mathematics well, you can often just remember it immediately because it seems like everything naturally has to be that way. Even for complicated things, I find that I can often reconstruct what I need by deriving it from more familiar information. But you will have to take exams, which means that you will, at some point, have to have a lot of mathematics at your fingertips. In this section I’m going to discuss some ways of making this happen.

有一件事要做，这对程序特别有效，那就是不断练习，直到你正在做的事情成为常规。这有时在高等数学中很有效，就像你在高中时毫无疑问所做的那样。但是，正如第 1 章所讨论的，你将要学习的程序会更长，涉及更多的决策，你需要模仿的例子更少，固定的练习也更少。所以你不应该期望练习会像你早期接受教育时那样容易。你可能需要多花点心思去找练习题，使用更多的书籍，等等。或者，同样如第 1 章所讨论的，你可以考虑为自己设计练习。

One thing to do, which works particularly well for procedures, is to practice until whatever you’re doing becomes routine. This will sometimes work well in advanced mathematics, as it no doubt did for you in high school. However, as discussed in Chapter 1, the procedures you’ll be learning will be longer, they’ll involve more decisions, and you’ll have fewer examples to mimic and fewer set exercises. So you shouldn’t expect that it’ll be quite as easy to get the practice as it might have been earlier in your education. You might have to go a bit further out of your way to find practice problems, using more books, and so on. Or, also as discussed in Chapter 1, you might consider constructing exercises for yourself.

另一种记忆事物的方法是将它们与其他事物联系起来。有时，在这方面，数学语言对我们很有帮助。例如，回想一下，在第 3 章中，我们研究了函数增加的定义。如果你愿意，你可以死记硬背这个定义。你可以把它写在卡片上，然后反复测试自己，直到你做对为止。但我认为这会非常低效。增加的含义或多或少与大多数人认为它应该的含义相同，所以我不会试图记住它，而是试图通过捕捉我的直觉理解来重建它。可能是因为我喜欢图表，所以我会记住上一页那样的图表，然后从中重建它。

Another way to remember things is to relate them to other things. Sometimes, in this respect, mathematical language does us a favor. For instance, recall that in Chapter 3 we looked at a definition of increasing for functions. You could, if you wanted to, memorize that definition by rote. You could write it on a card and test yourself lots of times until you got it right. But I think that would be pretty inefficient. Increasing means more or less what most people think it ought to mean, so I wouldn’t try to memorize it, I’d try to reconstruct it by capturing my intuitive understanding instead. Probably, because I like diagrams, I’d remember a diagram like the one on the previous page, and reconstruct it from that.

现在就试一试。你能做到吗？如果能，那就太好了（但也许要检查一下你是否写了一些与我的版本在逻辑上等同的东西，以防万一）。如果不行，请回顾第 3.6 节中的定义，并确保你能明白每个部分与图表的关系。然后明天再试一次。

Have a go now. Can you do it? If so, great (but perhaps do check that you did write something logically equivalent to my version, just in case). If not, look back at the definition in Section 3.6, and make sure you can see how each part relates to the diagram. Then try again tomorrow.

类似的建议也适用于定理。有时定理陈述的内容相当复杂，你自己可能想不到。在这种情况下，可能需要刻意记忆一些内容，至少在你对课程有一定了解之前是这样。但有时定理陈述的内容简单，直观上很明显。在这种情况下，重构定理应该不太难。例如，考虑一下中间值定理（你可能会在名为“分析”的课程中遇到它）。这通常伴随着一个像下面这样的图表，它显示：

Similar advice applies for theorems. Sometimes theorems state rather complicated things that you would not have thought of for yourself. In those cases, a bit of deliberate memorization might be in order, at least until you have a reasonable grip on a course. But sometimes theorems state simple things that are quite intuitively obvious. In those cases, it shouldn’t be too hard to reconstruct the theorem. Consider, for instance, the Intermediate Value Theorem (you will probably meet this in a course called Analysis). This is often accompanied by a diagram like the one below, and it says:

定理：设f在[ a,b ]上连续， y0介于f ( a )与f ( b )之间，则存在x0∈ ( a,b ) ，使得f ( x0 ) = y0 。

Theorem: Suppose that f is continuous on [a, b] and that y0 is between f(a) and f(b). Then there exists x0 ∈ (a, b) such that f(x0) = y0.

首先，尝试将第 4 章中讨论的技能应用于此定理。你能看出图中的所有内容与它有何关联吗？对你来说，这个定理似乎是正确的吗？你能想象改变函数以便你可以检查结论是否总是成立吗？如果我们放宽f必须连续的前提，结论是否必然成立？你能看出为什么它被称为介值定理吗？然后试着掩盖定理，并在看图的同时重建它。

First, try applying the skills discussed in Chapter 4 to this theorem. Can you see how everything in the diagram relates to it? Does the theorem seem, to you, to be true? Can you imagine varying the function so you can check that the conclusion always seems to hold? What if we relaxed the premise that f has to be continuous—does the conclusion necessarily follow? Can you see why it is called the Intermediate Value Theorem? Then try covering up the theorem and reconstructing it while looking at the picture.

以下是一些关于进行这种定理重构的建议。通常情况下，记住结论似乎更容易。例如，你可能看上面的图表，首先想到写f ( x 0 ) = y 0。没有理由你不能先写下它，留下一两行空间，以便你可以围绕它安排定理的其余部分。然后，我们需要前提，并且（如第 4 章中所述）前提应该引入我们正在处理的对象。这里我们需要指定y 0在哪里，这将导致我们写出类似这样的内容：

Here is some advice about doing this kind of theorem reconstruction. Often it seems to be the case that remembering the conclusion is easier. You might, for instance, look at the diagram above and first think to write f(x0) = y0. There is no reason why you can’t write that down first, leaving a line or two of space so that you can then arrange the rest of the theorem around it. Then, we need the premise, and (as in Chapter 4) a premise should introduce the objects we’re working with. Here we need to specify where y0 is, which would lead us to write something like this:

[gap] 假设y 0介于f ( a ) 和f ( b ) 之间。

[gap] Suppose that y0 is between f(a) and f(b).

[间隙] f ( x 0 ) = y 0。

[gap] f(x0) = y0.

然后我们可以注意到需要引入x 0，并决定如何描述它。显然x 0在x轴上，我们无法确切知道它会在什么位置，除了它在a和b之间，而且显然不是每个x 0都有f(x 0 ) = y 0。因此，说存在一个具有此属性的x 0一定是合理的。这就完成了结论：

Then we can note that x0 needs to be introduced, and decide what to say about it. Clearly x0 is on the x-axis, we can’t tell exactly where it’s going to be except that it’s between a and b, and clearly it’s not the case that every x0 has f(x0) = y0. So it must be sensible to say there exists an x0 with this property. That finishes off the conclusion:

[gap] 假设y 0介于f ( a ) 和f ( b ) 之间。

[gap] Suppose that y0 is between f(a) and f(b).

则存在x 0 ∈ ( a, b ) 使得f ( x 0 )= y 0。

Then there exists x0 ∈ (a, b) such that f(x0) = y0.

这并没有完全完成前提，因为我们需要介绍函数及其属性。如果我们首先正确思考了这个定理，我们可能会想到函数需要连续——否则函数图中可能会出现跳跃，结论将不成立。所以现在我们可以完成这个定理：

It doesn’t quite finish off the premises because we need to introduce the function and its properties. If we’ve thought properly about the theorem in the first place, it will probably come to mind that the function needs to be continuous—otherwise there might be a jump in the function graph and the conclusion would not hold. So now we can complete the theorem:

假设f在 [ a, b ]上连续，且假设y 0介于f ( a ) 和f ( b ) 之间。

Suppose that f is continuous on [a, b] and suppose that y0 is between f(a) and f(b).

则存在x 0 ∈ ( a, b ) 使得f ( x 0 )= y 0。

Then there exists x0 ∈ (a, b) such that f(x0) = y0.

事实上，如果你使用其他线索，那么重建定理可能更容易。在分析中，你可能会遇到这个定理，一些研究的主要函数性质是连续性、可微性和可积性。您可能能够算出我们在这种情况下只需要连续性。但是，如果您总结得很好，您甚至可能不需要这样做；您可能只记得这个定理出现在连续性章节的末尾，所以这一定是我们所需要的。一些学生可能认为使用这种记忆技巧在某种程度上是作弊；一个专注的学生会从一开始就正确地学习一切。我想这可能是真的。但我不这么认为，因为成功的数学家聪明而有策略。他们不想花时间记忆东西，因为他们可以用一点努力和常识来重建它们。

In fact, if you use other cues then reconstructing a theorem might be even easier. In Analysis, where you will probably meet this theorem, some main function properties studied are continuity, differentiability, and integrability. You might be able to work out that we only need continuity in this case. But, if you’ve done your summarizing well, you might not even need to do that; you might just remember that this theorem appeared at the end of the continuity chapter, so that must be all we need. Some students might think that using such memory tricks is somehow cheating; that a dedicated student would just learn it all properly to begin with. I suppose that might be true. But I don’t think it is, because successful mathematicians are smart and strategic. They don’t want to spend time memorizing things when they could reconstruct them using a bit of effort and common sense.

不过，关于通过重构来记忆事物，有一件事我确实想强调：你必须给自己一点时间。我之所以这么说，是因为有时当我问学生一个问题时，我看到他们在还没想好之前就去翻看笔记。这让我很难过。有时我会在学生这样做的时候打断他们，问他们是否可以把数学从记忆中剔除。我想说，一半以上的时间，他们可以做到。他们可能需要一分钟（我的意思是真的一分钟），他们可能必须先记住其中的一部分，然后再重构其余部分。但一分钟并不比查阅所花的时间长，更重要的是，成功往往会提高他们的信心。

There is one thing I do want to emphasize, though, about remembering things by reconstructing them: you have to give yourself a bit of time. I say this because sometimes, when I ask a student a question, I see them reaching for their notes before they’ve even thought about it. This makes me sad. Sometimes I stop students as they’re doing this, and ask if they can pull the mathematics out of their memory instead. I would say that more than half of the time, they can. It might take them a minute (I mean literally a minute) and they might have to remember just part of it first and then reconstruct the rest. But a minute is no longer than it would have taken to look it up and, more to the point, succeeding tends to improve their confidence.

7.7 使用图表进行记忆

7.7 Using diagrams for memory

您可能已经注意到，在关于记忆的这些章节中，我谈了很多关于图表的事情。我们必须小心使用图表，因为很容易画出一些不够通用的东西，然后被它误导，而且图表不能代替正式证明。但图表可以以一种令人难忘的格式捕捉许多数学关系。

You might have noticed that in these sections about memory, I’ve been talking a fair bit about diagrams. We have to be careful with diagrams, because it is easy to draw something that is not quite general enough and then to be misled by it, and because a diagram does not replace a formal proof. But diagrams can capture a lot of mathematical relationships in a memorable format.

举一个简单的例子，考虑一些涉及角度的正弦、余弦和正切的标准关系。我不知道你怎么样，但我永远记不住哪个角度的正弦等于，哪个角度的正弦等于。幸运的是，我不需要。我可以通过绘制下图中的三角形并使用毕达哥拉斯定理来解决这个问题计算剩余边的长度。有时我需要尝试几次才能确定哪个长度应该是 1，但我仍然觉得这比分别记住所有正弦等等要省力；我不喜欢记住“事实”——我觉得这很困难、乏味，而且没有回报。

For a simple example, consider some standard relationships involving sines, cosines, and tangents of angles. I don’t know about you, but I can never remember which angle has sine equal to and which has sine equal to Fortunately, I don’t need to. I can work it out by drawing the triangles in the diagram below and using Pythagoras’ Theorem to work out the lengths of the remaining sides. Sometimes it takes me a couple of attempts to decide which length should be 1, but I still find this less effort than remembering all the sines, and so on, separately; I don’t like remembering “facts”—I find it difficult, tedious, and unrewarding.

在我看来，更好的是下面的图表，其中显示了一个单位圆、一个从正x轴顺时针测量的角度θ和一个直角三角形。

Even better, in my view, is the diagram below, showing a unit circle, an angle θ measured clockwise from the positive x-axis, and a right-angled triangle.

我们可以从这个图上看到什么？很多很多。首先，标记为x的点等于 cos θ。你能明白为什么吗？想想直角三角形中与θ相邻的边，其斜边长度为 1。我们可以以类似的方式在y轴上看到 sin θ。其次，我们可以看到 cos 0 = 1 和 sin 0 = 0，这很方便，特别是对于那些容易忘记正弦和余弦曲线与轴的交点的人来说。第三，它可以帮助记住和中的哪一个等于1/2。最后（虽然公平地说，似乎没有人会忘记这一点），该图清楚地表明我们总是有 cos 2 θ + sin 2 θ = 1。这是我最喜欢的图表之一，我总是很难过地看到 不熟悉它的本科生，因为它为我节省了很多工作。

What can we see on this diagram? Many, many things. First, the point marked x is equal to cos θ. Can you see why? Think about the side adjacent to θ in the right-angled triangle, for which the hypotenuse is of length 1. We can see sin θ on the y-axis in a similar way. Second, we can see that cos 0 = 1 and sin 0 = 0, which can be handy, especially for those who are prone to forgetting where the sine and cosine curves cross the axes. Third, it can help in remembering which of and is equal to 1/2. For the finale (although no-one ever seems to forget this one, to be fair) the diagram makes it obvious that we always have cos2 θ + sin2 θ = 1. This is one of my favorite diagrams and I’m always sad to meet undergraduate students who are not familiar with it, because it saves me so much work.

7.8 阅读记忆证明

7.8 Reading proofs for memory

在最后一节中，我将讨论记忆证明。学生们经常关心他们学习的这个方面。在他们看来，证明有很多，它们都是不同的，而且其中相当一部分很长。因此，这开始看起来像是一项困难的记忆任务，特别是在要求学生在考试中提供标准证明的课程中。我不会假装这并不难来侮辱你。但你可以通过采用一些你在数学程序工作中熟悉的策略来让自己轻松得多。

In this final section I will talk about remembering proofs. Students are often concerned about this aspect of their studies. It seems to them that there are many proofs, that they are all different, and that quite a few of them are long. This starts, then, to seem like a difficult memory task, especially in courses in which students are expected to produce standard proofs in an exam. I’m not going to insult you by pretending that it isn’t difficult. But you can probably make it a lot easier for yourself by adapting some strategies that are familiar from your work with mathematical procedures.

首先，请注意，当你记住一个过程时，你不会记住它的每个具体用法的细节，你只会记住主要步骤。例如，如果你必须告诉某人如何找到函数的局部最大值和最小值，你可能会说“对其进行微分，然后将导数设置为零并找到解，然后找到每个解的二阶导数；如果它是正数，则该点是最小值，反之亦然。”你不会说任何关于如何微分或特定函数的导数的内容；你只会描述主要步骤，并将其余部分视为常规计算。

First, notice that when you remember a procedure, you don’t remember every detail of a particular use of it, you just remember the main steps. For instance, if you had to tell someone how to locate the local maxima and minima of a function, you’d probably say something like “differentiate it, then set the derivative to zero and find the solutions, then find the second derivative for each solution; if it’s positive, the point is a minimum, and vice versa.” You wouldn’t say anything about how to differentiate, or about the derivatives of particular functions; you would just describe the major steps and treat the rest as routine calculations.

这也可以通过不太明显的程序性事物来实现。例如，如果你做过一些力学研究，你可能已经解决了涉及静止粒子的问题（在有摩擦的斜坡上，诸如此类）。你解决这类问题的步骤可能类似于“画一个图来表示物理情况，用箭头标记所有力，决定要处理的方向（水平/垂直或沿着斜坡向下并垂直于斜坡），然后在这些方向上平衡力。”同样，这在任何特定问题中如何发挥作用是一个细节问题。如果你对这个过程有一个概述，你可以在进行过程中为任何特定情况制定出那个细节。

This can also be done with less obviously procedural things. For instance, if you’ve done some mechanics, you’ve probably solved problems involving particles at rest (on a slope with friction, that kind of thing). Your set of steps for this kind of problem is probably something like “draw a diagram to represent the physical situation, mark all the forces on it with arrows, decide which directions to work with (horizontal/vertical or down the slope and perpendicular to that), then equate forces in those directions.” Again, how this plays out in any particular problem is a matter of detail. If you have an overview of the process, you can work out that detail for any particular case as you go along.

构造和重构证明可能有点像这样。开始可能相当机械。当证明一个定义是满足后，我们通常可以使用该定义来构建证明，而在证明更一般的定理为真时，该定理的结构也可以以类似的方式帮助我们（参见第 5 章）。我们总是可以尝试用定义来写出前提和结论，并且有几种标准证明类型和技巧可用于证明特定类型的陈述（参见第 6 章）。总之，我们可以将证明视为一种更高级的过程：“确定要证明的内容的结构，用定义来写出前提和结论，考虑标准证明类型（如果遇到困难，请尝试思考具体的例子）。”

Constructing and reconstructing proofs can be a bit like this. Getting started can be quite mechanical. When proving that a definition is satisfied, we can often use that definition to structure a proof, and when proving that a more general theorem is true, the structure of that theorem can help us in a similar way (see Chapter 5). We can always try writing premises and conclusions in terms of definitions, and there are several standard proofs types and tricks that are useful for proving particular types of statement (see Chapter 6). In all, we can treat proving as a sort of higher-level procedure: “ascertain the structure of what is to be proved, write premises and conclusions in terms of definitions, consider standard proof types (if get stuck, try thinking about specific examples).”

如果您以这种方式思考证明，并且如果您在寻找使用标准结构和技巧的地方，您应该会发现即使是很长的证明也不会显得太神秘。在本科阶段，很少证明会涉及多个好的技巧。因此，您可以将看到的大多数证明简化为压缩版本，类似于“根据定义编写，执行加减f ( x + h ) g ( x ) 的技巧，拆分部分，并以显而易见的方式操作代数”（这是对微分乘积规则证明的描述 - 您认出来了吗？）。如果您可以对遇到的大多数证明执行此操作，您会发现即使是证明繁重的课程也不会包含那么多想法。您看到的大多数 10 或 15 行证明可能可以简化为两三个主要步骤，因此您只需记住这些主要步骤即可重建整个内容。您必须填写一些代数运算或其他计算方面的细节，但您无论如何都习惯于使用程序来做这些事情。因此，能够在考试中重建证明并不容易，但是，如果您通过考虑主要步骤来减少工作量，这也并非不可能。

If you think of proving in this way, and if you are on the lookout for places in which standard structures and tricks are used, you should find that even long proofs don’t seem too mysterious. At the undergraduate level, it’s a rare proof that involves more than one good trick. So you can probably reduce most of the proofs you see to a compressed version along the lines of “write in terms of definitions, perform trick of adding and subtracting f(x + h)g(x), split up pieces, and manipulate algebra in obvious way” (that was a description of the proof of the product rule for differentiation—did you recognize it?). If you can do this for most of the proofs you encounter, you will find that even a proof-heavy course doesn’t have that many ideas in it. Most of the 10- or 15-line proofs you see can probably be reduced to two or three main steps, so that you only need to remember these main steps in order to reconstruct the whole thing. You’ll have to fill in some detail in terms of algebraic manipulations or other calculations, but you’re used to doing that with procedures anyway. So being able to reconstruct proofs in exams is not easy but, if you reduce the workload by thinking in terms of the main steps, it needn’t be impossible either.

作为本章的最后一点，我还有一点要说，关于为了记忆而阅读，尤其是阅读相当长的证明时：如果你决定死记硬背某些东西，一定要非常非常小心。我希望你无论如何都不要这么做，因为这不是一种值得花时间的方式。但如果你真的尝试了，你应该意识到，对于教授来说，当有人这样做时，通常非常明显。有时，在学生的考试中，我看到一个证明，当我把它放在手臂长度的地方时，它看起来还不错，但当我真正开始阅读它时，它完全没有意义。有时逻辑混乱，关键思想缺失，或者以奇怪的、不合逻辑的顺序呈现。有时符号在引入之前就被使用，或者引入后从未使用，或者引入时表示一种意思，但显然过去表示另一种意思。看到这种情况我感到很难过，因为很明显学生已经真正努力去记住这部分数学知识。但是，他们写得这么差，表明他们不理解它。因此，我不能给他们高分，因为我看重的是理解。所以，在你诉诸死记硬背之前，请尝试用尽所有可能导致理解的方法——你可以做很多事情，这会更令人满意。

As a final point in this chapter, I have one more thing to say about reading for memory, especially when it comes to fairly long proofs: be very, very careful if you decide you’re going to memorize something by rote. I hope you won’t do that anyway, because it’s not a rewarding use of time. But if you do try, you should be aware that for a professor, it is often very obvious when someone has done this. Sometimes, on a student’s exam, I see a proof that looks alright when I hold it out at arm’s length, but that makes no sense at all when I actually start to read it. Sometimes the logic is all over the place, and key ideas are missing or are presented in strange, illogical orders. Sometimes notation is used before it is introduced, or introduced then never used, or introduced to mean one thing but apparently used to mean another. I feel bad when I see this kind of thing, because clearly the student has made a genuine effort to remember this piece of mathematics. But, by writing it so badly, they have demonstrated that they do not understand it. I cannot, then, give them a good grade, because understanding is what I value. So please try to exhaust all approaches that might lead to understanding before you resort to rote memorization—there are many things you could do that would be much more satisfying.

概括

SUMMARY

• 学习数学专业需要独立阅读；您的这方面经验可能有限，因此可能涉及培养新技能。

• Studying as a mathematics major will involve independent reading; your experience of this might be limited so it might involve developing new skills.

• 您可能不会理解讲座中的所有内容，因此您必须研究讲义；不这样做的学生通常会发现很难开始解决问题。

• You will probably not understand everything in your lectures, so you will have to study your lecture notes; students who do not do this often find it difficult to get started on problems.

• 阅读讲义并不一定容易；笔记通常包含一般解释和示例的组合，并且可能需要一些工作来建立它们之间的联系。

• Reading lecture notes is not necessarily easy; notes usually contain a combination of general explanations and examples, and it might take some work to establish the links between them.

• 阅读数学应该包括识别不同项目的状态，查找先前的定义和定理，将例子与一般陈述联系起来，以及比普通阅读更多地回顾和展望。

• Reading mathematics should involve identifying the status of different items, looking up earlier definitions and theorems, relating examples to general statements, and looking back and ahead more than is usual in ordinary reading.

• 在阅读综合材料时​​，各种类型的摘要都很有用：您可能需要考虑保留内容列表、定义列表和概念图。

• Various types of summary can be useful when reading for synthesis: you might want to consider keeping contents lists, definitions lists, and concept maps.

• 可以使用摘要来帮助制定修订计划；我建议使用勾号/问号/叉号系统，并首先处理问号项目。

• Summaries can be used to aid revision planning; I suggest a check/questionmark/cross system, and working first on the question-mark items.

• 练习在阅读记忆中起着重要作用，但你的目标是能够记住图表或定义、定理或证明的关键思想，并重建其余部分。

• Practice has its place in reading for memory, but you should aim for a situation in which you can remember a diagram or the key ideas of a definition, theorem, or proof, and reconstruct the rest.

进一步阅读

FURTHER READING

有关阅读数学证明的更多信息，请尝试：

For more on reading mathematical proofs, try:

• Solow, D. (2005).如何阅读和做证明。新泽西州霍博肯：John Wiley。

• Solow, D. (2005). How to Read and Do Proofs. Hoboken, NJ: John Wiley.

• Allenby, RBJT (1997)。数字与证明。牛津：Butterworth Heinemann。

• Allenby, R.B.J.T. (1997). Numbers & Proofs. Oxford: Butterworth Heinemann.

有关考试准备的更多信息，请尝试：

For more on preparation for tests and exams, try:

• Moore, S. & Murphy, S. (2005)。《如何做一名学生：适合世界各地学生的 100 个好主意和实用习惯》。梅登黑德：开放大学出版社。

• Moore, S. & Murphy, S. (2005). How to be a Student: 100 Great Ideas and Practical Habits for Students Everywhere. Maidenhead: Open University Press.

• Newport, C. (2007)。《如何成为一名全优生：大学生在学习时间较少的情况下取得高分的非常规策略》。纽约：Three Rivers Press。

• Newport, C. (2007). How to Become a Straight-A Student: The Unconventional Strategies Real College Students Use to Score High While Studying Less. New York: Three Rivers Press.

第 8 章

数学写作

CHAPTER 8

Writing Mathematics

本章介绍了良好的数学写作的重要性，以及为什么你不仅要追求正确的答案，还要以专业的方式表达你的想法。它解释了如何确保你的数学论证清晰地表达出来，并给出了在使用新的数学符号时避免常见错误的技巧。

This chapter is about the importance of good mathematical writing, and why you should aim not only for correct answers but also for professional presentation of your ideas. It explains how to make sure your mathematical arguments are presented clearly, and gives tips on avoiding common mistakes when using new mathematical symbols.

8.1 识别优秀写作

8.1 Recognizing good writing

考虑以下两个计算，每个计算的作者都试图找到

Consider the following two calculations, the author of each of which is trying to find

不要关注你是否知道不同的（也许更好的）计算方法。相反，把自己想象成一个读者，并注意你需要做多少工作才能跟上每个人的思维。

Do not focus on whether you know a different (perhaps better) way of doing the calculation. Instead, think of yourself as a reader, and pay attention to how much work you have to do to follow each person’s thinking.

作为读者，您认为哪种计算更好？对于数学家来说，显然是第二种。这两个论点包含的信息基本相同，但第二种更容易阅读。它用几个词来解释每个阶段发生的事情，因此读者可以理解为什么某些操作是有效和/或合理的。它还为原始积分提供了一个名称并始终使用它，并使用星号来指示不同方程的组合位置。第一个计算并没有错，但它跳来跳去，没有解释，所以读者必须做很多工作才能明白它们是如何结合在一起的。数学家会认为这不是读者的工作——作者可以而且应该做更多来帮助他们。

As a reader, which calculation would you say is better? To a mathematician, it’s obviously the second one. The two arguments contain essentially the same information, but the second one is much easier to read. It has a few words to explain what is going on at each stage, so the reader can see why certain manipulations are valid and/or sensible. It also gives a name to the original integral and uses this throughout, and uses an asterisk to indicate where different equations are being combined. The first calculation isn’t wrong, but it jumps around without explanation, so the reader has to do a lot of work to see how it all fits together. A mathematician would believe that it’s not the reader’s job to do this—that the writer can and should do more to help them out.

现在，哪一个看起来更像你自己写数学的方式？如果你是一个典型的数学专业新生，而且你不是一个惯性撒谎者，你可能会说是第一个。我这样说并不是想打击你，恰恰相反：我想让你意识到，即使你写得并不总是很好，你也知道好的数学写作是什么样的。

Now, which of these looks more like the way you write your own mathematics? If you are a typical new mathematics major, and if you’re not an inveterate liar, you might have to say that it’s the first one. I don’t say this to be discouraging, quite the reverse: I want you to be aware that, even if you don’t always write well, you do recognize what good mathematical writing looks like.

即使考虑到这一点，学生们也常常对高等数学对写作的重视感到惊讶。这促使一些人到处说这样的话：“我不敢相信我们必须这样做——我选择数学是因为我不想写论文！”当然，这些人太夸张了。没有人要求你写论文。他们只是要求你把逻辑说清楚。我已经谈过这一点了——好的表达方式可以让别人更清楚地了解你的想法，并帮助你避免歧义。在本章中，我将回顾其中的一些想法，并描述一些常见的错误，以便你能够识别和避免它们。

Even with this in mind, students are often surprised by the focus on writing in advanced mathematics. It prompts some to go around saying things like “I can’t believe we have to do this—I chose math because I didn’t want to write essays!” Such people are being over-dramatic, of course. No-one is asking you to write essays. They are just asking you to make your logic clear. I’ve already talked about this—good presentation can make your thinking clearer to someone else, and can help you to avoid ambiguity. In this chapter, I will review some of those ideas, and describe some common errors so that you can recognize and avoid them.

8.2 学生为什么应该写好文章？

8.2 Why should a student write well?

如果你的老师和教授已经教过你专注于数学写作，那么本章中的许多建议可能对你来说很熟悉。如果没有，也不要担心——写好文章并不难，只是在高级课程中比在早期教育中更重要。不过，在开始之前，我要提醒你一句：你可能会认为本章中的一些建议过于挑剔和迂腐。如果是这样，请忍耐一下：你不想被认为是一个糟糕的数学思考者，而实际上你一个好的思考者，却是一个糟糕的作家。为了进一步激励你努力，我将为你提供三个写好文章的理由。

If your teachers and professors have already taught you to focus on mathematical writing, then much of the advice in this chapter might be familiar. If not, don’t worry—it isn’t hard to write well, it’s just considered more important in upper level courses than it typically is in earlier education. A word of warning before we start, however: you may think that some of the advice in this chapter is finicky and pedantic. If so, bear with it: you don’t want to be considered a poor mathematical thinker when you are actually a good thinker and just a poor writer. To further motivate you to make the effort, I will offer you three reasons for writing well.

第一个原因是短期的实用原因：写得好会让你获得更好的成绩。如果你能写得好，你将在课程作业和考试中取得更好的成绩。一些学生在开始学习高级课程时认为这有点不公平。他们认为，因为这是数学，所以重点应该放在得到正确的答案上。为了解释为什么这并不不公平，我通常会让他们想象有人给出了一个错误的答案。这种情况经常发生，尤其是在考试中。现在请你站在我的立场上，作为一名正在评分的教授。如果一个学生给出了一个错误的答案，但他们的论证写得逻辑清晰，那么我可以很有信心地说，他们知道自己在做什么，只是犯了一个小错误（少了一个减号，或者其他什么）。在这种情况下，我通常很乐意给他们大部分分数。另一方面，如果一个学生给出了一个写得很差的错误答案，我通常无法判断他们是否知道自己在做什么。如果他们写的论点到处都是，我都不知道它们应该如何串联起来，那么情况就更是如此了。他们可能知道自己在做什么，但也可能根本不知道，只是随便写下一些东西，希望得到部分学分。我应该相信他们吗？如果你是写了这样一个“论点”的学生，你可能会倾向于说是的。但如果你是一个得到了同样错误答案但论点写得很好的学生，你可能会认为写得不好的人不值得得到学分——你的论点表明了更好的数学理解。这就是我必须一直做出的判断。如果我不知道某人的想法是否合理，那么我就不能凭良心给他们一个好成绩。这对其他学生不公平。

The first reason is a short-term pragmatic one: writing well will get you better grades. If you do it, you will do better in coursework assignments and exams. Some students, when they start taking upper-level courses, think this is a bit unfair. They think that, because this is mathematics, the emphasis should be on getting the right answer. To explain why it is not unfair, I usually ask them to imagine that someone has given an incorrect answer. This happens quite a lot, especially in exams. Now put yourself in my shoes, as a professor doing the grading. If a student has given an incorrect answer, but has written their argument so that all their logic is clear, then I can say with some confidence that they knew what they were doing, and that they have just made a minor error (lost a minus sign, or something). In that case, I’m often happy to give them most of the points. On the other hand, if a student has given a badly-written incorrect answer, often I cannot tell whether they knew what they were doing or not. This is especially true if they have written bits of their argument all over the place, so that I don’t know how it is all supposed to fit together. It might be that they knew what they were doing, but it might be that they had no idea and were just writing down random things in the hope of getting partial credit. Should I give them the benefit of the doubt? If you were the student who had written such an “argument,” you might be inclined to say yes. But if you were a student who got the same wrong answer but wrote the argument well, you’d probably think that the person who wrote badly did not deserve the credit—that your argument shows better mathematical understanding. That’s the kind of judgment I have to make all the time. If I can’t tell whether someone’s thinking was reasonable, then I can’t in good conscience give them a good grade. It wouldn’t be fair to the other students.

写得好的第二个原因也是务实的，但更为长远，如果你有一天打算赚很多钱，那么它可能会吸引你。原因如下：无论你从事什么职业，都需要以书面形式与他人沟通，如果你做不好这件事，你会发现很难成功。如果你成为一名会计师，你将不得不用标准语言编写报告，以便公司的不同部门能够了解与他们有关的财务状况。如果你成为一名精算师，你将不得不研究你的客户公司应该如何投资员工的养老金供款，并提供建议，解释各种选择的优势和风险。如果你成为一家大型零售公司的物流经理，你将不得不决定如何有效地运输你的库存，并且你必须编写文件来解释你的系统如何运作以及为什么它是一个好的系统。如果你成为一名企业家，你将不得不为银行和潜在投资者制作文件，以令人信服地证明你的产品或服务的效用，并详细说明你和他们如何通过提供这些产品或服务来赚钱。如果你成为一名对冲基金经理，你将不得不为你的客户制作文件来解释和证明你的投资决策。如果你成为政府、气象服务或大型制药公司的统计员，你将不得不设计和测试统计模型来预测和解释现实世界的现象，你必须证明为什么你的模型比其他模型更好，以及为什么你的前辈如果想提高他们的预测就应该听你的。如果你成为一名教师，你将不得不每天向不同年龄和能力的学生做演讲，并以书面形式与家长、学校董事会、管理人员等进行沟通。你明白我的意思。如果你想要有工作机会，想要成功，那么善于解决问题显然很重要。但同样重要的是，能够令人信服地传达你认为最好的解决方案。聪明的人不会对结构不良或表达不佳的论点印象深刻，无论是数学论点还是其他论点。所以现在通过学习以让你的教授满意的方式写作来练习是个好主意。

The second reason for writing well is also pragmatic but is more longterm, and might appeal to you especially if you intend, one day, to make a lot of money. It is this: whatever career you go into, it will involve communicating with others in writing, and if you do not do this well you will find it difficult to be successful. If you become an accountant, you will have to produce reports in standard language so that different parts of your company can understand the financial situation as it pertains to them. If you become an actuary, you will have to work out how your client companies should invest their employees’ pension contributions, and provide recommendations explaining the advantages and risks associated with various options. If you become a logistics manager for a large retail company, you will have to make decisions about how to move your stock around efficiently, and you will have to write documents that explain how your system operates and why it is a good one. If you become an entrepreneur, you will have to produce documents for banks and potential investors that make a convincing case for the utility of your products or services and that detail how you and they can make money by providing them. If you become a hedge fund manager, you will have to produce documentation for your clients to explain and justify your investment decisions. If you become a statistician for the government or the weather service or a major drugs company, you will have to design and test statistical models to predict and explain real-world phenomena, and you will have to justify why your model is better than other models and why your seniors should listen to you if they want to improve their predictions. If you become a teacher, you will have to give daily presentations to students of various ages and abilities, and to communicate in writing with parents, school boards, managers, and so on. You see my point. If you want to be employable and you want to be successful, then obviously it’s important to be good at working out how to solve problems. But it’s also important to be able to communicate convincingly about whatever you think is the best solution. Intelligent people are not impressed by poorly constructed or poorly presented arguments, mathematical or otherwise. So it’s a good idea to get some practice now by learning to write in a way that satisfies your professors.

写作能力强的第三个原因是我认为的真正原因，它与学术领域的智力成熟度有关。在教育的这个阶段，你应该不仅发展数学知识，还要发展专业数学家的工作实践。这意味着理解他们的思维过程，但也意味着理解他们如何相互交流，并学会以同样的方式自己交流。要做到这一点，你必须学习符号使用的惯例，以及逻辑论证的更大规模布局。这样的惯例可能看起来很随意，但任何类型的惯例都会加快一切速度：每个人都知道会发生什么，所以每个人都能更快、更准确地处理新信息。这并非数学所独有。如果你是如果你在学习建筑学，如果你不能构建和解释标准图表和规范文档，你就无法取得好成绩；如果你在学习社会学，如果你不能撰写一篇论证严谨的文章，你就无法取得好成绩。如果你想成为一名数学家，如果你不能提出自己的论点，让同行认为这些论点连贯且合乎逻辑，你就无法取得好成绩。遵守标准惯例将帮助你做到这一点，从而获得成熟和有智力的数学思想家的认可。

The third reason for writing well is what I would consider the real one, and it is about intellectual maturity in relation to an academic field. At this stage in your education you are supposed to be developing knowledge, not only of mathematics, but also of the working practices of professional mathematicians. That means understanding their thinking processes, but it also means understanding how they communicate with each other, and learning to communicate in the same way yourself. To do so, you have to learn about conventions for the use of notation, and also for the larger-scale layout of logical arguments. Such conventions might seem arbitrary, but conventions of any kind speed everything up: everyone knows what to expect, so everyone can process new information faster and more accurately. This is not unique to mathematics. If you were studying architecture, you would not do well unless you could construct and interpret standard diagrams and specification documents; if you were studying sociology, you would not do well if you could not construct a cogently-argued essay. If you want to be a mathematician, you will not do well unless you can present your arguments so that those in your field recognize them as coherent and logically sound. Adhering to standard conventions will help you to do that, and thus to gain recognition as a mature and intellectually-able mathematical thinker.

8.3 写出清晰的论据

8.3 Writing a clear argument

在第 5 章和第 6 章中，我们研究了许多定理和证明，我评论了你应该注意的事项，并将它们融入到你自己的数学写作中。如果你遵循这个建议，你就不会犯太大的错误。然而，某些错误在本科生的写作中特别常见。在本章中，我将重点介绍其中的一些错误，首先是人们在试图提出逻辑论证时常犯的错误。

In Chapters 5 and 6 we looked at a number of theorems and proofs, and I commented on things you should notice about them and incorporate into your own mathematical writing. If you follow that advice, you should not go too far wrong. However, certain errors are particularly common in undergraduates’ writing. In this chapter, I will highlight some of these, starting with common errors people make when trying to present a logical argument.

首先，考虑论证的开头。学生经常做的一件事就是把想要的定理或结论写成开场白。例如，在回答“证明如果f是偶函数，则 d f / d x是奇函数”这个问题时，他们首先这样写：

First, consider the beginning of an argument. One thing students often do is write the desired theorem or conclusion as the opening line. For example, when addressing the question “Prove that if f is an even function, then df / dx is an odd function,” they begin by writing:

f为偶数 ⇒ d f / d x为奇数。

f is even ⇒ df / dx is odd.

我确信学生这样做是因为他们想提醒自己他们试图证明什么，从这个意义上说，这是明智的。但对于读者来说，这很令人困惑，因为看起来学生已经开始假设他们试图证明的事情。当然，写下你想要证明的东西是完全可以的，但你可以通过明确陈述的状态来帮助你的读者。例如，你可以写下以下内容之一：

I’m pretty sure that students do this because they want to remind themselves of what they are trying to prove, and in that sense it’s sensible. But for a reader it is confusing, because it looks like the student has started by assuming the thing they are trying to prove. Of course, it’s perfectly okay to write down what you want to prove, but you can help your reader by making the status of the statement clear. For example, you might write one of the following:

我们要证明f为偶数 ⇒ d f / d x为奇数。

We want to prove that f is even ⇒ df / dx is odd.

声明： f为偶数 ⇒ d f / d x为奇数。

Claim: f is even ⇒ df / dx is odd.

这两种表述方式都表明你知道自己要做什么，但同时你也知道你还没有证明这一点。

Either of these formulations shows that you know what you’re going for, but also that you know you haven’t proved it yet.

其次，考虑论证中各行之间的联系。在学校数学课上，你经常会写出类似这样的内容：

Second, consider the links between lines in an argument. In school mathematics, you will often have written things like this:

这样的一系列方程式并没有错，但各行之间没有明确的逻辑联系。作为一名面对此类问题的读者，我不知道学生的意思是每一行都蕴含着下一行，还是每一行都等同于下一行，或者完全是其他意思。这似乎并不重要，但事实上它很重要。我们可以通过查看这组方程式来看到这一点：

Such a series of equations is not wrong, but it has no explicit logical connections between the lines. As a reader faced with something like this, I don’t know whether the student means that each line implies the next one, or each line is equivalent to the next one, or something else entirely. This might not seem to matter but in fact it does, rather a lot. We can see this by looking at this set of equations instead:

尝试将x的解代入原始方程，你会发现有些地方出了问题。你能找出问题出在哪里吗？

Try substituting the solutions for x back into the original equation, and you will see that something has gone wrong. Can you work out where?

如果我们正确使用联结词，答案就会变得更加清晰。有些相邻的线对彼此等价，但我们对两边求平方的步骤仅作为单向蕴涵有效。虽然

The answer becomes clearer if we use connectives properly. Some adjacent pairs of lines are equivalent to each other, but the step at which we square both sides is only valid as a one-way implication. While it is true that

事实并非如此

it is not true that

因此，有了适当的逻辑联系，论点看起来就像这样（仔细看箭头）：

So with appropriate logical connections, the argument looks like this (look at the arrows carefully):

因此，我们可以得出如果x = 4则x = 1的结论，但我们不能立即得出如果x = 4 则或如果x = 1 则x = 4 的结论。这不是问题，因为这个论点的真正效果是缩小了解决方案的可能性。它告诉我们唯一可能的解是 4 和 1，所以我们只需要检查它们是否真的有效。

So we can conclude that if then x = 4 or 1, but we cannot immediately conclude that if x = 4 then or that if x = 1 then This is not a problem, because the real effect of this argument is to narrow down the solution possibilities. It tells us that the only possible solutions are 4 and 1, so then we just need to check whether either of them actually works.

蕴涵和等价箭头经常用于代数论证。在其他证明中，比如第 5 章和第 6 章中的许多证明中，你经常会看到以“因此”、“因而”、“这样”或“所以”开头的几行。这些词中的任何一个都表示该词后面的一行以逻辑上有效的方式遵循前一行或多行，再加上（可能）标准逻辑推理或代数运算，或已知的定义或定理。为了避免在使用这种语言时出现错误，要注意的一点是，数学中的“所以”总是用来表示“所以它得出那个结论”，而不是“所以我们需要证明那个”。学生们有时会忘记这一点。他们会写下类似这样的话：

Implication and equivalence arrows are often used in algebraic arguments. In other proofs, like many of those in Chapters 5 and 6, you will often see lines that begin with “Therefore,” “Hence,” “Thus,” or “So.” Any of these words indicates that the line after the word follows in a logically valid way from the previous line or lines, plus (perhaps) standard logical reasoning or algebraic manipulation, or a known definition or theorem. To avoid errors in using this type of language, one thing to note is that “so” in mathematics is always used to mean “so it follows that,” not “so we need to prove that.” Students sometimes forget this. They write something like:

我们要证明f为偶数 ⇒ d f /d x为奇数。

We want to prove that f is even ⇒ df/dx is odd.

所以f ( x ) = f (− x ) ⇒ f ′(− x ) = − f ′( x )。

So f(x) = f(−x) ⇒ f′(−x) = −f′(x).

他们的意思是：

What they mean is:

我们要证明f为偶数 ⇒ d f /d x为奇数。

We want to prove that f is even ⇒ df/dx is odd.

因此我们要证明f ( x ) = f (− x ) ⇒ f ′(− x ) = − f ′( x )。

So we want to prove that f(x) = f(−x) ⇒ f′(−x) = −f′(x).

但数学家读到的是：

But what a mathematician reads is:

我们要证明f为偶数 ⇒ d f /d x为奇数。

We want to prove that f is even ⇒ df/dx is odd.

因此得出f ( x ) = f (− x ) ⇒ f ′(− x ) = − f ′( x )。

So it follows that f(x) = f(−x) ⇒ f′(−x) = −f′(x).

最后一种比较令人困惑，因为看起来学生已经从他们想要证明的东西开始，并开始从中推论。这对读者来说似乎是“倒退的”，因为我们实际上想从前提开始，然后得出结论（这也在第 5 章中讨论过）。

The last of these is confusing, because it looks like the student has started with what they want to prove and begun deducing things from it. This appears to a reader to be “backwards,” because we actually want to start from the premise and work toward the conclusion (this was also discussed in Chapter 5).

“所以”的解释是“因此可以推论”只是惯例问题，你可以自由地认为这不是你想要的解释。但是，正如我上面所说，成为任何领域成熟的思想家的一部分就是了解其惯例并学会遵守它们。

The interpretation of “so” to mean “so it follows that” is just a matter of convention, and you are free to think that it is not the interpretation that you would choose. But, as I said above, part of becoming a mature thinker in any field is learning about its conventions and learning to adhere to them.

现在，如果新一行与前面几行在逻辑上不一致，你会写什么呢？这种情况通常发生在两种情况下。第一种情况是当你需要引入某个对象或符号时。我们可以在证明中随时这样做，通常我们这样做是为了引入一个任意对象或解释某些符号在证明的其余部分中的含义。在这种情况下，通常使用“Let”这个词，例如：

Now, what do you write if a new line does not follow logically from the previous lines? There are two situations in which this commonly happens. The first occurs when you need to introduce some object or notation. We can do this whenever we need to in a proof, and usually we do it either to introduce an arbitrary object or to explain what some notation will mean in the remainder of the proof. In such cases it is common to use the word “Let,” as in:

令θ ∈任意。

Let θ ∈ be arbitrary.

假设P ( n ) 表示

Let P(n) be the statement that

第二种情况是，证明需要分别发展两个想法，然后将结果放在一起证明定理。我喜欢在这种情况下使用“现在”这个词，你经常会在证明中间的一行开头看到“现在”。它的本质意思是，“好吧，我们刚刚证明了我们需要的一件事，现在我们要在把它们放在一起之前引入一些新的东西。”我们经常需要在较长的论证中做这样的事情，有一种方式来向读者表明我们正在将他们的注意力引向一个新想法是很有用的。这种较长的论证特别出现在第 6 章中，它是也许现在值得回顾一下其中的一些内容，记住所有关于传统语言的信息。

The second situation occurs when a proof needs to develop two ideas separately, then put the results together to prove the theorem. I like the word “Now” for situations like this, and you will often see “Now” at the beginning of a line in the middle of a proof. What it means, essentially, is, “Right, we’ve just proved one thing we’ll need, and now we’re going to introduce something new before putting it all together.” We often need to do something like this in longer arguments, and it is useful to have a way of indicating to the reader that we are directing their attention to a new idea. Such longer arguments appeared in Chapter 6 in particular, and it is probably worth looking back at some of those now, bearing in mind all of this information about conventional language.

8.4 正确使用符号

8.4 Using notation correctly

本节讨论本科数学中引入的新符号，并强调学生在学习使用新符号时经常犯的错误。如果你能设法避免这些错误，你的教授会非常高兴。

This section discusses new notation that gets introduced in undergraduate mathematics, and highlights errors students often make while learning to use it. If you can manage to avoid these errors, you will make your professors very happy.

第一个常见错误最容易用一个例子来说明。假设你试图证明一些关于奇数的事情。你知道，根据定义，我们可以这样来捕获奇数

The first common error is easiest to illustrate using an example. Suppose you’re trying to prove something about odd numbers. You know that, by definition, we can capture an odd number by saying

令n为奇数，则n = 2 k + 1 ，其中k ∈ ℤ。

Let n be an odd number, so n = 2k + 1 for some k ∈ ℤ.

但假设你试图证明涉及两个奇数的某件事（当我们将它们相乘时，我们得到另一个奇数，或类似的东西）。学生有时会写类似的东西

But suppose that you’re trying to prove something involving two odd numbers (that when we multiply them together, we get another one, or something like that). Students sometimes write things like

令n和m为奇数，因此n = 2 k + 1 且m = 2 k + 1。

Let n and m be odd numbers, so n = 2k + 1 and m = 2k + 1.

你能看出为什么这不合适吗？这个定义已经用过了，但在坚持使用这个定义时，学生无意中将字母k用作了两个可能不同的数字。这很容易解决。你可以改写为，

Can you see why this is not appropriate? The definition has been used, but in sticking to it the student has inadvertently used the letter k for two numbers that might be different. This is easily fixed. You could write, instead,

令n和m为奇数，则对于某个k ∈ ℤ ，有n = 2 k + 1 ；对于某个l ∈ ℤ ，有m = 2 l + 1 。

Let n and m be odd numbers, so n = 2k + 1 for some k ∈ ℤ and m = 2l + 1 for some l ∈ ℤ.

您可能已经在第 6.3 节中关于有理数和无理数的证明中注意到了类似的内容；该证明使用p / q表示一个有理数，使用r / s表示另一个可能不同的有理数。

You might have noticed something like this in the proof about rational and irrational numbers in Section 6.3; that proof used p/q for one rational number and r/s for another, potentially different one.

第二个常见错误是使用不合适的新引入的符号。例如，数学家使用 0 表示零和空集（不包含任何元素的集合）。有时学生学习符号，但当他们想要表示 0 时却开始使用它。现在，零和空集确实有一些相似之处。零是一个数字，当你将它添加到任何其他数字时，你会得到相同的数字。空集集合是一个集合，当你以某种方式将它与任何其他集合组合时，你会得到相同的集合。尽管如此，0 和并不等同于对象：0 是一个数字，是一个集合。学生有时会对此感到困惑，因为他们认为 0 是“无”。但 0 不是“无”，它是一个数字；你可以在数轴上标记它，就像你可以在数轴上标记任何其他数字一样。所以当你表示数字时，请使用“0”，不要因为它是新的就开始使用“ ”。

The second common mistake is to use newly-introduced symbols when they are not appropriate. For instance, mathematicians use 0 for zero and for the empty set (the set containing no elements). Sometimes students learn the symbol , but start using it when they mean 0. Now, zero and the empty set do have some similarities. Zero is a number, and when you add it to any other number you get the same number back again. The empty set is a set, and when you combine it in a certain way with any other set, you get the same set back again. Nonetheless, 0 and are not the same as objects: 0 is a number and is a set. Students sometimes get confused about this because they think of 0 as “nothing.” But 0 isn’t “nothing,” it’s a number; you could label it on the number line just like you could label any other number on the number line. So use “0” when you mean the number, and don’t start using “” instead just because it’s new.

类似但更常见的错误出现在符号“=”（等号）上。实际上，这让我觉得很好笑，因为数学专业的学生已经正确使用符号“=”超过十年了，可能只是在最近两年才开始误用它。误用发生在学生使用“=”时，不是表示两个事物相等，而是将其用作计算步骤之间的一种占位符。这是一个常见的例子，其中学生正在求y = 4 x 5 + 2 x的三阶导数：

Similar but even more common errors occur with the symbol “=” (equals). This amuses me, actually, because mathematics majors have been using the symbol “=” correctly for somewhere in excess of ten years, and probably only started misusing it in the last two. The misuse occurs when students use “=” not to say that two things are equal, but to act as a sort of placeholder between steps of a calculation. Here is a common example, in which the student is finding the third derivative of y = 4x5 + 2x:

这完全是错误的。第一个等式有效，但其他两个不有效。1这样的计算应该这样写：

This is just wrong. The first equality is valid, but the other two are not.1 Such a calculation should be written like this:

这确实涉及更多的单词和符号，但它的最大优点是正确。

This does involve a few more words and symbols, but it has the great advantage of being correct.

学生们有时也会在正确的地方停止使用等号，因为他们刚刚学会了新符号“⇔”，他们对此有点兴奋。他们开始写这样的东西：

Students also sometimes stop using equals signs in places where they would be correct, because they have just learned the new symbol “⇔” and they’re a bit over-excited about it. They start writing things like this:

这是错误的，原因更微妙。原因是“=”用于对象，“⇔”用于语句。表达式“ x 3 + 4 x 2 + 3 x − 10”不是一个语句——我们无法明智地询问它是否“真实”，因此它不能等价于任何事物。有两种方法可以解决这个问题。假设一个学生会做这种类型的计算，以便找到表达式x 3 + 4 x 2 + 3 x − 10 等于 0 的x值。在这种情况下，我们可以用等号重写，以适合等式表达式：2

This is wrong for a more subtle reason. The reason is that “=” is for objects and “⇔” is for statements. The expression “x3 + 4x2 + 3x − 10” isn’t a statement—we can’t sensibly ask whether it is “true” or not, so it can’t be equivalent to anything. There are two ways to fix this problem. Presumably a student would be doing this type of calculation in order to find values of x for which the expression x3 + 4x2 + 3x − 10 is equal to 0. In that case, we could rewrite with equals signs, as appropriate for equating expressions:2

或者，我们可以用彼此等价的语句重写整个计算：

Alternatively, we could rewrite the whole calculation in terms of statements that are equivalent to each other:

请注意，对于每个更好的论证，我们都可以逐字逐句地读出纸上的内容，因为用英语来说，它们完全合情合理。试一试。现在试着大声朗读原文，在看到符号“⇔”的地方说“当且仅当”。你会发现你无法用合理的语调读出来；这个句子似乎没有“结束”，因为它实际上不是一个句子。数学家写句子。有时句子里有符号，但它们仍然是句子。

Notice that for each of these better arguments, we can read out literally what is on the page because it all makes perfect sense in English. Try it. Now try reading out loud the original version, saying “if and only if” where you see the symbol “⇔”. You’ll find that you can’t read it with sensible inflections; the sentence doesn’t seem to “finish,” because it isn’t really a sentence. Mathematicians write in sentences. Sometimes the sentences have symbols in them, but they are sentences nevertheless.

最后，现在可能是时候再说一点关于描述数学的准确性了。学生们倾向于使用“方程”这个词来指代任何带有大量x和其他符号的事物。从技术上讲，这通常是不正确的。例如，x 3 + 4 x 2 − 7 x − 10 = ( x + 5)( x 2 − x − 2) 是一个方程，因为它是关于两件事相等的陈述。相反，x 3 + 4 x 2 − 7 x − 10 < 0 是一个不等式。而x 3 + 4 x 2 + 3 x − 10 本身不是一个方程，因为它没有说明相等。它应该被称为表达式。

Finally, this is probably a good place to say one more thing about accuracy in describing mathematics. Students tend to use the word equation to refer to anything with a lot of x’s and other symbols in it. Technically, that’s often incorrect. For instance, x3 + 4x2 − 7x − 10 = (x + 5)(x2 − x − 2) is an equation, because it’s a statement about two things being equal. In contrast, x3 + 4x2 − 7x − 10 < 0 is an inequality.
