And x3 + 4x2 + 3x − 10 on its own is not an equation, because it doesn’t say anything about equality. It should be referred to as an expression instead.

8.5 箭头和括号

8.5 Arrows and brackets

回想一下在导数计算中使用“=”的例子。你能看出为什么下面的常见错误更糟糕吗？

Recall the example about the use of “=” in the context of derivative calculations. Can you see why the following common error is even worse?

如果说 20 x 4 + 2 蕴含 80 x 3 ，这是什么意思呢？这有点像说 2 蕴含 10 或 5 蕴含 cos x；这毫无意义，因为对象不能“蕴含”其他对象。学生有时也会用普通箭头写出类似的东西，如下所示：

What would it mean to say that 20x4 + 2 implies 80x3? That’s a bit like saying 2 implies 10 or 5 implies cos x; it’s meaningless because objects can’t “imply” other objects. Students also sometimes write something similar with normal arrows, like this:

在这两种情况下，箭头都不是以数学方式使用的。它们实际上被用来表示类似“是的，就像，这是我接下来做的计算”之类的意思。在某些课程中，你可能勉强能做到这一点，但我建议你不要这样做。箭头在数学中通常具有特定的含义，特别是在函数定义中，以及在涉及极限的课程中（其中“→”可以大声读成趋向于或收敛于）。因此，如果你误用箭头，你就有可能写出毫无意义的东西。更好的建议是父母给他们沮丧的孩子的建议：用你的语言。如果你以模糊的方式使用箭头，你几乎肯定意味着“所以”或“暗示”或“因为我们在第 (1) 行中建立的”，所以请写一些更精确的内容。

In both cases, the arrows are not used in a mathematical way. They’re really being used to mean something along the lines of “Yeah, like, and this is the calculation I did next.” You might just about get away with this in some courses, but I would advise against it. Arrows often have specific meanings in mathematics, particularly in the definition of functions, and in courses involving limits (where “→” can be read out loud as tends to or converges to). Thus, if you misuse arrows, you run the risk of writing something that makes no sense. Better advice would be that given by parents to their frustrated toddlers: use your words. If you are using arrows in a vague way, you almost certainly mean “so” or “implies” or “because of what we established in line (1),” so write something more precise instead.

教授们经常会抱怨学生使用错误的括号类型。这其实不能怪学生，因为以前这并不重要。如果你只是需要让表达式的结构更清晰，没有人会在意你是否这样写

Another common bugbear among professors is students’ tendency to use the wrong kinds of brackets. Students can’t really be blamed for this, because it hasn’t mattered much before. If you just need to make the structure of an expression clearer, nobody cares whether you write

然而，在学习过程中，你会发现有些情况下括号的含义完全不同。例如，当我们谈论实数集时，我们使用以下约定：

However, during your major you will find that there are contexts in which brackets have quite different meanings. For instance, when we are talking about sets of real numbers, we use the following conventions:

• [0, 1] 表示包含 0 到 1 之间的所有数字的集合，包括“端点”0 和 1（称为闭区间）；

• [0, 1] means the set containing all the numbers between 0 and 1, including the “endpoints” 0 and 1 (called a closed interval);

• (0, 1) 表示包含 0 到 1 之间的所有数字的集合，不包括端点（称为开区间）；

• (0, 1) means the set containing all the numbers between 0 and 1, excluding the endpoints (called an open interval);

• {0, 1} 表示仅包含数字 0 和 1 的集合。

• {0, 1} means the set containing just the numbers 0 and 1.

第一个括号称为方括号，第二个括号称为圆括号，原因很明显。最后一个括号往往被称为“花括号”，我和很多学生都觉得这个名字很有趣，但我也说不出为什么。无论如何，请注意，方括号和圆括号符号只有在括号中有两个数字且数字较小时才有意义。当你看到集合的花括号时，里面出现的只是一个列表，因此它可以明确包含更多内容，例如 {1, 2, 3, i, 1 + i, 7.362}。

The first brackets are called square brackets, and the second are called round brackets, for obvious reasons. The last ones tend to get called “curly braces,” which I, along with lots of students, find amusing for reasons I can’t quite put my finger on. Anyway, notice that the square and round bracket notations only make sense if there are two numbers in the brackets, with the lower number first. When you see curly braces for sets, what appears inside is just a list, so it can explicitly include many more things, as in {1, 2, 3, i, 1 + i, 7.362}.

花括号在集合符号中的使用也更为普遍，如下所示：

Curly braces are also used in set notation more generally, like this:

这可以大声读出为“包含所有实数元素x的集合，使得x平方小于 2”。有时人们使用冒号代替竖线来表示“使得”。但在这种情况下使用圆括号或方括号会被认为是错误的。

This would be read out loud as “The set containing all the elements x in the reals such that x squared is less than 2.” Sometimes people use a colon instead of the vertical line to mean “such that.” But using round or square brackets in this case would be considered wrong.

巨型花括号也用于分段定义函数，正如我们在第 3 章中第一次看到的那样：

Giant versions of curly braces are also used for piecewise-defined functions, as we first saw in Chapter 3:

请注意这里只使用了左括号。

Notice that only the left-hand brace is used here.

确实存在括号类型不太重要的情况。如果你只是为了明确代数表达式的结构，那么任何类型都可以，而且通常用圆括号或方括号来写矩阵都是可以的：

There do remain cases in which bracket types don’t matter much. You will still be fine with any type if you are just making clear the structure of an algebraic expression, and it is usually fine to write matrices with either round or square brackets:

但是，您可能会发现教授使用不同的括号类型，如果有疑问，您应该坚持使用每门课程使用的符号。

However, you might find that professors use different bracket types, and if in doubt you should stick to the notation used in each course.

8.6 异常和错误

8.6 Exceptions and mistakes

除了括号部分，我写这些关于符号和传统布局的建议时，好像这些建议是一成不变的。你会发现，大部分建议都适用于任何地方，但你可能会发现你的一位教授使用符号的方式不同，也许是因为它与课程的其余部分有关。例如，他们可能会使用“→”而不是“⇒”来表示“暗示”，尤其是在一门侧重于逻辑而与极限无关的课程中。我希望我们能澄清这一点，但恐怕这并不现实：从历史上看，数学的不同分支是独立发展的，每个分支中的每个人都习惯于自己的符号，所以没有人愿意改变它。当你还是学生时，这很烦人，但在技术领域工作时，你必须习惯它。只要对它保持警惕，如果你不确定，就问某个符号是如何使用的。

With the exception of the section on brackets, I have been writing as though this advice about symbols and conventional layouts is set in stone. You should find that most of it applies everywhere, but you may find that one of your professors uses a symbol differently, perhaps because of the way it relates to the rest of the course. They might use “→” instead of “⇒” to mean “implies,” for instance, especially in a course that focuses on logic and doesn’t have anything to do with limits. I wish we could clear this up, but I’m afraid that’s not realistic: historically, different branches of mathematics developed somewhat separately, and everyone in each branch gets used to their own notation, so no-one wants to change it. This is annoying when you’re a student, but it’s something you have to get used to when working in a technical field. Just be alert to it and, if you’re not sure, ask how a particular symbol is being used.

另外，请记住，从开始学习专业的那一天起，您就不可能写得完美无缺。即使您仔细阅读了这些建议，在解决复杂问题时，您也可能会忘记其中至少一部分；当专注于更高层次的想法时，您可能不会注意到自己犯了符号错误。这没关系。但有时，您可能很容易放任不管，因为这一切看起来有点迂腐。不要那样做。不要偷懒。做对。您不能声称喜欢数学有正确答案这一事实，然后又声称您不想被这种细节所困扰。不精确就是马虎。在某些情况下，它会使您的答案模棱两可；在某些情况下，它会使答案完全错误。因此，当有人向您指出这样的错误时，适当的回应不是“哦，你太挑剔了，你知道我的意思！”，而是“哦，是的，我看到了错误，我会改正的，谢谢。”

Also, remember that you are unlikely to write perfectly from the day you begin your major. Even if you have read this advice carefully, you will probably forget at least some of it when you are working on a complicated problem; when concentrating on a higher-level idea, you might not notice that you’ve made a notational error. That’s fine. But sometimes it might be tempting to let things slide because it all seems a bit pedantic. Don’t do that. Don’t be lazy. Do it right. You can’t claim to like the fact that mathematics has right answers, then also claim that you can’t be bothered with this sort of detail. Being imprecise is sloppy. In some cases it will render your answer ambiguous; in some cases it will render it outright wrong. So, when someone points out such an error to you, the appropriate response is not “Oh, you’re so fussy, you know what I meant!,” it’s “Oh, yes, I see the error and will fix it, thank you.”

8.7 分离写作任务

8.7 Separating out the task of writing

希望你能明白，写得好是值得追求的。但你可能很难想象自己能写出所有的东西在进行所有必要的数学思考的同时，还要写得很好。我的建议是：不要尝试。你不必第一次就把所有东西都写得很好，完全可以先集中精力计算解决方案或寻找证明。但是，在你这样做之后，你应该以批判的眼光看待你的工作，并问自己：“现在，我可以改进我写作的方式吗？”在某些情况下，你只需添加几个词就可以改进它。也许是Let和Then，再加上几个So以及几个逗号和句号。一个很好的测试你是否做得好的方法是试着大声朗读——如果你发现自己添加了额外的解释词，可以考虑把它们写进去。

Hopefully you can see that good writing is worth aiming for. But you might find it difficult to imagine yourself being able to write everything well at the same time as doing all the necessary mathematical thinking. My advice about that is: don’t try. You don’t have to write everything nicely the first time, and it’s perfectly acceptable to concentrate first on calculating a solution or finding a proof. But, after you’ve done that, you should look at your work with a critical eye and ask, “Now, could I improve the way I have written this?” In some cases, you might be able to improve it with the addition of just a few words. Perhaps a Let and a Then, plus a few So’s and a few commas and periods. A good test of whether you’ve done this well is to try reading it out loud—if you find yourself adding extra words of explanation, consider writing those in.

在其他情况下，添加一些理由可能是合适的。也许你可以在某些行的开头或结尾陈述一些理由（“根据定理 3.1”或“使用连续性定义”），或者你可以添加额外的计算或论证来解释为什么某个特定步骤是有效的。在其他情况下，你可能希望以不同的顺序重写内容。也许你的证明最好以另一种方式呈现，以便它反映定理的结构。这种事情需要一点工作量，但只是一点点。你会发现，随着你的继续，适当的写作变得不那么困难了。

In other cases, it might be appropriate to add some justifications. Perhaps you could state some reasons at the beginnings or ends of some of the lines (“By theorem 3.1” or “Using the definition of continuity”), or perhaps you could include an extra calculation or argument to explain why a particular step is valid. In still other cases, you might want to rewrite things in a different order. Perhaps your proof would be better presented in the other direction so that it reflects the structure of the theorem. This kind of thing takes a bit of work, but only a bit. And you will find that writing appropriately becomes less arduous as you go on.

但我想说的是，你应该一直这样做。学生们往往不愿意这样做。有时学生让我看一些作业，我的回答是基本上还可以，但写作可以改进。然后学生经常说“但这只是草稿。”我对这个回答有两个反驳。第一，你练习写得越多，你就越自然地就会写得好，在考试中越容易快速写出来，等等。第二，几个月后当你修改时，你可能会想重读你的草稿。到那时，你会记得你当时在想什么吗？可能不会。在草稿周围写几个词来表明理由将大大提高你修改的速度。

What I would say, though, is that you should always do this. Students often don’t want to. Sometimes a student asks me to look at some work, and my response is that it’s basically fine, but that the writing could be improved. The student often then says “But this is just scratch work.” There are two counterarguments I make to this response. The first is that the more you practice writing well, the more naturally it will come to you, and the easier it will be to do it quickly in exams, and so forth. The second is that you will probably want to reread your scratch work in a few months’ time when you are revising. Will you remember, by then, what you were thinking? Probably not. Writing a few words around it to indicate the reasoning will much improve the speed with which you can revise it.

关于写好数学文章，我最后要说的是：坚持下去。每年我都会收到一批新的本科生指导，每年年初，他们的写作都离完美还有一段距离。每年，他们都会经历一个阶段，使用新的符号和语言，笨拙且容易出错，但他们会习惯它。每年年底，他们的写作都会好得多。

The final thing I would say about writing mathematics well is this: hang in there. Every year I get a new set of undergraduate advisees, and every year, at the start of the year, their writing is some way from perfect. Every year, they go through a phase of using the new notation and language in a clunky and error-prone way, while they get used to it. And every year, at the end of the year, their writing is much better.

概括

SUMMARY

• 即使您自己还不总是写出好的数学文章，您也可能会识别出好的数学文章。教授们希望您提高数学写作技能。

• You can probably recognize good mathematical writing, even if you don’t yet always produce it yourself. Professors will expect you to develop your mathematical writing skills.

• 写得好会让你在课程作业和考试中取得更好的成绩，并有助于你在职业生涯中取得成功。它还会表明你了解数学家的沟通方式。

• Writing well will earn you better grades on coursework assignments and exams, and will help you to be successful in professional life. It will also show that you understand how mathematicians communicate.

• 撰写数学论证时，您应该明确第一行（几行）的状态，适当使用逻辑连接词，并遵守“所以”、“因此”、“让”和“现在”等词的常规数学用法。

• When writing a mathematical argument you should make clear the status of the first line(s), use logical connectives appropriately, and adhere to conventional mathematical usage of words like “so,” “thus,” “let,” and “now.”

• 谨慎使用所有符号，尤其是“ ”和“⇒”等新符号。不要仅仅因为它们是新符号就过度使用它们。

• Be careful with all symbols, especially new notation such as “” and “⇒”. Don’t be tempted to overuse symbols just because they are new.

• 不同类型的箭头和括号具有不同的含义；确保您了解它们是什么，以便能够准确使用它们。

• Different types of arrows and brackets have different meanings; make sure you know what these are so that you can use them accurately.

• 一旦你弄清楚了如何解决问题，将写作视为一项单独的任务可能会有所帮助。要判断你的写作是否好，请尝试大声朗读。

• It might be helpful to treat writing well as a separate task to be undertaken once you have worked out how to solve a problem. To decide whether your writing is good, try reading it out loud.

• 在使用符号或阐述逻辑论证时，你几乎肯定会犯错误，尤其是在数学具有挑战性的情况下。但大多数学生在主修期间会大大提高数学写作水平。

• You will almost certainly make mistakes when using notation or laying out logical arguments, especially when the mathematics is challenging. But most students improve their mathematical writing considerably during their major.

进一步阅读

FURTHER READING

有关清晰的数学写作的更多信息，请尝试：

For more on clear mathematical writing, try:

• Vivaldi, F. (2011)。数学写作：本科课程。在线网址：http://www.maths.qmul.ac.uk/~fv/books/mw/mwbook.pdf。

• Vivaldi, F. (2011). Mathematical Writing: An Undergraduate Course. Online at http://www.maths.qmul.ac.uk/~fv/books/mw/mwbook.pdf.

• Houston, K. (2009).如何像数学家一样思考。剑桥：剑桥大学出版社。

• Houston, K. (2009). How to Think Like a Mathematician. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.

如果您准备考虑数学写作中更复杂的方面，并且想要提高您的书面英语水平，请尝试：

If you are ready to consider more sophisticated aspects of mathematical writing, and you want to improve your written English while you’re at it, try:

• Higham, NJ (1998). 《数学科学写作手册》。宾夕法尼亚州费城：工业与应用数学学会。

• Higham, N.J. (1998). Handbook of Writing for the Mathematical Sciences. Philadelphia, PA: Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics.

第 2 部分

学习技巧

PART 2

Study Skills

第九章

讲座

CHAPTER 9

Lectures

本章介绍在参加数学讲座时应注意什么以及应考虑什么。它包含有关如何在以讲座为基础的环境中充分发挥独立学习者的作用以及如何处理常见问题的建议。

This chapter is about what to expect and what to think about when attending mathematics lectures. It contains advice about how to get the most out of being an independent learner in a lecture-based environment, and about how to deal with common problems.

9.1 讲座是什么样的？

9.1 What are lectures like?

自从我读本科以来的 20 多年里，数学讲座发生了巨大的变化。那时，所有的讲座基本上都是一样的。教授会在黑板上写字，讲 50 分钟，学生们会听并记下教授写的内容。希望学生们也能利用教授的口头评论做额外的笔记，以便在复习材料时能够理解所有内容。

Mathematics lectures have changed enormously in the 20-odd years since I was an undergraduate. Back then, all lectures were essentially the same. The professor would write on the blackboard and talk for 50 minutes, and the students would listen and write down what he or she wrote. Hopefully, the students would also use the professor’s verbal comments to make extra notes so that they could understand everything when reviewing the material.

如今，教学方式更加多样化。一些教授仍然采用白板笔授课，尽管白板笔经常被白板笔取代。一些教授还通过讲义为学生提供大纲笔记或额外信息，这些讲义在课堂上分发或在大学的虚拟学习环境 (VLE) 上提供。一些教授使用 Powerpoint 或投影仪代替白板。一些教授提前将全套笔记放在 VLE 上，然后在课堂上复习这些笔记的关键方面和/或通过更多示例进行练习。一些教授将“空白”笔记放在 VLE 上，并希望学生在上课时自带笔记并填补空白。一些教授不提前提供任何笔记，但在每次讲座后或在课堂上将笔记放在 VLE 上。每个主要部分的末尾。我还可以继续讲下去——你会看到很多不同的方法。

These days there is much more variety. Some professors still give chalk-and-talk lectures, although the chalk is often replaced with whiteboard pens. Some also provide students with outline notes or extra information via handouts that they distribute in lectures or make accessible on the university’s virtual learning environment (VLE). Some use Powerpoint or overhead projectors instead of boards. Some put a full set of notes on the VLE in advance, then go over key aspects of these and/or work through more examples in lectures. Some put “gappy” notes on the VLE, and expect that students will come with their own copies and fill in the gaps during lecture time. Some professors do not make any notes available in advance, but do put them on the VLE after each lecture or at the end of each major section. I could go on—you will see lots of different approaches.

你还会看到教授和学生活动模式的变化。有些教授在开始上课前会概述一下课程内容，有些则不会。有些教授会让学生休息，有些则不会。有些教授希望学生在上课期间花大量时间讨论数学思想，有些教授偶尔会要求这样做，有些教授根本不要求这样做。有些教授希望学生为整个课堂（尤其是小组）贡献答案，有些则不要求。我还可以继续说下去。

You will also see variations in patterns of professor and student activity. Some professors give an overview of the lecture before they start; some do not. Some give students breaks; some do not. Some expect students to spend quite a bit of time discussing mathematical ideas during lectures; some ask for this occasionally; some do not ask for it at all. Some expect students to contribute answers to the whole lecture class (especially if it is a small group); some do not. Again, I could go on.

9.2 教授是什么样的人？

9.2 What are professors like?

另一个造成差异的原因是，教授也是人，所以他们都有自己的个性和技能。有些教授讲课风格乐观而热情，有些则比较安静和严肃。有些教授对应该写下什么和怎么写下非常清楚（甚至是独裁），而有些教授则把这个决定权留给学生。有些教授会特意与教室里的每个人进行眼神交流，有些则不会。有些教授能够很好地理解学生的想法，并倾向于预测可能犯的错误，而有些教授则经验较少，有时说话的水平很难理解。有些教授的字迹非常漂亮、清晰，有些则不然。您可能已经预料到了这一切，但您可能不知道的一件事是，您的许多教授可能不是来自您自己的国家。大学是非常国际化的地方——它们会尽最大努力吸引来自世界各地的优秀数学家。我所在的系有来自澳大利亚、奥地利、中国、爱沙尼亚、德国、希腊、意大利、黎巴嫩、毛里求斯、墨西哥、新西兰、俄罗斯、瑞典、英国和美国的教授，这对于一所成功的大学来说是相当典型的。这在很多方面都很棒，但这也意味着一些教授的口音或笔迹可能不熟悉。你可能需要仔细聆听和观察，直到适应每个人。

Still another source of variation is the fact that professors are human beings so they all have different personalities and skills. Some have upbeat and exuberant lecturing styles; others are more quiet and serious. Some are fairly clear (even dictatorial) about what should be written down and how; others leave that decision to the students. Some make a point of making eye contact with everyone around the room; some do not. Some have a good understanding of students’ thinking and tend to anticipate likely mistakes; others are less experienced and sometimes speak at a level that is difficult to understand. Some have excellent, clear handwriting; some do not. You could probably have anticipated all that, but one thing you might not know is that it’s likely that many of your professors will not be from your own country. Universities are very international places—they do their best to attract talented mathematicians from all over the world. In my department there are professors from Australia, Austria, China, Estonia, Germany, Greece, Italy, Lebanon, Mauritius, Mexico, New Zealand, Russia, Sweden, the UK, and the US, and that’s fairly typical for a successful university. This is fantastic in many ways, but it does mean that some professors might have unfamiliar accents or styles of handwriting. You might have to listen and watch carefully until you adjust to each person.

关于个性的另一件事是，你也有个性，所以你会以不同的方式回应你的教授。有些教授你会想模仿，因为你钦佩他们，喜欢他们的课。其他人的个性与你不符，你不会享受与他们相处的时光。希望前者比后者多，但你必须充分利用你的所有讲座，这就是下一节的内容。

The other thing about personalities is that you have one too, so you will respond to your professors in different ways. Some professors you will want to emulate because you admire them and enjoy their lectures. Others will have personalities that clash with your own, and you will not enjoy being in their company. Hopefully you’ll have more of the former than the latter, but you’ll have to make the best of all your lectures, which is what the next section is about.

9.3 让讲座为你服务

9.3 Making lectures work for you

在所有这些变化中，有些事情你喜欢，有些事情你不喜欢。也许你喜欢热情型的人讲的互动课，但有时你会发现自己在听某个你觉得很无趣的人讲课时完全被动。如果你运气不好，这个人的字迹可能也很难读懂，口音也很难听懂。你可能会花一些时间向其他学生抱怨这种事情，你可能会喜欢它——抱怨可以起到宣泄的作用，有助于你和同学们建立联系。然而，这并不是很有建设性。无论向朋友抱怨多少，情况都不会改善，所以，在你享受了一段被欺负的乐趣之后，你应该考虑制定一个计划来改善这种情况。

Amongst all this variety, there will be some things you like and some things you don’t. Maybe you like interactive lectures given by enthusiastic types, but sometimes you find yourself totally passive in lectures given by someone you find very dull. If you’re unlucky, this person might also have writing that is difficult to read and an accent that is difficult to understand. You will probably spend some time complaining to other students about this kind of thing, and you will probably enjoy it—complaining can be quite cathartic and it will serve to bond you with your peers. However, it isn’t very constructive. No amount of whining to your friends will improve things so, after you’ve had some fun feeling hard done-by, you should consider formulating a plan to improve the situation.

首先要记住的是，即使你所有的朋友都同意你对某一门课程的讲课的看法，其他学生可能并不同意。你认为极其枯燥的演讲在别人看来可能非常清晰。你认为生动活泼的演讲在别人看来可能很散漫。你认为太慢的演讲在别人看来可能太快（说真的，我有时会在同一门课程的反馈表上收到两种评论）。无论是在课堂上还是在生活中，你都必须习惯于处理一定程度的不完美，并承认其他人可能有不同的偏好。

The first thing to remember is that even if all your friends agree with you about the lectures in a particular course, other students might not. What you see as an incredibly dull presentation might seem, to someone else, magnificent in its clarity. What you see as a lively and enthusiastic presentation might seem, to others, to be scatty and all over the place. What you see as too slow a presentation might seem, to others, to be too fast (seriously, I sometimes get both comments on feedback forms for the same course). In lectures as in life, you have to get used to dealing with a certain amount of imperfection and to acknowledging that other people might have different preferences.

第二件要记住的事情是，如果有一个简单、实际的问题很容易解决，那么采取行动比抱怨要好得多。首先，运用你的常识。如果你看不清楚，但那是因为房间很大，你和那些酷酷的孩子坐在后面，那就找个其他能让你保持酷酷的地方，然后向前走（或者考虑检查一下你的眼睛——显然很多人在开始听讲座时就意识到他们需要戴眼镜）。如果，但是，如果你已经做出了合理的调整，并且你相信如果教授讲得慢一点或大声一点，或者写得更大一点或用不同的笔，你会理解得更好，那么你可以随时给他们发一封简短的电子邮件。要简短而有礼貌。例如：

The second thing to remember is that if there is a simple, practical problem that would be easy to fix, it is much better to do something than to whine about it. First, use your common sense. If you can’t see well, but that’s because the room is huge and you sit right at the back with the cool kids, find some other venue in which to be cool and move forwards (or consider getting your eyes checked—apparently quite a few people realize that they need glasses when they start going to lectures). If, however, you’ve made reasonable adjustments, and you believe you would understand better if the professor spoke more slowly or more loudly, or wrote bigger or in a different pen, you can always drop them a quick email. Be brief and polite. For example:

亲爱的X教授，

Dear Professor X,

我在上你的线性代数课。我和其他一些学生都觉得很难看清你的字迹。如果可以的话，你能不能把字写大一点，用黑色的笔（这样最容易看清）？

I am in your Linear Algebra course. Some of the other students and I are finding it difficult to read your writing. If possible, please would you write a bit bigger and in the black pen (that one is easiest to see)?

非常感谢，

Many thanks,

乔。

Joe.

一定要记得说明你正在谈论的是哪门课程——教授有时同时教授多门课程。

Do remember to specify which course you’re talking about—professors sometimes teach more than one at a time.

如果教授在 VLE 上做笔记，并在课堂上做额外的笔记，但并不总是清楚地说明两者如何结合在一起，这种方法也可能有效。他们可能能够通过公告或编号系统使链接更加明确，他们可能愿意这样做。不过，同样，首先要自己做出合理的努力——是不是你需要的一切都在你早已忘记的课程介绍文件中得到了解释？或者你只是没有学习太多，一个跟上时代的学生会毫不费力地跟上演示？如果是这样，先解决这个问题。

This approach might also work if, say, the professor puts notes on the VLE, and gives extra notes in class, but does not always make it clear how the two fit together. They might be able to make the links more explicit via announcements or a numbering system, and they might be willing to do that. Again, though, make reasonable efforts yourself first—could it be that everything you need was explained in a course introduction document that you have long since forgotten about? Or that you simply haven’t been studying very much and that an up-to-date student would have no problem following the presentation? If so, fix that first.

无论如何，如果你提出这样的要求，请记住要友善，因为教授也是人，他们不一定非常熟悉这部分工作。如果你每周必须站起来做三次长达一小时的演讲，内容涉及困难的技术性材料，那么你可能一开始也不会擅长。你甚至可能会感到害怕，如果有人告诉你他们喜欢你的讲座或讲义的某些方面，但如果你稍作调整，他们会发现从他们那里学到的东西会更容易，你可能会做出很好的回应。

In any case, if you make requests like this, remember to be kind, because professors are people and they aren’t necessarily very experienced at this part of their job. If you had to stand up and give three hour-long presentations a week about difficult, technical material, you probably wouldn’t excel at it to begin with either. You might even be terrified, and you might respond well to someone telling you that they like some aspect of your lectures or lecture notes but would find it easier to learn from them if you made a minor adjustment.

9.4 解决常见问题

9.4 Tackling common problems

即使做了合理的调整，你仍然会发现有些讲座并不适合你。在这种情况下，你应该考虑如何在课堂上尽可能多地学习，并确保你最终能得到一套可以有效使用的课堂笔记。以下是我针对典型情况提出的一些建议。

Even with sensible adjustments made, you will still find that some lectures are not ideal for you. In that case, you should think about how you can learn as much as possible during lecture time and make sure you end up with a set of lecture notes that you can use effectively. Here are some suggestions that I would make in response to typical situations.

首先，假设教授在课程开始前准备好一整套笔记，然后在课堂上花时间研究这些笔记。你（你是一个有条理的学生）已经打印了这些笔记并放在你面前，但是，由于你在课堂上没有什么实际行动，你往往会感到无聊并陷入白日梦。你可能会抱怨“课堂和笔记一模一样”，并声称课堂上没有什么可学的。当然，你错了——数学笔记可以非常简洁，包括所有关键思想，但没有太多解释它们如何联系在一起或一个聪明的人应该如何思考它们（见第 7 章）。教授将在他们的口头评论中提供此类信息，因此拥有笔记让你有机会做出不影响基本材料但确实捕捉到你应该如何思考它的注释。例如，教授可能会解释为什么证明中的一行紧接着上一行，或者可能会将你现在正在学习的内容与你在课程早期学到的东西联系起来。你可以把这些事情写下来，教授可能也希望你这样做。教授可能还认为，让你提前准备对你在智力上有很大帮助。在每次上课之前，你可以通读一下笔记中大致合适的部分，回顾一下似乎需要的先前概念，并标出你不理解的部分，以便在遇到这些内容时能特别注意。这就是独立学习的一部分——掌控你需要知道的东西，并想办法去寻找它。当然，如果这种方法不起作用，你可以停止打印课堂笔记，而是强迫自己把所有东西都写下来。

First, suppose the professor makes a whole set of notes available before the course starts, then spends the lectures going through these notes. You (organized student that you are) have printed these notes and have them in front of you but, because there’s therefore nothing physical for you to do in lectures, you tend to get bored and drift off into a daydream. You might find yourself complaining that “the lectures are just the same as the notes” and claiming that there is nothing to learn in lectures. You will be wrong about this, of course—mathematics notes can be very terse, with all the key ideas included but without much explanation about how they link together or how an intelligent person should think about them (see Chapter 7). The professor will provide such information in their spoken commentary, so having the notes gives you an opportunity to make annotations that don’t affect the basic material but that do capture how you should think about it. For instance, the professor might explain why one line in a proof follows from the previous line, or might link what you are studying now with something you learned earlier in the course. You could write down that sort of thing, and the professor probably expects you to do so. The professor probably also thinks that they have done you a big intellectual favor by allowing you to prepare in advance. Before each lecture, you could read through a roughly appropriate part of the notes, review any earlier concepts that seem to be needed, and highlight anything you don’t understand so that you can pay particular attention when it comes up. This is part of what is meant by independent study—taking control of what you need to know and finding ways to seek it out. Of course, if that approach doesn’t work, you could just stop printing out the lecture notes and force yourself to write everything down instead.

其次，假设某门课程的笔记结构不太好。也许没有太多的编号或分段系统，所以看起来材料只是一长串的定义、定理、证明、例子和计算。在这种情况下，你可能很难理解这门课程是如何组合在一起的。不过，同样，你可以做一些简单的事情来帮助自己。第一个也是最明显的事情是礼貌地请教授介绍一些章节。不过，也许你可以独立遵循第 7 章中给出的建议，尤其是关于综合阅读的建议：列出笔记中的内容，考虑对页面进行编号，也许将列表变成概念图。然后，你可以根据课程的主要细分情况，实施自己的编号系统。

Second, suppose that the notes for a given course are not very structured. Perhaps there is not much of a numbering or sectioning system, so it appears that the material is just one long stream of definitions, theorems, proofs, examples, and calculations. In this case it might seem difficult for you to get to grips with how the course fits together. Again, though, there are some straightforward things you can to do help yourself. The first and most obvious thing is to politely ask the professor to introduce some sections. Perhaps, though, you could independently follow the advice given in Chapter 7, especially the suggestions about reading for synthesis: make a list of what’s in your notes, consider numbering your pages, and perhaps turn the list into a concept map. Then you could impose your own numbering system, according to what seems to be the main breakdown of the course.

第三，假设问题集中出现的问题似乎与讲义中的材料没有明显的关联。这是学生们抱怨颇多的问题。如果你发现自己处于这种情况，并且还没有这样做，那么你应该阅读本书的第 1 部分。当教授在讲授材料时没有提供很多示例时，你可能正在寻找示例（参见第 1 章），并且你可能可以更有效地阅读（参见第 7 章）或在面对特定问题类型时找出解决方法（参见第 1 章和第6章）。与其他学生合作或将问题清单交给教授或其他支持人员（参见第 10 章）也可能会对你有所帮助。

Third, suppose that the problems appearing in problem sets don’t seem obviously related to the material in lecture notes. This is something that students complain about quite a lot. If you find yourself in this position, and if you haven’t done so already, you should probably read Part 1 of this book. It might be that you are looking for worked examples when a professor is presenting material without many of these (see Chapter 1) and it might be that you can become more effective in reading (see Chapter 7) or in working out what to do when faced with particular problem types (see Chapters 1 and 6). You might also benefit from working with other students or from taking a list of questions to your professor or to another support person (see Chapter 10).

这些只是您可能遇到的问题和您可能想要采取的应对措施的示例。您可能还会遇到其他问题，重要的是不要过分责怪他人——正如我所说，您需要为自己的学习负责。

These are just examples of issues you might encounter and things you might like to do in response. You might come across other problems, and the important thing is to avoid getting carried away with blaming someone else—as I’ve said, you’ll be expected to take responsibility for your own learning.

说到对自己的学习负责，还有一件事要做好准备，那就是你不必参加所有的讲座。如果你很努力，但发现某门课程非常令人沮丧，你认为如果你下载笔记并独立学习，你可能会学到更多，那么也许你应该考虑尝试一周。然而，你应该非常谨慎和有计划地这样做，而且只有当你知道自己是一个自律的人并且会完成工作时，你才应该考虑这样做。下一节将详细介绍原因。

Speaking of taking responsibility for your own learning, another thing to be ready for is that you do not necessarily have to attend all your lectures. If you are working hard but finding a particular course very frustrating, and you think you might learn more if you just downloaded the notes and studied them independently, then maybe you should consider trying that for a week. You should do so with great caution and planning, however, and you should only consider this if you know you are a disciplined person who will do the work. There’s more on why in the next section.

9.5 课堂学习

9.5 Learning in lectures

如果你想从讲座中学习，你必须去听。我这样说是因为大学让你有机会参加各种有趣的活动和人，而且在某些时候，你会发现其中的某一个比静坐一个小时或更长时间并听别人谈论线性近似更吸引你。但是，除了非常特殊的情况外，你应该去。有一件事研究得很清楚，那就是坚持听课的大学生比不听课的学生表现更好。1除此以外，听课能让你全身心投入学习的过程。在这方面，你可能一开始会表现良好——大多数人一开始都是怀着良好的意愿——但一定要注意这一点。不要以不喜欢的课程为借口偷懒，也不要因为缺席几节课就让你走上一条越来越少学习的下坡路。如果你真的开始走下坡路，赶快抓住机会，阅读第 11 章和第12章。

If you want to learn from a lecture, you have to go to it. I say this because colleges give you access to all sorts of interesting activities and people, and at some point you will find that one or another of these is more appealing to you than sitting still for an hour or more and listening to someone talk about linear approximations. However, very exceptional cases aside, you should go. One thing research is pretty clear on is that college students who consistently go to their lectures do better than students who don’t.1 Apart from anything else, going to lectures keeps you engaged in the process of being a student. You’ll probably start off well in this respect—most people begin with good intentions—but do keep an eye on it. Don’t use lectures you don’t like as an excuse to slack off, and don’t let missing a couple of lectures push you onto a slippery slope towards doing less and less work. If you do start slipping, catch yourself quickly and read Chapters 11 and 12.

关于在课堂上学习，还有一点要认识到，那就是一旦你在课堂上，你就应该集中注意力。这也不是火箭科学，但你可能会发现它出奇的困难。在你的很多讲座中，教授会讲整整一个小时。你的高中老师可能不会这样做；他们更有可能讲一会儿，然后给你练习，或者让学生分成小组，或者让别人接管黑板。你可能很难集中注意力听完一整堂高级数学课，因为数学内容会比以前更难，节奏会更快，而且你不一定能全面地了解所有内容的发展方向。然而，如果你不集中注意力，你就没有很好地利用你的时间。你在课堂上没有考虑的事情，你将不得不在课外考虑，而那时你可能更愿意参与那些有趣的活动和人。

Another thing to recognize about learning in lectures is that once you’re there, you should pay attention. This, again, is not rocket science, but you might find it surprisingly difficult. In a lot of your lectures, the professor will talk for a full hour. Your high school teachers probably didn’t do this; more likely they talked for a while and then gave you exercises to do, or let students work in small groups, or asked someone else to take over at the board. It might be hard for you to pay attention for a full lecture on upper-level mathematics, because the mathematical content will be more difficult than it was before, the pace will be faster, and you won’t necessarily have a global sense of where it’s all going. However, if you don’t pay attention, you’re not making very good use of your time. Things you don’t think about in lectures, you’re going to have to think about outside lectures, when you’d probably rather be getting involved with those interesting activities and people.

第三件要认识到的事情是，如果你准备得足够充分，那么在课堂上学习会更容易、更有趣。如果你知道课程中关键概念的含义，如果你熟悉通常使用的论证类型，如果你研究过将整个课程联系在一起的大定理，那么理解新数学就会更容易。第 7 章包含有关如何掌握这些事情的建议，第 11 章包含有关如何管理时间以便您能够有效地管理时间的建议。

A third thing to recognize is that learning in lectures is easier and more enjoyable if you are reasonably well prepared. It’s easier to understand new mathematics if you know the meanings of the key concepts in a course, if you’re familiar with the types of argument typically used, and if you’ve studied the big theorems that glue the whole course together. Chapter 7 contains advice on how to get to grips with such things, and Chapter 11 contains advice on how to manage your time so that you can do so effectively.

最后要认识到的一点是，没有人会强迫你去上课。从某种意义上说，这是不言而喻的：你的高中老师可能会注意到你走神了，并说：“艾米，请回来听我们讲课”，而你的教授可能没有机会知道你的名字，即使他们知道，他们也几乎肯定不会在其他 200 名学生面前说这样的话让你难堪。所以你有更多的责任让自己专注于任务。不过，我的观点远不止于此。在大多数大学里，没有人会强迫你去上课。一些大学会记录出勤情况，但许多大学不会。事实上，在很多情况下，即使你不去，也没人会注意到。如果你以前受到老师的极大关注，很容易将这解读为学校里的人不在乎你。如果你有点叛逆，你很容易就会觉得，如果你不去上课，而且没有因此惹上麻烦，你就是在欺骗这个体制。然而，相信这两件事中的任何一件都是一个严重的错误。如果你不学习，你就不是在维护你的独立性，你只是在给自己制造麻烦。人们确实会失败，当他们失败时，他们不得不做一些不方便甚至可能昂贵的事情，比如重修课程。你的大学和系确实关心你。他们非常希望你成功。但你现在已经成年了，虽然他们认为提供高质量的教学是他们的责任，但他们不认为让你学习是他们的责任。这取决于你。

A final thing to recognize about learning in lectures is that no-one is going to force you to do it. That’s trivially true in one sense: where your high school teacher might have noticed when you’d drifted off and said, “Amy, come back to us please,” your professor might not have a chance to learn your name and, even if they do, they almost certainly won’t embarrass you by saying something like that in front of 200 other students. So you have more responsibility for keeping yourself on task. My point goes further than that, though. In most colleges, no-one is going to force you to go to lectures. A few colleges do keep track of attendance, but many do not. Indeed, in many cases, no-one is even going to notice if you don’t go. If you’ve previously had a lot of attention from your teachers, it’s easy to interpret this to mean that the people in your institution don’t care about you. If you’re a bit rebellious, it’s also easy to feel like you’re getting one over on the system if you don’t go to lectures and you don’t get into trouble for it. However, believing either of these things would be a serious error. If you don’t study, you’re not asserting your independence, you’re just creating trouble for yourself. People do fail, and when they fail they have to do inconvenient and possibly expensive things like resitting courses. And your college and department do care about you. They would very much like you to succeed. But you’re an adult now and, while they consider it their responsibility to provide high-quality teaching, they don’t consider it their responsibility to make you study. That’s down to you.

9.6 讲课时的礼貌

9.6 Courtesy in lectures

去听讲座时，你应该准时到达。当教授开始讲话时，你应该做好准备：拿出笔，在适当的页面上打开笔记，等等。你应该关掉手机。教授讲话时，你不应该说话。所有这些都是基本的礼貌。它们向教授表示礼貌，教授可能花了几个小时为你准备这个数学演讲。它们也向你的同学表示礼貌，如果你的同学不听话，他们完全有权利生气你迟到了，从他们身边挤过去坐下，拖着脚步从包里拿出东西，然后通过和朋友耳语来分散他们的注意力。我将对这些要点逐一展开，因为我知道在大型讲座中很容易感到自己是匿名的，了解看似无害的行为可能会对他人产生怎样的影响非常重要。

When you go to lectures, you should arrive on time. When the professor begins speaking, you should be ready: pen out, notes open at the appropriate page, and so on. You should turn off your phone. You should not speak when the professor is speaking. All of these things are common courtesy. They show courtesy to the professor, who has probably spent hours preparing this mathematical presentation for you. They also show courtesy to your fellow students, who have every right to be annoyed if you come in late, push past them to get to a seat, shuffle around getting stuff out of your bag, and then distract them by whispering to your friends. I’m going to expand just a bit on each of these points, because I know it’s easy to feel anonymous in large lectures, and it’s important to understand how apparently innocuous behavior might affect others.

根据我的经验，每个人都知道如何礼貌，但人们往往不善于付诸行动。特别是，人们经常迟到。我认为这有两个原因。首先，学生通常住在离他们上课地点很近的地方。这听起来很矛盾，但事实并非如此——如果你知道通常需要 45 分钟才能到达某个地方，你往往会留出一个小时的时间，但如果你知道只需要五分钟，你往往只留出五分钟的时间。这意味着如果你忘记了什么或者分心了，你肯定会迟到。第二个原因是人们无意中有点以自我为中心。他们知道迟到会扰乱自己的学习——他们会错过部分课程，可能是讲解要点的部分。但他们没有考虑他们的迟到会如何影响他人。学生迟到会让教授分心，也会分散已经在场并试图集中注意力的学生的注意力。所以，如果这样能让你准时到达，就假装课程提前五分钟开始吧。如果你这样做了，当你开始尝试倾听时，你就会感到放松并拥有正确的心态，这也意味着你也能从讲座中获得更多。

In my experience, everyone knows how to be courteous, but people are often bad at acting on it. In particular, people are often late. I think this happens for two reasons. The first is that students often live very close to the location of their lectures. That sounds paradoxical but it isn’t really—if you know it usually takes you 45 minutes to get somewhere, you tend to allow an hour, but if you know it only takes you five minutes, you tend to allow only five minutes. That means that if you forget anything or get distracted at all, you certainly will be late. The second reason is that people are accidentally a bit self-centered. They know that being late will disrupt their own education—they will miss part of a lecture, possibly the part where the main point gets explained. But they don’t think about how their being late might affect others. Students coming in late puts the professor off their stride, and distracts the students who are already there and trying to concentrate. So pretend that the lecture starts five minutes earlier if that will get you there on time. If you do, you’ll be relaxed and in the right frame of mind when you start trying to listen, which means that you’ll get more out of lectures, too.

现在，我要说说手机。我建议你完全关掉它们。数学讲座可能非常密集，即使对于准备充分的学生来说，从中学习也具有挑战性。手机之类的东西有时被称为“干扰技术”，这是有原因的。手边放着一些会不断分散你注意力的东西来破坏你的注意力，这有点愚蠢。另外，要注意，当你使用手机时，你的教授可以看到你。从教授的角度来看，当学生坐直、手握笔、看着黑板、专心听讲时，教授是很明显的。当学生低着头坐着、一只手放在两腿之间发短信时，教授也是很明显的。有一次，我用一张桌子和一把椅子演示了这一点，结果引得大家哈哈大笑，那正好在演讲厅的前面。有时人们甚至会完全忘记自己，坐在桌子上，手肘靠在桌子上，手机在他们头顶的高度完全可见。显然，这更糟糕，但无论哪种情况，这基本上就是在对教授说：“我不在乎你花了多少精力教我，我甚至不会假装听。”这种行为可能不是有意要进行人身攻击，但给人的感觉就是这样。

Now, cellphones. I would advise you to switch them off entirely. Mathematics lectures can be very intensive and learning from them is challenging, even for the well-prepared student. Cellphones and the like are sometimes known as “interruption technologies,” for good reason. It’s a bit daft to undermine your ability to concentrate by having something to hand that will constantly distract you. Also, be aware that when you use your phone, your professor can see you. From the professor’s vantage point, it’s very obvious when a student is sitting up straight, pen in hand, looking at the board, and paying attention. It’s also very obvious when a student is sitting with their head down and one hand between their legs sending a text message. I once got a laugh by demonstrating this using a desk and chair that happened to be at the front of the lecture theatre. Sometimes people even forget themselves entirely, and sit with their elbow wedged on the desk and their phone in full view at the height of their head. Obviously that’s even worse, but in either case it basically says to the professor, “I don’t care how much effort you are putting into teaching me, I’m not even going to pretend to listen.” Such behavior might not be intended as a personal insult, but that is how it comes across.

最后，尽量不要在讲座上说话。同样，我认为大多数人并不是故意无礼，但由于匿名的幻觉，他们被诱惑这样做。他们认为别人听不到他们说话，或者他们认为学生太多，教授无法区分每个人，尤其是坐在后面的学生。他们错了，这两点都是错的。当有人说话时，我总是能听到，我能清楚地看到每个人。如果你对此表示怀疑，当你走过一个相当拥挤的演讲厅前面时，在某个时候停下来——你会发现你可以很清楚地看到所有人的脸。同样，当有人在说话时，我通常能准确地说出是谁。即使你认为你的教授视力比我差，而且太紧张而不能叫你安静，你也应该出于礼貌保持安静。

Finally, try not to talk in lectures. Again, I think that most people don’t mean to be rude, but they get tempted into this because of the illusion of anonymity. They think that they can’t be heard, or they think that there are so many students that the professor can’t distinguish individuals, especially if they sit near the back. They are wrong, on both counts. I can always hear it when someone is speaking, and I can see everyone perfectly well. If you doubt this, pause at some point when you are walking across the front of a fairly full lecture theatre—you’ll find that you can see all the faces quite clearly. Similarly, when someone is talking, I can usually tell exactly who it is. Even if you think your professor has poorer eyesight than me and is too nervous to tell you to be quiet, you should keep quiet anyway out of courtesy.

尽管如此，有些时候你肯定应该说话。如果你的教授要求你和其他学生讨论某件事，你就有机会表达你当前对某个想法的想法，这样你就可以在接下来的讲座中有一个良好的发展基础。抓住这个机会。如果你注意到教授在写作中犯了错误（应该写 m 而写成了 n 或类似情况），你也应该举手或以其他方式礼貌地说出来。这种情况有时会发生——教授很难同时连贯地讲话、记下他们所说的部分内容并与满屋子的学生保持合理的目光接触。当人们指出错误时，教授会很感激，因为立即纠正错误通常比稍后再回去纠正要容易得多。其他学生也会感激——如果你注意到了错误，其他人可能也注意到了，至少他们中的一些人会感到困惑，但太紧张而不敢问。如果您不确定是否存在错误，请随后与教授核对（并参阅第 10 章讨论在更非正式的环境中可以提出此类问题的其他时间和地点）。

All of this said, there are occasions when you definitely should talk. If your professor asks you to discuss something with other students, you are being given an opportunity to articulate your current thinking about some idea, probably so that you have a good basis for development in the rest of the lecture. Take that opportunity. You should also raise your hand or otherwise politely speak up if you notice that the professor has made an error in their writing (writing an n when there should have been an m, or similar). This will happen sometimes—it’s difficult for a professor to simultaneously speak coherently, write down a subset of what they’re saying, and maintain reasonable eye contact with a roomful of students. Professors are grateful when people point out errors, because it’s usually much easier to fix them immediately than to go back and do it later. Other students will be grateful too—if you’ve noticed an error, others probably have too, and at least some of them will be confused but too nervous to ask. If you’re not sure whether there’s an error or not, pop down and check with the professor afterwards (and see Chapter 10 for a discussion on other times and places at which you can ask such questions in more informal environments).

我在这一部分主要想说的是，我相信你是一个彬彬有礼的人，在大多数情况下都很体贴和有礼貌。在讲座中也表现出这样的态度，你会得到赞赏的。

What I’m basically saying in this section is that I’m sure you are a well-mannered person who is considerate and courteous in most situations. Be like that in lectures too and it will be appreciated.

9.7 讲座反馈

9.7 Feedback on lectures

当你被要求对课程给出反馈时，你就有了另一种表现礼貌的机会。这可能发生在每个学期末。你的教授会给出一份标准的反馈表，其中一部分会有很多项目，你可以标记“非常同意”、“同意”等，另一部分会有更多的开放式问题（“你喜欢这门课程的哪些方面？”）。当你收到这样的表格时，一定要阅读说明，因为它们通常是机器可读的，如果你没有正确地给小方框涂色（或其他什么），你会给别人带来不必要的工作。此外，要小心“同意”的回答。曾经有两个学生在交完表格后跑来对我说：“我们真的很抱歉！我们把数字读错了，看起来我们讨厌你，但实际上我们认为你真的很好！”

A different sort of opportunity to be courteous arises when you are asked to give feedback on your courses. This will probably happen toward the end of each semester. Your professor will give out a standard feedback form, part of which will have a bunch of items where you mark “strongly agree,” “agree,” etc., and part of which will have more open questions (“What did you like about this course?”). When you get such a form, do read the instructions, because they are often machine-readable and, if you don’t color in the little boxes correctly (or whatever), you will cause someone somewhere unnecessary work. Also, be careful with the “agree” responses. I once had two students run up to me after handing in their forms and say, “We’re really sorry! We read the numbers the wrong way around and it looks like we hate you when actually we think you’re really good!”

但更重要的是，请抓住机会写出建设性的评论。我强调，请写出建设性的评论。在回答“你喜欢这门课程的哪些方面？”这样的问题时，写“没有”真的没有什么意义。这种评论不包含任何有助于教授改进的信息。尽量具体一点，如果你有抱怨，就提出建设性的建议，说明哪些方面可以有效改进。当然，要确保这些建议确实可以改进——一个人可能无法摆脱中国口音，但他们可以说话慢一点。如果你的评论是正面的，这个关于具体性的要求也适用。作为一名教授，得到积极的反馈是件好事，但获得关于课程哪些方面最能支持学生学习的具体信息也很有用。

More importantly, though, please take the opportunity to write constructive comments. I stress, constructive please. There really isn’t much point in responding to a question like “What did you like about this course?” by writing “Nothing.” This comment contains no information that would help a professor to improve. Try to be specific and, if you have a complaint, give a constructive suggestion about what could usefully be changed. Make sure it realistically can be changed, of course—a person probably can’t stop having a Chinese accent, but they might be able to speak more slowly. This request about specificity also applies if your comments are positive. As a professor, it’s lovely to get positive feedback, but it’s also useful to get specific information about which aspects of the course best supported the students’ learning.

您可能还有更多非正式的机会来提供反馈。教授可能会在早期发放一份问卷，以了解哪些有效，哪些无效。或者他们可能会要求对首次尝试的活动或资源进行反馈。同样，您的回复要有建设性，如果有帮助，可以礼貌地要求进行小幅调整。最后，如果您喜欢某人的讲座并从中学到很多东西，请想办法让他们知道。教授们经常为他们的课程付出很多努力，得到认可是件好事。您不必太过分——在讲座结束时说一句简单的“谢谢”就会很感激。

You might have more informal opportunities to give feedback, too. A professor might give out a questionnaire early on, to get a sense of what is and is not working. Or they might ask for feedback on an activity or resource that they’re trying out for the first time. Again, be constructive in your responses, and make polite requests for small adjustments if these would help. Finally, if you enjoy someone’s lectures and learn a lot from them, do find a way to let them know that. Professors often put a lot of work into their courses and it’s nice to have this acknowledged. You don’t need to go overboard—a simple “thank you” on the way out of a lecture will be much appreciated.

概括

SUMMARY

• 讲座在演示媒介、讲义提供以及学生互动程度方面差异很大。

• Lectures vary a lot in terms of presentation medium, handout provision, and the degree to which students are expected to interact.

• 教授的风格各异，您可能会更喜欢其中的一些。许多教授来自海外，因此您可能需要适应不同的口音和书写风格。

• Professors have different styles, some of which you will like more than others. Many professors are from overseas, so you might have to adjust to different accents and styles of handwriting.

• 如果您对课程有小的实际问题，请考虑是否可以通过自己的行为解决。如果不行，请礼貌而有建设性地提出更改请求。

• If you have a small practical problem with a course, think about whether you could fix it via your own behavior. If not, make a polite and constructive request for a change.

• 如果提前发放课堂笔记，您可能会发现很难集中注意力，或者很难了解课程的结构，或者很难将课程笔记与问题集联系起来。有合理的方法可以解决这些问题。

• You might find it difficult to concentrate if lecture notes are give out in advance, or difficult to see how a course is structured, or difficult to link course notes to problem sets. There are sensible ways to tackle these issues.

• 你应该去上课，集中注意力。这是你的责任，如果你努力做好准备，事情就会变得容易得多。

• You should go to lectures and pay attention. This is your responsibility, and it will be easier if you make some effort to be prepared.

• 上课时要有礼貌：准时上课，关闭手机，教授讲话时不要说话。

• Courtesy in lectures will be appreciated: be on time, switch off your cellphone, and do not talk when the professor is talking.

• 当您有机会提供反馈时，请以具体且建设性的方式提供。

• When you get opportunities to give feedback, do so in a specific and constructive way.

进一步阅读

FURTHER READING

要了解有关从讲座和讲座笔记中学习的更多信息，请尝试：

For more on learning from lectures and lecture notes, try:

• Moore, S. & Murphy, S. (2005)。《如何做一名学生：适合世界各地学生的 100 个好主意和实用习惯》。梅登黑德：开放大学出版社。

• Moore, S. & Murphy, S. (2005). How to be a Student: 100 Great Ideas and Practical Habits for Students Everywhere. Maidenhead: Open University Press.

• Newport, C. (2007)。《如何成为一名全优生：大学生在学习时间较少的情况下取得高分的非常规策略》。纽约：Three Rivers Press。

• Newport, C. (2007). How to Become a Straight-A Student: The Unconventional Strategies Real College Students Use to Score High While Studying Less. New York: Three Rivers Press.

第 10 章

其他人

CHAPTER 10

Other People

本章就如何充分利用与教授和其他讲师的互动以及与其他学生合作时应考虑的事项提出了建议。它还讨论了您可能有机会与项目主管和实习经理进行更个人层面的互动，并描述了常见的大学支持服务。

This chapter gives suggestions on how to get the most out of interactions with professors and other instructors, and on things to consider when working with other students. It also discusses opportunities you might have to interact on a more individual level with project supervisors and internship managers, and describes common college support services.

10.1 教授作为教师

10.1 Professors as teachers

在本科教育期间，你会从其他人那里学到很多东西。这很明显，因为你的教授应该教你，但在学习期间，还有许多其他方式可以与不同的人互动。在本章的最后，我将讨论与其他学生一起学习，但我将从你与教授和其他权威人士互动的机会开始。

You will learn a lot from other people during your undergraduate education. This is obvious in the sense that your professors are supposed to teach you, but there are also many other ways to interact with different people during your studies. Toward the end of the chapter, I’ll discuss studying with other students, but I will begin with opportunities you have to interact with professors and others in authority.

在大学里，你可能不太容易接触到权威人士。在高中，你的老师可能每天都会向你提供帮助。他们会单独和你交谈，注意到你何时遇到困难，诸如此类。在大学里，班级规模可能更大，所以你的教授可能不会这样做。在一个有 100 人的班级里，教授抓住某个人说“那么，尼娜，你昨天的作业做得怎么样？”是不切实际的。

At college it might not be obvious that you have access to authoritative people. In high school, your teachers probably offered you help on a daily basis. They talked to you individually, noticed when you were having trouble getting started on a problem, that kind of thing. In college, classes can be bigger, so your professors probably won’t do that. In a class of 100 people, it just isn’t practical for a professor to catch someone and say “So, Nina, how did you get on with yesterday’s work?”

因此，你很容易与教授产生距离感，并认为他们没有多少支持。事实并非如此。支持是有的——很多——不同之处在于你必须主动寻找支持。这最初可能看起来令人生畏，尤其是如果你有点害羞的话。教授们往往看起来非常有权威和超智商，有些人觉得和他们交谈很可怕。但他们只是人，他们热爱数学，而且绝大多数时候他们都会很高兴和你谈论数学。在本章中，我将讨论如何与你的大学老师进行良好、有效的个人互动。

Because of this, it’s easy to feel distanced from your professors, and to get the impression that there is not much support available. This is not the case at all. There is support—lots of it—the difference is that you have to take the initiative and seek it out. This might initially seem daunting, especially if you are a bit shy. Professors tend to look very authoritative and hyper-intelligent, and some people find it intimidating to talk to them. But they are just people, and they love mathematics, and the vast majority of the time they will be delighted to talk to you about it. In this chapter I’ll talk about how to have good, effective, individual interactions with your college teachers.

10.2 复习和问题课

10.2 Recitations and problems classes

我们将从复习课（有时称为问题课）开始，因为这可能是解决你的数学问题最明显的地方。正如我在本书的介绍中所说，许多课程都有相关的复习课，这些课可能是由课程教授或其他教师（如正在攻读数学博士学位的研究生助教）主持的。复习课通常比讲座课小，这意味着复习课教师可能比教授更适合了解你个人并回答你的具体问题。

We’ll start with recitations (sometimes called problems sessions) because these might be the most obvious place to get your mathematical questions addressed. As I said in the introduction to the book, many courses have associated recitations, and these might be run by the course professor or by another instructor such as postgraduate teaching assistant who is studying for a PhD in mathematics. Recitation sessions are often smaller than lecture classes, which means that recitation instructors might be better placed than professors to get to know you personally and to answer your particular questions.

复习课的内容因机构和教师而异。你可能被要求每周解决一组指定的问题，并提交书面解决方案或将其带到课堂上。然而，它可能比这自由得多。你的老师可能希望你主动提出你遇到的问题或你不理解的讲座内容。在这种情况下，课程的有效性将取决于你的准备程度。1理想情况下，你应该带上你想问的事情的清单，以及所有相关的笔记和问题以及你自己的解决尝试。

What happens in recitations varies from institution to institution and from instructor to instructor. You might be expected to work on an assigned set of problems every week and to hand in written solutions or to bring these to the session. However, it might be much freer than that. Your instructor might expect you to take the initiative and bring along problems that you got stuck with or things from lectures that you didn’t understand. In that case, the effectiveness of the sessions will depend on how well you prepare.1 Ideally, you should take along a list of things you want to ask, as well as all the relevant notes and problems and your own solution attempts.

在背诵课上，谁做什么也各不相同。你的老师可能会说大部分话；他们可能会问学生遇到了什么问题，然后在黑板上解决问题。或者，学生可能会被要求分成小组，而老师则四处走动，帮助他们解决遇到的问题。在这种情况下，你会得到更多个人或小组关注，因此可能有一些关于如何提高你个人思考和写作水平的意见。你的导师甚至可能坐在后面，希望学生完成大部分的写作和谈话，并在适当的时候给予提示。如果发生这种情况，你应该接受这一点——这可能是你表达自己的想法和接受如何改进的指导的最佳机会。

Who does what during recitations varies too. Your instructor might do most of the talking; they might ask what problems the students are stuck with, then work through solutions at the board. Alternatively, students might be expected to work in small groups while the instructor goes around to help people when they get stuck. In that case, you’ll get more individual or small-group attention, and probably therefore some input on how to improve your individual thinking and writing. Your instructor might even sit at the back and expect students to do most of the writing and talking, with hints from them as appropriate. You should embrace this if it happens—it’s probably the best opportunity you will get to articulate your thinking and to receive guidance on how to improve.

不管你的复习是如何组织的，你都可以自由地询问除了老师正在讨论的问题之外的事情。当然，如果他们正在对全班同学讲话，我的意思并不是打断他们，但你可以提前发邮件，请他们复习一个特定的问题或重新解释一个重要的概念。如果你在讲座中听不懂某些东西，那么听听老师的另一种解释可能正是你所需要的。随着时间的推移，这个过程应该会变得更加有效——随着你的老师对班级的了解，他们会对学生已经知道的内容产生感觉，从而知道什么样的解释最有意义。如果他们确实来提供个人帮助，这也是询问课程其他部分问题的好时机。

However your recitations are organized, you should feel free to ask about things other than the problems that the instructor is discussing. I don’t mean interrupt if they’re talking to the whole class, obviously, but you might be able to email in advance and ask them to go over a particular problem or to re-explain an important concept. If there’s something you didn’t understand in a lecture, then hearing an alternative explanation from an instructor might be just what you need. This process should become more effective as time goes on—as your instructor gets to know the class, they will develop a feel for what the students already know and thus for what explanations are likely to make the most sense. And if they do come around to give individual help, that’s a good time to ask questions about other parts of the course too.

总的来说，你的复习老师能够很好地支持你作为一个独立的数学思考者，并帮助你提高你的现场推理能力，特别是如果他们还对你的书面作业给出反馈的话。这意味着你应该经常参加复习，并充分利用所提供的资源。如果你的老师是教授，还有另一个更平淡无奇的原因你应该经常去：在某个时候你可能希望这个人为你写推荐信。如果你请他们这样做，而他们的第一个想法是，“哦，是的，马丁，他很少出现，而且总是准备不足”，这并不能让他们心情愉快地写出你是多么的聪明。

Overall, your recitation instructor is well-placed to support you as an individual mathematical thinker and to help you to improve your on-the-spot reasoning, especially if they also give feedback on your written work. This means that you should always go to recitations and make the most of what is on offer. If your instructor is a professor, there is also another, more prosaic reason you should always go: at some point you might want this person to write a recommendation for you. If you ask them to do so and their first thought is, “Oh yes, Martin, he’s the one who rarely showed up and was always ill-prepared,” that doesn’t put them in a great frame of mind for writing about how brilliant you are.

10.3 课前和课后提问

10.3 Asking questions after and before lectures

你也可以在课堂上直接向模块教授提问。但是，大多数人都不喜欢在课堂上提问，尤其是在人数众多的低年级课堂上。这是完全可以理解的——你总是有可能误解了某些事情，虽然培养表达自己观点的信心是件好事，但不确定性，避免在其他 100 人面前冒这个险是正常的。但是，没有什么可以阻止你在讲座结束时站起来提出问题。这是完全可以接受的，也是许多教授积极鼓励的事情。我当然希望更多的学生能这样做，尤其是因为提问的人往往会帮到我一个大忙。有时他们会感到困惑，因为我犯了一个当时没人指出的小错误；知道这一点可以让我在下一堂课中纠正它。有时他们会误解我写或说的东西。由于人们通常不会做出疯狂的解释，其他学生也可能因为同样的原因而感到困惑，而且我可以使用这些信息在另一堂课上给出改进或不同的解释。

You can also put questions directly to your module professors in lecture time. However, most people are not comfortable asking questions in lectures, especially in big lower-level classes. This is completely understandable—there’s always a risk that you’ve misunderstood something and, while it’s good to develop confidence in voicing your own uncertainty, it’s normal to avoid taking that risk in front of 100 other people. However, there’s nothing to stop you going up at the end of the lecture and asking your question then. This is perfectly acceptable, and is something that many professors actively encourage. I certainly wish that more students would do it, not least because people who do ask questions often do me a big favor. Sometimes it turns out that they’re confused because I made a small error that no-one pointed out at the time; knowing this allows me to correct it in the next lecture. And sometimes it turns out that they’ve misinterpreted something I’ve written or said. Since people don’t usually make crazy interpretations, other students might well be confused for the same reason, and again I can use this information to give an improved or different explanation in another lecture.

当然，在课程结束时提问可能只适用于澄清一些小问题。如果你真的感到困惑，你可能无法那么快地提出你的问题，你可能需要离开一会儿，思考一下。在这种情况下，你可能想提前到达下一堂课，并在课前提问。这也可以。不过，请记住，你的教授可能无法立即关注你的问题。他们可能需要专心准备讲座，或者他们可能不得不在课程结束时匆忙离开，因为他们在校园的另一边有一个会议。即使他们能集中精力，他们也可能决定需要几分钟以上的时间才能给你一个正确的答案。无论哪种情况，他们都可能会要求你下次再来，或者与他们单独预约。不要因此而感到沮丧——这通常只是出于实际考虑。

Of course, asking questions at the end is probably only practical for small points of clarification. If you’re properly confused, you might not be able to formulate your question that quickly, and you might need to go away and think about it for a while. In that case, you might want to arrive early for the next lecture and ask before it starts. That’s fine too. Bear in mind, though, that your professor might not be able to focus on your query straight away. They might need to concentrate on setting up for the lecture, or they might have to rush off at the end because they’ve got a meeting on the other side of campus. Even if they can concentrate on it, they might decide that they need more than a couple of minutes to give you a proper answer. In either case, they might ask you to come back another time or to make a separate appointment with them. Don’t feel put off by this—it’s usually just because of practical considerations.

10.4 安排与教授的单独会面

10.4 Arranging a separate meeting with a professor

在某些情况下，您可能会认为与教授进行更长时间的会面会很有用。也许您甚至无法弄清楚让您感到困惑的是什么，或者您已经列出了一系列问题，并且似乎应该一次性全部问完。教授通常会为这种事情指定办公时间。办公时间会在模块文档或网络上公布，您只需在规定的时间和地点（通常是教授办公室）出现即可。如果教授没有办公室小时，不要因此而放弃。给教授发一封电子邮件并请求与他们会面是完全可以接受的。如果你想这样做，这里有一些建议可以让这个过程更有效。

In some cases, you might decide that a longer meeting with a professor would be useful. Perhaps you are having trouble even formulating what is confusing you, or perhaps you have built up a list of questions and it seems sensible to go and ask them all at once. Professors usually have assigned office hours for this kind of thing. Office hours are publicized in module documentation or on the web, and you can just show up at the stated time and place (usually the professor’s office). If a professor doesn’t have office hours, don’t let that put you off. It’s perfectly acceptable to drop a professor an email and request a meeting with them. If you want to do that, here are some suggestions for making the process effective.

首先，建议一个你可以来的日子（通常在这种情况下你会去教授办公室）。如果我是你，我会这样说：“也许我可以在周二下午来？如果你有时间的话，我下午 2-4 点有空。”我不会说得更具体——当学生说“我想在星期五 3:30 来见你”这样的话时，我会感到有点恼火，因为他们表现得好像我可以放下一切，随时和他们见面，这是很冒昧的。也许我在这方面异常暴躁，但无论你怎么做，都要表现出一些灵活性——教授们都很忙（见第 14 章）。

First, suggest a day on which you could come (usually you’d go to the professor’s office in these circumstances). If I were you, I’d say something like “Perhaps I could come on Tuesday afternoon? I am free 2–4pm if you have any time then.” I wouldn’t be any more specific than that—I find it a bit irritating when students say things like “I would like to come and see you at 3:30 on Friday,” because it’s presumptuous for them to act like I’ll just be able to drop everything and meet whenever they like. Perhaps I’m atypically irritable in this respect but, however you do it, show some flexibility—professors are busy people (see Chapter 14).

其次，考虑先和少数其他学生讨论你的问题，然后安排一起去。你的教授会很感激你的这种做法，因为这样可以有效利用时间。

Second, consider discussing your questions with a small number of other students first, and arranging to go along together. Your professor will appreciate this, as it makes for an efficient use of time.

第三，确保你事先清楚自己想问什么。如果学生带着一种模糊的感觉“不理解第 3 章”，那么帮助他们就很难了；如果他们说“我在做第 2 个问题时已经到这里了，但我不知道下一步该怎么做”，或者“我理解这个证明的大部分内容，但我不知道为什么从第三行到第四行的步骤是有效的”，那么就更容易直击问题的核心。带上一份问题清单，提醒自己到底想问什么，确保不会错过任何东西。如果清单很长，也不用担心。我注意到学生们可能会不好意思拿出一份长长的清单，但我很喜欢——这表明他们很有条理，这通常意味着我们可以在很短的时间内处理很多问题。当然，如果你真的对课程的整个部分感到困惑，那么提问是可以的，但要尽量以建设性的方式提出你的问题。您可以这样说，“我对第 4 部分的大部分内容都满意，但我一直在努力跟上第 5 部分，我想知道我是否错过了一个可以让一切变得更容易的关键思想。” 那么至少这个人知道从哪里开始。

Third, make sure you’re clear in advance about what you want to ask. It’s quite hard to help someone who comes in with a vague sense that they “don’t understand Chapter 3;” it’s much easier to get to the heart of the difficulty if they say, “I’ve got up to here when working on problem 2 but I don’t know what to do next,” or “I understand most of this proof but I don’t know why the step from the third to the fourth line is valid.” Take along a list of questions to remind yourself exactly what you wanted to ask and to make sure that you don’t miss anything. And don’t worry if the list is quite long. I’ve noticed that students can be embarrassed to show up with a long list, but I love it—it shows that they’ve been organized, and it usually means that we can handle a lot of queries in a pretty short time. Of course, if you genuinely are mystified by a whole section of a course, then it’s fine to ask, but try to frame your question constructively. You could say something like, “I was okay with most of Section 4, but I’ve been struggling to follow Section 5, and I wonder if I’ve missed a key idea that would make it all easier.” Then at least the person has some sense of where to start.

第四，带上你可能需要参考的所有资料。这一点很重要，因为你的教授可能没有所有资料，而且他们也不具备百科全书式的知识，不知道问题集 6 中的第 5 个问题到底是什么（我有时会被学生对我所写或所问内容的记忆所感动，但通常这是错误的）。事实上，出于另一个原因，拥有所有东西的版本是有用的：有时我看过学生的笔记，发现他们感到困惑的原因是他们抄错了一些东西。不用说，你应该确保你把所有的材料都整理好，这样你就可以轻松地找到与你的每个问题相关的内容。

Fourth, take along everything you might need to refer to. This is important because your professor might not have everything immediately to hand, and because they don’t have encyclopedic knowledge of exactly what question 5 from problem set 6 was about (I’m sometimes touched by the faith students have in my memory of exactly what I’ve written or asked, but usually this is misguided). In fact, it can be useful to have your version of everything for another reason: sometimes I’ve looked at a student’s notes and discovered that the reason they’re confused is that they’ve mis-copied something. And it goes without saying that you should make sure you’ve got all your materials organized so that you can easily find the things that are relevant to each of your questions.

最后，请记住，教授的职责之一就是在课程中为您提供支持，因此您应该觉得去见他们完全合理。当然，这并不意味着像 6 岁的孩子一样行事。您不应该在无法完成某件事时就敲他们的门——显然，您应该先好好考虑一下。但是，如果您确实决定要见他们，您可能会发现这是一次令人惊喜的愉快经历。作为一名学生，我在硕士课程即将结束时去见一位教授时才发现这一点，这比理想的情况要晚得多。他很高兴有人对他的学科感兴趣，并且愿意和我聊很长时间。

Finally, remember that it is part of your professor’s job to support you in the course, so you should feel perfectly justified in going to see them. This does not mean acting like a 6 year-old, of course. You shouldn’t knock on their door the minute you can’t do something—obviously you’re expected to give it some proper thought first. But, if you do decide you want to see them, you might find it a surprisingly pleasant experience. As a student, I found this out much later than would have been ideal, when I went to see a professor toward the end of a masters course. He was very happy that someone was taking an interest in his subject, and he was willing to talk to me for ages.

10.5 通过电子方式提问

10.5 Asking questions electronically

这些天，我通过电子邮件收到不少数学问题。说实话，收到这些问题让我感到有些疲倦。我很高兴学生问问题，这显然是件好事——他们提出问题比担心某事或感到困惑要好得多。但是，即使最近技术取得了许多进步，在普通的电子邮件环境中处理数学问题仍然很困难。有时我发现很难理解学生到底在问什么。其他时候，我可以理解他们在问什么，但我无法以书面形式提出非常明确的答复。通常，我觉得如果学生真的在房间里会更好，这样我们就可以在纸上看一些东西，并进行来回讨论，我可以尝试确保我们彼此理解。结果是，当有人通过电子邮件向我发送数学问题时，我经常最终要求他们来找我。

These days, I receive quite a few mathematics questions by email. If I’m honest, getting these makes me feel a bit weary. I’m glad the student is asking, obviously—much better that they ask a question than worry about something or get confused and stay that way. But, even with the many recent improvements in technology, it can still be hard to deal with mathematics in an ordinary email environment. Sometimes I find it difficult to understand what exactly the student is asking. Other times, I can understand what they’re asking, but I can’t formulate a very clear response in writing. Usually, I feel it would be much better if the student was actually there in the room, so that we could look at something on paper and have a back-and-forth discussion in which I could try to make sure we understood each other. The upshot of this is that when someone emails me a mathematics question, I often end up asking them to come and see me instead.

尽管如此，我确实知道其他教授热衷于使用各种技术工具与学生交流，他们利用课程网页上的讨论主题等内容。这是另一种情况你应该思考什么是实用的，并注意教授更喜欢什么。

That said, I do know other professors who are keen to communicate with students using various technological tools, and who make use of things like discussion threads on course webpages. This is another situation in which you should think about what is practical and be alert to what a professor seems to prefer.

不过，有一点要记住，无论何时联系教授，你都应该写得正确，并且（尽可能）使用正确的拼写、语法和标点符号。这是因为你与这个人是专业关系——事实上，他们是你的前辈。他们在课堂上可能表现得很轻松随意——他们可能会告诉你直呼其名等等——但他们不是你的朋友。一定要写一个合适的问候语（“亲爱的 Lara”或“亲爱的 Smith 博士”），要有礼貌，不要用短信语言书写（没有什么比写“我想要 2 cu”或类似的话更让你显得不成熟了）。一定要用你的名字签名，这样对方才知道如何称呼你，看在上帝的份上，不要在后面写吻。而且，从长远来看，如果你知道你的书面英语不是很好，可以考虑买一本短篇小说，学习如何改正（请参阅“进一步阅读”部分的建议）。真正让所有雇主感到厌烦的一件事是不知道在哪里放撇号或犯其他明显的语法错误的人。你最好现在就开始学习纠正这个问题。

One thing to remember, though, is that whenever you contact a professor, you should write properly, with (as far as you can manage it) correct spelling and grammar and punctuation. This is because you are in a professional relationship with this person—indeed, they are your senior. They might act in a relaxed and informal way in class—they might tell you to call them by their first name and so on—but they are not your buddy. Make sure you write a proper greeting (“Dear Lara” or “Dear Dr. Smith”), be polite, and do not write in textspeak (few things make you look more immature than writing “I wud like 2 c u” or similar). Make sure you sign off with your name so the person knows how to address you in return, and for heaven’s sake don’t put kisses after it. And, in the long term, if you know that your written English is not very good, consider getting a short book and learning how to fix it (see the Further Reading section for suggestions). One thing that really puts off employers of all kinds is a person who doesn’t know where to put their apostrophes or who makes other glaring grammatical errors. You might as well start learning to fix this now.

10.6 （数学）学习中心

10.6 (Mathematics) learning centers

随着时间的推移，大学的支持服务趋于扩大和更加专业化，许多机构现在都设有学习中心（有时称为辅导中心或类似名称），其中一些提供专业数学辅导。一般中心和专业中心通常都向整个机构的学生开放——许多学位课程既需要一般学习技能，也需要一种或另一种数学——尽管有些中心可能专门帮助新入学的学生或特定部门的专业学生。不要让这个名字让你认为学习中心只为那些真正挣扎的人服务——通常它们也向表现良好的人开放。

Support services in colleges tend to expand and get more specialized as time goes on, and lots of of institutions now have learning centers (sometimes called tutoring centers or similar), some of which offer specialist mathematics tutoring. Both general and specialist centers are usually open to students from across the whole institution—lots of degree programs require both general learning skills and one or another kind of mathematics—although some might specialize in helping either newlyarrived students or majors from particular departments. Don’t let the name make you think that learning centers are only for people who are really struggling—usually they are open to people who are doing well too.

学习中心有几种基本模式。在一些机构，你可以预约（可能是在线），然后在指定时间出现并获得一对一的帮助。帮助你的人可能是讲师，也可能是本科生或研究生。其他学习中心以开放学习空间的形式运营，你可以在那里走进去并加入排队系统。在我的大学里，这需要拿起一张层压卡上的号码并将其放在你面前的桌子上，这样值班的导师就知道你希望他们来找你。学习中心通常也有各种数学资源（书籍、电脑、传单），你通常可以直接进去，把它们当作学习的地方，无论是自己学习还是与其他学生一起学习。

There are a couple of basic models for learning centers. In some institutions, you book an appointment (probably online), and then show up at the appointed time and get one-to-one help. The person helping you might be an instructor or it might be an undergraduate or postgraduate student. Other learning centers operate as open study spaces, where you can just walk in and join a queuing system. In my university this involves picking up a number on a laminated card and putting it in front of you on the desk, so that the tutor on duty knows that you would like them to come to you. Often, learning centers have various mathematical resources (books, computers, leaflets) around too, and often it’s fine for you to just go in and use them as places to study, either on your own or with other students.

事实上，作为学习空间的学习中心可以促进学生之间的合作。在我所在大学的数学学习支持中心，我经常看到一群学生安静地一起工作。我还看到过互不相识的学生之间表现出真正的友谊和支持。有一次，我试图帮助某人学习一门不熟悉的高级课程，但由于我手头没有正确的知识，所以我做得并不好。这时，一位学生从另一张桌子走过来，指着她的朋友说：“我们正在这边做这件事，我想我们可以做那道题——如果你愿意，欢迎你来加入我们。” 救了我。多么美好的时刻。

Indeed, learning centers that operate as study spaces can facilitate cooperation between students. In the Mathematics Learning Support Centres at my university, I often see groups of students working quietly together. I have also seen acts of genuine friendship and support between students who did not even know each other. Once, I was trying to help someone with an unfamiliar upper-level course, and I wasn’t doing a great job because I didn’t have the right knowledge at my fingertips. I was rescued from this situation when a student came over from another table, pointed back at her friends and said “We’re working on that over here and I think we can do that question—you’re welcome to come and join us if you like.” What a lovely moment.

需要记住的一点是，在学习中心，您可能会得到一位对您正在学习的科目了如指掌的导师的帮助。如果是专业中心，而您需要的是低级课程的帮助，那么这种情况几乎总是存在的。但是，您现在已经达到了数学教育的阶段，人们开始专攻这一阶段，而且导师可能不会提供高级课程的帮助。一些导师可能仍然能够帮助您——他们可能学习过类似的材料，并且他们可能比您拥有更好的一般问题解决能力——但他们可能需要检查一些定义或找出您的课程教授如何使用某种符号。因此，请考虑从哪里获得最佳帮助，并且像往常一样，带上所有相关材料。

One thing to bear in mind is that, in a learning center, you might get help from a tutor who knows all about the subject you are studying. This should almost always be the case if it’s a specialist center and you want help with a lower-level course. But you are now reaching the stage of your mathematical education at which people start to specialize, and it might be that the tutors do not offer help with upper-level courses. Some tutors might still be able to help you—they might have studied similar material, and they might have better general problem solving skills than you do—but they will probably need to check some definitions or to find out how your course professor is using a certain notation. So think about where best to get help, and, as ever, take along all the relevant materials.

另一件需要注意的事情是，学习中心的导师可能有资格为您提供其他类型的学术指导，例如有关如何应对学习困难的建议，或者有关在学位课程的哪个阶段应该选修哪些课程的建议。但他们可能没有资格。例如，他们可能是能够帮助学习某些数学课程但没有资格就学院的文科要求提供建议的学生。对于这种类型的建议，您应该始终向合格的人寻求帮助；其他学生的建议，无论出于多么好的意图，往往都是过时的或具有误导性的。

Another thing to bear in mind is that tutors in a learning center might be qualified to give you other types of academic guidance, such as advice on handling learning difficulties, or on which courses to take at which stages of your degree program. But they might not. They might be students who are able to help with certain mathematics courses but who are not qualified to advise on the college’s liberal arts requirements, for instance. For that type of advice you should always go to a qualified person; advice from other students, however well-intentioned, is often out-of-date or otherwise misleading.

您可能已经知道，我认为您将有很多机会通过与更有经验的人交谈来加深您的理解。然而，尽管有所有这些积极的评论，但在某些时候，您（或朋友）在寻求帮助时可能会遇到不好的经历。这种情况非常非常罕见，但我确实偶尔会听说老师或导师告诉学生他们应该已经知道如何做某事，或者对他们缺乏知识感到惊讶，这让学生感到难过。万一这种情况发生在您身上，要记住的是，这个人表现得不敏感，您不想让一个不敏感的人（或者可能是一个通常很敏感的人，只是因为某种原因过得很糟糕）让您失望。所以向朋友抱怨一下这种经历，然后把它抛在脑后，问问别人。

As you can probably tell, I think that you will have lots of opportunities to develop your understanding by talking to more experienced people. However, despite all these positive comments it is possible that, at some point, you (or a friend) will have a bad experience when asking for help. This is very, very rare, but I do occasionally hear that an instructor or tutor has made a student feel bad by telling them they should already know how to do something, or has acted surprised at their lack of knowledge. In the unlikely event that this happens to you, the thing to remember is that this person has behaved insensitively, and that you don’t want to let one insensitive person (or perhaps an ordinarily sensitive person who’s just having a really bad day for some reason) put you off. So complain about the experience to a friend, then put it behind you and ask someone else.

10.7 项目和实习

10.7 Projects and internships

到目前为止，本章讨论了你在日常本科活动中与教授或其他有经验的人互动的方式。这可能是你在一两年内所经历的一切，那时你将参加讲座、研讨会和朗诵。然而，在你的学位课程后期，你可能有机会参加涉及不同类型的互动并培养不同技能的活动。

So far, this chapter has discussed ways in which you might interact with professors or with other experienced people during day-to-day undergraduate activities. This is probably all you will experience during your first year or two, when you will go to lectures, seminars, and recitations. However, later in your degree program you might have the opportunity to take part in activities that involve different types of interactions and that develop different skills.

首先，你可能有机会写一篇扩展的数学论文、项目或学位论文。这可能发生在你最后一年，它将取代一门、两门或更多门标准讲座课程。或者它可能是一个暑期研究机会，特别是如果你在参加荣誉课程。现在，项目（我将使用它作为一个总称）有一些风险。到你最后一年的时候，你会对自己在考试中的表现有一个相当好的了解，而项目是一个未知数。然而，这一事实也是做项目的关键优势：它将培养不同的技能。这一点值得认真考虑。与其他许多课程相比，数学课程非常统一，因为学生主要从讲座中学习。例如，数学专业的学生通常不会在小组中做大量的工作，也不会做很多演讲，也不会写报告和评论别人写的报告，也不会独立研究一些话题。这种情况本身并不坏，但它确实意味着，当潜在雇主想要举例说明他们如何发展自己的沟通技巧时，数学专业的学生可能缺乏可以借鉴的经验。

First, you might have the opportunity to work on an extended mathematical essay, project, or dissertation. This might occur in your final year, where it would act as a replacement for one, two, or perhaps more standard lectured courses. Or it might occur as a summer research opportunity, especially if you are in an honors program. Now, projects (I’ll use that as an umbrella term) have some risks attached. By the time of your final year, you will have a pretty good idea of how well you can do in exams, whereas a project is a bit of an unknown quantity. However, that very fact is also key to the advantage of doing a project: it will develop different skills. This is a point worth serious consideration. Mathematics courses, more than many others, are pretty uniform in that students mostly learn from lectures. Mathematics majors don’t usually do a great deal of work in groups, for instance, or give a lot of presentations, or write reports and critique those written by others, or independently research some topic. This situation isn’t bad in itself, but it does mean that mathematics majors can lack experience to draw on when potential employers want examples of how, for instance, they have developed their communication skills.

如果你做了一个项目，你将获得至少解决其中一些问题的经验。你将按照自己的节奏从书籍或研究论文中学习，或者你将努力将标准论证应用于新的例子，或诸如此类的事情。你可能必须在课程进行中或结束时向其他学生和/或教授做演讲。你几乎肯定会与担任你的项目顾问的教授一对一交流；这个人也可能会定期就你的书面作业给你反馈。如果你认为你可能想继续深造，这会特别有价值，因为这更像是成为一名博士生，而不是坐在讲座上。此外，你可能会发现你真的很享受这种经历并从中学到很多东西。写出一篇反映对某个主题的深刻理解的实质性书面作品，表明你可以以连贯清晰的方式组织对它的讨论，这本身就是一种满足。所以，虽然我无法对任何具体情况发表评论，但我的观点是，做一个项目的好处通常大于风险。

If you do a project, you will get experience that addresses at least some of these points. You will learn at your own pace from books or research papers, or you will work on applying a standard argument to a new example, or something like that. You might have to do a presentation to other students and/or professors, either part way through or at the end. You will almost certainly interact one-to-one with the professor who is acting as your project adviser; this person might also give you periodic feedback on your written work. This can be especially valuable if you think you might want to go on to further study, as it’s much more like being a PhD student than is sitting in lectures. In addition, you might find that you really enjoy the experience and learn a lot from it. There is something inherently satisfying about producing a substantial piece of written work that reflects a deep understanding of a topic, showing that you can structure a discussion of it in a way that is coherent and clear. So, while I can’t comment on any specific situation, my view is that the benefits of doing a project generally outweigh the risks.

您可能得到的另一个机会是出国留学一个学期或一年。通常您不能随便选择去任何地方（没有“我要去巴黎！”这样的说法），因为您在大学学习的课程与您在国外学习的课程必须具有可比性。但您的机构可能与世界各地的许多大学有联系，您可能想了解一下有哪些大学可供选择。如果您正在学习一门语言或打算学习一门语言，这一点尤其重要。但您也可能会发现与英国或其他英语国家的大学有联系。无论如何，出国一段时间将为您提供不同的教育体系的经验，并让您结识来自不同文化背景的学生和教授。同样，这具有明显的好处，未来的雇主会认可，而且本身就很有趣，可能会提高您的整体自信心。

Another opportunity you might get is to go and spend a semester or a year studying abroad. Usually you can’t choose to go just anywhere (there’s no “I’ll take Paris, please!”) because there has to be comparability between courses you would have taken at your college and courses you will take while you are away. But your institution might have links with a number of universities around the world, and you might want to look into what is available. This is especially true if you are studying a language or if you intend to do so. But you might also find that there are links with universities in the UK or in other English-speaking countries. In any case, going abroad for a period of time will provide you with experience of a different educational system, and will allow you to get to know both students and professors who come from a different cultural background. Again, this has obvious benefits that will be recognizable to future employers, as well as being enjoyable for its own sake and likely to improve your general level of self-confidence.

最后，你可能有机会实习。这不太学术：它通常是指在公司担任（带薪）实习机会可以是在某种企业担任助理（无薪或无偿）工作。许多大公司和其他组织都提供这样的实习机会，学生通常在暑假期间接受实习。通常，你的就业服务或部门会为你提供有关实习申请和如何找到空缺职位的一般信息，然后你会主动申请并参加面试，就像申请长期职位一样。如果你正在攻读一个辅修或双学位，并且该学位明显包含商业、金融或经济学内容，那么你所在的课程中的每个人都可能试图获得实习机会。如果不是，那么可能不是每个人都这样做，但你仍然有机会。我建议你研究一下这种可能性，至少如果你想从事金融或商业（广义上）的职业的话。实习可以让你学到很多关于你选择的行业的知识；从那些在该行业工作的人那里获取知识，并培养那种很难通过理论课程获得的商业敏锐度。根据我的经验，所有实习过的学生都会更好地了解在特定行业工作是什么样的，其中一些学生会因此获得工作机会。从实际情况来看，这并非易事——当你知道自己已经找到一份好工作时，你就可以更好地专注于学业的最后一年。

Finally, you might have the opportunity to do an internship. This is not so academic: it typically refers to a period of time spent working as a (paid or unpaid) assistant in a business of some kind. Lots of major companies and other organizations offer such internships, and students often take them up during a summer vacation. Typically, your careers service or department would be able to provide you with general information on internship applications and on how to find vacancies, and then you would take the initiative to apply and go for interviews, just as if you were applying for a longer-term position. If you are studying for a minor or double major that has an obvious business or finance or economics component, it might be that everyone on your program tries to get an internship. If not, it probably won’t be the case that everyone does it, but you might still have the opportunity. I would suggest looking into the possibility, at least if you want to go into a career in finance or in business (interpreted broadly). An internship can allow you to learn a great deal about your chosen industry; to pick the brains of those who work in it and to develop the sort of business acumen that it’s difficult to get by sitting in theoretical courses. In my experience, all students who work as interns get an improved understanding of what it’s like to work in that particular sector, and some of them get job offers out of it. That’s not a trivial thing when you consider the practicalities—you can focus much better on the final year of your studies when you know you’re already set up with a good job.

在所有这些项目和实习情况下，你与他人的常规关系模式将会发生动摇。你将不再是众多学生中的一个；相反，你将与特定的人密切互动，其中许多人你原本不会认识。有些学生欢迎这种生活中的多样性和变化，而另一些学生则不然，我并不是说每个人都会同样受益。但你可能想尽早了解提供的内容，特别是因为有些课程要求你保持一定的平均成绩才能参加。与本书中提出的其他问题一样，我只是建议你充分了解并深思熟虑地做出决定。

In all of these project and internship situations, your usual pattern of relationships with other people will be shaken up.
