You will not be just one student among many; instead you will interact closely with particular people, many of whom you would not otherwise have met. Some students welcome this type of variety and change in life, while others don’t, and I’m not saying that everyone would benefit equally. But you might want to find out early on what is on offer, especially as some programs require you to maintain a certain average grade if you want to take part. As with other issues raised in this book, I’d just advise you to be well-informed and to make your decisions thoughtfully.

10.8 与其他学生一起学习

10.8 Studying with other students

不过现在，回到本科学习的日常工作，特别是与其他学生一起学习。其他学生很多，他们都至少相当聪明，而且很多人都很友善。这使得它们是学习新数学时可以借鉴的极好的资源，这样可以使学习变得更加有趣。

For now, though, back to the usual business of undergraduate study, and in particular to studying with other students. Other students are plentiful, they are all at least reasonably clever, and lots of them are nice. This makes them an excellent resource to draw on when learning new mathematics, and doing so can make learning more enjoyable.

根据你之前的经验，你可能已经习惯了与其他学生一起工作。我经常看到学生们坐在一起，笔记散落在各处，分享想法，讨论如何最好地做事。我不确定这些小组一开始是如何找到彼此的，但在讲座和背诵中与人交谈肯定会为你提供一种让学习小组开始运作的方法。当然，一旦开始，你就应该考虑它的效果如何。一方面，达成聚在一起做某事的协议可以确保你真正做到，有点像去健身房时有一个伙伴。另一方面，如果你们一群人聚在一起是为了研究数学，但实际上你们只是分散彼此的注意力，这可能没什么用。也许值得考虑一个中间立场，你们都同意提前看一些东西，然后聚在一起讨论你们遇到的问题的部分。你还应该留意你从任何特定的讨论中得到了什么。如果你的朋友在某一门课程上比你更优秀，我不会太担心；他们会通过解释自己的想法来进一步提高理解力。但如果你插不上话，或者最终只是抄录别人说的话而不理解，我就会担心。在这种情况下，你可能对自己没有任何长期好处。

Depending on your previous experience, you might already be accustomed to working with other students. I often see students sitting down together with notes spread out everywhere, sharing ideas and discussing how best to do things. I’m not sure how the groups find each other in the first place, but talking to people in lectures and recitations will certainly provide you with a way to get a study group off the ground. Once it is off the ground, of course, you should think about how well it’s working. On the one hand, having an agreement to get together and work on something can make sure you actually do it, a bit like having a buddy for going to the gym. On the other hand, if a bunch of you get together with the aim of working on mathematics, but actually you just distract each other, that’s probably not very useful. It might be worth considering a middle ground in which you all agree to look at something in advance and then get together to discuss parts you were stuck with. You should also keep an eye on what you are getting out of any particular discussion. I wouldn’t worry too much if your friend is better at a particular course than you; they’ll improve their understanding further by explaining their thinking. But I would worry if you can’t get a word in edgeways, or if you end up just copying down what someone has said without understanding it. In that case, you’re probably not doing yourself any long-term favors.

或者，你可能不喜欢与他人合作。你可能会发现当你独自一人时，你可以更好地集中注意力，或者你可能只是认为数学是一项孤独的追求。这也很好，在大多数情况下，没有人会强迫你与其他学生一起工作（至少在讲座和独立学习中——一些老师可能希望你在背诵期间与他人合作）。但是，如果我是你，我会考虑取得适当的平衡，并确保你不会因为认为天才数学家就是这样做的而隐居工作。天才数学家有时确实独自工作，但他们有时也在研究小组中工作，无论哪种方式，他们肯定会通过参加会议和研讨会并辩论证明是否有效或想法是否真的会推广到新类型的对象来与更广泛的数学家网络互动。无论你是否想成为一名数学家，练习参加数学讨论和辩论都是一个好主意。

Alternatively, you might not like the idea of working with others. You might find that you can concentrate better when you’re on your own, or you might just think of mathematics as a solitary pursuit. This is also fine, and in most cases no-one is going to force you to work with other students (at least in lectures and independent study—some instructors might expect you to work with others during recitations). If I were you, though, I would think about getting the right balance, and make sure you’re not working in seclusion just because you think that’s how genius mathematicians do it. Genius mathematicians do sometimes work alone, but they also sometimes work in research groups, and either way they certainly engage with wider networks of mathematicians by going to conferences and seminars and debating whether a proof is valid or whether an idea will really generalize to a new type of object. Whether or not you want to be a mathematician yourself, it’s a good idea to practice taking part in mathematical discussions and debates.

另外，请记住，与其他学生一起学习可以校准你对自己学习效果的感知。如果你独自学习，你可能会对自己与其他学生的理解程度产生不太准确的感知。这可能没问题，但如果你觉得自己做得不好，那么孤立很容易加剧这种情况（见第 13 章）。因此，如果你发现自己独自学习很吃力，可以考虑至少花一些时间与他人一起学习。你可能会发现你的表现比你想象的要好。

Also, bear in mind that working with other students can calibrate your sense of how well you are doing. If you study in isolation, you might end up with a rather inaccurate sense of how your understanding compares with that of other students. That might be fine but, if you feel you’re not doing very well, isolation can easily exacerbate this (see Chapter 13). So, if you find yourself struggling on your own, consider spending at least some of your study time with others. You will probably find that you are doing better than you think.

听起来好像我在说学生应该多一起学习，但我不确定我是否真的会走那么远。当我还是一名本科生时，我花了很多时间独自学习，显然这对我很好。但事后看来，我这样做至少部分是因为这是我习惯的——在英国的高中，我是唯一一个选修高等数学的人，所以没有其他学生可以和我交谈，我从来没有养成这个习惯。后来在我的学位课程中，我确实与其他人一起学习了更多。我发现这样做提高了我的自信心，我真的很喜欢，真希望我以前这样做过。当然，如果你是一名兼职学生，或者是一名成熟的学生，或者如果你住在家里而不是校园里，你可能会发现出于纯粹的实际原因，与其他学生聚在一起会更困难。但大多数人在一周内至少有一些课间休息时间，你可以在其中一个课间进行定期学习。

It probably sounds like I’m saying that students should work together a lot, but I’m not sure I’d actually go that far. When I was an undergraduate, I spent a lot of time studying alone, and obviously that turned out well for me. But, with hindsight, I worked that way at least partly because it was what I was used to—at high school in the UK I was the only person taking something called Further Mathematics, so there weren’t really other students I could talk to, and I never got into the habit. Later in my degree program, I did study more with others. I found that doing so improved my confidence, and that I really enjoyed it and wished I had done it before. Of course, if you are a part-time student, or a mature student, or if you live at home instead of on campus, you might find it more difficult to get together with other students for purely practical reasons. But most people have at least some breaks between lectures during the week, and you could have a regular study session in one of those.

10.9 其他支持

10.9 Support with everything else

当你读本科时，你不仅仅是一名数学专业的学生，​​你还会成为一个拥有完整人生的完整人。希望你的人生会很精彩，你会在对数学的全面理解、良好的平均成绩和你想从事的有趣职业方面取得进步。但四年是一段很长的时间，有时事情会因为超出你控制范围的原因而出错。当你进入大学时，你会获得有关支持服务的信息，但我将介绍一下通常提供的服务。

While you’re an undergraduate, you won’t just be a mathematics major, you’ll be a whole person with a whole life. Hopefully that life will be excellent, and you’ll make progress toward a fulfilling understanding of mathematics, a good grade point average, and an interesting career in whatever you want to pursue. But four years is a long time, and occasionally things do go awry for reasons that are beyond your control. You will get information about support services when you arrive at college, but I’ll say a bit about those that are typically provided.

我先从就业服务开始。根据我的经验，大学就业服务人员都是见多识广、乐于助人的人，他们渴望帮助学生找到有趣、高薪的工作。他们最大的问题是是学生没有时间去看，或者至少他们要比理想时间晚得多。我能理解为什么会发生这种情况——至少对于数学专业的学生来说，总有一套问题需要解决，或者要准备一场考试，或者要去听另一堂课，这些事情似乎总是比思考未来更紧迫。此外，未来通常没有很好的规划，因此有点可怕，人们有时倾向于避免考虑它。

I’ll start with careers services. College careers services are, in my experience, staffed by well-informed and helpful people who are just dying to help students get into interesting and well-paid jobs. Their biggest problem is that students don’t get around to going to see them, or at least they don’t get around to it until considerably later than would have been ideal. I can see why this happens—for mathematics majors at least, there is always a problem set to work on or a test to prepare for or another lecture to go to, and these things always seem more urgent than thinking about the future. Also, the future is usually not well mapped-out and is thus a bit scary, and people are sometimes inclined to avoid thinking about it.

但即使你不知道自己想要做什么（这在开始攻读学位课程的人中很常见），有效利用职业服务也并不难。如果你处于这种情况，我建议你尽早去职业服务处，告诉服务台后面的人你打算主修数学，说你不知道自己长期想做什么，并询问他们可以给你什么文献来帮助你更好地了解可能适合你的职业。他们会给你提供精美的、杂志般的精美小册子，介绍各种不同行业的工作，你可以在闲暇时仔细阅读。当你这样做了，并且你对什么可能感兴趣有了更好的了解，你可以回去预约以获得更详细的建议。另一方面，如果你已经对自己想尝试什么有了一些想法，你可以尽早预约并寻求建议，比如如何获得暑期实习。如果你甚至无法面对这些，至少要留意职业服务机构发来的电子邮件，其中会告诉你雇主介绍会和职业活动，很多雇主会派出（通常是年轻的）员工来告诉学生他们的工作是什么样的。参加这类活动，你就会知道那里的情况。

But it’s really not hard to make effective use of a careers service, even if you haven’t a clue what you want to do with your life (which is very common in people starting a degree program). If you are in that situation, I’d suggest that you go to the careers service at the earliest opportunity, tell someone behind a help desk that you intend to major in mathematics, say that you don’t know what you want to do in the long term, and ask what literature they can give you to help you be better informed about careers that might be open to you. They will load you up with nice, magazine-like glossy brochures about jobs in a variety of different sectors, which you can peruse at your leisure. When you’ve done that and you’ve got a better sense of what might interest you, you can go back and make an appointment to get more detailed advice. If, on the other hand, you already have some idea of what you’d like to try, you can make an appointment early on and ask for advice on how to, say, get a summer internship. If you can’t even face any of that, at least look out for emails from the careers service telling you about employer presentations and about careers events in which lots of employers send along (usually young) staff to tell students what their jobs are like. Go to this kind of thing and you’ll get a sense of what’s out there.

再次强调，帮助是存在的，但你必须积极主动地去寻求帮助。不必太积极主动——按照我刚才的建议去做并不需要付出太多努力。但不要等着别人告诉你去做。他们可能会——如果你碰巧遇到像我这样的顾问，你可能会有人经常唠叨你。但很多数学教师并不认为这是他们工作的一部分。他们会认为你有足够的责任心来处理好这件事。有些学生会这样做，但有些学生不会，那些不会这样做的学生最终会在备战期末考试的同时试图找到工作。如果你早点收集一些信息，你就可以避免陷入这种境地。

Again, help is there but you have to be active in seeking it out. Not very active—it’s not much effort to do what I just suggested. But don’t wait for someone to tell you to do it. They might—if you happen to meet an adviser like me, you might have someone nagging you about it reasonably regularly. But a lot of mathematics faculty don’t consider this part of their job. They’ll assume that you’re responsible enough to take care of it for yourself. Some students do, but others don’t, and those who don’t end up trying to find out about jobs while studying for their final exams. If you do some information-gathering early on, you can avoid getting into this position.

除了就业服务，你还会发现你的大学还提供其他实用服务。显然会有图书馆。可能会有某种打印中心，供学生装订大型项目报告。会有一个中央学生管理办公室，你可以去那里办理注册和缴费等事务。可能会有一个学生就业中心，帮助那些想在当地找兼职工作的人。会有一个住宿办公室，帮助学生安排校内或校外住宿。可能会有一个计算机支持中心，可能还会有一个医疗中心——如果你想使用它，一定要弄清楚如何注册。可能会有一个一般的实用咨询服务，如果你与房东或电力公司或其他任何人发生任何问题，可以去那里寻求帮助。还会有一个学术咨询服务，帮助学生对他们的学位课程做出正确的决定。最后，你的部门本身可能有一个主办公室，你可以去那里提交课程作业或获得针对你专业的具体建议。

In addition to a careers service, you will also find that your university has support for other practical things. Obviously there will be a library. There might be some kind of printing centre, used by students for binding big project reports. There will be a central student administration office, where you might go to do things like register and pay fees. There might be a student job center to help those who want to get part-time jobs in the local area. There will be an accommodation office, which will help students to arrange on- or off-campus housing. There might be a computer support center, and there will probably be a medical center—make sure you find out how to register if you want to use it. There might be a general practical advice service, where you can go for assistance if you run into any problems with your landlord or the electricity company or whoever. There will also be an academic advice service to help students make good decisions about their degree programs. Finally, your department itself will probably have a main office, where you might go to hand in coursework assignments or to get advice specific to your major.

还会有某种残疾和其他需求服务。如果你患有诵读困难症或有运动或感官障碍或类似问题，请与他们联系，因为他们将能够为你提供有效学习所需的任何支持。如果你认为自己可能患有这种疾病但从未被诊断出来，他们可能会为你进行适当的测试。如果你处于这种情况，我也会以教授的身份向你提出请求。这样的服务会保密学生的需求，这意味着如果我的某个讲座中有某人需要什么，我不会自动被告知。例如，有时，一位笔记记录员会为患有诵读困难症或视力障碍的学生出现，但我不知道这个学生是谁。有时我可以做一些简单的事情来帮助这个人——用特定颜色书写，或提供一套更大尺寸的笔记。但这些信息不会很快传达给我。所以，如果你处于这种情况，并且教授可以做一些简单的事情，请问他们是否愿意这样做。如果它是可行的（当然对其他人也是公平的），他们可能会立即答应，你可能会发现这比仅通过官方渠道可以更快地让你得到你需要的东西。

There also will be some sort of disabilities and additional needs service. If you are dyslexic or have a movement or sensory impairment or something like that, get in touch with them, because they’ll be able to get you any support you need to study effectively. If you think you might have such a condition but you’ve never had it diagnosed, they can probably get you properly tested. If you are in such a situation, I would also make a plea with you as a professor. Services like this keep their students’ needs confidential, which means that I don’t automatically get told if there is someone in one of my lectures who needs something. Sometimes, for instance, a note-taker shows up for a student who is dyslexic or who has a visual impairment, but I have no idea who the student is. Sometimes I could do something simple to help this person—write in a particular color, or provide a larger-sized set of notes. But that information won’t reach me very quickly. So, if you are in such a position, and there is something simple a professor could do, ask them if they’d be willing to do it. If it is practical (and fair to everyone else, of course), they will probably say yes straight away, and you might find this gets you what you need more quickly than going only through official channels.

希望这些实用服务能满足你学生时代的所有需求。但也有针对情感和心理的服务支持。有时人们需要这些服务的原因显然很严重，例如身患重病、家庭成员去世、意外怀孕、成瘾问题、虐待关系、抑郁或其他某种心理健康问题。幸运的是，这种情况很少见，但确实时有发生。有时人们需要这些服务的原因不那么明显，但仍然会影响他们的学习能力。也许他们与长期的男朋友或女朋友分手，或者他们意识到自己是同性恋，或者他们的父母决定离婚，或者他们与一群酗酒的人混在一起，或者他们真的担心学位不及格，或者他们只是比预想的更想家。在任何这些情况下，获得专家支持可能真的很有用。

Hopefully these practical services will be all you need during your time as a student. But there are services around for emotional and psychological support too. Sometimes people need these services for obviously serious reasons such as experiencing a severe illness, or a death in the family, or an unplanned pregnancy, or an addiction problem, or an abusive relationship, or depression, or another mental health issue of some kind. Such things, mercifully, are rare, but they do occur from time to time. Sometimes people need the services for reasons that are less obviously serious but that can nonetheless interfere with their ability to study. Perhaps they break up with a long-term boyfriend or girlfriend, or they realize they are gay, or their parents decide to get divorced, or they get in with a crowd that’s drinking too much, or they are genuinely worried about failing their degree, or they are just much more homesick than they were anticipating. In any of these cases, getting expert support might be really useful.

支持服务应该很容易获得。如果你住在校园里，你会有一名住宿助理 (RA)，如果你有什么烦恼，他应该是你第一个可以求助的人。无论你是否住在校园里，你都可以使用大学咨询服务。所有这些服务的信息将在您到达时提供，并且很可能可以从您访问您所在机构的网站时首先打开的页面访问。

Support services should be easy for you to access. If you live on campus, you will have a resident assistant (RA), who should be a good first port of call if something is bothering you. Whether you live on campus or not, you will have access to a college counseling service. Information about all of these services will be provided when you arrive and will likely be accessible from the page that first opens when you access your institution’s website.

我想说的是，如果你确实有这样的问题，请去服务机构寻求帮助。我理解人们喜欢自己解决问题，但你不必感到羞愧，也不必独自挣扎。大学非常习惯处理这样的问题，没有人会对你说的话感到惊讶。如果你是遇到问题的人的朋友，这一切也适用。当你的朋友过得不好时，你很容易觉得自己没有权利难过，显然你会想专注于支持他们。但有时为了做到这一点，你需要得到一些建议或支持自己。

What I would say is that if you do have a problem like any of these, please go to one of the services to get help. I appreciate that people like to solve their own problems, but you do not have to feel ashamed, or to struggle on by yourself. Colleges are very accustomed to dealing with such issues, and no-one will be surprised by what you are saying. This all applies, also, if you are a friend to someone who experiences a problem. It’s easy to feel that you have no right to be upset when your friend is the one having a bad time, and obviously you’ll want to focus on supporting them. But sometimes in order to do that you need to get a bit of advice or support yourself.

这一切听起来有点令人沮丧，所以最后我想说，绝大多数学生在大学里过得很愉快，从来没有遇到过这些问题，甚至没有遇到过这些问题的人。他们结交了很多新朋友，与教授和其他教师保持着良好的关系。所以你不应该提前担心任何事情。只要记住，如果你在某个时候遇到问题，我们会提供支持。

This all sounds a bit depressing, so I want to end by saying that the vast majority of students have a great time at college and never have any of these problems or even meet anyone who has. They make many new friends and they enjoy positive relationships with their professors and other instructors. So you shouldn’t worry about anything in advance. Just remember that if you do have a problem at some point, support will be available.

概括

SUMMARY

• 可以在讲座、朗诵会以及有时（数学）学习中心联系到教授和讲师；学生应该主动寻求帮助。

• Professors and instructors can be accessed in lectures, recitations, and sometimes (mathematics) learning centers; students are expected to take the initiative in seeking help.

• 无论何时提问，最好随身携带所有相关材料，并明确说明自己想要了解的内容。如果合适，请列一个清单，并确保材料井然有序。

• Whenever you ask questions, it helps to have all the relevant materials with you and to be clear about what you want to know. Take a list if appropriate, and make sure your materials are well-organized.

• 考虑一下什么时候是获得问题答案最实际的时间，如果您发送电子邮件，请保持礼貌并写得好。

• Think about when would be the most practical time to get your questions answered and, if you send an email, be polite and write well.

• 了解你的大学通过项目和实习提供哪些支持。这些可以帮助你建立自信，获得雇主看重的各种技能，并与资深人士建立更多的个人关系。

• Find out what your college supports by way of projects and internships. These can help you to develop your confidence, to gain different skills that are valued by employers, and to have more individual relationships with senior people.

• 考虑与其他学生合作的策略。这样做可以让学习变得更有趣，并可以提高每个人谈论数学的技能，但要确保你不会分心。

• Consider your strategy for working with other students. Doing so can make learning more enjoyable and can improve everyone’s skills in talking about mathematics, but make sure that you are not just getting distracted.

• 大学提供多种支持服务。每个人都应该尽早去就业服务处。希望您不需要经常使用其他服务，但熟悉它们的运作方式可能还是值得的。

• Colleges have many support services. Everyone should go to the careers service early. Hopefully you won’t need to use the other services very much, but it is probably worth familiarizing yourself with how they work.

进一步阅读

FURTHER READING

有关与他人互动和处理大学生活实际方面的更多信息，请尝试：

For more on interacting with others and managing the practical aspects of college life, try:

• Newport, C. (2007)。《如何成为一名全优生：大学生在学习时间较少的情况下取得高分的非常规策略》。纽约：Three Rivers Press。

• Newport, C. (2007). How to Become a Straight-A Student: The Unconventional Strategies Real College Students Use to Score High While Studying Less. New York: Three Rivers Press.

有关数学专业职业选择的更多信息，请尝试：

For more on career options for mathematics majors, try:

• http://www.maa.org/careers/

• http://www.maa.org/careers/

• http://www.ams.org/careers/

• http://www.ams.org/careers/

• http://www.siam.org/careers/thinking.php

• http://www.siam.org/careers/thinking.php

为了提高你的书面英语水平，请尝试：

To improve your written English, try:

• Seely, J. (2004)。牛津 A-Z 语法和标点符号。牛津：牛津大学出版社。

• Seely, J. (2004). Oxford A–Z of Grammar & Punctuation. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

• Strunk Jr., W. & White, EB (1999). 《风格的要素》（第 4 版）。朗文出版社。

• Strunk Jr., W. & White, E. B. (1999). The Elements of Style (4th Edition). Longman.

• Trask, RL (1997).企鹅标点符号指南。伦敦：企鹅出版社。

• Trask, R. L. (1997). The Penguin Guide to Punctuation. London: Penguin.

• Trask, RL (2002)。《小心失言：企鹅英语常见错误指南》。伦敦：企鹅图书有限公司。

• Trask, R. L. (2002). Mind the Gaffe: The Penguin Guide to Common Errors in English. London: Penguin Books Ltd.

如果您正在编写更大的数学项目，请尝试：

If you are writing a larger mathematical project, try:

• Higham, NJ (1998).数学科学写作手册。费城：工业与应用数学学会。

• Higham, N. J. (1998). Handbook of Writing for the Mathematical Sciences. Philadelphia: Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics.

第 11 章

时间管理

CHAPTER 11

Time Management

本章将介绍如何安排学习时间，以便您能够跟上课程进度，避免因落后而产生的压力。它提供了实用的建议，帮助您制定切实可行的计划，并考虑到社交活动，让您可以享受这些活动，而不会觉得您应该学习。

This chapter is about how to organize your study time so that you can keep up with your courses and avoid the stress associated with falling behind. It offers practical suggestions for making realistic plans that you can actually stick to, and for factoring in social activities so that you can enjoy these without feeling that you should be studying.

11.1 为什么好学生要读本章？

11.1 Why would a good student read this chapter?

假设你已经是个好学生了，所以你可能会怀疑是否有人可以教你时间管理方面的知识。在这种情况下，你可能想知道，每年，当受指导者回来时，我都会问他们是否会做些不同的事情。他们每个人都说：“是的，我会更好地跟上学习进度。”这值得称赞，但很少有人能告诉我他们将做出哪些实际改变。通常，那些确实有所进步的人只能在事后谈论这些变化，即使这样，他们有时也有些含糊其辞。他们会说：“我开始每周一下午在图书馆和汉娜一起工作，这似乎有帮助。”更慎重一点会更好，在本章中，我提出了很多关于如何控制时间的建议，无论是在计划整个学期时，还是在计划一周时。所有这些建议都可以从你大学生活的第一天开始实施，也可以从你意识到自己没有完美地处理增加的自由和更艰巨的工作的那一天开始实施。（如果你正在计划复习，你可能还想阅读第 7 章；如果您因为已经落后而处于恐慌状态，请从第 12 章开始，然后再回到这一章。）

Presumably you are a good student already, so you might doubt that anyone has anything to teach you on the subject of time management. In that case, you might like to know that every year, when advisees come back, I ask them whether they will do anything differently. Every one of them says, “Yes, I will do a better job of keeping up with the work.” This is laudable but it is a rare person who can tell me what practical changes they are going to make. Usually people who do improve can only talk about the changes afterwards, and even then they are sometimes a bit vague. They say things like, “I started working with Hannah every Monday afternoon in the library, and that seemed to help.” Being more deliberate would be better, and in this chapter I make lots of suggestions about how to take control of your time, both when planning for a whole semester and when planning for a single week. All of these suggestions can be implemented from day one of your college life, or from whatever day it is when you realize that you’re not doing a perfect job of handling the increased freedom and harder work. (If you are planning for revision, you might also want to read Chapter 7; if you are in a state of panic because you are already far behind, start with Chapter 12 then come back to this one.)

不过，要记住的一点是，如果你是一个普通人，你将无法完全遵循这个建议。你可能会被其他事情分散注意力，或者你可能会过度努力而精疲力竭，或者你可能会觉得这一切都有点吓人。但有一个目标是有用的，即使你只采纳了一些实用的建议，你也会比你从来没有想过要好。当然，如果你知道轨道在哪里，那么保持正轨或回到正轨会更容易。不过，在我们开始讨论建议之前，我将先简短地提醒你目标是什么，以及你要避免什么。

One thing to bear in mind, though, is that if you are a normal human being, you will fail to fully follow this advice. You might get distracted by other things, or you might over-shoot and wear yourself out, or you might just find it all a bit intimidating. But it is useful to have something to aim for, and even if you only take up a couple of practical tips, you’ll be better off than if you’d never thought about it at all. Certainly it is easier to stay on track, or to get back on track, if you have some idea of where the track is. Before we get into the advice, though, I’ll start with a short cautionary section on what you’re aiming for and what you’re aiming to avoid.

11.2 目标和应避免的事情

11.2 Aims and things to avoid

首先，重要的是要了解本科数学课程的某个特定成就水平。你可能已经知道这一点，但考试成绩与成绩的对应方式存在一些差异：要获得 A 级，你可能需要在一门课程中取得 90% 的成绩，但在另一门课程中只需取得 70% 的成绩。70% 可能看起来很低，但它可以让教授奖励那些能够可靠地完成许多标准任务的学生，同时也为那些理解得足够好、能够在新考试问题中创造性地运用知识的学生留出适当的空间。

First, it’s important to have a sense of what qualifies as a particular level of achievement in undergraduate mathematics. You might know this already, but there is some variability in the way that exam scores correspond to grades: to get an A you might need 90% in one course but only 70% in another. That 70% might seem pretty low, but it allows professors to reward students who can reliably do a lot of standard things, while leaving room to give proper credit to those who understand well enough to use their knowledge creatively in novel exam problems.

其次，了解重修本科课程的含义很重要。如果你的成绩不好，大多数大学都会让你重修一门课程，而且这样做可能没有明显的惩罚。但选择这种方式可能会让你的生活变得困难，并打乱你向专业迈进的步伐。你的生活可能会变得困难，因为数学是非常分层的：高级课程将依赖于早些年的材料。如果你学习不好——如果你最终只知道一半的数学内容——你可能仍然会通过这些早期的课程，但你在以后几年取得好成绩的机会将大大降低。你的专业进展可能会受到先决条件结构的干扰：如果你选择重修一门课程，或者如果你不及格并被迫重修，那么保持你的专业进度可能意味着要参加暑期课程，而你宁愿赚钱或在山上的夏令营工作或四处旅行欧洲。即使先修课程规则很宽松，一门课程学不好也会对其他课程产生连锁反应。如果你在微积分 2 上表现不佳，你的大学可能会让你在学习微积分 3 的同时重修它。但微积分 3 可能严重依赖微积分 2 的材料，而微积分 3 教授会假设你了解这些材料；如果你不了解，同时学习这些课程可能会非常困难。

Second, it’s important to understand the implications of retaking undergraduate courses. Most colleges will let you take a course again if you do not get a good grade, and there might be no obvious penalty for doing so. But taking up this option might nevertheless make your life difficult and disrupt your progress toward your major. Your life might become difficult because mathematics is very hierarchical: upper-level courses will rely on material from earlier years. If you don’t study well—if you end up knowing only half of the mathematical content—you might still pass these early courses but your chances of doing well in later years will be substantially undermined. Progress toward your major might be disrupted by prerequisite structures: if you choose to retake a course, or if you fail one and are forced to retake it, then keeping on track for your major might mean taking a summer course when you would rather be earning money or working at a summer camp in the mountains or traveling around Europe. Even when prerequisite rules are lenient, failing to study well in one course can have knock-on effects in others. If you do poorly in Calculus 2, your college might let you retake it at the same time as you take Calculus 3. But Calculus 3 will probably rely heavily on material from Calculus 2, and the Calculus 3 professor will assume that you know this material; if you don’t, doing the courses simultaneously might be very difficult.

想要尽早取得好成绩的另一个实际原因是，有趣的机会往往取决于此。例如，获得或保留奖学金或荣誉课程名额可能需要一定的 GPA。如果这不关你的事，其他事情可能会：如果你申请暑期实习，你的潜在雇主会看你迄今为止的表现如何——学术上，这是他们唯一要看的。所以，从各方面来看，第一次就取得好成绩更好、更简单。

A further, practical reason for wanting to do well early on is that interesting opportunities often depend on it. A certain GPA might be required for getting or keeping a scholarship or a place on an honors program, for instance. If that doesn’t concern you, other things might: if you apply for a summer internship, your potential employers will look at how well you have done so far—academically, that’s the only thing they have to go on. So, all things considered, it is better and simpler to do well the first time around.

我之所以这么说，是因为在很多大学，你最终的成绩单只会记录你每门课程的最佳成绩。如果你的大学是这样的，那么我保证，在你学习的某个阶段，某个白痴会对你说：“啊，拜托，你可以稍后重修这门课程/提高你的 GPA——你不需要那么努力！” 这个人没有掌握行为会产生后果的基本原则。你不必告诉他们他们是白痴，但你也不必让他们影响你的行为。

The reason I’m saying this is that, at many colleges, your eventual transcript will record only your best score for each course. If your college is like this then I guarantee that at some point in your studies, some idiot will say to you, “Ah, come on, you can retake the course/get your GPA up later—you don’t need to work so hard!” This person has failed to grasp the basic principle that actions have consequences. You don’t have to tell them that they’re an idiot, but you don’t have to let them influence your behavior either.

11.3 学期规划

11.3 Planning for a semester

考虑到所有这些，并假设您想在不付出大量努力的情况下取得好成绩，那么做好充分的规划对您大有裨益。我们将从考虑大规模规划开始，然后逐步深入到细节。

With all of that in mind, and assuming that you want to do well without making silly amounts of effort, you can do yourself a big favor by doing adequate planning. We’ll start by considering large-scale planning and work our way down to the detail.

在规划一个学期时，你需要记住，你将有一系列的测试和作业，安排在不同的时间。如果你习惯于在学习新材料、复习新材料和考试时间之间划出明确的界限，这可能是一种新的体验。你还会发现，没有太多关于你应该做哪些工作的提醒何时。你的教授会期望你消化你所获得的有关考试和作业的信息，并自己想办法将它们全部安排好。你可能对此很满意，但你可能会发现你的父母和高中老师比你想象的更支持你的时间管理。无论哪种方式，要做的第一件事就是了解什么时候发生了什么，这样你就可以明智地选择何时做什么。这并不难做到，如果你在新学期开始时这样做，你会得到最大的好处。以下是我对如何进行的建议。

In planning for a semester, you need to bear in mind that you will have an array of tests and assignments, scheduled at various different times. This might be a new experience if you are accustomed to having a clean cut-off between times at which you learn new material, times at which you revise it, and times at which you are tested. You will also find that there are not many reminders about which work you are supposed to do when. Your professors will expect you to digest the information you are given about tests and assignments, and to work out for yourself how to fit it all in. You might be fine with this, but you might find that your parents and high school teachers supported your time management more than you thought. Either way, the first thing to do is to get a grip on what is happening when, so that you can make sensible choices about when to work on what. This is not hard to do, and you’ll get maximum benefit if you do it at the beginning of a new semester. Here is my suggestion for how to proceed.

首先要做的是购买或制作一个日历式的挂历。这可能很容易，因为大学和学生组织经常会发放这种东西。但对于我们来说，批量生产的挂历并不理想，因为它们往往涵盖一整年，而且侧面有很多关于活动和特价的信息，因此会让人分心。对于我自己的计划，我更喜欢制作一个格式简单的挂历。

The first thing to do is to acquire or make a calendar-like wall planner. This might be easy, because such things are often given out by colleges and student organizations. For our purposes, though, mass-produced ones are not ideal because they tend to cover a whole year and have lots of colorful and thus distracting information around the side about events and special offers. For my own planning, I prefer to make one with a simple format.

接下来要做的是获取有关考试时间和作业截止日期的所有信息。如果信息分散在每门课程的文档中，这可能需要一段时间，但这是值得的。

The next thing to do is to get hold of all the information about when your tests are happening and when your assignments are due. This might take a while if the information is spread across documentation for each individual course, but it is worth the time.

当你收集了这些信息后，你会发现有些测试安排在特定日期的特定时间。这些很容易添加到计划表中。但是，你也会发现其他事情定义得不那么明确。你可能必须进行在线测试，你可以在一周内的任何时间登录并进行测试。有几种方法可以做到这一点。一种方法是在测试可用的第一天将其写在计划表中。这样做的好处是你可以尽早专注于它并摆脱它。当其他人担心它几天时，你也会感到沾沾自喜。另一种方法是将其放在倒数第二天的计划表中。这将为你提供更多的准备时间，并且如果较早的日子与另一场考试发生冲突，也可能更好。你绝对不能做的一件事是将其放在最后一天。在线测试系统已经存在了一段时间，它们非常强大，但仍然会出现问题（有时甚至整个大学的计算机网络都会瘫痪）。如果你拖到最后一分钟，你可能会给自己带来各种压力。如果发生不好的事情，即使不是你的错，你也必须四处奔波，试图让教授对你宽容一些。

When you have assembled this information, you will find that some tests are scheduled at particular times on particular days. These are easy to add to the planner. You will also find, however, that other things are less well defined. It might be that you have to do an online test, and you can log on and do it at any time during, say, a week. There are several approaches to this. One would be to write it on your planner on the first day it is available. This has the advantage that you’ll focus on it early and get it out of the way. You will also feel smug when other people are worrying about it for several more days. Another approach would be to put it on the planner for the penultimate available day. This will give you more preparation time, and might also be better if, say, the earlier days clash with another test. The one thing you absolutely must not do is put it on the last available day. Online testing systems have been around for a while now, and they’re pretty robust, but things still do go wrong (occasionally whole college computer networks go down, even). If you leave it until the last minute you will risk causing yourself all sorts of stress. If something bad happens, even if it is not your fault, you will have to chase around trying to get your professor to be lenient with you.

还需要考虑将其他作业放在计划表的什么位置。这些作业都会有截止日期，我建议您至少假装截止日期是前一天。每年至少有一次，有人很晚才赶到我的课堂上，详细讲述打印机无法使用、学分用完、不得不去校园另一端再回来的故事，截止日期是 4 点，而办公室已经关门了……您明白了。这个人今天过得很糟糕，而且错过了其他课程，现在其他事情都落后了。如果您给自己一天空闲时间，虽然不能保证不会出现问题，但您可以冷静地处理它们。

It is also worth considering where on your planner to put other assignments. These will come with a deadline and again, at a bare minimum, I recommend that you pretend the deadline is the previous day. At least once a year someone comes rushing into one of my classes very late, telling a long and detailed story about how the printer didn’t work, and then they’d run out of credits, and then they had to go to the other end of campus and all the way back again, and the deadline was 4 o’clock, and then the office was closed.… You get the idea. This person has had a horrible day and, moreover, they have missed other lectures and are now behind with everything else. If you give yourself a spare day, you can’t guarantee that problems won’t arise, but you can deal with them calmly.

事实上，在某些情况下，明智的做法甚至可能是将这种方法发挥到极致。当我还是一名本科生时，我曾经写过一篇很长的数学论文，花了一整个学期的时间，并且要在英国复活节假期（四周）之后交。我意识到，如果我让它拖到复活节，它最终会占用整个假期，让我几乎没有时间复习暑期考试。所以我经常写论文，并在复活节前交上去。这绝对是我做过的最好的时间管理决策之一。

Indeed, the sensible approach might even be to take this to an extreme in some cases. When I was an undergraduate I once had a big mathematics essay that went on for a whole semester and was due after the (four-week) UK Easter vacation. I realized that if I let it run into Easter, it would end up taking the whole vacation, giving me very little time to revise for summer exams. So I worked on it regularly and handed it in before Easter. That was definitely one of the best time management decisions I ever made.

事实上，作业是多种多样的，除了简单的截止日期之外，可能还值得思考。如果作业很短，并且在截止日期前一周就下达，那么你几乎无能为力。但是，如果作业很长，在学期第三周下达，并在学期末截止，那么你就需要做出一些决定。大多数教授不会在学生看过至少一些相关材料之前就下达作业，所以你应该能够立即开始。你可以决定查看作业说明，了解作业要求，并设置一些合理的中间截止日期（例如，你将以某种方式分析某些数据的日期）。如果作业涉及小组工作，那么需要考虑的事情就更多了。其他人的问题在于，他们可能非常聪明和友善，但他们可能有点无能或不可靠。不管哪种情况，都值得安排至少几次早期会议，以便确定每个人要做什么以及何时将一切安排到一起；在后一种情况下，你会重视设置一两个假截止日期，以便处理你无法控制的事情。一如既往，将这些放在你的计划表上。

In fact, assignments are varied beasts and it’s probably worth thinking beyond straightforward deadlines. If an assignment is short and is given out a week before the deadline, there’s not much you can do. If, however, it is a massive thing that is given out in week 3 of the semester and is due at the end, then you have some decisions to make. Most professors don’t give out assignments before students have seen at least some of the relevant material, so you should be able to begin straight away. You might decide to look through the assignment instructions, get to grips with what it’s asking for, and set some sensible intermediate deadlines (e.g. a date by which you will analyze some data in a certain way). If the assignment involves working in a group, then there are even more things to consider. The problem with other people is that they might be extremely clever and nice, but they might be a bit incompetent or unreliable. In either case it’s probably worth scheduling in at least a couple of early meetings in order to sort out what everyone’s going to do and when you’ll put it all together; in the latter case, you’ll value having a pretend deadline or two to allow for things that are out of your control. As always, put these on your planner.

为了说明起见，假设您在此阶段没有任何复杂的事情，并且您的计划器如下所示：

For illustration, suppose you don’t have anything that complicated at this stage, and that your planner looks like this:

我们马上就能看到问题——如果你没有做好计划，第 9 周看起来会非常紧张——但我们稍后会再讨论这个问题。下一步要做的是把任何你不会在场或由于某种原因不会学习的日期添加到计划表中。例如，如果你是一名运动员或积极参与某种社团，你可能应该安排一些训练日或旅行。如果你每周六都要工作 14 小时，那么所有的周六也都不能安排（或者你可能决定周六不学习）。你也可能计划回家或周末去拜访朋友。你的计划表可以帮助你考虑这类事情。你可能无法控制日期：如果你要去参加你祖母的 80 岁生日聚会，或者你的表弟要主演百老汇音乐剧，全家要去参加首演，就把这些写进去。如果你确实有一些控制权，而你原本想出去的那个周末正好是在一项大作业要交之前，你可能需要重新安排。当然，有很多事情需要考虑：你在家里的工作效率与在大学相比如何，你需要多久从烦人的室友那里休息一下，你能忍受多久远离你的女朋友，等等。我只是提倡你做出明智的选择，而不是武断地做出最终会让你后悔的选择。

Right away we can see problems coming—week 9 looks like it will be pretty stressful if you don’t plan well for it—but we’ll come back to that. The next thing to do is to add to the planner any dates on which you will not be around or on which you will not be studying for some reason. For instance, if you are a sportsperson or are heavily involved in a society of some kind, you might have training days or trips that should be blocked out. If you work a 14-hour shift every Saturday, all the Saturdays are out too (or you might be determined that you are not going to study on Saturdays anyway). You will also probably have plans to do things like go home or visit a friend for a weekend. Your planner can help you think about this kind of thing. It might be that you have no control over the dates: if you’re going to your grandmother’s 80th birthday party, or if your cousin is starring in a Broadway musical and the whole family is going to the opening night, just write it in. If you do have some control, and it turns out that the weekend you were thinking about going away is right before a big assignment is due, you might want to reschedule. There are many things to consider, of course: how well you work at home compared with at college, how often you need a break from your annoying roommate, how long you can stand to be away from your girlfriend, and so on. All I’m advocating is that you make an intelligent choice, rather than an arbitrary one that you’ll end up regretting.

此时，如果您喜欢色彩鲜艳的演示文稿，您可能想为您的计划表进行颜色编码。就我个人而言，我太懒了，不愿意走到走廊去彩色打印机，所以我倾向于使用不同级别的阴影。无论如何，您最终会得到这样的结果：

At this point, if you are a fan of colorful presentations, you might like to color-code your planner. Personally I am too lazy to walk down the corridor to the color printer so I tend to use different levels of shading. At any rate, what you’ll end up with is something like this:

现在您可以看到您将要做的所有主要事情，这是一个很好的起点。

Now you can see all the main things you’ll be doing, which is a good place to start.

你可能会认为我接下来要建议的是制定一个学期的学习计划。完全不是。事实上，我认为这是一个愚蠢的想法。此时，你不知道你的各种课程有多难，你不知道你的朋友什么时候会建议你去找房子，你可能还没有消化任何社交活动的时间表。如果你提前为整个学期制定计划，你几乎没有希望坚持下去，整个计划很快就会变得毫无用处。相反，在这个阶段，我建议以典型的一周为单位进行规划。

You might think that what I’m going to suggest next is writing a study plan for the semester. Not a bit of it. In fact, I think that would be a stupid idea. At this point, you don’t know how difficult your various courses will be, you don’t know when one of your friends is going to suggest that you go apartment-hunting, and you might not have digested any of the schedules for social activities. If you made an upfront plan for the whole semester you’d have virtually no hope of sticking to it and the whole thing would quickly become useless. Instead, at this stage I’m going to recommend planning at the level of a typical week.

11.4 规划典型一周

11.4 Planning for a typical week

你会听到各种各样关于你每周应该投入多少学习时间的说法。有些人会说你每上一小时课就应该进行两到三个小时的自学。在我看来，这是不现实的。如果你有典型的五门四学分课程，那就意味着你每周要工作 70 个小时。也许有人能做到，但我不是其中之一。事实上，我不想这样做——如果我认为任何职业都会占用我那么多的时间和精力，我会认真考虑做其他事情。其他人（尤其是你的懒汉伙伴）会说你在复习考试之前不需要做任何事情。这些人要么在撒谎，要么在自欺欺人，要么害怕自己会失败并决心要拖累别人。不要被骗了。

You will hear all sorts of claims about the number of study hours you ought to put in each week. Some people will claim that you ought to be doing two to three hours of independent study for every hour in lectures. This, in my view, is unrealistic. If you have the typical five four-credit-hour courses, it would mean you’d be working something like a 70-hour week. There might be people who can do that, but I’m not one of them. In fact, I wouldn’t want to be—if I thought any occupation was going to take up that much of my time and energy, I would seriously consider doing something else instead. Other people (notably your slacker buddies) will claim that you don’t need to do anything until it’s time to revise for exams. These people are either lying, deluded, or afraid that they’re going to fail and determined to take others down with them. Don’t be sucked in.

我认为，将工作时间定为每周标准工作时间的 40 小时左右是合理的。如果已经安排了大约 20 小时，那么你每周可以额外花 3 个小时学习每门课程，再加上少量的空闲时间来完成大作业、准备考试、整理笔记、补上你错过的内容等等。这应该可以让你跟上进度，同时也让你有时间充分享受大学生活。当然，你的数字可能会有所不同。如果数学给你带来了如此多的如果你愿意花更多时间学习，那就去做吧。如果你是一名认真的运动员，或者你在外面工作很长时间，或者你只是知道你的主要目标是和朋友一起度过愉快的时光，那么你可能会决定减少学习时间。不过，无论你决定什么，一旦你知道你有多少时间，你就可以切实地了解在这些时间里可以取得什么成就。

In my view, it is reasonable to aim for roughly a standard working week’s worth of hours, say about 40. With about 20 hours already scheduled, that would give you another three hours per week for independent study for each course, plus a small number of spare hours for working on big assignments, preparing for tests, organizing your notes, catching up with anything you’ve missed, and so on. It ought to allow you to keep up, while also leaving you with time to make the most of college life. Of course, your number might be different. If mathematics brings you such joy that you want to work on it for more hours, go for it. If you are a serious sportsperson, or if you work long hours at an external job, or if you just know that your main aim is to have a great time with your friends, then you might decide that you will be devoting fewer hours to your studies. Whatever you decide, though, once you know how many hours you’ve got, you can get a realistic sense of what can be achieved in them.

要做到这一点，你需要大致计算出你一周的学习时间是如何分配的。我经常惊讶于学生们对此考虑得如此之少，我主张你应该考虑一些关键的事情。首先，你需要安排每周的课程表，你应该考虑一下这一点，因为至少对于某些课程，你可以决定参加哪个部分。要做出这个决定，我认为你应该问自己：一天中什么时候学习效果最好？根据我的经验，很少有新生考虑过这个问题，也许是因为他们以前没有太多选择来利用自己的时间。但我们大多数人一天中都有一些时间可以很好地思考，而其他时间我们则有点无用。例如，我早上第一件事就是工作效率最高。我通常在午餐前就筋疲力尽，午饭后的几个小时里也没什么用。然后我又会变得更有效率，比如下午 3 点到 7 点。我相信任何优秀的营养师都能指导我如何平衡我的能量水平，但我没有营养师，我想你也没有，所以你可能会有类似的好时光和坏时光。

To do that, you need to work out roughly how your hours are going to be distributed in a typical week. I’m often surprised by how little thought students give to this, and I would advocate that there are a few key things you ought to consider. First, you need to arrange your weekly class schedule, and some thought should go into this because, for at least some courses, you will be able to decide which section to attend. To make this decision I think you should ask yourself: At what time of day do I study best? In my experience, few new undergraduate students have thought about this, perhaps because they haven’t previously had much choice in how to spend their time. But most of us have some times of day at which we can think well, and others at which we’re a bit useless. I, for instance, do my best work first thing in the morning. I’m usually flagging before lunch, and I’m not much good for a couple of hours after it. Then I get a bit more capable again, say 3–7pm. I’m sure any decent dietician would be able to give me instructions on how to even out my energy levels, but I don’t have a dietician, and I assume you don’t either, so you probably have similar good and bad times.

你的好时光和坏时光可能会以各种方式影响你的日程安排。也许安排几节早课会迫使你起床开始新的一天。另一方面，也许这只意味着你会因为睡过头而错过很多课。也许你事先知道一门课很难，所以最好在你可能清醒的时候安排这门课；也许另一门课比较容易，所以最好在你不太可能进行富有成效的自学的时候安排这门课。当然，时间表永远不会是完美的，因为你的选择会受到可用资源的限制。但假设你已经考虑了各种选择，并且得到了这样的安排：

Your good and bad times might inform your schedule planning in a variety of ways. Perhaps scheduling a few early classes will force you to get up and start the day. On the other hand, perhaps it will just mean that you miss a lot of classes due to over-sleeping. Perhaps you know in advance that one course will be difficult so it would be good to schedule this when you are likely to be alert; perhaps another will be easier so it would be good to schedule this when you wouldn’t be likely to engage in productive independent study. A schedule will never be perfect, of course, because your choices will be constrained by what is available. But let’s say you’ve considered the options and you’ve got something like this:

看看这个时间表，我们可以发现一些有用的事情。首先，星期二看起来有点像噩梦。如果希望在那节晚课上集中注意力，你必须仔细考虑如何利用空余时间。如果你没有充分投入，讲座会很费力——材料密集而快速地涌向你，很难集中注意力。因此，我可能会计划在空余时间里什么都不做；花一天时间和朋友共进午餐，另一天去健身房，或者做其他事情。星期五看起来有问题，原因恰恰相反：到那时你会很累，如果你不考虑一下，缺乏安排的时间很容易意味着你最终什么都不做。如果你想在这样的日子学习，你必须考虑如何安排你的一天。

Looking at this schedule, we can observe some useful things. Tuesday looks like a bit of a nightmare, for a start. To have any hope of paying attention in that late lecture, you’ll have to think carefully about what to do with the open slots. Lectures are demanding if you are properly engaged—the material comes at you thick and fast, and it is hard to stay focused. Because of that, I would probably plan to do no work at all in the open slots; to spend one of them having lunch with friends and the other one at the gym, or something. Friday looks problematic for the opposite reason: you’ll be tired by then and, if you don’t give it some thought, the lack of scheduled hours could easily mean that you end up doing nothing at all. If you want to study on a day like that, you’ll have to think about how to structure your day.

然而，在我们讨论这个问题之前，还有一些事情可能会影响你的学习模式。为了帮助你考虑这些，你可能需要制定一个单独的、延长的时间表。这个时间表应该包括晚上和周末的时间，因为它应该能让你真正感受到你希望如何度过你的时间，包括你喜欢的事情和任何你想参加的新活动。

Before we get to that, however, there are some more things that might affect your study patterns. To help you consider these, you might want to make a separate, extended schedule. This one should include the evening hours and weekend days, because it is supposed to give you a genuine sense of how you want to spend your time overall, including the things that you enjoy and any new activities you want to take part in.

第一类要添加的内容是定期安排的活动。也许你在餐馆工作，每周工作两个晚上。或者你打曲棍球，并定期进行清晨训练。或者你的戏剧小组在周一晚上排练，你通常在周四去看电影协会的放映。或者你的姐妹会经常在周三举行派对。或者你是一个教堂信徒，所以周日早上总是很忙。你不想错过这些事情，也不想因为做这些事情而感到内疚，所以把它们考虑进去很重要。无论你打算做什么，都要在你的日程安排中划出它。

The first type of thing to add is regular scheduled activities. Perhaps you have a job in a restaurant, and work two evenings every week. Or perhaps you play hockey and have regular early morning training. Or perhaps your drama group rehearses on a Monday evening and you usually go to the Film Society’s showing on a Thursday. Or perhaps your sorority regularly holds parties on a Wednesday. Or perhaps you are a churchgoer so Sunday morning is always busy. You don’t want to have to miss these things, and you don’t want to end up feeling guilty for doing them, so it’s important to factor them in. Whatever you intend to do, block it out on your schedule.

要添加的第二类内容是会影响你是否学习的事情，因为它们会极大地影响你的警觉性和能力。也许，在早上训练之后，你总是饿得发慌，在吃完丰盛的早餐之前不可能做任何事情。也许你总是在聚会上喝很多酒，直到第二天中午才开始做任何事情。也许在周二漫长的讲座之后，你会筋疲力尽，所以除了看垃圾电视节目之外，你晚上真的不可能做任何更费力的事情。也许，事实上，你和你的室友沉迷于某个晚上的电视节目，虽然你总是告诉自己你只会看第一个小时，然后去你的房间学习，但这是个大谎言，你总是整晚都呆在沙发上。这些事情中有很多你不会为之自豪，但你最好承认它们，因为如果你不承认，它们无论如何都会发生，你会不断地责怪自己没有学习，但这从一开始就是不现实的。如果必须的话，请将它们添加到您的日程表中，不要加阴影或使用不同的字体，但一定要添加它们。完成此操作后，您的全周日程表可能看起来如下所示：

The second type of thing to add is things that will affect whether or not you study because they have a dramatic effect on how alert and capable you are. Perhaps, after your morning training, you are always starving and cannot possibly do anything until you’ve had a massive breakfast. Perhaps you always drink a lot at parties and are not up to anything until noon the next day. Perhaps you’ll be shattered after that long Tuesday in lectures, so there is not really any hope of you doing anything more demanding in the evening than watching trashy TV. Perhaps, in fact, you and your roommates are addicted to a certain evening’s TV shows and, although you always tell yourself that you will just watch the first hour and then go to your room and study, this is a big lie and you always end up stuck on the sofa all night. Many of these things you will not be proud of, but you might as well own up to them because, if you don’t, they’ll happen anyway and you’ll be constantly beating yourself up about failing to study when this was never realistic in the first place. If you must, add them to your schedule without shading or in different lettering or something, but do add them. Once you’ve done that, your full-week schedule will probably look something like this:

现在我们开始对哪些时间可以用于自学有了更现实的认识，我们可以制定一个粗略的计划，确定一个典型的星期中哪些时间可以用于自学。同样，这应该包括考虑什么时候学习效果好。如果你直到早上 10 点才有空闲时间，那么在此之前尝试学习任何复杂的东西都是没有意义的（尽管你可以做常规练习或复习基本内容）。如果你在晚上学习效果最好，那么你应该考虑在晚上投入大量时间。为了便于说明，假设你在清晨表现不佳，在下午晚些时候和傍晚表现最好，并且你不想在周六学习。我们还假设你的目标是大约 20 小时的自学时间。然后，你可以制定一个粗略的计划，如下页所示。这样你就有时间每天吃午饭，有几个晚上你可以出去而不感到内疚，还有一个慵懒的周日早晨。您不会总是坚持这样的细分，但它可以作为一个有用的框架。

Now we’re starting to get a more realistic idea of which hours are actually available for independent study, and we can make a rough plan for which ones to use in a typical week. Again, this should involve thinking about when you study well. If you are no use until 10 in the morning, there is no point in trying to study anything complicated before then (though you might be able to do routine exercises or to revise basic material). If you study best in the evenings, you should think about putting in a lot of your hours then. For the sake of illustration, let’s say you don’t do well in the early morning, you’re best in the late afternoon and early evening, and you don’t want to study on Saturday. Let’s also say you’re aiming for around 20 independent-study hours. Then you might block out a rough plan like that shown on the next page. This would give you time to eat lunch every day, a few nights when you can go out without feeling guilty about it, and a lazy Sunday morning. You won’t always stick to such a breakdown, but it will serve as a useful framework.

11.5 规划何时学习什么

11.5 Planning when to study what

如果你以前从未认真考虑过学习计划，那么上述建议可能对你来说已经足够了，你可能想跳过这一部分。另一方面，如果你已经准备好了，你可以更进一步，考虑在特定时间学习特定课程是否好。例如，假设你的数学计算课程是基于实验室的，你通常可以在实验室时间内完成工作。在这种情况下，也许你只需要一个小时的独立学习时间，总结主要技术，并提前完成课程作业。这意味着对于你的其他科目，你每门课大约有五个小时。你应该如何分配这段时间？对于数学课程，也许你想花一两个小时复习讲义（见第 7 章），三四个小时解决问题。我认为这可能是合理的，尽管显然会根据课程的要求而有所不同。什么时候做这项工作是明智的？这个问题没有明确的答案，但有一些事情需要考虑。例如，也许尽快复习一堂课是个好主意，这样它就会在你的脑海中记忆犹新。另一方面，也许在下一堂课之前立即复习一堂课是个好主意，这样你就可以做好准备。我无法告诉你其中哪一个是最好的（我不知道，我怀疑甚至没有一个有意义的答案），你实际上能做什么将受到你的日程安排的限制。但我确实认为你应该考虑这一点，并考虑权衡利弊。

If you’ve never given much thought to study planning before, then the advice above might be enough for you and you might want to skip over this section. If, on the other hand, you’re ready for it, you might go one step further and think about whether it would be good to work on certain courses at certain times. Suppose, for instance, that your Mathematical Computing course is lab-based, and that you can usually finish the work during the lab time. In that case, maybe you only want one independent study hour on that, to make summaries of the main techniques and perhaps get ahead on a coursework assignment. That would mean that for your other subjects, you’d have about five hours each. How should you divide up this time? For mathematics courses, perhaps you want to spend one or two hours reviewing lecture notes (see Chapter 7) and three or four working on problems. I think that’s probably reasonable, though obviously it will vary according to the requirements of the course. When would it be sensible to do this work? There is no definitive answer to this, but there are some things to consider. Perhaps, for instance, it’s a good idea to review a lecture as soon as possible, so that it is fresh in your mind. On the other hand, perhaps it is good to review one lecture immediately before the next one, so that you can go in prepared. I can’t tell you which of these is best (I don’t know, and I doubt there’s even a meaningful answer), and what you can actually do will be constrained by your schedule. But I do think you ought to consider it, and to think about the trade-offs.

例如，在我们的例子中，所有线性代数课程在周三上午结束。因此，如果你愿意，你可以把周三下午的时间用于学习该周的内容。这可能很好，因为它会给你一段集中精力思考一个主题的时间。另一方面，如果进展不顺利，那可能是一场灾难——你可能会花三到四个小时来理解笔记、做不出来问题，并且感到沮丧。你可以尝试避免这个问题，方法是同意在图书馆与朋友见面，每个人分别花一个小时复习笔记，然后一起讨论半个小时，然后分别花一个小时做问题，然后花一个小时讨论所有事情。当然，即使你这样做并且效果很好，你也面临另一个潜在的问题——五天后你才能去上另一门线性代数课，到那时你可能已经把所有事情都忘了。然后。也许你的教授会先回顾一下前一周的工作，但也许不会。所以最好将半小时的学习时间移到周一第一节课之前的间隙。你明白我的意思吧。

In our example, for instance, all the lectures for Linear Algebra are over by Wednesday morning. So you could, if you wanted to, devote Wednesday afternoon to study of that week’s material. This might be great in that it would give you a period of concentration to think about one topic. On the other hand, if it doesn’t go well, it might be a disaster—you might spend three of nearly four hours failing to understand notes, failing to do problems, and getting frustrated. You could try to avoid this problem by agreeing that you’ll meet a friend in the library and will each spend an hour separately reviewing notes, then half an hour together discussing them, then an hour working separately on problems, then an hour talking through the whole lot. Of course, even if you do that and it works well, you’ve got another potential problem—it will then be five days before you go to another Linear Algebra lecture, and you might have forgotten it all by then. Maybe your professor will start with a review of the previous week’s work, but maybe they won’t. So it might be good to move half an hour of your study to the gap before the first lecture on Monday. You see what I mean.

另一个极端是，也许你更愿意分散学习任何一门课程。这样做的缺点是你没有很长的集中时间，但好处是，从你不理解的东西中抽身出来，有时可以让你以全新的视角来看待它。另外，如果你非常讨厌某门课程，分散学习可能是一个好策略。如果你讨厌某门课程，那么花一个小时学习它要比花四个小时学习它容易得多。事实上，你可以尝试将不喜欢的工作分成更小的部分。比如，20 分钟复习讲座，20 分钟做计算题，20 分钟复习上一组问题的解决方案。无论如何，你可以在典型的一周计划中添加特定科目的工作，同时记住情况会每周都有所不同，尤其是在考试的时候。

At the other extreme, maybe you’d prefer to spread out your study of any particular course. This has the disadvantage that you wouldn’t have a long period of concentrated time, but the advantage that taking a break from something you don’t understand sometimes allows you to come to it with fresh eyes. Also, spreading things out might be a good strategy if you absolutely loathe some course. If you loathe something, it’s much easier to gear yourself up for an hour of it than it is for four hours of it. Indeed, you might try breaking unlikeable work into even smaller chunks. Say, 20 minutes reviewing a lecture, 20 on a calculation problem, and 20 going over the solutions to a previous problem set. In any case, you could add work on specific subjects to your typical-week schedule, while bearing in mind that things will vary from week to week, especially when tests roll around.

11.6 规划实际的一周

11.6 Planning for an actual week

回想一下，我说过，我认为提前很久制定详细的学习计划是疯了。相反，我建议你每周制定一次粗略的计划。下面是我的做法。

Recall I said that I think you’d be mad to make detailed study plans a long way in advance. Instead, I suggest a system in which you make a rough plan about once a week. Here is how I would do it.

在一周开始时（或者最好在前一周结束时），拿出你的日程表和学期计划表。列出每门课程的名称，然后针对每一门课程，查看学期计划表并写下你那一周需要完成的任何具体任务（课程作业、准备考试等）。确保在做这件事时提前考虑——你可能想要开始准备一场大考试或开始三周后要完成的课程作业。

At the beginning of a week (or, ideally, at the end of the previous one), get out your schedule and your semester planner. Write a list with the name of each of your courses then, for each one, look at the semester planner and write down any specific tasks you need to do that week (coursework, preparing for a test, etc.). Make sure you look ahead when doing this—you might want to start preparing for a big test or begin a coursework assignment that’s due in three weeks.

列出这些具体任务后，为每门数学课程添加“讲义”和“问题”，并为其他课程添加等同的日常学习任务。如果您已经列出了关于某门课程的问题清单，请考虑为该课程添加“寻求帮助”。如果您对某门课程或多或少了解，也许您不需要添加“问题”，但您可以考虑添加“提前阅读”。所以您的清单可能看起来像这样：

When you’ve listed these specific tasks, add “lecture notes” and “problems” to each mathematics course, and equivalent routine study tasks to any others. If you’ve built up a list of questions about a particular course, consider adding “seek help” to that course too. If you’re more or less up to date with a particular course, maybe you don’t need to add “problems” but you could consider adding “read ahead” instead. So your list might look like this:

线性代数：讲稿、问题

Linear Algebra: lecture notes, problems

微积分 4：考试准备、讲义、问题、寻求帮助

Calculus 4: test preparation, lecture notes, problems, seek help

数学计算：开始作业

Mathematical Computing: start assignment

心理学：提前阅读，论文笔记

Psychology: read ahead, essay notes

德语：时态练习，复习词汇

German: tense exercises, revise vocab

此时需要考虑一种特殊情况，即学期的第一周。在第一周，你可能没有任何课程作业或考试，也可能没有任何既定问题或阅读材料。在这种情况下，你很容易认为自己无事可做。这是我有时从受指导者那里听到的。在学期开始时，我会问他们进展如何，他们会说：“是的，很好，我们还没有布置任何作业，所以我们没什么可做的。”这种回答在几个层面上都很疯狂。首先，请记住，你在大学里的工作不仅仅是等待布置的作业——你还需要花时间理解你的讲义。其次，即使这个阶段的讲义很简单，你仍然可以做很多有用的事情。如果你是一年级学生，暑假过后你的知识就会生疏，你应该拿出你的高中课本，确保你熟练掌握了所有学习过的材料，在必要时填补空白。如果您在高年级或低年级，您可以复习以前大学课程的相关内容。有时课程名称会让这变得简单 - 如果您即将开始学习名为“微分方程 2”的课程，那么复习微分方程 1 中的关键思想可能是个好主意。如果课程名称没有让您轻松完成，请检查哪些内容是新课程的先决条件，您将获得相同类型的信息。每个人，无论是否是新生，都可以拿到课程教科书或提前了解是否提供任何笔记，并可以提前阅读以了解接下来的内容。您不需要有人站在您面前谈论事情，然后您才能学习它们。因此，如果是第一周，您的所有课程都应该有“复习相关材料”的项目，并且至少其中一些应该有“提前阅读”的项目。

There’s a special case to consider at this point, and that’s week 1 of a semester. In week 1, you probably won’t have any coursework assignments or tests, and you might not have any set problems or reading. In this situation, it’s easy to think that you have nothing to do. This is what I hear from advisees sometimes. At the beginning of the semester I’ll ask how it’s going, and they’ll say, “Yeah, fine, we haven’t been set any work yet so we haven’t got much to do.” This response is crazy, on a couple of levels. First, remember that your job at college is not just to wait for set work—you will need to spend time understanding your lecture notes too. Second, even if the lecture notes are straightforward at this stage, there are loads of things you could usefully do. If you’re a first-year student, you’ll be rusty after the summer and you should get out your high school books and make sure you are fluent with all the material you have studied, filling in gaps where necessary. If you’re in later semesters or years, you can review relevant things from previous college courses. Sometimes the names of courses will make this easy—if you are about to start something called “Differential Equations 2,” it’s probably a good idea to review the key ideas from Differential Equations 1. If the course names don’t make it that easy, check which things are prerequisites for your new courses and you’ll get the same kind of information. Everyone, new student or not, can also get hold of a course textbook or find out whether any notes are made available in advance, and can read ahead to get a sense of what’s coming. You don’t need someone to stand in front of you and talk about things before you can study them. So, if it’s week 1, all your courses should have the item “review relevant material” and at least some of them should have the item “read ahead.”

当你完成这些后，你就有了一份本周可以花一些时间学习的任务清单。在“正常”的几周里，这可能很适合你的典型的一周计划，这样你就可以看看计划中要学习的科目，看看该科目要学习的内容列表，然后开始学习。这很简单，制定一个计划有很多好处。不过，到了学期后期，当有更多的课程作业要完成，更多的考试要准备时，这个清单可能会开始看起来有点令人担忧。上面可能有 20 项，而你只有 20 个小时可以玩。显然，你必须确定优先事项。让我们想想怎么做。

When you’ve done that, you’ve got a list of tasks that could do with some study time this week. In “normal” weeks, this might fit nicely into your typical-week plan, so you can just look at the plan for what subject to work on, look at the list for what to work on in that subject, and get on with it. That’s straightforward, and there’s a lot to be said for having a routine. Later in the semester, though, when there are more coursework assignments due and more tests to prepare for, the list might start to look a bit alarming. It might have 20 items on it, and you only have 20 hours to play with. Clearly you are going to have to prioritize. Let’s think about how.

首先，回顾一下学期计划，特别是第 8 周。你可能很想把第 8 周的整个时间都用来准备微积分考试。但这是一个好主意吗？这可能意味着你已经为考试做好了充分的准备，但你在其他方面也会落后。特别是，你将有一周的时间不去考虑线性代数和德语，这两门课不到一周后就要考试了。更不用说数学计算的作业了。我发现在这种情况下，学生可能会变得非常短视。就好像他们戴着护目镜，只能看到未来几天的情况，结果就是他们给自己带来了很大的压力。在这种情况下，有些人会把第 8 周的整个时间都用来准备微积分考试。然后，当考试结束时，他们会意识到自己在数学计算作业上什么也没做。他们会整个周末都为作业而惊慌失措，但无法完成作业，因为他们没有下载他们需要的东西，或者因为他们不理解其中一个问题，教授不在身边可以提问，其他人似乎也不知道。然后，当他们交了一份未完成的作业时，他们会很生气，因为他们的线性代数和德语已经落后一周，他们完全没有为考试做好准备。然后，当他们做完测试（不是很好）时，他们会发现除了线性代数和德语之外，他们现在落后了所有东西，他们不再理解讲座上的任何内容。他们总是感到失控。作为一名学生，你可以这样做，但这并不令人愉快。

First, look back at the semester planner, and week 8 in particular. It might be tempting to devote the whole of week 8 to preparation for the Calculus test. But would that be a good idea? It might mean that you’re well prepared for the test, but you will also be behind with everything else. In particular, you’ll have had a week of not thinking about Linear Algebra and German, both of which have tests coming up less than a week later. Not to mention that assignment for Mathematical Computing. I find that students can be alarmingly short-termist in situations like this. It’s as though they are wearing goggles that allow them to see only a couple of days into the future, and the result is that they create a lot of stress for themselves. In a situation like this, some people will devote all of week 8 to the Calculus test. Then, when that’s over, they’ll realize they’ve done nothing on the Mathematical Computing assignment. They’ll spend all weekend panicking about the assignment, but won’t be able to finish it because they didn’t download something they need, or because they don’t understand one of the questions and the professor isn’t around to ask and no-one else seems to know either. Then, when they’ve handed in an incomplete assignment, they’ll get wound up because they’re a week behind with Linear Algebra and German and they’re totally unprepared for the tests. Then, when they’ve done the tests (not very well), they’ll find they’re now behind with everything except Linear Algebra and German, and they don’t understand anything in their lectures any more. They feel out of control all the time. You can operate like this as a student, but it’s not very pleasant.

我并不是建议你像往常一样在第 8 周分配时间。显然，花一些额外的时间来准备微积分考试是值得的。但可能不值得放弃其他一切。你至少想让其他事情继续下去。一种方法是每天花大部分时间独立学习微积分，但在开始之前，花一个小时做其他事情。这意味着你保留了一些东西——在其他事情都按部就班地进行，但之后就没事了，这会让你感觉自己花了足够多的时间准备考试。你可能还想在这样的一周里增加几个额外的学习时间，比如错过电影或请假。而且，如果你确实有一周时间不正常，你可能想制定一个修改后的实际周计划，这样你就有东西可以参考，感觉一切都在掌控之中。

I’m not suggesting that you divide up your time as usual in week 8. Obviously it’s worth devoting some extra time to studying for the Calculus test. But it probably isn’t worth dropping everything else. You want to keep the other things ticking over, at least. One way to do that is to spend the majority of each day’s independent study on Calculus but, before starting, to do an hour on something else. This means that you keep the something–else ticking over, but then it’s out of the way, which leaves you feeling that you’re devoting plenty of time to test preparation. You might also want to add a couple of extra study hours in a week like that, perhaps by missing the film or by booking a shift off work. And, if you do have a week that’s atypical, you might like to make an amended actual-week version of the schedule so that you’ve got something to refer to and you feel in control.

现在，你可能会觉得，要做出所有这些决定，决定哪些事情不该做，哪些事情要减少一周左右，这令人担忧。我理解这一点。但问题是，如果你没有有意识地做出这些决定，你无论如何都会在无意识中做出这些决定。如果你不去想你的时间，这并不能让你在一周内有更多的时间，只会让你对自己如何利用这些时间有点妄想。

Now, you might find it alarming to think of making all these decisions about what not to do, or what to cut back on for a week or so. I understand that. But, the thing is, if you don’t make these decisions consciously, you’ll be making them unconsciously anyway. If you avoid thinking about your time, this doesn’t give you more hours in a week, it just allows you to be a bit delusional about how well you’re using them.

11.7 你将在哪里学习？

11.7 Where will you study?

一旦你有了你的日程安排，无论是典型的一周还是实际的一周，你都应该考虑一下你将在哪里学习。这个问题以前可能没有发生在你身上。上大学之前，你可能在学校的时候在图书馆或其他自习室学习，在家的时候在卧室学习。在大学里，你会有更多的选择。在我的大学里，我们有一个多层图书馆、两个数学学习支持中心、有电脑的一般学习空间、没有电脑的一般学习空间、各种咖啡店和咖啡馆，可能还有各种我不知道的地方。这些地方也有很多种类。有的很大，有的很小。有些有大的共享桌子；有些有单独的桌子，周围有隔间墙。有些有很多资源，比如书籍和讲义，也许还有人可以帮忙；有些则完全空无一物。有些是学生独自安静地工作时使用的；有些是小组一起安静地工作时使用的；有些是更吵闹的群体使用，也有很多人经过。就我个人而言，我不知道人们如何在繁忙的地方完成工作，但如果你刚买了一套新衣服，并且想炫耀它，那么这些地方可能非常适合你。

Once you’ve got your schedule, either a typical-week one or an actual-week one, you should give some thought to where you will study. This question might not have occurred to you before. Prior to college, you probably studied in a library or other study room when you were at school, and in your bedroom when you were at home. At college you will have many more options. At my university we have a multi-floored library, two Mathematics Learning Support Centres, general study spaces with computers, general study spaces without computers, various coffee shops and cafés, and probably all sorts of other places that I don’t even know about. There’s a lot of variety within these places too. Some are big and some are small. Some have big shared desks; some have individual desks with cubicle walls around them. Some have lots of resources such as books and handouts and perhaps people available to help; some are completely bare. Some are used by students working silently on their own; some are used by small groups working quietly together; some are used by noisier groups and have a lot of people passing through as well. Personally, I don’t know how anyone gets any work done in the busy places, but they are probably excellent if you have just bought a new outfit and you want to show it off.

当然，我喜欢的东西可能和你喜欢的东西不一样。你可能喜欢在房间里工作，房间里有你所有的东西，你你可以打开音乐，如果不想被打扰，也可以关上门。或者，你可能会发现你所有的东西都会分散你的注意力，厨房和新室友的距离也很近，如果你去图书馆一个安静的地方，你会做得更多。你可能会喜欢图书馆的某一层楼，但有些日子去那里可能不太实际，因为你所有的讲座都在校园的另一边。你明白我的意思。关键是你应该考虑一下，也许可以试试几个地方。

What I like, of course, might be different from what you like. You might like working in your room, where you have all your stuff around you, you can put your music on, and you can close the door if you don’t want to be disturbed. You might, alternatively, find that all your stuff is a distraction, as is the proximity of the kitchen and your new roommate, and that you’d get more done if you went to a quiet spot in the library. You might develop a liking for a particular floor of the library, but then on some days it might not be practical to go there because all your lectures are on the other side of campus. You see what I mean. The point is that you should think about it, and perhaps try a few places on for size.

11.8 整理你的资料

11.8 Organizing your stuff

无论你计划在哪里学习，你都需要确保随身携带相关材料。这不是什么高深的学问，但确实需要一点思考，因为作为一名学生，你将拥有大量纸张，你需要一个管理它们的系统。如果你把所有东西都放在一个地方，你的文件就会塞得满满的，可能还会压得你一个人或几个人肩膀酸痛。如果你喜欢随时把所有东西都放在手边，那可能就没问题了。不过，我最终还是采用了双重归档系统。我为每门课程准备了一个活页夹，我把它们放在我的房间里。然后我还有一个单独的随身携带的活页夹，里面只保存了每门课程最近的笔记页，用主题分隔符隔开。我通常也会在这个活页夹中保存最近的问题集。

Wherever you plan to study, you will need to make sure that you have the relevant materials with you. This is not rocket science, but it does require a bit of thought because, as a student, you will be the owner of lots of paper, and you will need a system for managing it. If you keep it all in one place, you will end up with a file that is wedged completely full, and probably one or more aching shoulders. You might be okay with that if you like to have everything to hand all the time. What I ended up doing, though, was having a dual filing system. I had a binder for each course, and I kept those in my room. Then I had a separate cart-it-around binder in which I kept just the most recent pages of notes from each course, separated by subject dividers. I usually kept recent problem sets in this binder too.

关于单独的文件夹和主题分隔符，请务必妥善归档您的笔记等。如果您有足够的组织能力阅读本书，那么您可能也有足够的组织能力做到这一点。但我确实遇到过很多学生，他们把所有东西都毫无秩序地塞进一个单薄的纸板文件夹中。看着这些人努力学习真是令人心痛。他们花了很长时间才找到他们需要的东西，所有东西都折了角，有时他们会把东西全部弄丢。所以不要这样，不要担心归档需要一些时间。这是工作的一部分，如果你在东西进来时就这样做，比你稍后再整理要省时得多。

Regarding separate folders and subject dividers, please do keep your notes and so on properly filed. If you’re organized enough to read this book, you’re probably organized enough to do this anyway. But I do come across lots of students who have everything stuffed in no order at all into a single flimsy cardboard folder. It’s painful to watch these people trying to study. It takes them ages to find what they need, everything ends up dog-eared, and sometimes they lose things altogether. So don’t be like that, and don’t worry if filing takes a bit of time. It’s part of the work, and it takes a lot less time if you do it as things come in than if you try to sort it all out later.

11.9 没有完成的事情

11.9 Not finishing things

学生们常常认为，一旦开始做某事，就应该坚持下去，直到彻底完成。他们的高中经历似乎让他们觉得“放弃”在道德上是错误的，即使是暂时的。如果你倾向于相信这一点，我关于规划短时间的建议可能会让你想，“但我永远也做不完任何事情！”当然，你是对的。大多数情况下你都做不完事情，或者至少你不会对结果感到满意。总会有一组你永远做不完的习题，或者你听不懂的讲义，或者你知道自己答得不好的课程作业问题。问题是，即使你真的努力做完所有事情，情况仍然如此。当人们试图完成某件事但做不完时，主要是因为他们做不到。他们没有得到他们需要的灵光一现，或者他们被打断了，或者他们累了。或者他们最终花了太多时间试图完成一件事，以至于在最后一刻被迫匆忙做其他事情。

Students often believe that once they start something they should keep going until it is completely done. Their high school experience seems to make them think that it’s morally wrong on some level to “give up,” even temporarily. If you tend to believe that, my advice about planning for fairly short bursts of time might make you think, “But I’ll never finish anything!” You’re right, of course. Mostly you won’t finish things, or at least you won’t get to a point where you’re thrilled with the result. There will always be a problem set that you never complete, or a bit of your lecture notes you don’t understand, or a question on a coursework assignment that you know you didn’t answer very well. The thing is, that would still be true even if you did try to work on everything until you finished it. When people try to finish things but don’t, it’s mostly because they can’t. They don’t get the flash of insight they need, or they get interrupted, or they get tired. Or they end up spending so much time trying to finish one thing that they are forced to do other things in a rush at the last minute.

更重要的是，那些试图这样学习的人会花很多时间实际上根本没有学习。他们可能会因为没有足够的时间完成某件事而避免开始做某件事，而事实上开始做某件事可能会有好处，因为这会让他们仔细考虑想法，然后再回到更困难的问题上。或者他们可能一开始就打算完成，但却越来越沮丧和分心，把时间都花在盯着窗外看、给朋友发短信或幻想着心理学 201 班的那个女孩或男孩身上。即使工作进展顺利，也存在收益递减规律：你可以再花两个小时来完成一组问题或在作业上多得 10 分，但这真的是时间的良好利用吗？你会从中学到很多东西吗？你现在可以在其他地方取得更多进步，然后再回来做吗？而且这只有在你工作顺利的情况下才行。如果你工作不顺利——如果你要花两个小时坐在那里却几乎一事无成——那么真的没什么可说的：至少暂时放弃吧。如果你对此仍然感到不舒服，请阅读第 13 章。

More importantly, people who try to study like that spend a lot of time not actually studying at all. They might avoid starting something because there isn’t enough time to finish it, when in fact starting could be beneficial because it would allow them to mull over the ideas before coming back to the more difficult problems later. Or they might start with the intention of finishing, but get increasingly frustrated and distracted, and spend their time staring out of the window or texting their friends or daydreaming about the girl or boy from Psych 201. Even if the work goes well, there’s a law of diminishing returns: you could spend another two hours trying to finish a problem set or to get an extra 10 points on an assignment, but would that really be a good use of time? Would you learn very much from it? Could you, right now, make more progress elsewhere and come back to it later? And that’s only if you are working well. If you aren’t working well—if you’re going to spend the two hours sitting there but barely achieving anything—then there’s really no contest: let it go, at least for the time being. If you’re still uncomfortable about this, read Chapter 13 as well.

对你来说，目前本章中的建议可能听起来不错，但又让人不知所措；你无法想象自己能如此系统地做所有事情。没关系。你可以尝试采纳其中的一些建议，比如制定学期计划或思考一个典型的星期；然后，随着课程的进展，你可以添加更多策略。

It might also be that for you, at the moment, the advice in this chapter sounds good but overwhelming; that you just can’t imagine yourself doing everything so systematically. That’s okay. You can always try adopting just some of the suggestions, like making a semester planner or thinking about a typical week; you can then add more strategies as you progress through your program.

关于时间管理，最后要记住的是，每个人都会经常失败。即使你有一个好的开始，但有时你也会点，偏离轨道。作业比你想象的要难，工作中出现加班的机会，人们互相举办惊喜派对，有时你心情不好，不想学习。所有这些都很正常，任何一件事都可能让你偏离轨道。问题是，如果你有一个相当好的计划系统，你可以重新评估，列出另一个清单，然后迅速回到正轨。这就是你的目标。

The last thing to remember about time management is that everyone fails at it, on a regular basis. Even if you make a great start, you will, at some point, get derailed. Assignments turn out to be harder than you think, opportunities come up to do extra shifts at work, people throw each other surprise parties, and sometimes you’re in a bad mood and you just don’t feel like studying. All of this is perfectly normal, and any of it can throw you off track. The thing is, if you’ve got a pretty good planning system in place, you can just re-evaluate, make another list, and get back on track quickly. That’s what you’re aiming for.

概括

SUMMARY

• 大多数人可以提高时间管理能力。这样做可以帮助学生跟上学习进度，感觉自己掌控一切，从而享受大学生活。

• Most people could improve their time management. Doing so can help a student to keep up with their studies, to feel in control, and thus to enjoy college life.

• 重修课程可能会被允许，但是有充分的理由避免这样做。

• Retaking courses will probably be allowed, but there are good reasons to avoid it.

• 数学是分层次的；你应该确保你理解了早期课程的材料，以便在后面的课程中取得好成绩。

• Mathematics is hierarchical; you should make sure you understand the material in early courses in order to do well in later ones.

• 制定学期计划可以帮助您了解何时发生什么事情、计划周末活动以及安排课程和考试准备。

• Making a semester planner can help you to get an overview of what is happening when, to plan for weekend activities, and to schedule in coursework and test preparation.

• 制定一个典型的一周计划可以让你切实考虑何时学习。将社交活动纳入计划将有助于确保你可以享受这些活动而不会感到内疚。

• Planning for a typical week can allow you to think realistically about when you will study. Including social activities on a plan will help to ensure that you can enjoy these without feeling guilty.

• 列出不同课程当前的学习任务，可以帮助您确定优先顺序并决定如何在特定的一周内分配时间。

• Making a list of current study jobs for different courses can help you to prioritize and decide how to allocate time in a particular week.

• 您应该考虑一下何时何地最适合学习，以及如何整理您的东西以便随身携带所需的一切。

• You should give some thought to when and where you study best, and to how to organize your stuff so that you have everything you need with you.

• 学生有时会觉得他们必须努力完成某件事。实际上，这很可能是无效的，我建议计划缩短学习时间。

• Students sometimes feel that they have to work on something until they finish it. In reality, this is likely to be ineffective, and I suggest planning for shorter bursts of study time.

• 大多数人都会定期出现时间管理失败的情况，但是，如果你知道自己的目标是什么，就应该能够很快回到正轨。

• Most people have periodic failures of time management but, if you know what you are aiming for, you should be able to get back on track quickly.

进一步阅读

FURTHER READING

有关学生的时间管理技巧，请参阅：

For time management tips for students, see:

• Moore, S. & Murphy, S. (2005)。《如何做一名学生：适合世界各地学生的 100 个好主意和实用习惯》。梅登黑德：开放大学出版社。

• Moore, S. & Murphy, S. (2005). How to be a Student: 100 Great Ideas and Practical Habits for Students Everywhere. Maidenhead: Open University Press.

• Newport, C. (2007)。《如何成为一名全优生：大学生在学习时间较少的情况下取得高分的非常规策略》。纽约：Three Rivers Press。

• Newport, C. (2007). How to Become a Straight-A Student: The Unconventional Strategies Real College Students Use to Score High While Studying Less. New York: Three Rivers Press.

想要一份实用的时间管理指南，让你在学业之外也能轻松应对，并应用于职场，请尝试：

For a practical guide to realistic time management that will take you beyond your studies and into a career, try:

• O'Connell, F. (2009)。少工作，多成就：重获新生的好主意。伦敦：Headline Publishing Group。

• O’Connell, F. (2009). Work Less, Achieve More: Great Ideas to Get Your Life Back. London: Headline Publishing Group.

第 12 章

恐慌

CHAPTER 12

Panic

本章讲述了人们学习落后的原因，以及如果你落后太多而陷入恐慌状态，如何回到正轨。

This chapter is about why people get behind with their studies, and how to get back on track if you get so far behind that you find yourself in a state of panic.

12.1 落后

12.1 Getting behind

大多数人在学习过程中都会在某个时候落后。有些人落后太多，以至于陷入恐慌状态，无法集中精力完成任何一项工作，因为他们太担心其他事情了。如果你正处于这种情况而阅读本章，请直接转到“做什么”部分并按照说明进行操作。如果不是，请继续阅读。

Most people get behind at some point during their studies. Some get so far behind that they find themselves in a state of panic, unable to concentrate on any particular piece of work because they’re so worried about all the others. If you’re reading this chapter because you’re in that situation now, turn straight to the “What to do” section and follow the instructions. If you’re not, read on.

人们陷入恐慌状态的原因有很多。有些人是因为偷懒而陷入的。这可能是因为他们是故意偷懒的人（这很公平）。这可能是因为他们有故意偷懒的朋友，总是鼓励他们做学习以外的任何事情。但这可能是因为他们是普通的、容易犯错的人，他们会放任事情发展，然后发现很难重新回到数学中，然后放任事情发展得更慢，等等。通过这种方式很容易陷入糟糕的境地，你放任的时间越长，情况就越糟。所以要警惕它，特别是如果你发现自己通过不必要地参与其他事情来逃避学习——在不需要的时候加班、承担额外的社会责任、痴迷地整理，诸如此类。如果你发现自己说“嗯，学期快结束了，我回家后再补上。”要特别小心。说这句话的人经常发现当他们的笔记不完整并且身边没有人支持他们时，他们要赶上进度要比预想的要困难得多。

People get into a state of panic for a number of reasons. Some get into it by slacking off. This might be because they are wilful slackers (fair enough). It might be because they have wilful slacker friends who are always encouraging them to do anything other than study. But it might be because they are ordinary, fallible human beings who let things slide a bit, then find it difficult to get back into the mathematics, then let things slide a bit more, and so on. It’s easy to get into a bad situation by this route, and the longer you let it go on, the worse it gets. So be alert to it, especially if you find yourself hiding from your studies by getting unnecessarily involved in other things—taking extra shifts at work when you don’t need to, taking on extra responsibilities with a society, obsessively tidying up, things like that. Be especially wary if you find yourself saying “Well, it’s nearly the end of semester, I’ll catch up when I go home.” People who say this often find that it’s a lot harder than they anticipated to catch up when they’ve got incomplete notes and no-one around to support them.

当然，有些人会无辜地陷入困境。也许他们会病上几个星期（我是说真正生病，而不是流鼻涕）。也许他们的住房出现了某种危机，或者他们的家庭遭遇了创伤性事件。遭遇这种事情的人完全有理由对这个世界感到愤愤不平，并且会发现很难集中注意力。你不应该提前担心这些事情——大多数人都能完成学业，除了重感冒之外，没有其他更糟糕的事情。如果你确实经历了更痛苦的事情，请记住你应该善待自己，大学有很多支持服务可供选择（见第 10 章的最后一节）。与此同时，本章中的建议应该有助于你继续学习。

Of course, some people get into a difficult situation through no fault of their own. Perhaps they are ill for a couple of weeks (I mean properly ill, not just a bit sniffley). Perhaps there is some kind of crisis with their housing, or perhaps they suffer a traumatic family event. People to whom this kind of thing happens have every right to feel aggrieved with the world, and to find it doubly hard to concentrate. You shouldn’t worry about such things in advance—most people get through their studies without anything worse than a bad cold. And if you do experience something more traumatic, bear in mind that you should be kind to yourself, and that universities have a lot of support services available (see the last section of Chapter 10). In the meantime, the advice in this chapter should help to keep your studies moving.

在懒人和真正遭遇危机的人之间，有些人处理事情的方式并不算糟糕，但也不算很好。例如，有时，很多课程作业要同时完成；在一周的截止日期里，你很容易面临比实际能完成的更多的工作。有时人们会一时热情高涨，为某个社会或慈善机构承担大量工作，然后发现他们无法跟上学习进度，也无法兑现这些承诺。处于这种情况的人也应该会发现本章很有用，他们也应该阅读第 11 章。

In between the slackers and the people suffering genuine crises there are people who haven’t exactly handled anything badly but who haven’t exactly handled it well either. Sometimes, for instance, lots of pieces of coursework are due together; it’s easy to end up facing more work than you can actually do in a week full of deadlines. Sometimes people have an early fit of enthusiasm and take on a lot of work for a society or a charity, then find that they can’t quite keep up with their studies as well as living up to these promises. People in such a situation should find this chapter useful too, and they should also read Chapter 11.

12.2 下一步该怎么做

12.2 What to do

当你处于恐慌状态时，首先要意识到这其实是一种正常的经历。大约每年都会有一次有人以这种状态来我的办公室，而且那只是我熟悉的学生——可能还有很多人会告诉别人或自己处理。来找我的人通常都会在我向他们描述自己的经历时感到宽慰，我是这样描述的：你感觉头顶上悬着一大堆工作要做，你走来走去看起来很正常，但它却跟着你到处走，每次你试图从中抽出一些东西来工作时，你都会发现自己无法集中注意力，因为你还在担心其他事情，所以你根本没有任何进步，你已经到了无法面对任何情况或只是发现自己茫然地盯着事物的地步。结果是你几天甚至几周都没有有效地学习；你不知道如何摆脱这种情况，你已经失去了所有的信心。

The first thing to do when you’re in a state of panic is to be aware that this is actually a normal experience. About once a year someone comes to my office in this state, and that’s only among the students I know well—probably there are many more who tell someone else or who handle it on their own. The people who come to me usually seem to relieved when I describe their own experience to them, which I do thus: You feel like you’ve got a giant ball of work-to-do hanging over your head, and you’re walking around looking pretty normal but it follows you everywhere, and every time you try to pull something out of it to work on you find you can’t concentrate because you’re still worrying about all the other things, so you don’t make any progress at all, and you’ve got to a point where you either can’t face any of it or you just find yourself staring blankly at things. The result is that you haven’t studied effectively for days or maybe weeks; you can’t see how you’re ever going to get out of this situation, and you’ve lost all your confidence.

好消息是，我有一个系统可以扭转这种局面，而且几乎无一例外，使用过这个系统的人第二天回来告诉我他们现在没事了。我知道这听起来令人难以置信，但事实确实如此。你可以这样做（如果你在正常状态下阅读这篇文章，它听起来会有点独裁和具体，但在恐慌状态下，人们似乎需要具体的指导）：
