The good news is that I have a system for turning this around and, almost without exception, people I’ve used this with come back the next day and tell me they’re fine now. I realize that sounds unbelievable but it’s actually true. Here is what you do (if you’re reading this in a normal state of mind, it will sound weirdly dictatorial and specific but, in a state of panic, specific instruction is what people seem to need):

1. 列出你目前正在学习的每一门课程。在一张纸上写下这些内容，每门课程之间留出一到两英寸的空白。

1. Make a list of each of the courses you are currently studying. Do this on a piece of paper and leave an inch or two of space between each one.

2. 对于每门课程，写下你必须要做的最紧急的事情，以及相关的截止日期。这可能是课程作业、考试准备或其他任何事情。如有必要，查找截止日期。如果有两件紧急的事情，请列出两者。如果没有紧急的事情，只需写“笔记和问题表”。

2. For each course, write down the most urgent thing you have to do, together with any associated deadline. This might be a piece of coursework, preparation for a test, or whatever. Look up the deadlines if necessary. If there are two urgent things, list both. If there are no urgent things, just write “notes and problem sheets.”

3. 再拿一张纸，在纸的顶部写上“今天”（除非你晚上最后才做这件事，在这种情况下就写“明天”）。现在从你的清单中挑出四件总体上最紧急的事情。把每一件事都写在“今天”的纸上。如果有四件以上的事情，就选那些截止期限最紧迫的。如果事情少于四件，就用你最担心的科目的“笔记和问题表”填满空格。在每件事旁边的括号里写上“30 分钟”。

3. Get another piece of paper and write “today” at the top of it (unless you’re doing this last thing at night, in which case write “tomorrow” instead). Now pick out the four things from your list that are most urgent overall. Write each one on the “today” paper. If there are more than four things, pick those with the tightest deadlines. If there are fewer than four things, fill the spaces with “notes and problem sheets” for whatever subject(s) you are most worried about. Next to each one, write “30 mins” in brackets.

4. 现在考虑清单上的第一项。你将计划如何在 30 分钟内完成它。我知道这听起来像是很短的时间，但在你目前的状态下，你很难长时间集中注意力，而这种方法会很有效。你能做些什么来在这件事上取得进展？写下来，记住你只有 30 分钟，所以时间必须很短。以下是一些建议：

4. Now consider the first item on the list. You are going to plan how to work on it for 30 minutes. I know that sounds like a very small amount of time, but in your current state you are having difficulty concentrating for a large amount of time, and this will work. What can you do to make progress on that item? Write it down, remembering that you only have 30 minutes so it has to be small. Here are some suggestions:

（a）如果这是一份课程作业，也许你可以花 30 分钟仔细阅读作业表，并计算出您需要学习笔记的哪些部分。也许您已经开始了，需要查找一些内容，然后尝试回答问题 2。也许在下载相应的笔记或数据文件之前您什么也做不了，所以您需要先下载这些。

(a) If it’s a piece of coursework, perhaps you could spend 30 minutes reading the assignment sheet carefully and working out which bits of the notes you’ll need to study. Perhaps you’ve already started it and you need to look something up then try question 2. Perhaps you can’t do anything until you have downloaded the appropriate notes or data files, so you need to do that first.

(b) 如果是考试或测试准备，如果你还没有这样做，也许你可以对课堂笔记的相关部分做一个总结。如果你已经有了总结，也许你可以尝试做一道模拟考试的问题，或者你可以通过仔细阅读一个例子来巩固你对一种重要计算类型的知识。

(b) If it’s exam or test preparation, and if you haven’t done so already, perhaps you could make a summary of the relevant part of your lectures notes. If you have a summary already, perhaps you could try a question from a practice test, or perhaps you could consolidate your knowledge of an important type of calculation by carefully reading an example.

(c) 如果是“笔记和问题单”，那么，同样，也许你可以对笔记的某些部分进行总结。如果你已经有了总结，你可以找出一个重要的定理或定义（似乎经常使用的定理或定义），并尝试理解它的内容和用法。或者，你可以在问题单上尝试回答前两个问题。这可能是你在 30 分钟内能做的全部事情。

(c) If it’s “notes and problem sheets” then, again, perhaps you could make a summary of some section of your notes. If you already have summaries, you could identify an important theorem or definition (one that seems to be used a lot) and try to understand both what it says and how it is used. Or perhaps you could try the first two questions on a problem sheet. That’s probably all you can do in 30 minutes.

5. 您现在将获得如下所示的列表：

5. You will now have a list that looks something like this:

今天

TODAY

线性代数测试：总结第 3 章（30 分钟）

Linear Algebra test: summarize Chapter 3 (30 mins)

微积分在线测试：尝试练习版中最简单的问题（30 分钟）

Calculus online test: try easiest questions from practice version (30 mins)

统计作业：下载数据文件并进行描述（30 分钟）

Statistics assignment: download data file and do descriptives (30 mins)

数论：下载笔记并更新定义列表（30 分钟）

Number Theory: download notes and update definitions list (30 mins)

此时你可能会想，“但这只是两个小时的工作——远远不够！”当然这还不够，但你必须从某个地方开始。这就是我们所做的一切，开始——一旦开始，我们就会担心其余的事情。所以，如果你感觉有点紧张，深呼吸几次，让你的肩膀远离耳朵，冷静下来。

At this point you might be thinking, “But that is only two hours’ work—it’s nowhere near enough!” Of course it isn’t enough, but you have to start somewhere. That’s all we’re doing, starting—we’ll worry about the rest once we’ve started. So, if you’re feeling a bit flappy, take a couple of deep breaths, get your shoulders away from your ears and calm down.

6. 确定你什么时候做作业。也许直接做，在两个小时十分钟的时间段内（十分钟是中间的休息时间）。也许在讲座之间分成两个一小时的时间段（不过，确保你为此留出适当的时间——如果你必须你不能在一小时内走一段距离，但你不可能完成一小时的工作。确定什么时候做哪件工作，算出做这件事需要带什么东西，然后把所有的东西都整理好。

6. Identify when you’re going to do the work. Maybe straightaway, in a block of two hours and ten minutes (the ten minutes is for a break in the middle). Maybe in two one-hour blocks between lectures (though make sure you allow proper time for this—if you have to walk some distance in a one-hour gap, you can’t do an hour’s work as well). Identify which piece you’ll do when, work out what you will need to have with you to do it, and assemble all the stuff.

7. 将清单贴在你能看见的地方。或者，更好的办法是，找一个值得信赖的人，向他们展示清单，告诉他们“我打算在这段时间做这些事情”，然后约定一个时间，稍后再与他们联系。

7. Pin the list up somewhere you can see it. Or, even better, find a trusted person, show them the list, say “I am going to do these things at these times,” and agree a time to check in with them later.

8. 准备就绪后，确保能看到时钟，记下时间，然后开始做第一件事情。开始后，如果发现你需要一些你没有预料到的东西，就去拿它——你需要它，所以这是合理利用时间的做法。如果发现你无法在不研究笔记的情况下完成计划好的问题，那就去研究——同样，这是问题所需要的，所以这是合理利用时间的做法。

8. When you are ready, make sure you can see a clock, note the time, and start on your first item. Once you’ve started, if it turns out that you need something that you didn’t anticipate, go and get it—you need it, so this is a legitimate use of your time. If it turns out you can’t do the question you’d planned without studying some notes, do that studying—again, this is needed for the question, so is a legitimate use of your time.

9. 工作 30 分钟后，停下手头的工作，开始做第 2 项。你必须这样做，即使这意味着要打断自己。如果你不这样做，你又会担心其他事情，然后又回到按照这些说明之前的状态。不过，在开始第 2 项之前，先从列表中勾选第 1 项，并在其下方写下你接下来需要为这门课程做的事情（即使只是更多相同类型的活动）。

9. When you have been working for 30 minutes, stop what you are doing and move on to item 2. You absolutely must do this, even if it means interrupting yourself. If you don’t, you’ll get worried about the other items again, and will be back to where you were before following these instructions. Before you start item 2, though, tick item 1 off your list and, underneath it, write down what you need to do next for this course (even if it’s just more of the same kind of activity).

10. 对第 2、3 和 4 项也进行同样的操作。如果一次性完成所有事项，请在中途稍事休息，吃一根香蕉或者泡杯茶什么的，以免精疲力竭（但请不要吃太多巧克力或者喝含有咖啡因的碳酸饮料——您需要保持冷静，而不是兴奋过度）。

10. Do the same for items 2, 3, and 4. If you’re doing it all in one go, have a short break in the middle and eat a banana or make a cup of tea or something so that you don’t wear yourself out (please don’t have loads of chocolate or one of those caffeine-loaded fizzy drinks, though—you want to stay calm, not go off on a stimulant high).

11. 当你在四项任务上各花费 30 分钟时，花点时间坐下来，在脑海中回顾一下你做了什么。你可能做了很多。事实上，如果你和大多数人一样，你会对自己取得的进步感到惊讶。

11. When you’ve done 30 minutes on each of the four items, take a moment to sit back and mentally review what you’ve done. It’s probably quite a lot. In fact, if you’re like most people, you’ll be surprised by how much progress you’ve made.

12. 回顾你的课程列表和“今日”列表，并为接下来两小时的工作制定一份新的列表。

12. Review your list of courses and your “today” list, and make a new list for the next two hours’ work.

13. 如果愿意，可以停止一天的学习（除非你还有讲座或其他什么——显然你应该去听）。我是认真的。两个小时的工作可能看起来并不多，但如果你一直处于恐慌状态，那么这可能比你最近几天做的要多得多，你应该为此感到高兴。

13. Stop studying for the day if you feel like it (unless you still have lectures or whatever—obviously you should go to those). I really mean this. Two hours’ work might not seem like very much but, if you’ve been in a state of panic, it’s probably a lot more than you’ve done in recent days, and you should feel pleased about it.

14. 如果你向别人展示了你的清单，请与他们核对。告诉他们你做了什么，总结你学到了什么，并告诉他们你下一步要做什么。这似乎很有帮助，因为它让你从外部承认你已经完成了你打算做的事情。如果你认为这很有用，也可以在完成下一项工作后安排一个时间与他们核对。

14. If you showed someone your list, check in with them. Tell them what you’ve done, summarize what you’ve learned, and tell them what you’ll do next. This seems to help because it gives you external acknowledgment that you’ve done what you intended to do. If you think it would be useful, arrange a time to check in with them after your next bits of work too.

在大多数情况下，你会发现遵循这些步骤可以治愈你的恐慌。你会感觉重新恢复控制，并相信你只是暂时的失控，而不是长期的崩溃。你可能还有很多事情要做，但现在你应该觉得你知道如何继续取得进步（进步是你的目标——请参阅第 13 章，了解有关现实的学习期望和坚持的建议）。如果你仍然因为严重的潜在问题而感到焦虑，可以考虑咨询大学支持服务（见第 10.9 节）。否则，如果你确实再次出现动摇，只需再次执行这些步骤即可。

In most cases, you will find that following these steps has cured you of your panic. You’ll be feeling back in control, and confident that you were suffering from a temporary blip rather than a long-term meltdown. You might still have a lot to do, but you should now feel that you know how to keep making progress (and progress is what you should be aiming for—see Chapter 13 for advice on realistic study expectations and on keeping up). If you still have anxiety because of a serious underlying problem, consider consulting a university support service (see Section 10.9). Otherwise, if you do have another wobble, just run through the steps again.

概括

SUMMARY

• 人们由于懈怠、疾病、创伤事件以及放任不管而落后于学习。

• People get behind with their studies due to slacking, illnesses, traumatic events, and just letting things slide.

• 如果您发现自己处于恐慌状态，您应该能够通过列出需要做的事情并在短时间内系统地处理最重要的事情来回到正轨并恢复信心。

• If you find yourself in a state of panic, you should be able to get back on track and restore your confidence by listing what you need to do and systematically working on the most important things for short time periods.

进一步阅读

FURTHER READING

有关如何管理时间和避免焦虑的信息，请参阅第 11 章中的“进一步阅读”部分。

See the Further Reading section in Chapter 11 for information on how to manage your time and avoid anxiety.

第 13 章

（并非）最优秀

CHAPTER 13

(Not) Being the Best

本章将介绍本科阶段数学成功应有的面貌和感受。本章旨在消除一些常见的误解，并用关于成功意味着什么的现实观念取而代之。

This chapter is about what mathematical success at the undergraduate level should look and feel like. It aims to dispel some common misunderstandings and replace them with realistic notions about what it means to do well.

13.1 数学专业成绩优异

13.1 Doing well as a mathematics major

人们通常知道他们进入大学后会经历的实际变化。其中一些变化有趣而令人兴奋：结交新朋友，更加自由。有些变化则平淡无奇：自己洗衣服，生活拮据。然而，似乎很少有学生准备好接受学术体验的不同感受。本章应该向您保证，一些体验最初可能看起来是负面的，但可以看作是高等教育结构的正常后果。

People are usually aware of the practical changes they will experience when they move to college. Some of these are fun and exciting: new friends, much more freedom. Some are mundane: doing your own laundry and living on a tight budget. However, few students seem to be quite ready for the way that the academic experience might feel different. This chapter should reassure you that some experiences might initially seem negative but can be seen as normal consequences of the structure of higher education.

一个显而易见的变化是，如果你仔细想想，就会发现他们不太可能在大学里的所有班级里都名列前茅，但人们往往没有意识到这一点。这对于那些在高中时一直是班级里最优秀的学生，并因此被精英大学录取的人来说尤其成问题。精英大学的特点是他们招收最优秀的学生。在排名靠前的大学里，几乎每个人在高中时都是班级里最优秀的。在其他大学和学院，人数可能会少得多，但数学上的成功和天赋仍然会高度集中。这意味着许多人在大学生活的某个阶段会经历智力状态的变化。

One change that’s obvious when you think about it, but that people often don’t see coming, is that they are unlikely to be the best in all of their college classes. This is particularly problematic for those who were always the best in their class at high school and who, as a consequence, are accepted by elite institutions. The thing about elite institutions is that they take the best students. At the very top-ranking universities, it is probably the case that almost everyone in the room was the best in their class at high school. At other universities and colleges, it might be far fewer people, but there will still be a high concentration of mathematical success and talent. This means that many people experience a change in their intellectual status at some point during their college life.

高中时成绩不佳的人往往能轻松应对这种情况。当然，他们有时会感到忧虑——他们可能认为只有最优秀的学生才适合数学专业，他们可能会担心自己达不到预期。但通常他们已经掌握了一些应对此类忧虑的技能，通常不会被暂时的困难所困扰；他们往往不会将这些解释为即将出现长期失败的迹象。

People who were not the best in their high school tend to cope with this without major problems. They sometimes suffer from worries, of course—they might think that a mathematics major is only for the best of the best, and they might be concerned that they won’t live up to expectations. But usually they have developed some skills for coping with such worries, and they are generally not disturbed by temporary difficulties; they don’t tend to interpret these as signs of impending long-term failure.

然而，高中时成绩最好的人有时会遭遇信心危机，因为他们往往没有意识到自己的身份认同与擅长数学有多大关系。在我们的文化中，许多人认为数学能力是智力的体现，它基于天赋而非努力。这种观点值得怀疑，但却非常普遍。因此，那些一直擅长数学的人往往被认为有些特别，这根植于他们认为自己是有价值的人的原因中。所以，如果他们不再脱颖而出，就会动摇他们对自己在世界上地位的认识。

People who have been the best in their class at high school, however, sometimes suffer a crisis of confidence, because they tend not to realize how much of their sense of identity is tied up with being good at mathematics. In our culture, many people think that mathematical ability is particularly indicative of intelligence, and that it is based on inherent talent rather than hard work. This view is questionable but very pervasive. As a result, those who have always been good at mathematics tend to be thought somewhat special, and this gets built into their sense of why they are worthwhile human beings. So, if they no longer stand out, it can shake their sense of their place in the world.

事实上，在大学里，我认为“最好”是没有意义的；在任何一届学生中，都不会有一个人是“最好的”。本科数学比你想象的更加多样化。不同的人会喜欢不同的东西，擅长不同的东西，有条不紊地学习的人很容易比那些在某种程度上“更聪明”但懒散的人做得更好。目前还不清楚那些在高中时表现出色的人是否会在主修期间脱颖而出，也不清楚本科数学成绩优异是否自然而然地会导致研究生学习或数学职业的成功。这些事情可能是相关的，但它们也需要不同的技能。每个人都应该觉得这令人鼓舞——你可能会发现自己对以前从未考虑过的事情有真正的天赋。

In fact, at college, I do not think that “the best” is meaningful; there will not be one person who is “the best” in any given intake of students. Undergraduate mathematics is more varied than you might think. Different people will like different things and excel at different things, and someone who studies in an organized way might easily do better than someone who is “brighter” on some measure but who slacks off. It’s not clear that those who stood out in high school will stand out during their major, and it’s not clear that excelling at undergraduate mathematics leads naturally to being successful in postgraduate study or mathematical careers. These things are probably correlated, but they also demand somewhat different skills. Everyone should find this encouraging—you might discover that you have a real flair for something you’ve never even considered before.

尽管如此，高中数学成绩优异的经历似乎确实会让人产生期望，而这些期望如果直接应用到本科学习中，就会出现问题。因此，以下是一些关于常见期望以及如何做到现实的信息。

That said, experience of doing well in high school mathematics does seem to set up expectations that are problematic if applied directly to undergraduate study. So here is some information about common expectations and about how to be realistic.

13.2 理解是什么样的？

13.2 What does understanding look like?

我时不时会遇到一些学生，他们担心自己以前认为自己擅长数学，但现在却觉得自己不擅长。当我更详细地询问这个问题时，通常发现他们对擅长数学的外表和感觉有一个不准确的想法。特别是，他们经常对自己对本科数学的理解应该如何发展抱有不切实际的期望。

Periodically, I meet a student who is worried because they used to think they were good at mathematics and now they think they’re not. When I ask about this in more detail, it usually turns out that they have an inaccurate idea of what being good at mathematics should look and feel like. In particular, they often have unrealistic expectations about how their understanding of undergraduate mathematics should develop.

通常，这个人过去几乎能理解高中老师说的所有内容，但对教授说的却几乎一无所知。他们认为这意味着他们不懂本科数学。但这种推理是错误的。他们实际上是在将“我能理解的数学”等同于“我能立即理解的数学”，而事实上，前者可能要大得多。我很同情，因为处于这种情况的人可能在看待自己与学习的关系方面经历了巨大的转变。如果你理解了大部分内容，你会感觉很好，而且你可能不需要做太多工作就能理解所有内容。如果突然间，你不太理解，你会感觉很糟糕，而且你可能不得不做大量的工作才能理解所有内容。显然，这是令人生畏的。

Often, it turns out that this person used to understand just about everything their high school teachers said, but they don’t understand anywhere near everything their professors say. They take this to mean that they don’t understand undergraduate mathematics. But there is an error in this reasoning. They’re essentially equating “mathematics I can understand” with “mathematics I can understand straightaway,” when in fact the first of these two sets is probably a lot bigger. I’m sympathetic, because someone in this position has probably experienced a dramatic shift in how they view themselves in relation to their studies. If you understand most of what is said, you will feel good about it, and you probably won’t have to do much work to get to a point where you understand it all. If, suddenly, you don’t understand very much, you will feel bad about it, and you will probably have to do a great deal of work to get to a point where you understand it all. Obviously that’s daunting.

如果你发现自己处于这种情况，首先要做的就是认识到这完全正常。你听不懂讲座上的所有内容并不意味着你不再擅长数学，这只意味着数学更难，节奏更快。为了跟上它，你必须做更多（或更好）的工作。但其他人也一样。这是理所当然的（如果学习数学专业很容易，那么每个人都会这样做）。一旦你认识到这一点，就真的没有别的办法了，只能停止把精力花在担心上，开始努力工作。通常这并不像你想象的那么难，特别是如果你用好的策略（见第 7 章和第11章）来处理任务，并且对你应该努力实现的目标有现实的态度（见下文）。

If you find yourself in this position, the first thing to do is to recognize that it’s entirely normal. The fact that you don’t understand everything in lectures doesn’t mean that you are not good at mathematics any more, it just means that the mathematics is harder and the pace is faster. To keep up with it, you will have to do more (or better) work. But so will everyone else. And that’s as it should be (if studying for a mathematics major was easy, everyone would do it). Once you’ve recognized this, there’s really nothing for it but to stop devoting your energy to worrying, and start making a dent in the work. Often this won’t be as hard as you think, especially if you approach the task with good strategies (see Chapters 7 and 11) and with realism about what you should be trying to achieve (see below).

13.3 保持领先

13.3 Keeping up

有些人会纠结于课程开始时他们不理解的某些内容。他们会想，“如果我连开头都听不懂，我怎么能理解剩下的内容呢？”这会导致他们在课程进行的过程中花费大量时间担心。但这种想法也包含一个重要的推理错误。可能这个开头的项目（称为项目 A）对于课程的其余部分非常重要；课程的结构如下：

Some people get hung up on the fact that they don’t understand something at the beginning of a course. They think, “If I can’t even understand the beginning, how will I understand the rest?” This can lead them to spend a lot of time worrying while the course moves on ahead of them. But this thinking, too, contains an important error in reasoning. It might be that this beginning item (call it item A) is very important for the rest of the course; that the course is structured like this:

但有可能项目 A 只是一种方法所需要的，或者是一个有趣的理论部分，但不是课程其余部分的关键；结构更像是这样：

But it might be that item A is needed for just one method, or is part of an interesting theoretical aside but is not key to the rest of the course; that the structure is more like this:

因此，在投入大量精力担心 A 项之前，最好先弄清楚它有多重要。如果提前提供了讲义，而且这个概念似乎总是出现，那么可能值得整理一下。如果没有，那么你可以放心地把它放在一边，以后再回来看，你现在的努力可能最好花在对整个课程至关重要的事情上，或者花在接下来几周会经常用到的事情上。

Therefore, before devoting lots of energy to worrying about item A, it’s a good idea to have a stab at working out how important it is. If lecture notes are provided in advance and the concept seems to come up all the time, it is probably worth sorting it out. If not, it might be something you can safely put aside and come back to later, and your current effort might be better spent on something that’s central for the whole course, or on something that’s going to be used a lot in the next couple of weeks.

课程落后的学生也面临一个相关的问题。落后会给你一个选择：你是回到你上次理解的地方继续学习，还是尝试理解新内容的本来面目，然后根据当前需要回头填补空白？我倾向于后一种选择，理由如下。

A related problem is faced by students who get behind in a course. Being behind presents you with a choice: do you try to catch up by going back to where you last understood it and working forwards, or by trying to understand the new material as it appears, and going back to fill in the gaps according to what is currently needed? I would favor the latter option, for the following reasons.

首先，向前学习选项在情感上令人不快，因为您可能总是落后。这在实践上也是浪费时间，因为这意味着您将花费大量时间坐在您不理解的讲座上。其次，从这里开始并返回填补空白的选项更符合第 7 章中讨论的从讲座笔记中学习的策略。不过，要使其发挥作用需要一点思考，我建议如下。如果课程有提前发放的讲座笔记，请查看下一堂课的内容。如果没有，请查看最近一堂课的笔记。无论哪种方式，请确定使用的任何关键概念或定理，然后回去学习它们：查找相关的定义、示例和证明，使用第 1 部分的策略学习它们，并尝试任何相关问题。这样，您将填补一些空白，并且您将能够更好地跟上下一堂课。这样做几次，你可能会发现你已经赶上进度了，尽管你仍然有一些差距。事实上，你应该对课程的结构有相当好的把握，因为你将专注于前后材料之间的联系。如果你只是坐在课堂上抄写东西，你不太可能达到这一点。这是一个很好的例子，说明掌控自己的学习是关键。

First, the working-forwards option is emotionally unpleasant because you will probably always be behind. It is also practically wasteful because it means that you’ll spend a lot of time sitting in lectures you don’t understand. Second, the start-from-here-and-go-back-to-fill-gap option fits in better with the strategies for learning from lecture notes discussed in Chapter 7. Making it work requires a bit of thought, though, and I suggest the following. If the course has lecture notes that are given out in advance, look at what’s coming up in the next lecture. If it doesn’t, look at the notes from the most recent lecture instead. Either way, identify any key concepts or theorems that are used, and go back to study those: look up the relevant definitions, examples, and proofs, study them using the strategies from Part 1, and try any associated problems. That way, you’ll fill some gaps, and you’ll be better placed to follow the next lecture. Do this a few times and you’ll probably find that you feel you have caught up, even though you still have some gaps. Indeed, you should develop a pretty good grasp of the structure of the course, because you’ll be focusing on links between earlier and later material. You would be unlikely to reach this point if you just sat in lectures copying things down. This is a good example of a situation in which taking charge of your own learning is key.

13.4 理解和速度

13.4 Understanding and speed

很多人认为数学好就意味着算得快。这种观点似乎与推理上的一些错误有关，所以让我们来分析一下其中的逻辑，看看这两者到底是如何结合在一起的。

Lots of people think that being good at mathematics means being fast at it. This belief seems to be associated with several errors in reasoning, so let’s unpick the logic and work out how the two actually fit together.

当然，在其他条件相同的情况下，在数学方面快一点总比慢一点好。快意味着你有更多的时间做更多的练习，或者研究另一个主题，或者和朋友出去玩。同样，擅长某个数学主题的人——那些对它有深刻透彻理解的人——通常能很快地解决相关问题，无论这些问题涉及的是常规计算还是复杂的证明。然而，擅长数学的人通常也很快这一事实并不能告诉我们他们是如何变得快的。他们可能从第一天起就很快，或者他们可能花了很长时间仔细研究细节，只有掌握了知识后才加快速度。试图通过从一开始就快速模仿他们不一定是最终快速的最佳方法。

It is certainly the case that, all else being equal, being fast at some piece of mathematics is better than being slow. Being fast means that you’ll have more time to do more practice, or to study another topic, or to go out with your friends. It is also the case that people who are good at some mathematical topic—those with a deep and thorough understanding of it—are often fast at solving associated problems, whether these involve routine calculations or complex proofs. However, the fact that people who are good are often also fast does not tell us how they got to be fast. They might have been fast from day one, or they might have spent a long time carefully studying details, and only sped up when they’d mastered things properly. Trying to mimic them by being fast from the outset is not necessarily the best way to be fast in the end.

只为速度而努力的问题在于，它与长期数学成长所必需的深刻透彻的理解不太相容。那些试图快速完成的人经常会错过巩固理解的机会，因为一做完一道题就急着去解决下一道题，这意味着他们不会反思自己学到了什么，不会思考它与自己已知的事物有何关联，也不会紧紧抓住它，以便记住它并能够在新的情境中运用它。反思可能只需要一分钟，但它可能会极大地提高你对所做事情的理解（第 1.2 节提出了一些反思问题）。

The problem with trying to be fast for its own sake is that it is not very compatible with developing the deep and thorough understanding that is necessary for long-term mathematical growth. People who try to be fast often miss out on opportunities to consolidate their understanding, because racing on to the next problem as soon as they finish one means that they do not reflect on what they have learned, do not think about how it relates to things they already know, and do not tighten their grip on it so that they’ll remember it and be able to apply it in new situations. Reflecting might only take a minute, and it might dramatically increase your understanding of what you have done (Section 1.2 suggests some reflection questions).

此外，那些想快速回答问题的人经常会犯一些本来可以避免的错误。有时他们这样做是为了给别人留下深刻印象——向老师和同学展示他们快速而有洞察力的思考。例如，我最近有一个学生，当我问问题时，他几乎总是第一个回答。他的第一个答案经常是错的。然后他会给出第二个答案，这个答案是正确的，显示出很好的洞察力。这并不是说他不能思考，而是他没有给自己时间去好好思考。如果他等一分钟，好好思考，然后在第一次尝试时给出更好的答案，我会更印象深刻。

Also, people who try to be fast often make mistakes that they could have avoided. Sometimes they do this in a bid to impress others—to demonstrate quick and insightful thinking to their teachers and fellow students. I recently had a student, for instance, who was almost always first to answer when I asked a question. His first answer was often wrong. He would then give a second answer that was correct and that showed good insight. It wasn’t that he couldn’t do the thinking, it was that he didn’t give himself time to do it properly. I’d have been more impressed if he had waited a minute, thought properly, and then given the better answer as a first attempt.

在最糟糕的情况下，为了快速完成任务，人们会死记硬背程序，却根本不明白自己在做什么。正如第 1 章所讨论的，这有时可能是一种合适的做法，但值得思考的是，它是否真的能帮助你实现长期目标。

In the worst case, trying to be fast can lead people to memorize procedures without understanding what they are doing at all. As discussed in Chapter 1, this might occasionally be an appropriate way to proceed, but it’s worth thinking about whether it is really helping you achieve what you want to achieve in the longer term.

13.5 不要试图理解一切

13.5 Not trying to understand everything

回到现实主义的话题，重要的是要记住，即使在考试的时候，你也可能无法理解给定课程的所有内容。这听起来可能很可怕，特别是如果你是一个专注的人学生。但这是数学环境变化的自然结果。数学专业应该对最聪明、最勤奋的学生提出挑战。当班上都是这样的学生时，这确实很有挑战性。

Returning to the subject of realism, it’s important to bear in mind that you probably won’t understand everything in a given course, even by the time of the exam. That might sound horrifying, especially if you are a dedicated student. But it’s a natural consequence of the change in the mathematical environment. A mathematics major is supposed to challenge even the brightest and most hardworking students. When the class is full of such students, it has to be very challenging indeed.

这并不像听起来那么糟糕，特别是如果你还记得你不一定需要知道所有内容才能获得 A（请参阅第 11.2 节）。这样做的一个后果是，你可以自由地不再担心某些事情。到考试的时候，会有一些你无法可靠地应用的方法和你无法理解的证明。但这没关系。事实上，瞄准这种情况可能是个好主意。这听起来可能也很可怕，所以我会解释一下。有两个基本原因。首先，在许多课程中，最好是很好地理解大部分材料，而不是糟糕地理解所有内容。想象一下，一个学生试图掌握 100% 的材料，但对它并不十分了解，所以他们只能可靠地获得任何给定问题的 60%。这使得预期总分数为 60%。现在想象一下，他们只掌握了 80% 的材料，但对它的了解足以让他们有信心在该材料的任何问题上获得 90% 的分数。 80% 的 90% 等于 72%。这样好多了。我的经验是，有些学生很自然地接受了这个概念，但其他人却很难接受。他们似乎觉得不努力学习所有东西就是在欺骗系统。我不知道该怎么说，但这表明他们对系统希望你达到的目标存在误解。数学家不希望学生最终拥有百科全书式的知识，但底层理解却不可靠。他们对深刻理解印象更深，至少在高级课程中，他们倾向于通过让考试中的至少一些问题要求原创思维或数学思想的新颖应用来测试这一点。因此，要取得好成绩需要良好的解决问题能力和对课程中的概念和方法以及它们之间的关系的扎实理解。你不能通过记忆更多的东西来为此做准备。

This isn’t as bad as it might sound, especially if you recall that you do not necessarily need to know everything to get an A (see Section 11.2). One consequence of this is that you are free to stop worrying about some things. By the time of the exam, there will be methods that you can’t reliably apply and proofs that you can’t get your head around. But that is okay. Indeed, it might be a good idea to aim for such a situation. That might sound horrifying too, so I will explain. There are two basic reasons. First, in many courses, it is better to understand a large chunk of the material well than it is to understand all of it badly. Imagine that a student has tried to master 100% of the material, but does not know it very well, so they can only reliably get 60% on any given question. That gives an expected score of 60% overall. Now imagine that they have only mastered 80% of the material, but know it well enough to be confident of getting 90% on any question on that material. 90% of 80% is 72%. That’s much better. My experience is that some students take to this notion naturally, but others find it very hard to accept. They seem to feel that they are cheating the system by not trying to learn absolutely everything. I’m not sure what to say about this, except that it indicates a misunderstanding of what the system would like you to achieve. Mathematicians don’t want students to end up with encyclopedic knowledge but dodgy underlying understanding. They’re more impressed by deep understanding, and, at least in upper-level courses, they tend to test for this by making at least some of the questions on their exams require original thinking or novel applications of the mathematical ideas. Doing well thus requires good problem solving skills and a solid understanding of the concepts and methods from the course as well as the relationships between them. You can’t prepare for that by memorizing ever more stuff.

你可能考虑不学习部分内容的另一个原因是，将同样的精力投入到课程的每一部分不太可能有效，原因如下。在任何一门课程中，都会有一些你理解得很好的东西，有些东西你有点明白但不太确定，还有一些东西你觉得完全令人费解（如果你读过第 7 章，你会从第 7.5 节关于使用总结进行复习的论点中认识到这一点）。如果你如果你在每种事情上投入相同的工作量，那么你将浪费一些时间去复习你并不真正需要学习的东西，而更多的时间则浪费在为那些完全令人费解的事情而撞墙。我认为你最好主要研究那些你不太确定的事情。有了这些事情，你很可能会取得一些进步。这会感觉很好。此外，在取得进步的同时，你可能会复习比较容易的事情，因为你必须以新的方式使用它们。这将涉及在比较容易的事情之间建立新的联系，这可以说比一遍又一遍地练习它们更好。最后，进步意味着一些以前令人费解的事情现在看起来更容易理解了。你可能不会理清所有令人费解的事情，但正如上面所说，这没关系。

The other reason that you might consider not learning some of the material is that devoting the same amount of energy to every part of the course is unlikely to be effective, for the following reason. In any given course, there will be some things that you understand well, some things that you kind of get but are not really sure about, and other things that you find totally mystifying (if you have read Chapter 7, you will recognize this argument from Section 7.5 on using summaries for revision). If you do the same amount of work on each kind of thing, you will waste some time going over things you don’t really need to study, and more time bashing your head against a brick wall with the totally mystifying things. I would argue that you’d be better off working primarily on the things that you are not really sure about. With these things, you are likely to make some progress. This will feel good. Also, while making progress, you are likely to revise the easier things, because you will have to use them in new ways. This will involve making new connections among the easier things, which is arguably better than just practising them over and over again. Finally, the progress will mean that some of the previously mystifying things will now seem more accessible. You probably won’t sort out all of the mystifying things but, as argued above, that’s fine.

显然，理解所有内容都是很好的目标，你当然应该在开始每门课程时都抱着掌握所有主要思想和原则的目标。你可能不会每次都做到这一点，但没关系。你不应该把这当作你不再很优秀的证据，或者当作你应该放弃的迹象。相反，把它当作迎接挑战的机会。

Obviously understanding everything is a fine aim, and you should certainly begin every course with the intention of grasping all the main ideas and principles. You probably won’t manage it every time, but that’s okay. What you shouldn’t do is take this as evidence that you’re not very good any more, or as an indication that you should give up. Take it as an occasion to rise to the challenge, instead.

13.6 神话中的天才

13.6 The mythical genius

说到这儿，也许值得说说那些神话般的天才，他们什么都不用做，但很快就能理解一切，每门课都能拿到 A。你无疑会听到关于这种学生的故事——人们喜欢那种可以毫不费力地做所有事情的天才的浪漫想法。我并不怀疑这种学生的存在，但我确实认为他们的数量比很多人让你相信的要少得多。如果你听说过这样的学生，一定要钦佩他们，但在此之前，你要问自己两个问题。

At this point it’s probably worth saying something about the mythical genius who does no work at all but who understands everything immediately and gets an A in every course. You will doubtless hear tales of such students—people like the romantic idea of the genius who can do everything effortlessly. I do not cast doubt on the existence of such students, but I do think they’re much fewer and further between than a lot of people would have you believe. If you have heard about one, admire them by all means, but not before you’ve asked yourself two questions.

首先，这个人真的像大家想象的那样优秀吗？我之所以这么说，是因为曾经有几个学生告诉我，他们的朋友就是这样的人——他不费吹灰之力就学会了一切。听起来难以置信，但后来我发现，他不仅成绩不佳（B 级，没有更好），而且他去年的很多课程实际上都不及格，现在正在重读！你不得不佩服这个学生——他欺骗别人的能力真是太棒了在朋友眼中，他可能只是在开玩笑。或者，更宽容地说，也许有一天他的朋友们表现得很钦佩，而他却不忍心告诉他们真相。无论如何，你听到的关于人们的故事并不一定反映他们的实际能力。在你过于痴迷之前，请注意这一点。

First, is this person actually doing as well as everyone seems to believe? I say this because I was once told by a couple of students that their friend was one of these people—that he just picked everything up with no effort. Incredible as it sounds, I later found out not only that he was not doing outstandingly well (B grades, no better), but also that he had actually failed many of his courses the previous year and was repeating them! You have to admire this student—he’d done a cracking job of pulling the wool over his friends’ eyes. Or, more charitably, perhaps his friends had acted impressed one day and he hadn’t had the heart to tell them the truth. In any case, stories you hear about people do not necessarily reflect their actual abilities. Be aware of this before you get too starry-eyed.

第二个问题是，这个人真的不工作吗？或者他们实际上做了相当多的工作，但却是悄悄地做的？有些人很害羞，喜欢安静地做事，不大惊小怪。其他人喜欢培养一种无忧无虑的形象，但愿意在幕后努力工作，以确保自己掌控一切。无论如何，仅仅因为这个人不经常学习，并不意味着他们没有学习。事实上，我认为一个真正有才华的人几乎什么都不做是不可信的。擅长做事的人往往喜欢做事。我猜他们可能不花时间学习课程，因为他们找到了一本关于高级主题的有趣书，并开始学习，但即便如此，他们也会练习本科学习中有用的推理类型。

The second question to ask is, does the person really do no work? Or is it possible that they actually do quite a bit of work, but do it on the quiet? Some people are quite shy and like to get on with things without making a big fuss. Others like to cultivate a devil-may-care image, but are prepared to work hard in the background to make sure that they keep on top of things. Either way, just because this person is not often seen to be studying, that doesn’t mean that they’re not. In fact, I do not think it credible that a really talented person would do next to nothing. People who are good at things tend to like doing them. I guess it’s possible that they’d spend no time studying for their courses because they’d found an interesting book on an advanced topic and were studying that instead, but even then they’d be practising the types of reasoning that would be useful in undergraduate work.

尽管如此，你在学习期间很可能会遇到一个非常有才华的人。至少，你可能会和一个在某些科目上比你优秀得多的人成为朋友。你可能会对这个人有点敬畏，你可能会很享受这种体验，因为敬畏某人是一种情感上的投入——有点像成为一个真正伟大的乐队/滑板运动员/电视科幻作家的粉丝，只不过你真的认识这个人，可以向你的其他朋友炫耀。但是，如果你发现自己处于这种情况，我认为你应该再问自己一个问题，这才是真正重要的问题：

All of this said, you might well run across an extremely talented person during your studies. At the very least, you will likely become friends with someone who is substantially better than you at some subjects. You will probably be a bit in awe of this person, and you might quite enjoy the experience, because being in awe of someone is emotionally engaging—a bit like being a fan of a really great band/skateboarder/TV sci-fi writer, except that you actually know the person and can show off about it to your other friends. But, if you find yourself in this situation, I think you should ask yourself one more question, which is really the important one:

我可以从这个人身上学到什么？

What can I learn from this person?

你之所以要问这个问题，是因为无论这个人有多大的天赋，数学都不会不请自来。他们的天赋必须体现在实际的想法和行动中，如果你能找出其中的一些，你自己就可能更好地掌握这门学科。如果你很幸运，你的朋友可能会直接告诉你他们是如何如此迅速地发展出如此好的理解的。也许他们总是通过将某个概念与某个图表联系起来来思考，这使得记忆变得容易，关系变得明显。也许他们总是通过提前阅读来开始学习，以确定课程中的主要定理，然后在讲解过程中将材料与这些定理联系起来。他们可能会做各种各样的事情，你可能没有想到，但一旦你听说了这些事情，你也许能够做得很好。如果你不那么幸运，你的朋友可能无法告诉你他们在做什么，因为这对他们来说是自然而然的事情，所以他们从来没有想过。即便如此，通过与他们讨论如何处理各种类型的问题，你也许能够推断出一些有用的思维方式。

The reason you should ask this is that no matter how much talent this person has, the mathematics doesn’t just jump into their brain unbidden. Their talent must manifest itself in actual thoughts and actions and, if you can find out what some of these are, you can probably get better at the subject yourself. If you are lucky, your friend might be able to tell you directly what they are doing to develop such a good understanding so quickly. Perhaps they always think of a certain concept by relating it to a certain diagram, which makes memory easy and relationships obvious. Perhaps they always start their study by reading ahead to identify the main theorems in the course, then relating material to those as they go along. There are all sorts of things they might be doing that might not have occurred to you, but that you might be able to do pretty well once you’ve heard about them. If you’re less lucky, your friend might not be able to tell you what they are doing, because it comes naturally to them so they’ve never reflected on it. Even so, by engaging them in conversation about how to approach various types of problem, you might be able to infer some useful ways of thinking.

当然，你必须深思熟虑，就像你和别人一起工作时一样。模仿某人的外在行为与思考不同——你必须做的不仅仅是盲目地模仿。但是，正如第 10 章所讨论的那样，人类并不是孤立存在的，你在生活中学到的很多东西都是从别人那里学到的。如果你愿意分享你的知识和理解，并且以一种友好、公平、允许每个人参与的方式这样做，你会发现其他人也愿意回报你。

Of course, you have to be thoughtful about this, as you always do when working with others. Mimicking someone’s outward behavior is not the same as doing the thinking—you have to do more than just mindlessly copy. But, as discussed in Chapter 10, human beings don’t exist in isolation, and a great amount of what you learn in life you will learn from other people. If you are willing to share your knowledge and understanding, and to do so in a way that is friendly, equitable, and allows everyone to participate, you will find that others are willing to return the favor.

概括

SUMMARY

• 许多人在攻读数学专业时，智力水平会发生变化。有些人因此遭受暂时的信心危机。

• Many people experience a change in their intellectual status as they progress through a mathematics major. Some suffer a temporary crisis of confidence because of this.

• 本科数学比高中数学更难，进度也更快；发现这是一个挑战是正常的，并不意味着你不再足够优秀。

• Undergraduate mathematics is more difficult than high school mathematics and is presented at a faster pace; finding this a challenge is normal, and does not mean that you are not good enough any more.

• 如果您将注意力集中在课程的中心思想或可能在接下来的讲座中用到的思想上，跟上进度可能会更容易。

• Keeping up might be easier if you focus your attention on the central ideas in a course or on those which are likely to be used in upcoming lectures.

• 擅长数学并不一定意味着学得快。花时间去正确理解事物是值得的。

• Being good at mathematics is not necessarily the same as being fast at it. Taking the time to understand things properly is worthwhile.

• 考试时无法理解所有内容是正常的；了解了这一点，您应该思考如何分配精力以取得好成绩。

• It is normal not to understand everything by the time of an exam; knowing this, you should think about how to distribute your effort in order to do well.

• 您可能会听到关于天才学生的传说，您肯定会发现其他人有时比您更了解事物。如果您愿意分享您的知识，其他人也会回报您。

• You will probably hear myths about genius students, and you will certainly find that others sometimes understand things better than you do. If you are willing to share your knowledge, others will reciprocate.

进一步阅读

FURTHER READING

欲了解更多有关现实期望和适应大学生活的信息，请尝试：

For more on realistic expectations and adjusting to university life, try:

• Moore, S. & Murphy, S. (2005)。《如何做一名学生：适合世界各地学生的 100 个好主意和实用习惯》。梅登黑德：开放大学出版社。

• Moore, S. & Murphy, S. (2005). How to be a Student: 100 Great Ideas and Practical Habits for Students Everywhere. Maidenhead: Open University Press.

• Newport, C. (2007)。《如何成为一名全优生：大学生在学习时间较少的情况下取得高分的非常规策略》。纽约：Three Rivers Press。

• Newport, C. (2007). How to Become a Straight-A Student: The Unconventional Strategies Real College Students Use to Score High While Studying Less. New York: Three Rivers Press.

要更多地反思你的知识并成为更好的问题解决者，请尝试：

For more on reflecting on your knowledge and becoming a better problem solver, try:

• Mason, J.、Burton, L. 和 Stacey, K. (2010)。《数学思维》（第 2 版）。Harlow：Pearson Education。

• Mason, J., Burton, L., & Stacey, K. (2010). Thinking Mathematically (2nd Edition). Harlow: Pearson Education.

• Pólya, G. (1957)。《如何解决它：数学方法的新方面》（第二版）。新泽西州普林斯顿：普林斯顿大学出版社。

• Pólya, G. (1957). How to Solve It: A New Aspect of Mathematical Method (2nd Edition). Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press.

第 14 章

数学

教授做什么

CHAPTER 14

What Mathematics

Professors Do

本章描述了数学家们在不讲课时会做些什么。本章旨在让人们了解教授的生活，以及本科教育如何融入大学的众多活动中。

This chapter describes what mathematicians do when they are not giving lectures. It aims to give an idea of what it is like to be a professor, and of the way that undergraduate education fits into a university’s many activities.

14.1 当教授不讲课时

14.1 When professors aren’t lecturing

本科生通常不太清楚教授的工作内容。当然，没有教授你也可以成为一名成功的本科生，但我个人认为，了解你每天接触的人的广泛活动是很有趣的。而且，你永远不知道，有一天你自己也可能想成为一名数学家。

Often, undergraduate students do not have a very clear idea of what a professor’s job involves. You can be a successful undergraduate without one, of course, but personally I think that it’s interesting to learn about the wider activities of people you come into contact with every day. Also, you never know, you might want to become a mathematician one day yourself.

鉴于学生在高中的经历，他们不知道教授在做什么并不奇怪。如果高中老师不教你，他们通常也在教别人，或者在准备教学，或者在给学生打分，或者参加培训课程学习新的教学技巧。更资深的老师还会花时间管理学校：决定如何花费预算，聘请新员工并监督他们的培训，与学校董事会联络，参加教育会议等等。

The fact that students don’t know what professors do is not surprising given their experience in high school. If a high school teacher is not teaching you, they are usually teaching somebody else, or preparing to teach, or grading students’ work, or going to training sessions to learn new teaching techniques. More senior teachers also spend time managing the school: deciding how to spend the budget, hiring new staff and overseeing their training, liaising with the school board, attending educational meetings, and so on.

对于大学教授来说，工作则大不相同。一年中，一位典型的教授可能只将大约 40% 的时间花在与教学相关的活动上；他们可能将 10% 的时间花在行政工作上，其余 50% 的时间花在研究上。以下是有关每种工作类型的一些信息。

For university professors, the job is rather different. Across the year a typical professor might spend only about 40% of their time on teaching-related activity; they spend perhaps 10% doing administrative work, and the remaining 50% doing research. Here is a bit of information about each type of work.

14.2 教学

14.2 Teaching

教授的教学工作是每个人都能看到的。例如，我讲课（当然），我组织背诵，我每周与一小群一年级学生见面一小时，我每周在我们的数学学习支持中心花两个小时。我还撰写讲义、问题表和解决方案，将它们发布在 VLE 上，为我的学生的课程作业评分，与担任助教的博士生联络，并回复学生的电子邮件。我编写考试和补考，并根据内部主持人（我所在部门的另一位教授）和外部考官（另一所大学的经验丰富的教授，负责审查部门的所有考试以确保保持标准）的反馈进行调整。最后，我为我课程的所有考试评分。这需要很长时间，而且非常无聊——如果你看到一位教授在考试结束后不久就因无聊而目光呆滞，你就会知道原因。

Some of the teaching that professors do is visible to everyone. For instance, I give lectures (obviously), I run recitations, I see a small group of first-year advisees for an hour a week, and I spend two hours a week in our drop-in Mathematics Learning Support Centre. I also write lecture notes, problem sheets and solutions, post these on the VLE, grade my advisees’ coursework, liaise with the PhD students who act as teaching assistants, and respond to students’ emails. I write exams and resits and adjust them according to feedback from an internal moderator (another professor in my department) and an external examiner (an experienced professor from another university who vets all the department’s exams to make sure that standards are being maintained). Finally, I mark all the exams for my courses. This takes forever and is inordinately dull—if you see a professor looking glassy-eyed with boredom shortly after the exam period, you will know why.

但是，其他教学则不那么引人注目，因为涉及的学生较少。例如，我通常有一两个最后一年的项目学生（见第 10 章），每周我会和他们每个人见面大约一个小时。我有一个实习学生（再次见第 10 章）；我每年两次去他们的公司看望他们，并给他们写的两份工作报告评分。我也会与我的二年级和三年级的学生保持联系，每年单独见他们几次。我喜欢我工作的这部分——很高兴看到他们变得更有经验，并开始决定如何度过自己的人生。我现在在英国工作，所以你的教授可能有不同的教学职责，但他们的工作可能都类似这样。

Other teaching, however, is less visible because it involves fewer students. For instance, I usually have one or two final-year project students (see Chapter 10), each of whom I see for about an hour a week. I have a student on an internship (again see Chapter 10); twice a year I go to visit them at their company, and I grade two reports they write on their work. I also keep up with my second- and third-year advisees, seeing each of them individually a couple of times a year. I enjoy this part of my job—it’s nice to watch them become more experienced and start making decisions about what to do with their lives. I work in the UK now so your professors might have different teaching responsibilities, but they probably have an array of work somewhat like this.

14.3 管理

14.3 Administration

“行政”是指使部门顺利运转的事情。其中一些是由管理员完成的，他们维护学生记录、收集和归还课程作业、整理课程作业和考试成绩、安排开放日等等。不过，有些是由学者完成的（教授们经常这样称呼自己）。例如，教授回答潜在学生的问题、进行开放日演讲、分配教学任务，担任新教授的导师，安排外部演讲者进行部门研讨会，更新有关各个学位课程的信息，运行部门网站，评估晋升申请，并参加有关财务和发展战略各个方面的机构会议。

“Admin” refers to things that keep the department running smoothly. Some of this is done by administrators, who maintain student records, collect and return coursework, collate coursework and exam scores, arrange open days, and so on. Some of it, though, is done by academics (professors often refer to themselves in this way). For instance, professors answer queries from potential students, give open day talks, assign teaching tasks, act as mentors to new professors, arrange for external speakers to give departmental seminars, update information about various degree programs, run the department’s website, assess promotion applications, and attend institutional meetings about various aspects of finance and development strategy.

大多数教授都以某种方式参与此类活动。资历较浅的教授通常只负责小部分工作，不会占用太多时间。资历较深的教授则可能负责大部分工作，承担很多责任。事实上，有人会担任系主任——一个负责管理系并在更高级别委员会中代表系主任的重要职位。有时，担任此类重要职位的人根本不需要做任何教学工作，因此，如果您的系主任实际上不讲课，也不要感到惊讶。

Most professors are involved in some way in activity like this. Those who are fairly junior usually have a small role that doesn’t take up much of their time. Those who are more senior might have a large role with a lot of responsibility. Indeed, someone will be Head of Department—a big role that involves running the department and representing it at higher-level committees. Sometimes people with big jobs like this are not expected to do any teaching at all, so don’t be surprised if your Head of Department doesn’t actually give lectures.

14.4 研究

14.4 Research

许多教授花费大量时间进行研究，对于数学家来说，这意味着开发新的数学。这有时会让新本科生感到惊讶，如果他们仔细想过这个问题，往往会认为数学已经“完成”了。但是，正如我在第 4 章中所说，二次公式才为人所知约 400 年；你在本科期间学到的大部分知识都是在大约 200 年前开发的，而且，根据你所在部门的工作人员和你的选项，你学习的数学可能只存在了 20 多年。世界各地成千上万从事研究的数学家一直在开发新的数学。

Many professors spend a large amount of time doing research, which in the case of mathematicians means developing new mathematics. This sometimes surprises new undergraduates who, if they’ve thought about it at all, tend to assume that mathematics is already “finished.” But, as I said in Chapter 4, the quadratic formula has only been known for about 400 years; much of what you’ll learn as an undergraduate was developed about 200 years ago and, depending on your department’s staff and your option choices, you might be learning mathematics that has only been around for 20-odd years. New mathematics is developed all the time by the thousands of research-active mathematicians around the world.

数学研究的目的取决于数学家的专业和研究兴趣。纯数学家研究抽象结构，证明这些结构间关系的一般结果。如果你思考第 2 章中的讨论，你可能会对此有所了解，其中涉及思考抽象对象及其属性。纯数学家通常为了自己而研究这些结构，但结果往往在现实世界的应用中很有用。应用数学家更直接地研究数学，其应用显而易见，也许设计和测试越来越准确的现实世界现象模型，如大脑活动或人群中疾病的传播。然而，也存在中间立场，数学家与来自不同专业或学科的其他人合作是很常见的。

The aim of mathematical research depends upon a mathematician’s specialism and research interests. Pure mathematicians work with abstract structures, proving general results about relationships across these structures. You can probably get a sense of what this feels like if you think about the discussion in Chapter 2, which involved thinking about abstract objects and their properties. Pure mathematicians usually work on these structures for their own sake, but the results often turn out to be useful in real-world applications. Applied mathematicians work more directly on mathematics with an obvious application, perhaps designing and testing increasingly accurate models of real-world phenomena like brain activity or the spread of diseases in a population. There is middle ground, however, and it is common for mathematicians to collaborate with others from different specialisms or disciplines.

因此，数学研究的形式涉及各种不同类型的活动。一些数学家使用笔和纸，在纸上写下手写的计算和尝试证明。其他人则利用强大的计算能力进行复杂的计算或运行模拟。1所有人都花大量时间阅读，关注研究期刊上的论文，以了解其他人在各自领域取得的进展。也许有人证明了一个有用的新定理，或者对现有定理提出了新的、更优雅的证明，或者表明一个定理可以以一种有趣的方式推广。事实上，也许有些数学家对定理的兴趣远不如对证明的兴趣大；他们阅读是为了将这些想法应用到自己当前的研究问题中。当然，数学家们会试图将自己的作品发表在这些期刊上。这需要提交一篇关于该作品的论文，然后将其发送给少数其他数学家进行审查。如果审稿人认为其中有错误或解释不充分，他们可能会要求修改，然后作者会修改论文（如果可以的话），直到期刊编辑最终决定它值得发表（或拒绝它认为它不充分）。因此，数学家也参与了这种审查过程，其中一些数学家还担任期刊编辑。

As such, the form taken by mathematical research involves quite different types of activity. Some mathematicians work with pen and paper, filling pages with handwritten calculations and attempted proofs. Others make use of substantial computing power to perform complex calculations or to run simulations.1 All spend a lot of time reading, keeping up to date with papers in research journals in order to learn about progress made by others in their field. Perhaps someone has proved a useful new theorem, or produced a new, more elegant proof of an existing theorem, or shown that a theorem can be generalized in an interesting way. Perhaps, in fact, some mathematicians are less interested in the theorem than in the proof; they might read in order to adapt the ideas to their own current research problem. Then, of course, mathematicians attempt to get their own work published in these same journals. This involves submitting a paper on the work, which will then be sent out to a small number of other mathematicians for review. The reviewers might request changes if they think that there is an error or an inadequate explanation, and the author(s) will then amend the paper, if they can, before the journal editor eventually decides it is worthy of publication (or rejects it as inadequate). So mathematicians are also involved in this type of review process, and some of them work as journal editors.

数学家也参与了很多口头讨论。许多数学家与博士生一起工作，为他们设置要解决的问题，指导他们阅读什么，并支持他们，使他们不再像本科生，而更像独立研究人员。数学家们也会互相讨论他们的工作，有时是非正式的——数学家可能会意识到他们的工作需要一个特定的概念，并决定与更了解这个概念的同事交谈——有时是正式的，参加当地、国家和国际研讨会、讲习班和会议。这些活动的性质略有不同（如下所述），但它们通常涉及人们发表演讲其他人则在听。这有点像在课堂上，只不过每个人都更像老师而不是学生；人们会提出具有挑战性的问题，如果他们对某个论点不确定，就会要求解释，就理论的细微之处展开辩论，并通过努力了解自己的理解与演讲者和房间里其他人的主张之间的关系来完善和扩展自己的理解。

Mathematicians are also involved in a lot of spoken discussion. Many work with PhD students, setting them problems to work on, pointing them toward what to read, and supporting them as they become less like undergraduate learners and more like independent researchers. Mathematicians also discuss their work with each other, sometimes informally—a mathematician might realize they need a particular concept for their work and decide to speak to a colleague who is more knowledgeable about it—and sometimes formally, taking part in local, national, and international seminars, workshops, and conferences. These events are somewhat different in character (as explained below) but they usually involve people giving talks while others listen. This is a bit like being in a class except that everyone is more like a teacher than a student; people ask challenging questions, demand justifications if they are not sure about a particular argument, get into debates about the finer points of a theory, and refine and extend their own understanding by working to see how it relates to the claims made by the speaker and by others in the room.

研讨会通常规模较小，只有一个人发言。你的系里可能会有一位教授担任研讨会组织者，邀请其他大学的数学家就特定研究小组感兴趣的话题发言；留意一下，你可能会在布告栏或信息屏幕上看到即将举行的研讨会的列表。研讨会通常规模稍大一些。有些是定期会议，涉及一个既定的研究小组，有些是一次性活动，一群具有相似数学兴趣的人花几天时间互相介绍工作，讨论其优缺点。会议通常是最大的；最大的国际会议汇集了多达几千名数学家。这些人的兴趣并不相同，所以大型会议通常会结合各种规模的会议。可能会有国际知名数学家发表主题演讲，数百人参加，也可能有关于更专业主题的小型会议，其中 20 个或更多会议同时举行，以便人们可以决定他们想参加什么。有些会议是一天的活动，但有些会议持续数天，白天每个人都会喝很多咖啡，晚上则根据他们的嗜好喝很多酒。与所有学术科目一样，此类活动的社交方面被认为非常重要——人们通常在非正式谈话中了解同事的新想法并发展合作关系。由于这种会议，大多数在学术领域工作一段时间的人都会与来自全国和世界各地的人建立亲密的友谊和工作关系。有时，这些合作会导致进一步的旅行；数学家休假并花几个月时间与其他机构的同事一起工作并不罕见。

Seminars, usually, are fairly small and involve just one person speaking. Your department will probably have a professor who acts as seminar organizer, inviting mathematicians from other universities to speak on topics that are of interest to particular research groups; keep your eyes open and you will probably see lists of upcoming seminars on notice-boards or information screens. Workshops are usually somewhat larger. Some are regular meetings involving an established research group, and some are one-off events where a wider group of people with similar mathematical interests spend a few days presenting work to each other and discussing its merits and consequences. Conferences are usually the biggest; the largest international conferences bring together as many as a few thousand mathematicians. These people don’t all have the same interests, so big conferences usually have a combination of sessions of various sizes. There might be keynote talks given by internationally famous mathematicians and attended by hundreds of people, and smaller sessions on more specialist topics, 20 or more of which happen simultaneously so that people can decide what they want to attend. Some conferences are one-day events, but others run for several days and involve everyone in drinking a lot of coffee during the day and, depending on their proclivities, a lot of alcohol in the evening. As in all academic subjects, the social aspect of such events is considered very important—it is often in informal conversation that people catch up with their colleagues’ new ideas and develop collaborations. Because of this sort of meeting, most people who work in an academic field for any period of time develop close friendships and working relationships with people from all over the country and the world. Sometimes these collaborations lead to further travel; it is not uncommon for a mathematician to take a sabbatical and spend a few months working with colleagues at another institution.

所有这些的结果是，大学里有很多事情要做，教授的工作很有趣，也很多样化。这不是一份适合所有人，但如果你有上进心，并且有兴趣发展知识，我强烈推荐你去那里。工资不高，而且可以自由地在你想工作的时间、地点和工作内容上工作，这真是太棒了。

The upshot of all this is that there is a lot going on at a university, and that the job of professor is interesting and varied. It’s not a career that’s right for everyone, but I highly recommend it if you are self-motivated and interested in developing knowledge for its own sake. The money’s not bad and the freedom to work largely when you want, where you want, and on what you want, is extraordinary.

14.5 成为一名数学家

14.5 Becoming a mathematician

我在写这本书的开头就说过，我希望这本书的内容对任何想学习数学专业或已经学习数学的人都有用。我希望它能给你一些见解，帮助你专注于正确的事情并享受学习。我也希望随着你专业的发展，你会继续发现这本书很有用；如果你定期回顾它，你可能会发现你对这本书涵盖的想法有了更细致入微的看法。

I started this book by saying that I hoped its content would be useful to anyone who wants to study as a mathematics major or who is already doing so. I hope it has. I hope it has given you some insights that will help you to focus on the right things and to enjoy your studies. I also hope that you will continue to find it useful as you progress through your major; if you return to it periodically, you will probably find that you are developing a more nuanced view of the ideas the book covers.

我当然希望你们在学业上取得成功，并希望你们在完成学业后，能感受到自己对数学的力量和美感有了更深刻的理解。事实上，我希望你们认识到，无论你们最终是否在职业生涯中使用数学，你们所养成的思维习惯都将对任何行业都有用。例如，本书的一些读者将从事零售经理、人力资源人员、管理顾问或国际销售主管等一般的毕业生工作。他们可能永远不会再区分函数，但他们会经常使用他们所开发的技能来构建逻辑合理的论点，批评他人的论点，并在书面和口头交流中清楚地表达他们的结论。其他人将从事更明显的数学职业，如会计师、保险精算师、统计学家、金融家或教师。这些人可能不会使用他们在学位中学到的所有数学知识，但他们会发现其中一些知识会用于新的应用，并且他们的数学问题解决技能在日常生活中很有用。

I certainly hope that you will be successful in your studies, and that you will complete them with a feeling that you have developed a deeper appreciation of the power and beauty of mathematics. I hope, in fact, that you come to see that the habits of mind you have developed will be useful in any walk of life, whether or not you end up using mathematics in your career. Some readers of this book, for instance, will go into general graduate jobs as retail managers or human resources people or management consultants or international sales executives. They will probably never differentiate a function again, but they will regularly use the skills they’ve developed in constructing logically sound arguments, in critiquing arguments made by others, and in presenting their conclusions clearly in both written and spoken communication. Others will go into more obviously mathematical careers, as accountants or actuaries or statisticians or financiers or teachers. These people might not use all of the mathematics they’ve learned in their degree, but they will find that some of it is put to work in new applications, and that their skills in mathematical problem solving are useful on a daily basis.

不过，我确实希望有些读者确实想成为数学家。我希望他们能喜欢一门特定的课程，开始专攻该领域，做一个项目来体验更独立和原创的工作，在一位鼓舞人心的导师的指导下攻读博士学位，并成为一名成功的研究数学家。其他人对下一篇文章有​​比我更多的话要说

I do hope, however, that some readers do want to become mathematicians. I hope that they’ll enjoy a particular course, begin to specialize in that area, do a project to experience more independent and original work, study for a PhD under an inspiring supervisor and go on to be a successful research mathematician. Others have more to say than I do on the next

这个过程的阶段，所以如果这适用于你的话，我请你参阅进一步阅读部分。

stages of this process, so I refer you to the further reading section if this applies to you.

无论您的个人情况如何，我都很高兴您想学习数学，因为这是一门很棒的学科，我祝您一切顺利。

Whatever your individual situation is, I’m pleased that you want to study mathematics because it’s a fantastic subject, and I wish you the very best.

概括

SUMMARY

• 数学教授通常参与教学、管理和研究活动。其中一些活动本科生可以看到，但有些活动则在幕后进行。

• Mathematics professors are usually involved in teaching, administration, and research activities. Some of this will be visible to an undergraduate student, but some goes on in the background.

• 积极参与研究的数学家通常与博士生一起工作，发表研究论文，并参加地方、国家和国际研讨会、讲习班和会议。

• Mathematicians who are active in research usually work with PhD students, publish research papers, and participate in local, national, and international seminars, workshops, and conferences.

进一步阅读

FURTHER READING

要查看数学期刊列表（并浏览部分期刊的内容，具体取决于您所在大学的访问权限），请单击以下链接：

• http://www.jstor.org/

• http://www.jstor.org/

有关数学专业职业选择的更多信息，请尝试：

For more information on career options for mathematics majors, try:

• http://www.maa.org/careers/

• http://www.maa.org/careers/

• http://www.ams.org/careers/

• http://www.ams.org/careers/

• http://www.siam.org/careers/thinking.php

• http://www.siam.org/careers/thinking.php

有关成为数学家的更多信息，请尝试：

For more information on becoming a mathematician, try:

• Stewart, I. (2006)。《致年轻数学家的信》。纽约：Basic Books。

• Stewart, I. (2006). Letters to a Young Mathematician. New York: Basic Books.

• 陶哲轩的网站：http://terrytao.wordpress.com/career-advice/

• Terence Tao’s website at http://terrytao.wordpress.com/career-advice/

参考书目

BIBLIOGRAPHY

Aberdein, A. (2005). The uses of argument in mathematics. Argumentation, 19, 287–301.

Ainsworth, S. (2008)。学习复杂科学概念时多重表征的教育价值。JK Gilbert、M. Reiner 和 M. Nakhleh (Eds.)，《可视化：科学教育中的理论与实践》（第 191-208 页）。纽约：Springer。

Ainsworth, S. (2008). The educational value of multiple-representations when learning complex scientific concepts. In J. K. Gilbert, M. Reiner, & M. Nakhleh (Eds.), Visualization: Theory and Practice in Science Education (pp. 191–208). New York: Springer.

Alcock, L. & Simpson, A. (2005). Convergence of sequences and series 2: Interactions between nonvisual reasoning and the learner’s beliefs about their own role. Educational Studies in Mathematics, 8, 77–100.

零，15，160​

1如果您不明白为什么需要证明什么，请等待第 5 章的讨论。

1 If you can’t see why there would be anything to prove, wait for the discussion in Chapter 5.

1顺便说一句，当你第一次接触到角度正弦的概念时，你可能花了一些时间测量长度和计算特定角度的正弦。当我们谈论正弦函数时，我们谈论的是将每个角度转换为正弦的函数，所以我们一次处理所有可能的正弦计算。这类似于多项式函数，不同之处在于，除了将输入视为数字之外，我们还可以将其视为角度。

1 By the way, when you first met the idea of the sine of an angle, you probably spent some time measuring lengths and calculating sines of particular angles. When we talk about sine as a function, we’re talking about the function that takes each angle to its sine, so we’re dealing with all of those possible sine calculations at once. This is similar to, say, polynomial functions, except that as well as treating the input as a number, we can also think of it as an angle.

2有些人在自然数中包含 0，而有些人则不包含，因此请确保你知道你的教授包含的内容。

2 Some people include 0 in the natural numbers and some do not, so make sure you know what your professors are including.

3当您想表达“有理数”的意思时，应使用短语“有理数”而不是“分数”。“分数”的使用范围往往更广且不够精确，而使用正确的词语在数学上更为复杂。

3 You should use the phrase “rational number” rather than “fraction” when that’s what you mean. “Fraction” tends to get used more broadly and imprecisely, and it is more mathematically sophisticated to use the proper word.

4如果我们使用这个积分来找到速度与时间图下的面积，这个数字将告诉我们相对于原始位置的位移，但我假设我们在这里只处理纯数学，因此我们可以只考虑数字。

4 If we were using this integral to find the area under a graph of velocity against time, this number would tell us about displacement from an original position, but I’ll assume we’re just dealing with pure mathematics here so we can think about numbers alone.

5这些操作也许会得出这样的结论：事实上没有解决方案，但我们通常会继续进行，就好像我们会在此期间找到一些解决方案一样。

5 Maybe the manipulations will lead to the conclusion that, in fact, there are no solutions, but we usually proceed as though we’ll find some in the meantime.

1我最近在艺术展上看到的 12 英尺高的“桌子”是桌子吗？ 某种程度上是，但它不符合功能标准，例如不是可以放置物品的平面 — 没有人能够够到，而且无论如何也不允许触摸展品。

1 Is the 12 ft tall “table” that I recently saw in an art exhibition a table? Sort of, but it wouldn’t meet functional criteria such as being a flat surface you could rest things on—no-one would be able to reach, and anyway touching the exhibit was not allowed.

2不过，我确实曾经听​​过一个故事，一个博士生在开放日上非常严肃地告诉一些家长，他的研究是在 2 到 4 之间寻找一个新的偶数，这让一些家长感到困惑。很多数学幽默都基于这种事情。

2 Though I did once hear a story about a PhD student who confused some parents at an open day by telling them very seriously that his research involved searching for a new even number between 2 and 4. Much mathematical humor rests on this kind of thing.

3如果你已经有一些高等数学经验，你可能会注意到其中一些定理可以表述得更精确。我在这里只是简单地陈述了它们，以免让初学高等数学的读者感到困惑，但我将在第4 章和第 8章。

3 If you already have some experience in upper-level mathematics, you might notice that some of these theorems could be stated more precisely. I have stated them simply here so as not to confuse readers new to advanced mathematics, but I will discuss this issue in Chapters 4 and 8.

4这可能并不完全适用于每一门课程——有时教授更多地在叙述段落中介绍想法——但你会发现几乎总是如此。

4 This might not be quite true all the time in every course—sometimes professors introduce ideas more in narrative paragraphs—but you will find that it’s almost always the case.

5你可能会想说，只要x位于x轴上某个点的右侧，。这没问题。数学家有时会指定一个定义并不在整体上成立，但在某些受限域上成立。

5 You might find yourself wanting to say that the function is increasing as long as x is to the right of some point on the x-axis. That’s fine. Mathematicians sometimes specify that a definition does not hold overall but does hold on some restricted domain.

6如果你想说“选择d = 0”，请记住，定义禁止这样做，定义规定必须让d > 0。

6 If you are tempted to say “choose d = 0,” remember that this is forbidden by the definition, which specifies that we must have d > 0.

7事实上，开集和闭集的概念可以重新表述，以便更广泛地应用，而不仅仅是实数的子集。你能想象如果我们考虑平面上的面积而不是直线上的区间，开集会如何运作吗？

7 In fact, the notions of open and closed can be reformulated so as to apply much more generally, beyond just subsets of the real numbers. Can you imagine how open sets might work if we think about areas in a plane, for instance, rather than intervals on a line?

8您可能习惯于由单个公式定义的函数，但这是一个恰好以分段定义的完美函数。

8 You might be used to functions defined by a single formula, but this is a perfectly good function that just happens to be defined piecewise.

1这个单词的发音不太明显。在英国，我们读作 coROLery，但有一次我无意中让一班美国学生因为这个单词而大笑——他们读作 CORolairy，并认为我的发音很搞笑。

1 It is not obvious how to pronounce this. In the UK, we say coROLery, but I once inadvertently had a whole class of American students in fits of laughter over this—they say CORolairy and thought my pronunciation was hilarious.

2定义也可能明确指定 (− x ) 必须在f的定义域内。在高级数学中，你会发现数学家对这样的技术要求越来越谨慎。

2 A definition might also explicitly specify that (−x) must be in the domain of f. In upper-level mathematics, you will find that mathematicians are increasingly careful about technical requirements like this.

3如果你想知道为什么我没有使用 ⇔ 来进一步缩写，而是使用“当且仅当”，那是因为人们在定义中不倾向于这样做。我不知道为什么。

3 If you’re wondering why I haven’t abbreviated further using ⇔ instead of “if and only if,” it’s because people don’t tend to do that in definitions. I don’t know why.

1等式链中的最后一步是有效的，因为当h → 0 时，我们有x + h → x，所以f ( x + h ) → f ( x )。此外，lim h → 0 g ( x ) = g ( x ) 自动成立，因为g ( x ) 不依赖于h，所以它不会随着h → 0 而改变。最后，整个证明依赖于关于极限的和与乘积的定理；你的教授可能会证明这些定理并强调它们的使用位置。

1 The last step in the chain of equalities is valid because as h → 0 we have x + h → x, so f(x + h) → f(x). Also, limh→0 g(x) = g(x) automatically because g(x) does not depend on h so it does not change as h → 0. Finally, the whole proof relies on theorems about sums and products of limits; your professor might prove these theorems and highlight where they are used.

1事实上，由于我接受过额外的训练，我知道将导数视为可以用这种方式操纵的分数有时是不可靠的，但由于这来自一组讲义，因此可以安全地假设它在这种情况下必须起作用。

1 In fact, because of my extra training, I’m aware that it is sometimes dodgy to treat a derivative as a fraction that can be manipulated in this way but, since this comes from a set of lecture notes, it seems safe to assume that it must work in this case.

1第二和第三个等式至少在一般情况下是无效的——是否存在特定数字使它们成立？

1 The second and third equalities are invalid in general, at least—are there any specific numbers for which they do hold?

2顺便注意，第三行中的“或”很重要；它不应该被替换为“和”，因为我们不能同时得到x = −1 和x = 2。

2 Notice, by the way, that the “or” in the third line is important; it should not be replaced with “and” because we can’t have x = −1 and x = 2 at the same time.

1如果你对统计学有所了解，你可能会意识到，出席率和成绩之间的相关性并不一定意味着去听课会让人们表现得更好——也许只是积极性高的人表现很好，而且碰巧也会去听课。但你真的想冒这个险吗？

1 If you have some knowledge of statistics, you might be aware that a correlation between lecture attendance and achievement does not necessarily imply that going to lectures causes people to do better—perhaps it’s just that highly motivated people do well and happen to go to lectures too. But do you really want to take that chance?

1我听说过一位老师，如果学生没有提出任何问题，他就会再次将学生打发走。这听起来有点极端，但我理解他的立场。大学学习的主要责任在于学生。

1 I’ve heard of an instructor who sends his students away again if they show up without questions. That sounds a bit extreme to me, but I understand his position. The main responsibility for learning at college lies with the student.

1请注意，在第二种情况下，不是计算机在做智力工作——数学家必须决定什么值得计算，对计算机进行编程来执行计算，并解释和报告结果。

1 Notice that it’s not the computer doing the intellectual work in this second case—the mathematician has to decide what’s worth calculating, program the computer to do it, and interpret and report the results.
